reviews.review: Great historical place. There is a lot to see and learn here. But I recommend to hire a guide. We had a great one and he explained so much. Things I did not know prior to visit. If you hire a guide ask him to bring you to the healing bowl guy. Great experience.

Must do cultural walk. Kathmandu Durbar is full of history and culture and is a must see for visitors to the city of wood. It's $US10 to enter the area. You'll be approached by licensed guides after you pay at the ticket window. Use one of the guides. Their knowledge is amazing, and you'll get more from the experience. Make sure they have a license. If you ask how much, they'll tell you to decide at the end. We chose to pay $US20. We had great service.

Hammered by the quake but still worthwhile seeing . The side streets are far more impressive than the main square which was hit very badly by the earthquake. If you get the chance go to Bahktapur, it's more impressive thanks to the German restoration.

Under Construction. The place is very crowded due to festival and under construction due to the collapse of the buildings. The entry fee is 1,000 rupees. Better save it when the reconstructions are done. However, if you don't expect to come Nepal again, why not have a look this time to avoid the regrets.

Amazing Buildings. This place and its surroundings are amazing , even with the renovation works that are going on. Obviously the main museum and historical buildings are a must but do venture into the surrounding streets to take in the architecture/ culture and the people there. It is also worthwhile just stopping at a street corner to people watch, never a dull moment. And so many photographic opportunities. Find out before if there are any ceremonies taking place, they are a must. Official guides are a must !
Cultural. Durbar Square is a city in itself-lots of things to see and a truly cultural nepalese experience - a must do for the itinerary

History.Culture.Museum.Temples. Its one of the most popular spots in Kathmandu with lots of temples,a museum, lots of coffee shops and eateries all around.Few of the historic structures were destroyed by the mega earthquake of 2015 but whatever remains are also beautiful..help people understand the beautiful culture and tradition of Nepal.Its very close to the main commerical street of Kathmandu-New road with lots of shopping options around.

Still in Ruins. The square is very badly damaged from the earthquake, and it's buildings have sadly still not been repaired. Despite this, they are an interesting sight, and the surrounding streets are worth a visit. If you want to go around the square without paying, tell the attendant you are going to the Himalaya Java coffee house - which by the way is a nice place to stop for a drink.

Good to see that plans are underway to remed quake impact. amazing architecture and history to this site. Whilst heavily impacted by the quake there is still grandeur and power to the site. Beautiful. And would hope to return to see the restoration completed some day.

Interesting tour. Amazing to see the destruction the earthquake did. Still able to tour the area with cost of $1000NR per ticket. Also had local guide that approached us at the gate, his name was Bish and had so great knowledge of the area which help led greatly. Guide was also $1000NR but think was worth it for his knowledge. Recommend doing.

Centre of Kathmandu's history. Due to the serious need for reconstruction, Durbar Square charges a steep entry of 1000NPR for foreigners. While I understand the need for entry fee, it's frustrating to get singled out by security to pay while local-looking folks waltz straight through. However, this certainly is the centrepiece of the city's history and architecture.

Must Visit. The durbar square is among national heritage sites in Nepal. It has beautifully carved architectures, museum, ancient wooden crafts and windows. You can buy great souvenirs around the place. It is located near the freak street which is surrounded by hotels, restaurants and main shopping area(newroad).

Damaged by the Earthquake but still awesome!!. While this area was highly affected by the 2015 earthquake it is still worth a visit. Upon entering you'll be approached by a guide however this is not he person I hired. While looking a gentleman approached me provided a wealth of information then offered his services as a guide, showing me his badge / certification. Based on my experience I highly recommend you hire a local guide to explain the history of the area. I paid $10 for 1hr of explanation. There are many details that will go unnoticed unless you have a knowledgeable person there to point them out.

Historical temples. This was an interesting area, with many historical buildings and interesting shops. There were Hindu temples, being repaired after the earthquake did the damage. Tour guide, Sonics, was great.

Annoying guides that keep bothering you. I really hated Durbar square! And that was mainly because of all the guides that wanted to offer me their services. Every 2 minutes there was another one asking me if I needed a guide. After 15 minutes I was so sick off it that I left the square. Best tip I can give you: just book a damn guide so the others stop bothering you.
Needs to be rebuild after the Eathquake. I'm sure it is of great beauty but still a work in progress. It is a must see but ... but ... but... I wish there was more.

Great treasures. We found some very interesting antiques and the prices were reasonableBe sure to bargain hardThen walk away. There last price at that point us their last price if it is a good deal take itWe mussed some items when we went back they were gone
Another must see on your check list! . Amazing architecture throughout, some destroyed by the earthquake, some with scaffolding and others perfectly fine but you can't help but admire this place!

Historic centre of Kathmandu survived the earthquake!. Although there is clear evidence of the effects of the earthquake on the ancient buildings of Durbar Square the atmosphere of the place remains magical. The work of salvaging and restoring the buildings is gargantuan yet the business of the square continues daily with prayers and commerce sitting side by side. Well worth a visit and the entrance fee goes towards the restoration of this beautiful place.

Heavily damaged by earthquake. Still worth visiting, but many of the temples were damaged in the 2015 earthquake. Local guides that approach can help explain the significance of the temples and buildings.

You can see the living Dewi from 4 to 6 pm and may be there is also another morning session.

Must See - a taste of life of the Nepalese folk. A lot of history/culture - must do if you go to kathmandu. Street markets, spices, locals, local customs , enjoyed this experience very much. - cultural

But after walking through the entire square, I was left feeling that I'd just squandered $10 needlessly. Admittedly there is interesting history and architecture in this square, but then again, there is interesting history and architecture throughout Nepal, so I can't see encouraging anyone to spend money to pass through here.

Impressive level of detail!. This UNESCO heritage site is a wonderful display of architecture and incredible level of detail when it comes to the specific wood carved windows. Do not miss it!

culture of nepalese. its great place to see how the people lives and many important temples there also , but some one rebuild because the earthquake from 2 year ago , so easy to be there from thamel area , we can to walk or take a taxi if you dont have a lot of time .you need a fees before to enter or take any pictures .mostly people hate and angry from you if you will take a pic to them,

Building site. There are a number of Durbar Squares in Kathmandu - the main one was destroyed by the earthquake and is currently still a building site. It's 1000 rupees to visit - around £7.30 but there is now little to see apart from the main temple where the child goddess pits in an appearance most days - but even this has its front held up by large wooden supports.It used to be one of the must see sights - but Nepal government really need to get on with the restoration of this sight of they are going to draw the tourists again!

The Results of the Earthquake are visible. Though the earthquake hit this area hard, it is still a very attractive place. Many buildings are propped up. But you can see lots of artisans working hard to bring it back to it's old glory. Pity there are so many touts there. They are very hassling

If there's one MUST in Kathmandu - this is it!. There's a reason the Durbar Square complex is World Heritage listed and the top of any list of sites to seen in Kathmandu - it's simply breathtaking and fascinating. Don't skimp on the 1000 rupees admission to visit the Hanuman temple complex - the woodwork carvings are intricate, ornate, awe-inspiring and, in parts, erotic. Not to mention the ticketed are was give some respite from the ever present Kathmandu background of touts and souvenir sellers.

Not too amazed . For being the top listed thing to do in Thamel I was a bit disappointed. The square still has a lot of damage from the earthquake and is fenced off mostly (which is understandable). It's an easy sight to see if wandering around Thamel area and a good view point to have lunch upstairs from. But not much more
Nice place.. I visited it very often .Very important place to know nepali culture.Beautiful nigth and day.Dont loose it !.

Historic and interesting. We travelled with a private guide so learnt many things - worth the cost compared to self guided. We ate in a restaurant four stories above the square and looked at the passing parade of locals, tourists, "tractors" and animals with amusement at times. It was dry and dusty..but it was April so no rain. The historic significance was awesome, the damage done by the earthquake 12 months before was tragic, so some areas were taped off, but our guide was still able to fill in details of the history and local events. Magic!

For Lovers of History. The KTM Durbar square is by far the largest Ive been in Nepal. I have been to three sadly only after the great earthquake but it was breath taking nonetheless. But then again we would love to help in Nepals recovery effort. Also dont forget to visit the love temple with intricate kamasutra carvings and perhaps catch a glimpse of the Kumari, Nepals living goddess.

There are plenty of cafes and hotels, some with roof top bars, which I highly recommend. We watched the sun set over the mountains from one such bar, such an experience.

Get the Visitor Pass. Visited the square in August 2016, as others have written there is still a lot of earthquake damage. But still a must-do in Kathmandu.Entry fee (paid at a booth) is 1000Rs per person. However, if you stay in Kathmandu for a few days, you can get a Visitor Pass for multiple entries to the square. Just take your entrance ticket, your passport and a passport photo to the Site Office, where they will convert your entrance ticket to a Visitors Pass. This pass is valid as long as your visa is valid. Great if you are in Kathmandu longer than a few days.Otherwise, there are many guides offering their service. Some are very persisent, which can be annoying.

A must visit place. We enjoyed our visit here, and it is an essential place to visit. Interesting and sad to see the earthquake damage, very busy, and some pestering by guides. Get a taxi there, the roads around it are a nightmare! Cost 1000 Ns to get in (increased so they can repair the damage)

"HEALING IN PROGRESS: WOUNDS OF THE KATHMANDU EARTHQUAKE". I'd visited to Durbar Square opposite to the old royal palaces in Nepal, consists of temples, idols, open courts, water fountains, etc. Before the Unification of Nepal, there were small kingdoms, and Durbar Squares are most prominent remnants of those old kingdoms in Nepal.In particular, three Durbar Squares in the Kathmandu Valley, belonging to the three Newar kingdoms situated there before unification, are most famous: Kathmandu Durbar Square, Patan Durbar Square, and Bhaktapur Durbar Square.All three are UNESCO World Heritage Sites.On April 2015 Nepal had experienced the earthquake with a magnitude of 7.8Mw or 8.1Ms and a maximum Mercalli Intensity of IX (Violent), killed over 8,000 people and injured more than 21,000. A major aftershock occurred on 12 May 2015 at 12:50 NST with a moment magnitude (Mw) of 7.3. It was the worst natural disaster to strike Nepal since 1934 Nepal–Bihar earthquake.Centuries-old buildings were destroyed at UNESCO World Heritage sites including some at Kathmandu Durbar Square, Patan Durbar Square, Bhaktapur Durbar Square, Changu Narayan Temple, Boudhanath stupa and the Swayambhunath Stupa.Although some are renovated, evidently many more remained as crumbled ruins.
Taste of Kathmandu. Get your feet wet by visiting Durbar square and exploring the shops, street vendors, native Nepali, and much more.

Heritage site with Holistic History!. Kathmandu Durbar Square is a heritage place to visit! It's a real architecture of wonder with lot's of ancient places story related to the culture of Nepal.

Great buildings. I didn't know what to expect but lots to see...I think my guide helped on pointing out what was what. Buildings heavily affected after the earthquake in 2015. A busy place and would have been nicer if it were quieter.
Still standing tall. Its sad and many of the structures is affected bad by the recent earthquake. Lots more to repair and needs help in terms of funding.

Ancient and lovely. Kathmandu Durbar square is an architectural wonder listed as a world heritage site. It holds ancient palaces, temples and quadrangles.Its definitely a hit and make sure you dont miss the area. its crowded and theres a lot of souvenir stalls happening, the usual KTM sight. its not the cleanest but go there for the artistry, architecture and history, some areas are being restored when we visited and expect to pay some entrance fee. you can just sit in the middle of the square and watch the chaos as you catch your breath after walking through every corner of the square.

Still an interesting place!. Although several temples were destroyed or damaged in the 2015 earthquake Durbar Square is still an intriguing place to visit. The people, the sites, and the history are so amazing here that it is a "must see" when in Kathmandu.
Temples and goods. Lots of temples, shops, restaurants and stands. Lots of people moving around, lots of colours. You have to pay 1,100 rupies to go there if you are a tourist

Not happy with the process of admission. Durbar Square suffered a lot from the Earthquake, and we didn't like the way we were treated.. Once you walk into the Square a guide quickly came to us and said that we needed to pay 1000 Rps which is a lot compared to other temples in Nepal or India so we were approached by some military person and made us all pay (no student or child discount) when we asked how was the process of charging that fee (because there is no control entrance) they said they just spot tourist-like people or people with cameras and stop them. Then we asked why so much and they said they needed money to restore the damage from the earthquake so that's why the charge so much.

Not as good as Patan Durbar Square. It's 1,000 NRP for foreigners to get in, which is 250 more than Patan Durbar Square. The temple of the living goddess was interesting, but there's a lot of earthquake damage.

nice place. Nice place but recently hit by the earthquake. it consists of very old temples,palaces,baths,fountains etc. I recommend pay a small fee and get a guide who would take you through. Though you can do it on your own, the guide get you some history data that even wikipedia might not have . One of the famous heritage structures in kathmandu. dont miss

Go and support the restoration. . Durbar square is at the end of the Thamel main touristic street. We paid 200rs for a rickshaw from the beginning of Thamel to Durbar square. I'm sure you can do it for 100rs. Entrance of Durbar square was 10,000 rs. And no one was really checking if you paid the ticket or not. The ticket is used to go inside a museum but is not really having much interesting things. What we saw was the pieces that we're going to be use for the restoration of the buildings. If you need to choose between Bhaktapur Durbar square or KTM Durbar square. Bhaktapur is more preserved. We saw our entrance to the place as a donation for the restoration of the earthquake of 2015.

Nice place, but lot of damage of earthquake . It is a very nice place to see. You have to pay around 1,000 rupees for foreigners (including an extra fee for restoration after the earthquake). Beautiful architecture.. Kathmandu Durbar Square in front of the old royal palace of the former Kathmandu Kingdom is one of three Durbar Squares in the Kathmandu Valley in Nepal, all of which are UNESCO World Heritage Sites.  As such, the square remains the Kathmandu’s most beautiful legacy of traditional architecture.  It is too good to spend hours wandering around the square. But unfortunately the earthquake  has damaged the structures to a good extent. Worth a visit.

Feeling Relaxed. feels so Relaxed when visit's this place. Beautiful architecture with old king's palace. It is really fun in the evening to see the locals having a good time there. You can Shop there as well. These architecture depict a lot. You can feel the royalness of the palaces here. Although the earthquake has brought the place to pieces but still the feel comes.

Old towns around the palace ( durbar ) . You will get the chance to experience authentic architecture of Nepal along with attractive shops along the palace square. There are basically three durbar in kathmandu and each one has their own uniqueness in their design and layout. Its one of tourist attraction site and its a worth visiting place

Earthquake ridden. A year after the earthquake... Quite a lot has been destroyed. But still, one can see and feel culture, history.As I've felt about other places in Kathmandu, this one too had been neglected. But I won't crib much as the earthquake did cause damage that is not easy to repair. Must visit nevertheless.
worth a few days. Emense --a virtual massive museum--do not forget to get the pass at the office--you will need a phot and your passport and then coming back during your stay is free

Ancient city with old Palace. Beautiful architecture with old king's palace. It is usually fun in the evening to see the locals hanging around, socializing and drinking "Chiya" TEA. Mama's tea Shop is recommended if you want to enjoy tea the nepali way.

Business with A Little Pleasure Mixed In. Kathmandu Durbar Square in front of the old royal palace of the former Kathmandu Kingdom is one of three Durbar Squares in the Kathmandu Valley in Nepal, all of which are UNESCO World Heritage Sites. As such, the square remains the traditional heart of the old town and Kathmandu’s most spectacular legacy of traditional architecture. It was easy for us to spend hours wandering around the square and watching the world go by. Although most of the square dates back from the 17th and 18th centuries, it has been left badly damaged after the April 2015 earthquake and the aftershock.

Safe to visit July 2016. Beautiful temples, palaces and people. Stay away from holy men scammers, though! Gorgeous rich culture all around, festivals, ancient sites to visit, highly recommend. There are some nice guides who are less aggressive further in if anyone wants a history guide of the ancient sites.

Extraordinary Site-but extremely destroyed by earthquake. Very few city can offer such a genuine and valuable architecture as Durbar Square In Kathmandu.. The buildings and the soul of that area is really misterious but the distractitoion appauling. I guess it takes lot of years to recover. There are still lot of ruins and debris around the medievel district.

Take a tour. This is an interesting place to go, but if you don't have a guide, you won't really get much out of it (unless you bring your own guidebook.) It's chocked full of history and religious information. Very interesting and informative.
Durban Square half a day trip. Beautiful square surrounded by temples. You could see the destruction caused by earthquake. Because of which tourist cannot enter the temples

Not so good after earthquake . I've been here with friend today.First of all the prices are not the same for all tourists, if you are not from India, Bangladesh or some nearby country you will pay a lot more to see the Durbar square (1000 compared to 250 for those countries). They don't have any student discount. Even one year after the earthquake they didn't to obviously nothing to undo the damage of earthquake.Second of all you should bring the photo if you want to get the pass for whole staying in Nepal (it is nice to have that) - but they don't say nothing about photo when you pay the ticket - they just say 'you can get the stamp for whole staying, just go to Site office'.All in all - nice to see, but not value for the price of 10 dollars.

Living Museum. This is excellent place to visit in the morning and late afternoon time. Visit the living Goddess Kumari and all the Courtyard is very interesting. Once you are there visit the National Museum also.

MAJESTIC!!. If you are visiting Kathmandu for a day or weeks I think you will never run out of history in each corner of this sacred area. The shops were like a scavenger hunt.. treasures behind each shop door. I can't wait to go back and explore.
Durbar Square after the Earth Quake. I was saddened to see the earth quake damage. Nevertheless, it was wonderful to be there and people are still worshiping and working.
Expensive. Entrance fee for a visit of a square is quite expensive. Many temples are closed to foreigners and going around the streets should not have any cost. A bit disappointing

Go for the Kumari. There are several squares in Kathmandu. As far as beauty of buildings and historical structure, Durbar is lacking. But it's worth the trip to see the living goddess Kumari. We went around 4:00 and were able to see her for about 30 seconds. The area is obviously damaged from the earthquake, and I wish I could have seen it before! But for buildings and beauty, I liked Bhaktipur more.

The Golden Temple hidden away in Durbar Square. to me Durbar Square was the grandest place i visit during my second visit to Nepal..This place is a very crowded historical place, were locals and foreigners come to visit. Make sure you do not have leather goods with you carring these is prohibited in the temple's compound. Before entering the place make sure you purchase your entry tag which you have to wear during you visit. For foreigners it is 500 NPR, for locals entry is free of charge. You will see many vendors selling all kind of nick nacks. you will see temples and shrines dating back to the 3rd century.Take a stroll through the side alleys and you will discover a world that stems from the Newari and Tibetan culture, an evidence of spiritual ties forged between Patan ( the district were Durbar square is located )and Tibet through centuries of trade.as you stroll the lanes you will come to the tiny Golden Temple which is not well visited , maybe because it is hidden away almost at the end of Durbar Square. it is the most opulent little temple in Nepal, it is a must visit when in Nepal.Aside of the main temple courtyard ( in the temple gardens ) is the monastery restaurant which i had mentioned early in another review. It looks to tempting with vegetarian and non vegetarian food, moreover what tempted us to have lunch in this restaurant was that all the vegetables & herbs they use in their cooking comes from the monastery's garden. Unfortunately we were very disappointed with the lunch we were served. The vegetable still had soil in them and some other matter perhaps better not to know, we were offered coffee and cake as compensation, but in the end eventually charged for. the intricate artwork in wood or silver of all the buildings and temples is a must see for every visitor to Nepal. You will just stand there in awe and wonder how people at that time were able to do such kind of precise work. Namaste

A day at Durbar square. Completely destroyed by the earthquake all that remains is the ruins and the signs of destruction that the earthquake caused. there is nothing left here so one should avoid this place and spend the time visiting other attractions

Historical place ravaged by the earthquake. Visited the place in May 2016 and could only imagine what the place would have looked like in its full glory before the earthquake took its toll on the place. Situated right in the midst of the hustle and bustle of the market area in Kathmandu, the area is the centre of what used to be the seat of power at Kathmandu with its temples and palaces. Though some of it has been damaged, it still gives a view of the old style architecture of the area with its brick and wooden buildings. One can go to the rooftop of some of the restaurants at the place and enjoy food and rinks with a view of the surrounding hills and the durbar square.Overall, a must visit place in Kathmandu

Historic area hit very hard by the earthquake. This temple area most once have been beautiful. Many shops line the area and Freak Street is along one side but the devastation to the temples and palace from the earthquake extensive. I loved walking around the area and enjoying lunch in a bordering cafe. There is a 1000 rupee charge to enter this area and keep a hold of ticket as they may ask to see it. Within walking distance- 20 minutes from Hotel Vajra.

A stroll back in time. Despite the earthquake and the extensive damage sustained this place is still worth your time. You will need to purchase a ticket costing ten dollars per person but it is good if for re-entry for as long as your visa is good. For return you will need to get a free ticket that they will paste you picture to, so carry extra photos. The place itself has amazing architecture with lots of places to explore. Be careful not to sign up for a tour guide if you don't want them, there are some that are heavy sell.

Yes do go since it supports rstoration but there is probably still a lot of damage from the 2015 earthquake. This is a very impressive area despite a lot of damage being visible in March April 2016. Many of the smaller shrines just pancaked during the earthquake and are just stacks of rubble. But most of the larger palaces and buildings are still there held up by massive props / beams. It is definitely worth going - you do have to pay as you enter the area (you will be chased down by the police / soldiers if you just walk past. necessarily obvious where you pay at first glance but there are small official kiosks. There has been a lot of International support pledge to rebuild these heritage sites but the government is not the fastest at getting its act together to take advantage of aid whether to repair buildings or support its residents. Note except is some very localized areas such as Durbar Square or some other heritage sites, earthquake damage was not very visible in Kathmandu during March / April 2016. (There are still a couple of large refugee camps in Kathmandu but not in the central or tourist areas)

I would go again. I think this is one of the places you have to go if your travel as far as Kathmandu. That being said, there is a lot of earthquake damage and not a lot to do besides stroll around. During the evening the area become a "local market" where people come to buy clothes and such. I would go again... It's a quick visit for me though.
Amazing history. Well worth a visit. Sad to see earthquake damage. Shame there is so many people following you around trying to convince you to spend money!

A must visit while in Kathmandu. I actually really like this place!
It was hugely affected by the earthquake and many of the buildings have been damaged or completely destroyed, but it still has its charm. There are a few rooftop restaurants close to it that can get you a different angle of the place.
historic & Artistic place. you will never find such woodcraft and artistic design in the world, we can feel it like heaven. its master piece.

Unique Cultural Viewing. This place is easily accessed and much more peacful than other areas where locals try to pry on 'American' appearing 'tourists.'
It would be a nice place to walk around and I'd suggest it as a unique attraction that provides insight to the overall area.

Awful place - go to Bhaktapur Durbar Square instead. Even with the earthquake damage - this place is a smelly, filthy, ugly wasteland. There is basically nothing endearing about the square. Plagued with irritating prospective guides, tacky souvenir vendors & perilous motorbikes, don't waste your money or precious moments of your life and go somewhere better (which is basically anywhere), maybe Bhaktapur's Durbar Square, which is worth a visit.

Highly recommend, even after earthquake damage.. Whilst a lot of this place has been ruined by the earthquake I would still recommend visiting, one, to see the devastation of the earthquake and how much it impacted upon the life, culture and religion of the Nepalese people, and two to put money back into restoring such an important place for the Nepalese people. It is still very interesting to visit as a tourist, and lots to see around the site. Entrance fee of NPR1000 or USD$10.

Only happening place. One of the oldest area in KTM. It houses the King palace which is now a museum, many eateries, bars, 5 star hotels, Little Italy restaurant, global brands like Bally showroom for some shopping. Easily one can spend 2-3 hours here.

some major earthquake damage. A lot of the temples have damage from the 2015 quake but there are still alot of temples and shrines to see. grab a local guide for about £10 who will take you round for an hour
Beautiful . Name called as Kathmandu darbar square is one Of the oldest UNESCO recognized place you may able to see life gaurd called kumari. This is the magic thing to see on that place.
Must see. a very nice place to walk around we stayed in Thamil street and walked there busy market on the way too many ppl offering smoke and stuff

Centerpiece of the City. Great part of Kathmandu to see. There is still some earthquake damage and will be for some time to come. The entrance fee is pretty cheap and a good many buildings to see. There are also several "guides" waiting to help you if you don't have one..each will charge a "fee" on how "happy" you are...don't forget to venture a little out from the square where you will find additional temples and sites on side streets.

Some earthquake damage, but still nice temples. This is pretty touristy, but it is one of the main temples and a good example of one even with the damage. There is some interesting shopping on the side streets around the temple, so if you have shoppers with you, plan on some extra time.

GO post-earthquake!. It is a shame that the news portrayed complete destruction of Durbar Square in Kathmandu. Though there is extensive damage on the south side of the site, the northern site still has plenty to see, including excellent people watching. Unfortunately the decline in tourist numbers accounts for the pushy guides, especially on the south side outside the Kumari temple. The entrance fee may seem more than other sites, but it is still worth a visit and your ticket can be extended to multiple days if you have your passport with you. Take small change: you'll want to take pictures of the holy men walking around, and they'll insist on a 'little something'.

The soul of Kathmandu.. DURBAR SQUARE. KATHMANDU. In the heart of the city, and together with Pasupatinaht the main attractions. Ticket, i think 1000 R (two days). Several places to visit: museum, etc. Kumari house, the living goddessa, only the courtyyard. The destruction of the earthquake are patent, but you can see several old constructions. Yes, you must-to-see-it.
Excellent Temples - Authentic Neap. Amazing architecture and temple artifacts; safe place to visit. Guides were readily available, inexpensive to visit. A must see.

Interesting, but expensive. Place really shows the devestating effects of the earth quacke. However it is a shame they ask 1000 rupees entrance. Other sightseeing places in KTM are either free or 200 rupees.

Beautiful but ruined. This used to be a beautiful place. One would be mesmerized by the cultural beauty and art especially in the evening and night. But recently due to the earthquake hit this place has been partially destroyed. Still I would recommend people to visit this place because its still worth watching.

Very damaged by earthquake.. Be aware that this was very damaged and has not been built back up. We were shocked by this site but strangely interested. It's worth a look but be ready to see the devastation caused.

Beautiful. Really nice place which was built in the 16th century I believe. Buy your ticket at the southeast corner of the area. Valid for one day unless you provide a photo of yourself and show them your passport. It will then be valid for the rest of your visa. Only annoying thing are all of the guides trying to get you to hire them. I finally gave up and a man showed me around quickly and then led me to a store which sold paintings of samsaras and mantra etc. Apparently they were handmade and it was obviously overpriced. I told them I wouldn't buy anything and after the rest of the tour it was a bitter atmosphere. If you want a proper guide check out "Welcome to my yard". Their 3h walking tour includes durbar square and it's a non-profit organization.

sad to see the earthquake damage. sadly Durbar square was badly damaged by the 2015 earthquakes and many of the famous temples have been levelled. For the first time I noticed that tourists are now plagued by hawkers trying to sell their wares which got a bit much after a while as we couldn't talk, take pictures or even pages to look around. I understand that some people are desperate to get income but even after we tried to spend some money, we were simply surrounded by even more people trying to sell. Its a sad situation and I guess understandable.
great experience. this is a fantastic place, its such a shame that the earthquake caused so much Damage, not just here but all over

Try to catch a glimpse of the living goddess. Despite the damage from the earthquake, Kathmandu's Durbar Square is still a great place to visit. I was particularly fascinated to see the living goddess Kumari. Entering her temple does require a paid ticket but it was worth that intriguing split second. So many questions!

Excellent ancient Architecture in Kashth(wood). Very nice Architectural view with gorgeous historical stories.The Main Kashth Mandapam is badly damaged in earthquake. Other buildings are also damaged but still beautiful.A must visit place in Kathmandu.The name kathmandu is derived from Kashth Mandapam. Two hours time is enough if you dont want to study deeply the history and archtecture

A beautiful place to be . To enter majority of the area is free but there are some parts where you'd have to pay to get into like the museum. We climbed to the top of the rooftop at the casino which was tiring but well worth the ending as you can see all of Durbar square at the top! Don't be fooled by the " guides" as they charge more for you to get in which essentially is cheaper for you to explore on your own. You need about 2-3 days to finish the entire thing if you want to take your time exploring as there's so much to see!

Damaged from earthquakes and expensive. . Entry was about 1000rs which we avoided paying by walking around. Would be good if you were into temples but I was quite over it at that stage. Photo ops were ruined by earthquake damage and we were hassled by tour guides.
Beautiful. This is a must see during a visit to Kathmandu. One of the most wonderful Palaces that you will visit during your trip.

Glad to help out Nepal in my own little way. Never have I visited a place that has affected me as profoundly as Nepal. The people are so gracious and somehow their peace rubs off on you (tourists). Going back to Durbar, it's an feast for the senses-the damage from the April 2015 earthquake is still very much evident but activity is bustling and back to normal.Shopping as always is very reasonable with a variety of things to bring hpme-decor, jewelry, clothes, spices and a lot more.

Severely damaged after the quake. There is lots of work to do for the nepali woodworkers as many temples in the central part of durbar square have collapsed after the earthquake. Still, there is plenty of undamaged things to see.
Good Place to see.. I visited this place last week.So many heritage buildings are here.But unfortunately, earthquake ruined many buildings.But, good place to see.
Must see in Kathmandu. You may have to ask around to locate but it is well worth the walk. Or you may take a taxi or Rikcha to the entrance.

Wonderful Old Structures at Durbar Square. I visited before the earthquake. This was a very nice area to walk around and marvel at the buildings that surround this area. Don't know how much of the buildings and structures have survived the earthquake. Visited in 2008.

More temples. I think I was pretty much over temples on our second day of sightseeing in Kathmandu. On this day we visited three squares and most cities seem to have a Durbar Square. Unless Hindu temples are your thing do one square such as this as it is all pretty boring after the first.
Interesting place. Lots of temples, some.of them damaged by the earthquake. You can find there Kumari's temple. Plenty to see and do, but you have to pay to enter 1000 Nepali Rupes.

Crimson Nepal Adventure Day Tour. My family and u recently went for a day tour to Durbar Square. Our tour guide was Pawan from Crimson Nepal Adventure and he introduced us to this ancient city of Kings. The history of this place is incredible. We felt transported to an exotic time in history. Crimson Nepal Adventurewas very informative and we learned a great deal about the culture and history of this timeless place.

Only with a guide worth it. We spent the 1000 rps entrance fee and did not want to pay more money for a guide. But we realised soon that his explanations might be very valuable since the sights are not too impressive without any deeper knowledge about it.so we bargained with a guide who eventually showed us around for appr. 1.5 hours for 800 (with tip 1000) for two persons. If you dont want to spend appr. 1500 rps per person/ or having a great guide book dont go there since you will be unhappy to pay the high emtrance fee but only seeing destroyed monuments... With a guide totally worth it but for nepal still expensive!

beautiful square. Beautiful square in the middle of the city. In the lonely planet several walking routes will show you this square. A lot of tourist guides hang around and will show you around for a small amount of money. And although you can just walk the square and all statues, including Kumari house, yourself it is so much nieces with a guide informing you about the history. Kumari House is a must visit, without guide the chance of seeing the Kumari is small, with a guide you are 99% sure she will show herself for a few moments.

Day tour Kathmandu with Mountain Mart Treks & Expedition. It was raining during our visit to Dubar Square, the buildings there were very impressive even though the earth quake in 2015 damages some part of it.

Nice Afternoon Walk. One of the three Dunbar Squares in the Kathmandu Valley and well worth the visit if you like historic architecture, temples and people watching. Plan to spend at least a couple of hours slowing walking around the sites.

Durbar Square. This probably was really special before the earthquake. It still is worth seeing but you should know going in that the earthquake caused a lot of damage and it will take a few years to get rid of all the rubble and to get the building built back up.

Ruins tell a tale of opulence. In ruins now post the Nepal earthquake, the place displays great potential to be revived.Unfortunately even after an year of the quake, the restoration activity seemed slow.Old fallen buildings, wooden ornate doorways and structure boast of a great legacy.The multi storied palace now in ruins almost invokes pity.The child goddess building evokes mixed reaction of historical superstition or blind faith mixed with anger at the still practiced ancient belief.Worth a visit definitely.
Interesting place of Kathmandu. Nice little stroll through the place. We arrived by bicycle and did some photos see the at twistingspokes.com

Interesting visit, but not really worth the cost. Durbar is probably still a must-see attraction in Kathmandu, despite the state of the square. Many of the monuments and buildings have been severely damaged by the 2015 earthquake, and are undergoing restoration. It's a pricey visit considering it's an open air square, and it feels a little unjust to see locals walking through for free while tourists are targeted aggressively and forced to pay 1000 rupee. Almost all squares, monuments and historical sites in Kathmandu attract entry fees, but most are only around 100-300 rupee, so 1000 felt like a big sting considering apart from viewing the monuments, there isn't a lot on offer. My hope is that the fees for entry go toward the restoration effort, but I definitely can't confirm that, and can only hope for the best in people.

Looks great but.... I'm torn about Durbar. It is a fascinating place to be sure - the markets are quite good and the buildings are amazing.. but the hassle at the square is some of the worst in Nepal. You feel as though you are being swarmed on. There is also a hefty entrance fee even if you just want to walk through the square. My advice would be to skip Durbar and go directly to Bhaktapur which is very similar but more interesting with less hassle (there is still hassle there! but less) Or visit a restaurant overlooking Durbar so you can see the buildings without having to deal with all the shenanigans below.

Didn't find interesting like people say. Firstly it affected from earthquake badly. Nobody found in our friend group anything interesting in there. We made one quick round than finished. I don't think so it worth 1000 rupees. But we didn't see Kumari because of our timing.

Another temple area . A good atmosphere, scenery starting to look the same as everywhere else. The earthquake stamped with despair. Rubble, ruins and meagre poles wedged to stop buildings from falling. Perhaps in years to come it will be a prettier place to visit. A little sadness to see hundreds of years crumbling around you.

Historic but destroyed in earthquake. If you have never been to Durbar Square you should go. A guide for $5 for an hour makes the visit much more interesting. If you went to Durbar Square before the earthquake, do no return as the damage is extensive and not much is being done about it. Your heart will break.
A pity you must pay as tourist. Beautifu place being renewedAs a tourist you must buy a ticket for 3,5 Euros or 500 Rupis!Everywhere in Nepal you must pay entrance
Recovering from Earthquake. This is a must see place in Kathmandu, so many temples and culture in here. The place has been badly damaged and needs our help, so go there...

Beautiful old city in the Kathmandu valley. We really loved the charm of this historic area. The 2015 earthquake damage was very apparent, but there is still much more that is intact or only slightly damaged. You pay entrance to an entire city, so the religious buildings are only part of the visit. Lots and lots to see here. Our main guide and driver got us a guide from the area and he helped us significantly in understanding the historical importance of each temple or building. A must see as part of a visit to Kathmandu.

A must see. Patan Durbar Square is a must see. some of the properties are under reconstruction due to the earthquake. But still it holds within so much culture. The architecture is lovely and the museum is a must see also.

A must see. Even with the devastation of last years earthquake this is a beautiful site to visit. The tour guides are great and offer great information and tips (like getting a free upgrade up to a three week pass card for future visits). It might take five to ten years to get everything back to normal but there is still a lot to see, a lot of culture and an amazing place to take pictures. Probably the best way to help in the reconstruction is to actually go to this sight and spend a little time, money and support the locals instead of waiting for the repairs.
the attraction of old things. True to its status as a UNESCO world heritage site, the architecture in this place is sure to linger in your mind
Interesting authentic old Nepal. Has recovered well post-earthquake! Happy to pay the tourist entry fee to help support renovations and heritage improvements.

City main square. This is a place where time has frozen since the 12th century a square housing all the arts of ancient times..stone art, metal, wood carving and terracotta with architectural showpieces. There is the National Art Gallery a place where once can spend a couple of hours studying the history. The palace of 55 Windows is just amazing as one enters from the ornate gate. Lots of temples dominate the square, many of which got destroyed during the 2015 earthquake. Restoration work is in progress. At every corner there stands an architectural beauty. The square has plenty of restaurants to enjoy both local and continental cusine. There are guesthouse to stay. Recommend staying here to get a complete feel of the place.

adversely damaged by earthquake. the kathmandu durbar square has been adversely damaged by the earthquake. i got no chance to observe the beauty but i could feel how wonderful it would have been before!

Expensive for tourists . Shocked by the entrance fee which was 1000rps for tourists. I believe that since the earthquake prices may have gone up as they are using the money for rebuilding / renovating.

Go on Friday to see the living goddess Kumari!. The square has a market that sells lots of souvenirs and trinkets. Feel free to bargain. There are many temples and I walked into a temple where the living goddess Kumari lives. She only comes out on Fridays, throughout the day for a minute or so. It will be a strange custom to many and the guides there remind us not to take this as a joke. The square is full of guides offering their services for a small fee, usually 500 rupees for an hour or so.

Worth it if you don't have to pay. They make you pay 1500 rupees to walk past the , unfortunately crumbled down ruins, of the temple.. Unless you are not white. Then you can walk past. Very interesting surrounding parts of the city though. Alive with activity and local spirit,

Historical Place. This is a wonderful place for religious and historical tour. I may even consider it as a pilgrimage. The people would love to be visiting this place and enjoy the warmth of the people there.

claustrophobic. Glad I wasn't there during the earthquake. Was a maze of shops with persistent "salespeople". You could find anything you need here as souvenirs, but not a relaxing experience. Very high energy and crowded

Feel sad for the place. I was approached by a good guide that had to earn his dole for his fMily. The visitors had dropped. I hope that the places can be restored soon and bring back the charm and vibrant Kathmandu.

Restorations from the Earthquake Underway, but Still Beautiful. A fascinating place to visit for so many reasons. The buildings and the art are incredibly beautiful and detailed. This is a great place to people watch as there are people from different walks of life everywhere you turn, old, young, merchants, worshippers, tourists and business people. Truly fascinating.
OK. It was a great place to learn about the history, but the place was dirty. Good to waste some time but you have to pay an entrance fee

Significant EQ Repairs underway but still amazing. The 2015 earthquake may have damaged some buildings but there is still much to see here. There is the open markets at the back to buy souvenirs and you can still walk through the building and see the artifiacts and historical significance of Durbar Square which must have been impressive in historical times. A MUST SEE for travellers to Kathmandu! TIP: If you are in town for 2-3 days or longer, if you take your passport, a passport photo and you admission ticket to the Tourist Office at the back of the complex, they will extend your admission ticket for as many days or weeks as you like FOR FREE!

Busy. A rather busy place was Durbar Square, with both tourists & locals buzzing around doing their thing. We saw a group of men dragging some old relic along, R-E-S-P-E-C-T! I've never seen so many pigeons either!

Beautiful wooden architecture. Sadly these temples have suffered damage through the earthquakes however works are underway to refurbish. The place is still worth a visit (gate prices are a bit hexy) and one thing to look for is the wooden carvings on the doors and windows, though simple it is beautiful. I particularly enjoyed the doors, yes the doors, they vary and are very nepalese with vibrant colours and paneling.

kathmandu. well lkind of old style building with student art shop with custom painting avaivable made by students resonable priced,with many pigeons in the square eating food locals and tourist bring,its a nice trip to take by the bicycle with cart

A bit chaotic. Kathmandu’s Dunbar Square was the third such square we'd visited- after Bhaktaput and Patan and they are all different. Kathmandu’s square is larger than the other two and it has suffered far more damage from the 2015 earthquake with virtually every building scaffolded or prompt up. A couple of the buildings including the 12th century temple Kasthamandap were totally devastated. We travelled to the square in a mini bus and had to walk the remaining 200 metres down a muddy road as the bus couldn't enter the square- but cars, motor cycles and scooters could, making for a somewhat manic journey and a seemingly continuous noise of horns and the need to regularly move to one side. The sheer chaos to me spoilt the religious worship that was ongoing in the various temples can on the square. Entry to the square is 1000 Nepalese dollars (around £6.50) for tourists which goes to refurbishment, but with the amount of work needed this will take many, many years even with the necessary will and money being available. One other negative of the square was the annoyingly aggressive nature of the street traders who just wouldn't leave you alone, the square was the only place we'd experienced this during our complete tour of Nepal.

Know heritage to Feel own identity. If one is traveling to Nepal, he or she must visit this unique old architectural attraction. It is amazing that how those designers and architect had done that. The way they imagined and made turned out in reality it is something beyond dream. Wonderful temple, house & other establishment really lift the Durbar Square to a different height. People, some birds around there will be making your visit lively with history feelings.

Still worth a visit . Still worth a visit after the earthquakes as there are still buildings intact. The price of a 1000 rupees seems a bit much though and I wonder if this money goes to the reconstruction of the site.
Amazing woodworking. The squire has some of the oldest craved Hindo temples in the country. The details are amazing. I highly recommend a tour guide to fully appreciate this site!

Nice place. Nice place shows the antique side of Kathmandu but the magic of the building has been debased by the earthquake. Still to see the traditional architecture of Nepal but a nice place for street shopping

ruins of past glory. Durbar Square was, until the 2015 earthquake, the historical heart of Kathmandu. It has an amazing collection of historical buildings: temples, a museum, palace, markets and in-between amazing sculptures, mostly in stone but also in wood. Much of this was ruined and the present situation is one of chaos, derelict buildings, remains. There is still beauty to be seen, as well as erotic wooden sculpture on one of the temples and a huge display of Kali, the God of revenge. But the markets have gone, the pyramidal structure is in ruins, the museum is closed. The entrance fee is still levied (keep the ticket and come back the next day!), and it's good to contribute money for restoration. But there is a long way to go. The open-air market of trinkets, bells, games, puppets is still there (bargaining compulsory, check the very mediocre quality and don't believe anything is old), but it lacks life.
Right Place. This place is very good for photo hunter and stuff hunter. Its complete.You can bargaining in the market near this place.

Wish to see you again soon in a better shape. The first feeling, and a quite overwhelming one when entering the compound, is one of sadness as you compare the current cityscape with the one shown in the beautiful pictures taken before the earthquake. The sight of debris and wooden posts is everywhere, but the place is still a charming one, especially if weather helps with a beautiful sunshine.A mandatory stop is at the Kumari ghar, the house of Living Goddess, where you will be told the story of how a girl is identified by a committee of elders as a living goddess when she is 3, and must leave the position to a younger girl before she reaches puberty. The building where the goddess lives can be partially visited, with a beautiful courtyard whose walls are enriched with elegant elaborate wooden carvings.I was lucky enough to visit Durbar Square while the first of the Newari traditional ‘barha’ wedding ceremonies was being held, where 3~4 year-old girls were being married to the wood apple, a fruit produced by a tree native to India. They will be married again (to the sun, this time) before they are 12, and only after then they can get married to a man. The main point is to avoid that they are identified as widows if their husband dies prematurely, thus sparing them the related disadvantages within the traditional Nepalese society.Can only wish that this beautiful place is restored to the traditional splendour as soon as possible.

Expensive.... We went to this site, only to leave when we saw the entry fee to be 1000 NR per person. Far too much money in comparison to other sites, especially when so much of it appears to have been destroyed in the earthquake.
Interesting but so badly damaged.. Very interesting but so badly damaged by the 2015 earthquake that it can only be a shadow of its former self.

Nice Place. Nepal is the great place .that I travel one of this. all the view are very nice.tample are very cute. museum was very nice. most of the tample are made by woods nice arts with different funny picture and gods . I really miss that place .

Shows History of Nepal Architecture. Must visit place in kathmandu, the surrounding is peaceful, sometimes a little crowdy in the evenings, there are small markets for shopping nearby, road side non veg food, snacks are available, definitely we are returning back soon at this place.

Devastation in a major scale. This Kathmandu Durbar Square is heartbreaking...it is virtually in ruins...I cannot see this ever being what is was before.It was unrecognizable from my last visit it was heartbreaking.

Amazing Pagodas with great history. the place called Durbar Square seems exactly as mentioned in its name, Durbar is the place where normally earlier ruler's assembled with their ministers and bureaucrats to discuss on all issues. No doubt that after recent earth quakes in Nepal these historical buildings/Pagodas effected very badly but still carrying the charm and attraction of thousand years old history of Hindu ruler's. the Historical temple situated inside Durbar allowed only Hindu devotees to enter but unfortunately closed for any prayers and activities.must to visit place for all tourists visiting Nepal.

Another site you can't miss.. When you go here, take a tour guide or hire one at the site. However, be prepared that they will take you in a shop that sells Thanka's and pressure you to buy one. You can probably avoid this stop if you tell your guide ahead of time.

Good for walking and taking in the history. A beautiful setting where you can be struck with awe and wonder and the history before you. Despite damage from the 2015 earthquake, this is a must see sight in Kathmandu
Must see first visit. Typical tourist area and a must see. Great culture and history can be seen with our without a guide however all foreigners pay to get in. No big deal

Wow...history everywhere you turn.... Definitely worth a stop. Lots of temples that are very old and old palaces. Interesting stories and history go along with each. Easy walking by walking key to see everything. Wear comfy shoes.

Best place to look at. . It is the best place and with beautiful surrounding. I went there a couple of time, you can even find good eating places too.

Needing lots of repsir. Damaged by earthquake in 2015.Still needing lots of work to restore to the previous glory. Admission fee of 1000 NrpIs quite steep. After seeing Patan Durbar square not that much difference.

So sad but still worth a visit.. Although Durbar Square in Kathmandu is a shadow of it former self there as still reason to visit, perhaps the first is just to realise what has been lost. The entrance fee is 1000R for a day visit, if you plan to spend more than a day, take your day ticket, your passport and a passport photo to the "site office" in Basantapur Square and for no extra charge they will turn it into a multi day pass, this only took a matter of minutes to complete and was easy. Stunning architecture. I was so glad I got to visit this square when visiting Kathmandu. It was very sad to see so many of the buildings crumbling and condemned, mere shadows of their former glory. You cannot help but imagine that fully restoring the many buildings in the square will take at least a decade. It will be a long time, but small ticket sale price that all tourists pay go towards the restoration process, so I encourage you to have a look and contribute to the rebuilding process. We had an excellent guide who explained the many different buildings are their purposes: I would thoroughly recommend a guide as we got so much more out of it as a result, although they do give you quite a useful pamphlet with your ticket purchase.

Amazing cultural place. Durbar Square, although parts of it destroyed during my visit, is still really amazing! People going about with their life, sellers, visitors and the best part was the appearance of Kumari, the Child Goddess. I left the place with more questions than answers.

I was solo and was easily targeted by the 'local guides' this guy had an honest face so I let him show me around for an hour. I really didn't have the money to spend and I wish I hadn't. I would have been better off reading about everything in my Lonely Planet book. Great History and Shopping . This is a great place, with lots of history. Its best to tour Durbar with a guide to understand the cultural and historical significance of the buildings. For history lovers. If you love history, Durbar square will tell you many things. Sad return to Durbar Square Kathmandu. This was my first return to Kathmandu Durbar Square after the earthquake. It was very sad to see the damage and also what seems to be no work to start any form of renovation after a year - unlike at Bouddha. Disappointed that they are still trying to charge 1000 Rs to go into the square as there is nothing to see but rubble. Hopefully by my next visit work will have started.

Great area. There is a charge for tourists to enter this area, to go towards helping restore some of the buildings. There doesn't seem to be too much of a rush on any restoration here that i noticed. But is a great cultural area to see.

Utter disgrace and overpriced. I first visited Kathmandu in the late 1990s and we use to routinely visit Durbar Square to see the various Malla and Shah Royal Palaces, showing exceptional Newari craftsmanship. They however remained fairly dilapidated, but were well used by local people and tourists brought money by buying trinkets, visiting restaurants and coffee shops and going to Freak Street. I think it was about 2007 that World Heritage status was granted, but this resulted in tourists being charged to visit the square. This is fine, but over the years the charge has increased so much that it became prohibitive for those going to Kathmandu on a regular basis. What has been most upsetting is that over the years there has been little evidence of the money being spent on the actual site, so it has remained dilapidated. It was therefore a shock to see the extensive damage inflicted by the 2015 Earthquake on this world Heritage site. I could have wept at the loss of such old and beautiful craftsmanship, but even more shocking was the fact that we were forced to pay Rs1000 to see what is now mostly a pile of rubble and severely damaged buildings. Some scaffolding has gone up, but very little has been done since the Earthquake to repair the damage. Years of tourist money has been mismanaged/wasted/pilfered and still it is the same old problem; take the money but do nothing with it. This is an utter disgrace. Even though the rest of the world donated £4.1 billion to Nepal, it is hard to see what has been done with the money. It certainly hasn't been spent on Durbar Sq!I cannot recommend that tourists visit this important World Heritage site as they are being over charged. I feel that tourists have been ripped off for may years and more so now.

Heart of Kathmandu city. Major Heritage sites crumbled down to the ground after 26 April 2015 Earthquake. Kathmandu durbar square is situated in the heart of Kathmandu city. This place is fully surrounded by local markets. restaurants & hotels.

Great Rebuilding Efforts. Sad to see the destruction that the earthquake caused but heartwarming to see the rebuilding efforts, the locals and tourists still coming in droves and how much of the beautiful woodwork has been saved and cherished
good memory . very goods musium nice heritage palaces good old royal palace too meny deference tipe temple old palace so I mist recumbent

nice square. the time I visited (July 2015), some parts of it were in ruins maybe they are still now. but it's definitely worth a visit as there are a large part of it still there n u will love the architecture and all. the atmosphere is nice. it was like the nepalese life is all there.. shared with them the sorrow after the earthquake but at the same time saw them thrive and very much keep their positivity in life.

Mismanaged ... only place in the world where you must pay just to walk on the capital city''s main square. Where else must you pay just to walk or sit in the main square of the capital city ? (Of course, it is possible to enter free). And especially now, half the historical monuments have been destroyed and there is no sign of reconstruction.Mismanaged. Most cities in the world have successfully redeveloped their historical center in a public - private partnership, by converting buildings into topend hotels, restaurants, bars, shops ... that then pay for the upkeep of the place.

No plan survives contact with the enemy. Man, i had so many plans when i was preparing my trip, but once i arrived at Durbar Square, everything seemed to fall by the wayside. I had to pay to 'enter' the square, but no one else seemsed to be paying, i think it is only for tourists. as i was trying to take in the sights, i was totally caught off guard by the hustle and bustle of traffic and people goign about their daily routines. even standing and taking a photo sometimes was difficult sometimes. Tons of motorcycles whizzing by and sometimes a group of tourists would literally trample me as they stampeded by. A lot of interesting sights but i couldn't tell what was what and generally disoriented and not brave enough to take on a guide. I had some bad experiences with guides in Morocco who are basically con men, inflating the price and then screaming at you to pay and this turned me off the guide option. However, in retrospect i may have done well to have had a guide. As it was , i was left staring respectfully at various piles of stones and temples without knowing what i was looking at. Nothing is really well labeled and the occasional Sadhu i spoke to didn't speak English. Will have to do more research next time before going.

Beautiful archictecture. It has a very beautiful architecture and gives you a royal feeling. Though the earthquake sure has damaged it but im sure u can find very interesting parts by just having a walk around it.

The earthquake damage is visible!. Many damaged historic buildings are sealed off: still visible and snapable though and he atmospher is still buzzing! It costs 1000Nrps now but if u go early in the morning you won't be asked to pay.

Durbar and Patan square must visits. These two squares are must if you visit Kathmandu. It's sad though watching the remnants of the earthquake here and there. There is a pigeon feeding area with ladies selling dried corn.

Heartbreaking. Came to Kathmandu exactly a year after the deadly earthquake. It was sad to see the destruction and damage that the earthquake has done.Its very disheartening to see that Durbar Square is still in shambles. It looks like the earthquake came not a year ago, but a week ago. Debris still lying around, very little repair or restoration work going on :(I really love Nepal and hope that some good sense prevails and they take up restoration work with sincerity.

Spiritual awakening at Kathmandu Durbar Square. The Kathmandu Durbar Square gives you a glimpse into the royal living style. The inner complex has grand courtyards. The temples in the square exuberates a mystical feeling. They are constructed in pagoda style. The architecture is stunning. Worthwhile is attending the evening Aarti, its amazing view may give you goosebumps.You can simply walk through Thamel market towards the Durbar Square and its a lovely walk with lot of local lifestyle seen both the side of the road. Earthquake has destroyed few structures but still i would say its worth seeing a place.

Kathmandu Kings' Square. At the time of our visit , this age-old square was heavily damaged during the April '15 earthquake.. It's still worth visiting but the entry-price is much to high for viewing what is left. Some ruins were being used as garbagebelts and public toilets!

A gem of art and culture waiting for the interested. Excellent piece of art in everything that is presently there. Plan to spend a good 2-3 hours or more if you really want to enjoy the architecture and the ancient art, culture. Don't miss the golden temple tucked slightly away in durbar area.

Great to see despite the earthquake damage. Still impressive. We snuck in via our hotels back entrance (world heritage hotel) but it is still easy to get in via side streets and avoid the tourist trap ticket booths. As many Nepalese consider the government corrupt save your 1000 rupees and buy some souvenirs to support the local economy. The square has suffered some significant damage and most of the buildings are supported with sympathetic wooden supports. What remains is still very beautiful with intricate carvings etc. Definitely worth seeing, especially to have this number of temples and shrines all in one place.

Enjoyable afternoon wandering . We wandered around Durbar square in the late afternoon. The buildings are obviously badly damaged by the earthquake and several are just rubble. There are helpful boards by these which show what they looked like previously. It was a fascinating few hours wandering and people-watching. We took on board advice from this message board and avoided paying the 1000rupees fee for foreigners. We then bought from the locals inside. There are beautiful Thanka shops, shawls etc and a market was set up in the largest square. Here you feel your money is going to the locals rather than just a tourist tax.

excelllent square with lots of temples. i was here before the earthquake and was mesmerised by every bit of it. I would say a bit of cleanliness would help but still a great place to hang out and locals are very friendly.
Better go to bhaktapur. Bhaktapur Durbar square is much better, it's nicer and it's less crowded. But Siddhidas marg around Kathmandu Durbar square has to be seen!

sad. Nepal needs to get its act together and fix this square to what it used to be. If your going to charge people 1000 NPR then do something with it. The rest of the country thanks to its people seem to have rebounded from the quake, why not this square?

A must see in KTM but not a highlight. Everyone that is visiting KTM should at least have a look at the Durbar Square but don't have high expectations. Many tempels were destroyed or damaged. I personally enjoy Patans Durbar Square more.

Most of it is destroyed and inside is not too clean, there is a lot of rubbage and burning.Early morning was too early for touts so noone approached to offer services.You can finish in about half an hour becaause there is nothing that really catches your eye - only ruins.Hopefully government does something to improve the situation.

Lively and impressive even after earthquake. We enjoyed visiting durbar square. The damage is clear, but it hasn't stopped the local population from making this a great place to visit. I enjoyed keeping myself quietly in the background.
