Must see all 3. You have 3 Durbar Square, one in Katmandu, Patam and Braktanpur, the last 2 , you need to go by car or public transport, I went by taxi.
Amazing square!. They lost a few temples in the earthquake, but the remaining palaces & temples are breathtaking. Make sure you go into the museum in the palace.

Great Place. Basantapur Durabar Square is an amazing place to visit around, this is kind of historic place and worth to visit. Although, some part of the palaces are destroyed by the devastating earthquake, it is still recommended to visit. You can walk to this temple from Thamel as well, it takes less than 20 minutes to reach there. Do not miss to visit this place while you are in Kathmandu.

Support Nepal's recover. Durbar square remains a treat even after the earthquake - and plans are posted for its careful restoration. The fact that the site has some unfavourable reviews below is unbelievably selfish. Nepal suffered a terrible earthquake impacting people, communities, and culture. It will take years to recover, Surely tourists who have enough money to travel to Nepal can afford a small fee towards helping this recovery. You cannot rebuild all WH sites overnight as UNESCO and national agencies have procedures to follow. Please visit this site and help show that tourists have some sympathy with the people and culture of Nepal.

Step back in time. Stepping into Durbar Square is like taking a step back in time. The temples are beautiful. The Earthquake of 2015 has damaged the buildings and some are held up by wooden stalks, one would hope that they will find the money to do repairs soon. You can't go to Kathmandu without visiting Durbar Square

Great history, amazing place.. Very sad to see the damage from the earthquake. We walked around for about 30 minutes and then had a lovely tea in ome of the cafes. Alot of free guides on offer from 100 to 500 INR.

amazing place. This must have been quite a place before the 2015 earthquake. There is enough still standing to be able to appreciate its greatness. Love seeing the locals hanging out around the buildings...sleeping , courting ...
What devastation. This beautiful square is now mostly rubble and damaged buildings which will take a long time to restore, if at all! Such a shock to see this place after the earthquake!
Durbar Square. One of the top sites to visit in kathmandu..m definitely interesting to see the after effects of the earthquake. I would highly recommend to rent a tour guide to know more!
Very interesting . Sadly there is still much earthquake damage remaining. However, we still were able to view beautiful historic structures and enjoyed the experience.

Rip off and not taken care off. Very dissapointing experience. First they charge you 1000 rupees per person which is a whooping 10 dollars to see a semi destroyed old square. It's so bad. Also locals don't buy entry but foreigners are forever too. We spent 30 minutes there including seeing the "kumani" living God which also seems to be just another tourist attraction. I can't no recommend visiting at all. Go to Patang Durban square instead it's a 50 minute walk from this one.

Ancient and impressive place. You got to pay an entrance fee to enter the area. I took a private guide who bought the tickets and showed me around. I would definitely recommend a guided tour since there is a lot of history to be experienced which will be missed without the right explanation.
Quite a bit of damage from earthquake but still go visit.. You can see a lot of the earthquake damage but there is still a lot to see. There is work going on all around but wasn't a problem.

Great for tourists. I grew up around Lalitpur and even though I saw this place every so often I am amazed by how amazing it gets everytime I visit.Since I live in the UK, my association with everyday Nepali heritage has lessened. So, by coming here every time I visit Nepal, I feel much like home. If you wanna know more about Nepali culture come here.... or Thamel would do as well.

A must visit in Kathmandu.. If you are traveling in Kathmandu, you have to visit the durbar squares at Patan, Kathmandu and Bhaktapur. Has lots of restaurants and places to eat with some of the best views.

A shadow of itself & a Tourist ripoff !. So Sad. Durbar Square was an icon of KTM, it was a meeting place and a somewhere you could sit atop the steps of a pagoda to watch the world pass by below.Now it is relics of a past era and some scant scaffolding on the old museum/palace.The big stupa at Boudha suffered in the earhquake, they removed the whole top structure and rebuilt it in 11 months. A credit to the Tibetan community. Durbar Square ripps Tourists off to the tune of 1000Nr to enter, only to see a prime example of "we dont care". Nothing has been done apart from bulldoze away most of the rubble, we saw that happening in May 2015. What has the passing of 11 months shown, nothing !Shame on the government for such a lack of interest, yet taxing tourists even more than before.

Great architecture. A great display of formal imperial glory, this place was heavily damaged by the most recent earthquake. it has great carvings and the presence of the locals is a real delight. a portrait photographers's dream location.

Living goddess is a terrifying reminder of cultural differences. Most of this place has been destroyed by the earthquake in 2015 - as a fellow traveller put it, it's not very good value for travellers today to see it. The fact that the living goddess was left in her little house whilst the earthquake savaged the city is even more terrifying than the fact that such a thing as the living goddess (a pre teen) even exists and people think it's supposed to be an honour.

Take a guide. On entering the square we got approached by a guide who conducted the tour for Rs1500. It was well worth it as i don't think we would have understood any of the significance or history of the area without him. Like everything in Kat, a lot of it is in poor condition, but an interesting sight nevertheless.
Nice walk. We didn't spend a lot of time here but it was a nice walk, heartbreaking to see the damaged buildings. Our son loved feeding the birds here. Worth it if you are in the area.
historical place. this place was royal area with so old building... after hearth quake a big part drop down.. or half broken but it so nice place. you should visit.

History. A fantastic place with many historical temples dating hundreds of years. Discover the intricate wood working of the Nepalese people reflected in all the temples. Many street vendors of typical handcrafted goods.
walk around for local life. we did a short walk early morning time around the area recommended by the lonely planet nepal and really enjoyed it - gave us an insight into local life!

Bored?. Seems to be too commercial, everywhere you turn people trying to sell. Their own works, that look just like everyone else. Could not tell one painter from the next when all works are the same.

beautiful!. Such an amazing place ! It's like you traveled back in time, beautiful ! The damage done by the earthquake was heartbreaking to see in person. However, its beauty still remains unshaken #NepalStrong

Centre of Attraction. Durbar Square is like the old city of Kathmandu. You have to view this place with a different paradigm altogether else all that you would witness is dirt and ruble. I enjoyed my time here when I first visited in 1997. Tourists blended with locals and the old buildings were architectural wonders, however the earthquake devastated it all. Couple of years back. This courtyard has seen lots of historical movements in the past and the ever changing political scenario of the world’s only Hindu nation has more to witness in the future too. Every temple has its own story behind it .It is all well preserved but after Earthquake most of temple is ruined. Ancient Kingdom in Nepal from where you can learn and see the Civil and Architectural Engineering examples how ancient people design and develop their cities.
Still much to see and explore. We visited this site one year after the earthquake. There were still so many beautiful houses to see. If you come here now, you support the reconstruction.

Traditional heart of the old town. Designated a World Heritage Monument in 1979, it's really three loosely connected squares. Once the palace for Nepal, it's now simply a collection of poorly maintained buildings. Earthquake damage is seen throughout the square.

Damage many thing after earthquake. 1st time i traveled there 2008 that time it was really a most attraction place in Nepal. but after earthquake many building was damage. Government taking project to fix them. locally this place name Basantapur. its only 2 km far from Thamel. Excellent architectural, very planed city was made (1484-1520). Really i like to visit this place but feeling sad after when i see after earthquake. Most be visit if you Travel Nepal.

wonderful feeling after visit. everytime i go to the Kathmandu durbar square , i always get proud of how rich our cultural heritage is. But when i went recently , we see how defeated it was when so strong earthquake rattle everything beneath Nepal . Though many part lost than, durbar square still stood with everything that remains still in same manner carrying glorious history of Nepal

The architect. It's amazing old part of kathmandu still earth quake also standing like pillar of kathmandu,few heritage site destroyed but still look like heaven and the unesco heritage site to.hope my next visit like every thing same as before.

Hectic, loud and pushy!. We strolled through on our way to lunch and were yelled at to pay a fee to enter the square (it is free for locals but foreigners must pay). It would have been fine if we were going to stay for a while but we were just passing through to meet a friend at a cafe. There was a man yelling at us to stop so we looped around the square and he followed behind us yelling that we had to pay. Not only did he not have any identification saying he was actually an official but he was relentless. We ended up getting lost in the many small alleys trying to avoid him and were beeped at by so many motorcycles maneuvering through tiny alleyways. Not an enjoyable experience.
Fantastic place to visit. Whenever I have time in Nepal, i head to Durbar square and take photos, I have snaps of the same place for moe than 100.. wow.

Wonderful despite the earthquake damage. Teeming with locals, surrounded by many shops and painfully few tourists. This is a must-see in Kathmandu. The square is a focal point of the city, not to be missed.

Some monuments have been destroyed but still worth it. By sure to take a ticket at one of the extremity of the square; it is free for Nepal people but foreigner have to pay to be on the square. We took a guide that offered his service while we were buying ticket, it was well worth it. He toured us on the square but also around it, there are few other things to see (golden temple, upper view of Durbar Square, Painting school, singing bowl shop).

History architectural Heaven. An amazing place for historical walk! Malla Dynasty's work of engineering magic! This is a reflection of the golden period of Nepal. It's shows the magic spell the world refers to as the Shangrila!!! Try the Newari food inside all restaurants, enter old freak street and live love the magic of the Malla's and the 70's hippie age.

Worth to see some building. Not all building were destroy by earthquake but it worth to visit this place..i come to this place with my nepali friend and bargain price taxi for 350 rupees since we live near airport..when we reach here..i can still take some of the pictures here and take selfie alot with local school teenagers..of couse im still wearing mask all the time

Kathmandu Durbar Square. Kathmandu Durbar Square ( "UNESCO World Heritage Site") also known as Hanuman Dhoka square is one of the major attractions in Kathmandu Valley. Most of the cultural centers of Nepal are concentrated around the Kathmandu valley; among those cultural sites, the important one is the Hanuman-dhoka Durbar Square. The name Hanuman-dhoka Durbar came from the statue of Hanuman established by the King Pratap Malla at the entrance of the royal palace in 1672 A.D. storeyed residence built by King Prithvi Narayan shah in 1770,is called Basantapur Durbar(palace). The whole complex is also known as Kathmandu Durbar Square. Located at the heart of ancient city in Kathmandu it is srounding both Hindu and Buddhist temple. Most of them are built in the pagoda style embellished with intricately carved exteriors as well as Most of the buildings we see here date from 15th to 18th century . The Durbar Square, with its old temples, palaces, epitomizes the religious and cultural life of the people. The major Interesting things to see here are "Kumari (The Living Goddess) Gar" "Kastha Mandap"Maru Ganesh, Mahadev Temple, Shiva Parvati Temple, Bhagwati Temple, Old palace, Saraswoti temple, Krishna Octangular Temple, Big drums, Kal Bhairav, Jagannath Temple, and Taleju Temple etc.. The Durbar Square are is actually made up of two sub-areas. The outer complex is renowned for numerous interesting temples as Kumari Ghar , Kasthamandap , Shiv-Parbati Temple, Jagannath Temple, Big Bell etc ,while the inner complex comprises the old palace area ,Hanuman-dhoka and itscourtyards as Nasal Choke ,Mul Choke ,Sundari Choke, Basantapur Durbar and other. Besides the magnificent temples and shrines, it has other interesting aspects are various festivals , cultural activities and traditions people are following from centuries, which are presented in the Durbar Square. The major festivals include Indrajatra, Dashain, Gaaijatra, Machchhindra-nath jatra ets. These are the occasion when the people from all over the city gather here to mark their centuries old traditions. All the carving and architecture in this area are exceptionally fine which make the architecture in this Hanuman-dhoka Durbar square among the most important sights for travelers to see.
A Piece of the Past.... Despite the destruction wrought by the earth quake in 2015, the place is worth a visit especially if you value things of the past...

Living museum. . Three queen city of kathmandu valley has 3 Durbar square which is a living museum. Travelers will enjoy watching people moving around with their activities like praying to their favorite god n goddess, buying daily necessary goods n relaxing by beautiful temple. Travelers can also enjoy taking photos of beautiful temples and activities of people. Durbar square is the part of palace of ancient Malla kings of kathmandu valley date back to 12th to 17th century AD. The square is fully equipped with great cultural heritage of that time.

Such a shame! But please still visit!. Like so many others I was shocked by the devastation that has destroyed so many great old buildings and monuments. But they are slowly being rebuilt and done are still, just, standing! Please visit to see what was, and will be again!
destroyed in earthquake. The whole Pagoda structure was demolished by earthquake and the place is waiting to be constructed again.

Amazing Achitecture. The buildings here are really amazing and it's a more relaxed feel to it than the other squares and temples in Kathmandu. A lot of the smaller structures have been damaged by the earthquakes but still an lovely place to walk around.

Good for a visit; heavily damaged.. Visited as part of an organised tour paid a lot to get In but was given a tourist card upon providing a photo which meant I could come back for free any time. There was a lot of damage in the palace and to the stupas/ pagodas. Yes the price is high but in western times its not that much and there is some reconstruction work going on and the area is of great interest.
Must-see in Kathmandu. It is one of those must-see places if staying in Kathmandu. Great history and historic places and the sights, smells and sounds of Nepalese life.

Worth a visit but there is not much left. I am definitely happy for visiting the Durbar Square if you are in Kathmandu, the remaining buildings give an indication of how it would have looked before. However, it was fairly expensive in my opinion as the majority of main sites are either impossible to access for health and safety or reduced to piles of bricks if not totally demolished. Moreover, it does not feel particularly safe being around the remaining buildings. A few locals like some of the stall holders there were complaining to us about the fact that not much has been done in the past year by the government, despite the high entrance fees and the international aid given to Nepal. I just hope that the remaining buildings get restored before they collapse even more and anyone else gets hurt.

Not worth paying - go to Bhaktapur instead. If you can just walk through KTM durbar square, then that's fine to look at the remaining temples and Kumari house. But it's not worth paying to see any of the structures. The awful security tail you and yell at you to ask for your ticket. You can explain you're just walking through, and sometimes they'll let you, but most times they'll make you take a different route in a back alley. Locals are free, but tourists have to pay. I understand the concept, if you're visiting the sites. But this is a square in the middle of 3 major shopping areas so many people walk through. As a local that has been living here paying taxes, it is very annoying and rude to be constantly tailed and asked to pay just to walk through when other locals do not have to pay. The major temples were demolished in the earthquake and there is not much to see here in regards to the remaining temples. It's not worth paying 1000 rupees so go to Bhaktapur instead. The entry fee there is 1500 rupees, but well worth it to see 4 squares and many more buildings that are nicer and grander. The town of Bhaktapur itself is charmingly quaint and old. You feel like you're walking through a 1500s novel with the old water wells still in use. Most of the surrounding buildings are original old houses as well, so photos will be better there than in Kathmandu's durbar square which is small and crowded and surrounded by concrete buildings.
Awsome. The effects of earthquake are there to see but there are many buildings left standing which are amazing.

Ancient place to chill. Once in Nepal, you have to visit this place, people say that many of the monuments were destroyed after the earthquake, but I am sure there is a lot to see yet. Feel the energy in this place, take a day to sit in on the roof restaurants in the square, read a book and relax.
Shopping and food. Well not good experience because KFC their seema different from rest of the world and same with other retail brands like Zara and giardano

Very interesting history. Be aware that you will be bombard with 'guides' left right and centre when you pay for your ticket here. But it's worth getting one, otherwise you have no idea what you're looking at. We managed to get a great guide Kumar who we managed to get for 700Rs for the two of us. We was very knowledgable and it wouldn't have been anywhere near as interesting without him. The earthquake has damaged a far bit of the square, but it was still very beautiful and interesting.

Temples on the Square. Durbar Square is located in Bhaktapur,the entrance the the royal palace is here and is marked by the "Golden Gate". The old city has seen a lot of damage from the earthquake last April but you can still see a classic showcase of Medieval Nepalese town life. It's a place where cars and concrete have yet to dominate, the narrow streets are rich in everyday traditional life.

Indomitable spirit. This area has been ravaged by the 2015 earthquake, with many historic buildings either damaged or completely destroyed. However, it is still a marvel to behold: this place truly embodies the spirit of Nepal, and is uniquely fascinating. Moreover, Nepal needs tourist support more than ever at the moment, to help the restoration and rebuilding of places such as this.

Hit by the earthquake. First of all you have to pay a 1000RP entry fee. Guides will attract the tourists and are asking money afterwards, be aware of that. We just walked away.The square is seen as one of the highlights of Kathmandu. It is still nice to visit, seeing the tempels and pigeons, but the earthquake destroyed so much ... Many tempels are 'under construction' now.That beeing said, if u have some spare time, just go. If not, the scamming guides, ticket entry and the fallen monuments are not that special.
A good historic place in Kathmandu. One of the few tourist attractions in Kathmandu. I would recommend you all to go out of Kathmandu to see the real beauty of Nepal.

Overpriced admission, hassling agents. This is one of the most historically unique of locations in Kathmandu, but most buildings have crumbled, lying in a heap of rubble. Adding to the confusion, its hard to tell where the premises begin and end, but there are aggressive, menacing agents trying to collect 1,000 Nepal Rupees (about US$10) to approach. Gates are non-existent, and so hordes of people walk through, in-and-out, so ticket-collectors selectively decide who to charge and who to let pass--rather confusing.

Air of Vulnerbility. You truly feel for the Nepalese people and the devastation that is evident with a stroll through the square. I know they are in need of funds, but I prefer to give donations instead of charging to see destruction. The locals are free to walk around while foreigners have to wear badges. There was a 5.5 quake during the middle of the night, but we never felt it. Most of the temples have had some form of damage.
Many sites still closed. After the earthquake a lot of temples inside the square is closed for visitors. They are renovating the place so it will take sometime to repair everything.
Few temples but needs repairs. Somewhat earthquake ravaged square with several temples. Admission relatively pricey but needed for repairs. In the centre of major shopping area of Kathmandu.

One of the most beautiful places on earth!. Such wonderful history and culture, but also so sad to see what the earthquake has done to this historic site. The Nepalese people are strong, so it is just a matter of time before these beautiful temples/buildings are rebuilt! Seeing lines of volunteers passing bricks to help rebuild destroyed buildings are just amazing! The power of the human spirit is fully displayed in this square!!

Interesting but sad..... Sad because after the earthquake there are a lot of the temples and monuments that have been obliterated. Lots of debris lying around, one wonders when the government will actually do something about it!

Destroyed but still magnificent. Paid 15$ for entry and that was disappointed with the state of the buildings. You can still see the magnificence of the place and recognise their previous glory but just too busy with lost of people bothering you on every corner and asking for money. Happy to pay the price as ute will help to rebuild this place, tons of work needed though...

Overpriced for Budget Travellers. While they may once have been beautiful, the 2015 earthquake and dust have somewhat dampened the view. The entrance fee of 1000 rupees is more than I would have paid had a realised what a state of ruin it is in, but it is so high for restoration fees so at least some good comes of it. I would suggest going instead to the Durbar Square of Patan, half the price and in a much better state - the guards there even told us the ticket would last a week but I cannot confirm if this was a 'one time offer' because we were hesitant or a permanent offer.
Good. All is good that old music but most affected by earthque, eassy to walk from thamel around 10 m. Is really hostrical nice squre.see you next time.

OK, but got hassled by Guides trying to sell me tours Monkey temple is better :D. Ok, you'll probably go here as its one of Kathmandu's Famous landmarks. In all honesty I wasn't all that impressed, Possibly due to the fact that it was my first day in Kathmandu and I got continuously hassled by this one guide trying to sell me a guided tour of the square, when in reality I just wanted to wander by myself and have a look round and take some pictures. I wasn't all that bothered that I might have missed some amazing historical fact or whatever, or that I wouldnt know what a particular shrine or temple was for. This guide in perticular started off at 4000 roupees and over the course of the hour or two I was in durbar square proceeded to keep coming back to me multiple times with lower offers eventually getting down to 500, which by that time it was starting to get dark and I Just left I was that fed up with him. I had actually extended my ticket for two days so I could come back tomorrow (which you can do for free in their ticket office) But I couldnt face any more hasstle from this guy lol!Anyway Durbar square is a fairly interesting collection of old temples, stupas and fallen down buildings, you have to pay 1000 rupees to get in, if you've got time to spare go and have a look round as its not to far from Thamel. If you're short on time and its a toss up between this and the Monkey temple however go see the monkey temple, its much better and the guides were nowhere near as annoying .

Interesting but so sad. The heart and soul of the city but the damage inflicted by recent earthquakes is devastating.You have to pay 1000 rupees now to enter which I did not mind as it goes to help the restoration.Lets hope that the government gets help from other nearby countries to rebuild this lovely ancient site.

The real truth beyond magnificent history. Came to Kathmandu for the conference, had some spare time to stroll around... The Durbar square is not far from Thamel. I walked passed district market. The entrance fee for foreigners is 1000NPR, besides the ticket booth the local will ask you if you want the tour. Referring to what i read in TA review, I just say no so that I can have more time to explore and most importantly selfie. Not much traveler uses selfie stick here, so I was spotted easily to be a traveller. Some children wanted to be in my frame, some hand just come to ask me again if I want a tour guide, some in English, some in Chinese! I may reconsidered if they can speak My language-Thai. Lol. There's a leaflet full with information which I'll read later. But the temple or houses among the square is quite magnificant, different kind of artistic. I came here in Feb 2016, the evidence of earthquakes were still here. This let's me think about Bhuddha preach, about everything is changing all the time no mater how you want to keep it the same...

highly damaged but interesting architecture. the square was very damaged in the 2015 earthquake. there are some temples standing but the entire complex is needing much repair. also a lot of locals have figured out that many tourists are here and i was very annoyed to be bothered every 3 seconds asking for money or a tour. it really took away from the experience. you can see the place where the 'living princess' appears every afternoon. i enjoyed Patan's Durbar square much more than Kathmandu.

Lots of Cool Trinkets. Be prepared for pushy sellers. Lots of cool stuff here. Make sure to haggle because they will start much higher then they expect to sell. The price will drop rapidly unless you get lucky and find one of the few lower starters. It's a great spot to check out and definitely worth a visit. Like I said in the title come prepared so your politeness isn't used against you, and your not pushed into buying anything you don't want. Make sure to shop around unless you don't want the hassle. Kind of a time versus money thing, depends on what's worth more too you.
Ancient Kingdom in Nepal.. Ancient Kingdom in Nepal from where you can learn and see the Civil and Architectural Engineering examples how ancient people design and develop their cities.

Really old city. Durbar Square is like the old city of Kathmandu. You won't see the beauty of this crowded, dirty place if you don't really look. I enjoyed my time here. Tourists blended with locals and the old buildings were amazing.

Make sure you hire a guide - it makes a lot more sense. Interesting place to visit - a lot of work going on there just now as many of the ancient buildings were damaged in the earthquake but having a guide helps to explain everything. A good guide shouldn't cost more that 1000 rupees. It also costs 1000 rupees to get in but if you have a handy passport photo with you - ask to be taken to the office to have it made into a visitor pass and then you can use that to visit all the other attractions in Kathmandu - and come back to Durbar as often as you like.
Old town Square. This will take you to history of Nepal which belonged to the monarchy. You will see buildings of old architecture . Great to take pictures and soak in history.
Earth Quake of 2015 and 2016. Once upon a time, this was one of the best sight seen in Kathmandu Nepal but two eart quake made this historical place in very damaged condition.

Main attrcation of the city. This is one of the main attraction of the city and a must see for every visitor but it is really sad to see amount of the damage caused by earth quake. Local people complaint restoration pace is very slow.

So many interesting sights. Despite severe damage in the earthquake, rebuilding work is coming along slowly. Many of the temples were destroyed but despite this, the remaining temples and buildings are beautiful and so full of history that it is still a must see sight in Nepal.
Interesting if damaged. Worth a visit for the history and culture components. But more than this, it's worth taking a look to understand the extent of the damage from the earthquake.
nice area to see with many temples. Viewed many temples damaged due to April 2015 earthquake. Fee of $10 required . Nice area and amazing temples

Must visit. This is my second time here and in was surprised to see everything destroyed. I was here 2 years before and it was so beautiful full of local people. Everyone should visit here and help this place make better.

A piece of history. If you are in KTM, you have to visit this area. A real piece of history which unfortunately was hit hard by the earthquake. There are guides who charge a high price to take you around, but I found it was just as good doing on our own.

Historical Walk. This is a historical walk to see many temples, palaces and buildings. Definitely, a tour guide will be most helpful to explain each building's historical background. The after effects of last year's earthquake is still visible. Very interesting and a must do.There are many street peddlers persistently trying to sell their goods and we have to consistently say no thank you!

Great historical location. Some major damages.. Has great history of the Nepalese royalty and religious significance. Had extensive damages from the earthquake. The restorations will take time. Some temples are wiped off.
antique Town but living. It is an old town but full of lives. We saw the real wedding and children wedding. We chatted with local people. We don't go through the history but also experience it.
Amazing history. Great spot to see lots of varieties of temples. Different worship practrices and an array of gods and goddesses. Really interesting.

Kathmandu Durbar Square - Post-Earthquake - A MUST DO. I was in the Kathmandu earthquake on April 25, 2015 - also here for the second major quake on May 12, 2015. I had spent 2 months here pre-earthquake. I just returned to KTM in January, 2016. I now live here.Inaccurate, and disturbing, hyper-drama news reporting said Kathmandu was leveled. It was not. Kathmandu Durbar Square was not leveled. Yes, there was major damage at this site, many people died. I watched locals live, cooking, sleeping - in the open spaces at this site - but I am positively delighted at what did NOT fall down and can be still deeply experienced.I STRONGLY suggest that you do NOT hire a guide through this area (they will high-pressure you) and that you move slow - take your time - engage your own brain, eyes, feelings - let your camera record. Guides talk non-stop - you want the FEEL of this ancientness - not get slaughtered by their FACTS. With someone's mouth constantly in motion - you will surely miss it. For the history - read the guidebook before or after your visit.There is a hefty entrance fee of 1000 rupees ($10) but it is good for the length of your visa. If you have time to visit more than once - at different times of day you will see different things going on. This square is packed with locals - an earthquake did not make it stop being their treasure trove. They just started to shovel and sweep and clean it up.There are many places to sit - hang out - watch how everyone else does it. Engage a local street seller in conversation - ask them where they were at earthquake time - these quiet, native people love to interact with foreigners. Ask them to order a sweet, yummy tea for you (20 rupees) - offer to buy them one - then watch how it arrives and where it comes from. They have beautiful things to sell you but if they know you just want to talk with them they are most obliging and will be as curious about you as you are about them.Check out the magnificent Telaju Temple - observe locals doing ritual worship in the several small temples around this large square. You can still walk through the ground-level area of the palace which will give you a good idea of what ancient palace life.was like.Wander the open air market of Basantapur. The historical, hippie culture, Freak Street is adjacent to it with its tatoo parlors, hookah pipe shops, coffee houses, cafes. Have a Lavazza coffee. Or an excellent Americano at Himalayan Java. Have lunch in one of the many rooftop cafes that dot the square. Wander off down side streets, you will not be disappointed.Everything here is alive and well. If you try to complete this site in 1 or 2 hours you will be the loser. Guaranteed.HIGHLY RECOMMENDED.

Interesting. I visited Kathmandu Durbar Square in October 2015, six months after the devastating earthquake in April, but there was still a lot of rubble lying around the place, and some of the old palace buildings looked as if they were just about to crash. It was a sad picture. Still I enjoyed the remaining great architecture, sculptures and wall art - the place hasn't lost the spirit of its former splendour, it just needs rebuilding, like the other Durbar Squares.

A little lackluster and a bad guide . Seems like it suffered a lot of damage from the earthquake. Lots of rubble. Our visit was all but ruined by a terrible guide that started following us around. We were new to Nepal and didn't know about the pushy guides. He told us the same stories at least three times and took us to pushy salesmen, including his "parents." Then he demanded a big tip and got aggressive and nasty when we didn't want to give it to him. Maybe other people had a better experience but we left with such a bad taste in our mouths and wouldn't recommend Durbar Square to anyone else.
wonderful. we visit this stupa and it was very nice. but i feel the entrance fee is little high but other is fine there

Great place to walk around. This is a must-do when in Nepal- the architecture is amazing, even though some places had been affected by the earthquake, there was still a lot to see and walking around, you got a true feel of the history of this place.

Durbar Square. A very interesting visit with a great deal of history. If you buy one thing from the peddlers at the square they will not leave you alone, so but somewhere else. Otherwise a great place to visit.

Earthquake damaged. . Glad I visited, but it doesn't seem like they will ever fully recover from the earthquake. The town is so old it's going to take a monumental effort to rebuild and maintain the old charm.

interesting but still suffering from earthquake. So much potential but needs much work. Hopefully the government will spend some money to clean up the fallen ruins and clean up the area so tourist will return. The lumber holding up the walls need to be removed and the walls reinforced by appropriate engineering.

Interesting and overwhelming. Kathmandu offers great history but can be overwhelming especially if you travel with children. Cars everywhere, honking horns, cows in the middle of it, a lot of people around, noise, pollution..but the sites make it all worth it. Durbar square is a place where history meets and the Nepalese culture is evident.

one of the 3 squares. We loved our time here. it's really interesting yet also so sad to see the destruction caused by last years earthquake. Don't let this deter you from going! Nepal needs tourists!

History in front of your Eyes. This is the place where you can see the history made by the people. You can also get the feel of vast infrastructure, however this is now damaged by the earthquake so all structures are supported.
Amazing place. Very nice environment loaded with history and peace. The core of the city and the culture of the country.
Interesting but .... You have to pay to get in. Not a lot - 1000 NPR but there is a lot of hassle from guides and traders. I found it a bit overwhelming.
A great morning. We enjoyed Bahktupur more than anything in Kathmandu. Magical to walk around the old part of the city.

so interesting. very very interesting......just walk about and ignore the people selling things.......just sit and soak it all up......so interesting
shame that some damage but still worth visiting
Good calm place. I like this place in the middle of Thamel. The biggest problem is the guides always trying to follow you around, ruining the experience for you. The temples are really beautiful.

So so . I didn't pay the entrance fee that's suppose to give you access to some part of the building. Walking around the buildings, nothing much special. But I did found a Thangkal shop nearby there that recommend me an art school in Thamel. 18000 rupee for a month course. Was glad I found it as it's hard to find a reasonable priced one in Thamel. Most of the affordable ones are in Bahktupur.

Lots History. This courtyard has seen lots of historical movement and witness change in country.Every temple has its own story behind it .Its all well preserved but after Earthquake most of temple is ruined.

Changed a lot since the earthquake but still worth seeing. I visited here back in 2004, so was able to compare it now after the earthquake to how it was before. It has been significantly damaged - some pagodas were reduced entirely to rubble - but I still really enjoyed hearing about the history and meaning of the buildings and representations of deities. One of the highlights for us was seeing the Kumari girl, who represents a goddess in human form (need to pay a little extra for her to come to the window, and you can't photograph her). The touts were quite bad here, following us around, so I think it would probably be better early/late in the day. Relatively expensive (for Nepal) at NRS1000 for foreigners (but in my opinion, worth it).
Very nice. Very interesting place , see the Nepalese around and enjoy views. some come to do different point. I will come back to see them again
architecture history. After earthquake seen lots damage but still its very intresting to visit this place i had visit with my fns ,worth visit

Shameful. Went to see the square on our first day, we were stopped and told to pay 1000 rupees.We refused to pay as all the locals including beggars were walking in for free and the next day we went in with an organised tour.It was worth visiting but the entrance fee it is ridiculous.Lots of building are destroyed, lots of them are hold up with pieces of wood.Mind you it is impressive evem in the poor conditions it is now, sadly every day you want to go back you have to pay.Glad i went but won't go back!

All Nepali Architecture. This is probably the most damaged in the earthquake. Even them it is an amazing feeling to visit this place. However, i would rank the three durbars as follows in order of priority of you are short of timePatan > Bhaktapur > Kathmandu durbarHowever, each is splendid in its own way !

Fantastic, even after being earthquake damage. You have to pay 1,000 [$10] to get inside, but that feels a small price to pay to help sustain and repair this wonderful collection of buildings. The "tour guides" will come up to offer their services, but - unlike in India - will take a polite "no thanks" almost all the time.And then bask in the wonders of the buildings and feel sad at the damage wrought by last year's quakes.

Significant damage from the earthquake. Had lunch at a rooftop restaurant overlooking Durbar Square, which is a great way to get an overview of the square. We then wondered around the square, which was really interesting due to the very visible damage caused by the earthquake. How they will repair these historical buildings will be a major challenge.

Worth visiting site. In spite of the damage caused by the Earthquake of Apr 2015, this site is worth visiting. The fascinating temples with beautiful wood carving and the old palace definitively deserve the titel of World Heritage Site. The damaged parts had been cleaned and the tourist visit was safe.

Clearly suffered damage during the earthquake. Shopping area that had some good buys and that was clearly damaged during the earthquake. Interesting to see structures with support beams outside of them to stabilize the structure. Walking around the area was interesting and people were friendly. Not nearly as crowded as India. However, some of the vendors were just as pushy.
Spend hours looking around the different temples.. Wonderful area in Kathmandu. All the temples have so many different designs and artwork. Great for photography.

Crowded but amazing. . It is hard to rate Durbar square in Kathmandu as there is really nothing quite like it on Earth. Patan and Bhaktapur have Durbar squares as well but each is unique and distinctive. The history, art and living culture of these places could absorb a lifetime. Make sure you buy a visitor pass at the entry. It doesnt cost much and the money helps with the upkeep of the site.

Impressive view. Even after the heartquakes, Durbar Square is very impressive. There are several monument scrapped and collapsed but you can visit them all. For people who saw the location before the heartquakes, it is a shock.People around is so nice and there are several guides offering the opportunity to show and explain the details. In case you have to stay more than two days, take with you a printed picture (like the passport one) in order to have a special pass paing the turist entry ticket just once.Nepal is ready now to welcome turists!

Visited this place before the earthquake . The grandeur lights up in the evening. Many stalls selling snacks. An entrance ticket is a must for tourists. The views are breathtaking. A great place to sit around and have a cup of tea.
Best time in nepal . This is best place in nepal. I was there but all bulding is damage from earthquake. It is very good place for looking
just arrive from ktm. big activities around durbar square severely damage by the earthquake of last year many nepaleese people work step by step bricks after bricks to rebuild the huge durbar

Overpriced. Most of temples are destroyed (70-80%), so I don't understand why do they still charge 1000 NPR for the entrance! Everyone wants to be your guide, it is always noisy and crowdy there. Face mask is a must.

Westerners get hassled!. We visited Durbar Square recently as we had heard so much about it! We already knew there was a 1000 rupee charge for westerners but didn't mind as we were lead to believe that the money goes towards maintaining and conserving the square... After talking to locals it appeared that perhaps not much, if at all, any went toward this... Only tourists paid the charge even though home nation visitors were requested to pay 150 rupees! Whilst walking around it was devastating to see the damage the earthquake caused. The temples were incredible and well worth the sight however the whole time you were in the square you were either hassled by tour guides, beggars or market holders.. It wasn't possible to stand and read the plaques next to the temples for more than a few seconds without being grabbed by children or beggars! Post earthquake I can imagine these temples were even more amazing, hopefully in the future they can be repaired and conserved for future visitors. Walking around the backstreets of Kathmandu and finding hidden temples was far less hassle and still as interesting! If you can spare the charge and ignore bustle it's certainly worth a visit!

A great historic site. Despite the earthquake damage, the Durbar Square is a most view when in Kathmandu. Beautiful temples, palaces, and museums proves that Kathmandu Valley had a a great civilization.
Nice but crowded!. This is an interesting place however, it is very crowded as is most of Kathmandu. I still recommend visiting it by all means.

beautiful architecture. Durbar is worth visiting, so many temples and places to see along with good restaurants. Unfortunately there was some earthquake damage, but thankfully there is still a lot left to see.

nice...overwhelmed by guards. Nice... Could be very special but it's a unproporsionate 1000rupee to even walk through. Unfortunately the guards?? Are constantly checking that you have a ticket and telling you that you must pay you must pay even though you have a ticket...I think this and the cost is driving away tourist... it seems only westerners are targetted.
overwhelming. it is terrible what the erthquake did to this site, but it is still amazing. Hopefully reconstruction will start now

Remarkable . Very sad to see all of the earthquake damage but this is still a must see stop on any visit to Nepal. We were impressed by how many structures are still standing. Hope they can rebuild soon.

Damaged but still worth seeing! . Lots of the temples are damaged in some way, however there is enough upstanding to make the 1000 rupee entry fee worth it. Would recommend hiring a guide to bring the square to life. Be sure to visit the temple housing the living goddess of Nepal!

Amazing workmanship in the historic homes and temples. Walking around seeing the historic history of the magical place is like stepping back in time. So much to see from local crafts to the colour that fills the streets watching the locals go about their day . Take time to walk around if you can, you can spend from half a day to a full day just wondering around taking in all that there is to see. You do have to pay to get in , but once in you will have an amazing day , I seen tourist family's wandering around taking in the sites, I thought this was a very educational and more importantly a good eye opening experience for children and teenagers , this historical place not that long ago experienced a tragedy, loosening many life's and historic temples and homes.A Earthquake destroyed many buildings , you can see a picture of the original building that is placed next to the site.I felt a sense of loss, as the rubble is surround the area .The locals are rebuilding, and stabilising the buildings , so they can still live in their homes
Durbar square visit. Great place in Katmandu, though a lot damaged by recent earthquake...A must visit while travelling to Katmandu.
Durbar square in Kathmandu. I was there in December 2015. It is damaged by April earthquake, but even half distorted it is fascinating and spectacular.

Wonderful architecture. First, be very careful eating at one of the restaurants. I live by the matra if it's not boiling and you can't peel it don't eat it, especially when visiting a third world country. Almost everyone who ate at a restaurant in the sqaure got sick and missed the private flight along Everest. The architecture leans towards asian and away from boardering India and beautifully intricate. Beware as hawkers, people spunging for money by selling cheap merchandise, although this is part of the experience. The hawkers can get aggressive so make sure you keep close watch on your wallet and purse. Shopping around the square is plentiful and reasonably priced. I heard the recent earthquake destroyed many buildings which is incredibly tragic.

The best tourist spot in Kathmandu! Do not miss!!. Hands-down, the Patan (Lalitpur) Durbar Square was our favourite sight-seeing spot in Kathmandu! We visited it at around 11 am in late December and were amazed to see the beautiful architecture (a mix of Indian and east Asian influences), the locals soaking up the sun and the tourists gawking at everything! :) Facts: SAARC citizens have to pay 100 NPR as entrance fees and non-SAARC citizens a little more. This was the norm in most tourist spots that we visited in Nepal. The earthquake damage is not quite as bad in the Bhakatapur Durbar Square (as per our guide). Wooden supports have been placed under the ancient structures and one old temple's top has completely collapsed and is being re-constructed now. Other than this, everything was intact. TIP: Do wander around and visit the temple (if you are a Hindu). Do visit the restaurant in the museum bldg; it has a lovely ambience, a good view, delicious food and a clean toilet. DO visit the painting/art shops near the end of the Durbar Square; look for the painting shop no. 2/3 on the left-hand side. Negotiate and DO BUY from there. We saw artists pain-painstakingly working on the minute details in the shop. They need your support. And really, the prices are a real bargain!

Poor preservation of Historical sites. The corruption of Nepal is at the peak of it's level. There are no clear boundaries of who will pay to get in. It is a public place where cars and motorbikes pass, but the white people get's stopped and asked to pay but for most asians they don't even bother. Such discrimination towards western foreigners and sometimes to the asians.
Stunning. This is such a lovely place. Beautiful architecture. So much to see and do. Loved the atmosphere here.

Glad not all is destryed. A lot of history here and it broke my heart to see some of it just gone.Nevertheless the place is packed with tourists and locals alike and you must give yourself 2-3 hours to explore this place.I would strongly recommend a guided tour for it would be impossible to absorb all that information from a written document.It's easier to listen and ask questions.

You will need to use your Imagination. Unfortunately most of the buildings here have major earthquake damage. There are loose bricks everywhere and wooden sticks holding up buildings. It will take awhile for this square to restore its former glory. Entrance is 1000 rupees.We had a guide. Plan to spend an hour to an hour and a half here.

Touring with a real Living Goddess from the Kumari Lineage. I realize in writing this review that many words fail me. Kathmandu cannot be described accurately. Paris, you can describe it. It's archetypal. London, it makes sense. But Kathmandu, I think someone once said, is an absurd city. Not only did I come to Kathmandu with no reference points, making it utterly alien to me.  I also had the special honor of seeing Durbar Square as the guest of one of the former Kumari girls who are chosen from special families to be living goddesses in Kathmandu and two other cities. She is now 25 and was a Kumari for a few years. Please read up on these special youth. Ganga B. now works as the assistant manager of the World Heritage Apartments and Hotel, which is connected by a small passageway to the Durbar Square, right behind what used to be the Krishna Temple, which was completely destroyed after the 2015 earthquake. She suggested we have dinner at a small restaurant on the square. We set out at night, after all the vendors had gone home (except one), and all the pigeons had gone to sleep. The place looked slightly abandoned. The cool mist of late December was falling into the city. The electricity had been cut. We walked by a painting vendor who was closing shop, you could make out the paintings inside from the glow of a single light bulb powered by a car battery. Ganga suggested that we go in, just to look. After sitting down with the vendor, he explained to me the karmic cycle of Buddhist life, and we selected a tonka together, which I bought, and will hang in my office. We negotiated. I got a fair price, and came away with a rolled up tonka describing the three causes of pain and suffering, and the god that looks over us all and decides if we go to heaven or hell. Hint: the secret is in balancing spirituality with desire. Walking around the square at night, Ganga brushing against me and talking about her love for the mysterious darkness overtaking the city, really empties the mind of distractions. We walked all around the square and then snaked our way outside of the square down dozens of alleys with absolutely no lighting. It turned out that this was the eve of the Garung caste's new year (garung is a type of caste that lives in Nepal, and they celebrate New Year's Eve on January 30), fires dotting the grounds, and people wearing glow in the dark devil's horns on their heads. All of this gave the city a mysterious quiet. I looked at the shells of the buildings and former temples. They seemed animated, like the haunted houses in a Disney film, looming over our heads in the super close alleys and streets. It was like walking through a labyrinth. The earthquake has made the inside and the outside of the square look abandoned and torn down. Many roofs are hanging lopsided off the sides of the buildings. Large beams are pushing up the falling walls. It's a combination of war zone and peaceful, community square. And that night, as temperatures got lower, and people left the streets to sleep or to sit inside and make fires, I thought that maybe the royal family is gone, but they have left behind a kind of temple to the reality of the present moment. A city swirling with chaos that in a moment can become quite, still and filled with possibility.

Damaged from Earthquake, great at night. Durbar Square is definitely one of the top attractions in Kathmandu, but has seen serious damage since the earthquake. You have to buy a ticket to get in, and there are locals who will offer to guide you around if that is your speed.My recommendation is to walk through Durbar Square at night, preferably after 7 or 8 pm. It's safe and lit, but transforms into a pedestrian-ish area. It is pretty low key with folks hanging out and chatting. There are some vendors selling clothes and snacks, and the structures are magical in the twilight/darkness.

A visit is as worthwhile as before although for different reasons. Durbar square is the old royal part of the city. It lost a number of its main temples in the 2015 earthquake. The central area - where the large stepped foundations of the temples would be filled with people - now, with no temples on the foundations, have just a few stragglers, who are periodically chased away by policemen. The square is just as noisy but without the old purposeless purpose.There seems to have been no restoration work done but I was informed by one of the locals that there are Chinese engineers designing support for building that were damaged but not destroyed. One interesting - although cynical - development is that there are now signs with photos and descriptions at some of the temples that were destroyed, whereas before there were temples but no signs.There is also access that wasn't available in the past. You can, for example, stand on the foundation of the Kasthamandap Temple to view and photograph, from an angle previously impossible, the small and dilapidated-looking Ashok Binayak Temple. You can climb to the top of the Trailokya Mohan Narayan Temple to view and photograph a magnificent stone Shiva-Parvati sculpture which likely was previously buried in the innards of the temple. In Nasal Chowk, enclosed within the palace, have been accumulated struts and other wooden objects with intricate carvings that are easily viewable, whereas before they would have been high on the temple. It's not a silver lining but makes a visit as worthwhile as before although for different reasons. Entry fee is about $10 but, if you're staying in town for while and expect to visit Durbar Square multiple times, you can get a pass for the duration of your stay - be sure to have a passport style photograph for them.

Good. But didn't surprise me much.. It was good but did not surprise me much. The entry fee was very expensive and not worth it. There are shops there too.
Visited and felt a little tired.

NEED TO VISIST TO HELP. After the earthquake in April, the authorities have worked very hard to save as much of the historic buildings as possible. Huge lengths of timber are propped up against the walls of numerous buildings in a bid to offer some support. Even though some temples and buildings have been removed, the remaining ones still give the visitor a feel for the history of these beautiful buildings. My daughter who was having her first trip to Nepal was so impressed with the buildings and the various designs. She had no reference point to compare to so I kept quite about how good they used to look and let her find things for herself. So, if a 19 year old can look at Durbar Square and still see the beauty in the history of the place, then every one should still go, pay the 1000R and enjoy the place. The money you pay could help restore one of the buildings to its former glory or just allow work to be done to prevent it from falling altogether.
Great. An absolute worthwhile visit here to Durbar Square. Lots to see and view from amazing structures that have stood the test of time after the earthquake and some that haven't. :(
Unique. Went in July 2014, Wonderful place with very old monuments. Good to spend 1/2 hours walking around. A good insight into how far back nepalese traditions date back

Historical Durbar square Kathmandu Nepal. The square with surrounded temples and houses are 400 - 600 years old. Located in front of Kathmandu’s royal palace, this spectacular square reflects the artistry that prevailed in the past. We came here on the rainny day, but we weren't disappointed. We knew why this is in UNESCO world heritage tentative list. Some temples are not only religious mosque but the garden and serenity places as well.

Interesting to see but not essential. It is worth seeing this location to get a real feel for how much damage the earthquake caused. However, the square itself doesn't have a lot to offer. You get a lot better feel for the culture and the people by wandering in the small streets and lanes around the square. It is one of those tourist "must dos" for many, but if you are short on time, you won't miss much if you skip it.

May it return to pre-quake glory. I was fortunate to visit Durbar Square the week before the earthquake. The history, the spirituality, and the importance of this part of Kathmandu will continue despite the quake. If you have the chance to visit, visit.
Beautiful!. You must have some time to walk around Kathmandu center and see the beautiful squares around. The architecture is something amazing!

Worth a visit but slightly underwhelming. The square and surrounding area hold a lot of history and cultural significance, but there were a lot of people just hanging about, like hanging all over the monuments and shrines. It was kind of awkward to step back and enjoy it.

tiny details that matter. Hmm.. First of all, my heartfelt sympathy to all the victims of the earth quake. I've heard that this place has been pretty much levelled after the quake. I found this to be a trip back in time. The houses, the pretty frescos, the tiny little carvings on every building, the entire ancient layout, the friezes that suddenly appear on every corner and take your breath away.. it was all worth the day that I spent there. The carvings that decorated the temples were finely carved. The bazaar street was lined with people teeming and there were all sorts of things that you won't expect, like excellent restaurants inside the tunnel of carved wood, a little garden in an isolated place and a small class where they taught how to make those lovely intricate buddhist paintings. I hope they can remake it... in all of its glory!!

Visit Nepal. Visit this beautiful, chaotic city and spend a couple of hours exploring Durbar Square. Be sure to take your camera and photograph the few amazing buildings that still stand after the earthquakes. Bring some cash to buy from the artisans along the street.

Sad, that its lost so much since the Earthquake. The people and movement is fascinating. But so many of the temples and palaces were badly damaged, that when I was here in Oct 2015, it was just not that amazing. I found Thamel much more picturesque. But it is great to see and walk around.
My visit in October 2015. A must when visiting Kathmandu, some damage due to earthquake but lots of photo opportunities and Nepal is working hard to restore all its monuments.
a must see. The architecture is amazing! The wooden structures have intricate details. You can see the devastation from the earthquake. I hope Nepal is able to rebuild to its original glory.

Surprisingly empty and in need of some loving care and attention. This was my first visit back to Nepal since the Earthquake and a good proportion of this fantastic area has been affected very badly. The efforts to preserve the materials and the sense of the area have been heroic and no doubt over the years the area will regain its former glories - meanwhile the 1000NPR entrance fee for the area is a great idea to help raise the necessary funds for such a mammoth rebuilding task.Within the area there are still great and historic buildings to be seen and enjoyed and as there are fewer visitors at the moment now is a good time to soak up the atmosphere and spent some time looking closely at the history and architecture of this special area.

Lot in small. Durbar square offers you lot in a small area. You might get a big idea of the history, culture and religion of Nepal by having a one hour walk in this square. There are many restaurants and some good one are around the place. Many have roof tops and you may have a nice look around from there. But after seen the earthquake not sure how much of this place has left to see. It is a tragic.

Must Visit. The 1st time i saw a beautiful breath taking 'Durbar' means place but t 2nd trip was heart breaking as most of the building wete pull down to earth by t earth quake. If you have missed to visit this place i am so sorry for you as the original palace is gone..its a holy city by itself..where ever you walk there will be a small lingas n temples just openly like that. Its a Unesco world heritage site in 1979. Its so so beautiful done centuries ago with full faith on GOD.

A lot of damage but still worth it. Kathmandus main Durbar square has had the most damage out of the tree Durbar squares but it is still worth visiting. The rubble has been cleared already and on many of the buildings repair work is already underway though it will take years. Amazingly the museum which has been the worst damaged is partially open to walk through the courtyards - where it is possible to see the amazing carvings and watch the restoration work taking place. It's nowhere near what it was but worth a visit anyway and while you have to pay 1000 rupees the money is going to the reconstruction.

The "greatest" place in Kathmandu! :). Very vibrant with tourists and locals alike (just beware of these quite "persistent" sellers & guides especially if you're a single person!), this fairly big area adjacent to Thamel (just about a ten-minute walk south from the small Chetrapati roundabout which is pretty much at the heart of Thamel) is one place that I would say no tourist should leave Kathmandu without going to!! :) On the west side of the square and stretching from north to south are temples with beautiful red cloth trims hanging down around the roofs and the steps by which you could go up (but cannot actually go inside the temples once you got above); be sure to look up the temple with two big sculptures of lions in front and you'll see two statue figures looking out from a window!On the south side are the three-story residence of Hindu Goddess Kumari (with an inner courtyard) and Kasthamandap (with about four levels and it was like the ONLY temple on the square that people can go inside on the first level, but sadly I heard that temple was destroyed in the earthquake). On the east side of the square (you have to go around to the back area by turning left from the front area if you enter from the north coming down from Thamel) is Hanuman Dhoka Palace with its nine-story Basantapur Tower with great views from above (toward the west, you can see the Swayambhunath hill with the Stupa above); and on the ground around the palace courtyard are displays of some royal things including a carriage and a pretty decorated big chair (which I guess was sat on by the king) behind the glass on one side and portraits of the kings of Nepal (in the chronological order) on another side (the side just to the left of the courtyard entrance). Also be sure to check out the back courtyard where there are intricate-designed columns on the ground supporting the structures above with slanted windows (they're on the front side of the palace too, and you look out through the holes on their covers when you go up the Basantapur Tower) which is probably a "unique" Nepalese style since I haven't seen that type of window anywhere else that I've travelled.The only "loss" for me at the Square when I visited was that the big Degu Taleju Temple at the back area right beside Hanuman Dhoka had its gates closed for some reason, so I could only view it from outside.And I'm personally glad to hear that the Basantapur Tower here survived the earthquake although it's sad to hear Dharahara (Bhimsen Tower) about a 20-minute walk south from here (go out the south side, walk straight for about 15 minutes, then turn left and about a 5-minute walk) came down, but I hope they'll keep what's left of the tower the way it is.

Recovering. The devastating Gurkha earthquake damaged this extraordinary historic place. However, kind heart people have put their efforts to recover this place. Hope it will be back to the same state as before in few years.

Takes some imagination. With the effects and destruction of the earthquake many of the temple's and age old buildings are in ruins. Efforts are under way to rebuild, but it will take many years to restore this once beautiful square in the heart of Kathmandu. One must stretch your imagination in order to see what once was there. The 1,000 rupee charge for entry seems extreme for viewing a post earthquake damaged area. I would feel better if I knew those funds were 100% going to rebuilding. The magic is gone for now.
Visit to World Heritage Site - Durbar Square. This was a super visit to a World Heritage Site - Kathmandu Durbar Square which is largest of all Durbar Squares as compared with Bhaktapur and Patan.
Still recovering. Since the earthquake, not what it used to be. Construction still going on; they have a long way to go.

some still standing!. Despite the tragic earthquakes earlier this year it is amazing how many of the 'cultural sites' are still standing albeit a little 'propped up' .. Within the area are more visual signs of the devastation with 'temporary accommodation still under tarps'. Please visit- these people need tourism

Must see for historical perspective of Kathmandu. We went on a private day tour with Kishore through Ace the Himalaya and had such an interesting time. We learned so much about the historical context of this place and Kishore showed us in detail the effects of the earthquake. I really found the Kumari's residence so interesting and the whole story about Kumari- the living goddess. We weren't lucky enough to see her in the window, but we did see her caregiver. I would definitely suggest going with Ace the Himalaya for a private tour because you learn much more than you ever could on your own.

Still beautiful after the earthquake. Durbar square is the main city square in Kathmandu. It used to have multiple temples there but unfortunately the earthquake destroyed quite a few of them. However this does not mean that it is not worth visiting. You can still see and understand the beauty of the square and what it would have looked like before the earthquake. If you take a guide you can still learn about the history and the buildings. We were there on a Saturday (Nepal's one weekend day) and it was bustling with locals and markets. You do need to pay a fee to get in (about US$10) and the entrance has changed due to earthquake damage.

Under re-construction. Quite a few buildings to see, as well as the Royal Palace -- note the entry fee for the whole area, pay at the kiosk. Many buildings heavily damaged in the 2015 earthquake, but still much left to see, including the carved, 16th-century erotica in the framing of some temples....

Ancient Palace Within the Heart of the City.. surrounded by ancient Statues and Palace, durbar Square is very close the the famous Freak Street and Basantapur is very chilled place to hangout in the evening with friends or family.

Great place. Just watch out for scamming -people giving you directions, then asking for food instead of money, then asking you to pay 8000 rupees! & women who plead you to give then money, when its not their child. Otherwise everyone else is friendly and loving

A centre point. My visit to this place was prior to the earthquake, indeed I hope things will be normal again,The sheer simplicity and colonial architecture side by side with Nepali buildings was indeed a sight to see, numerous antiques used to sold roadside by vendors, and wonderful paintings too.

EARTHQUAKE LEVELED A LOT BUT STILL WORTH A VISIT. There was a lot of carnage human and man made after the earthquake to this area of Kathmandu. We were still able to see the Living Virgin Goddess and the Kamasutra temple along with some other cuturally valuable landmarks. I HIGHLY RECOMMEND HIRING A LICENSED GUIDE. We opted out at first but changed our minds and I was so glad that we did. He took pictures for us and was very knowledgeable and I think we probably would not have seen the Goddess without him.
