Hidden treasure. We were lucky enough to visit Durbar Square the week before the earthquake, have been in Nepal previously and the Square is always a hub of exciting things to see
A must in Kathmandu!. Durba Square is a very historical place in Kathmandu and therefore a must for all visitors! Currently many Stupa are bearing traces of the last earthquake!
beautiful. i went in dec 2014 before the natural disasters hit nepal... very sad and hope for recovery. lots of history and beauty
Its all gone. There is no reason in the world to pay the entrance fee into Dunbar Square to see nothing except rubble. Don't bother is no worth the trouble or the money.

Amazing temples, many destroyed... overpriced though!. A lot has been destroyed from the Earthquakes, but it is still such an amazingly beautiful historic and important place for Kathmandu communities. I was disappointed that they hadn't reduced the entrance fee since you can't see half of the stuff and also there aren't any promises that your entry fee goes to the repair of the temples.Also, they don't have discounts for volunteers - which I think they should introduce. It is quite expensive. Patan Durbar Square is currently free and well worth a visit!

Heritage , destructed. The City Center in Kathmandu supposed to be a History Teller to the visitors standing hugely damaged due to this year beginning Earthquake. Believed this second time it faced such destructive blow due to natural calamity. Each monument worth to spend time and understand the importance of it. The temples around this square are mostly damaged. The earthen type construction by age not able to stand against the tremors.The renovation to its original shape may take a long time to come. Wish Nepal able to recover it as soon as possible.Every tourist must visit this place and understand the history behind it, which is interesting.

Beautiful architecture and history. . I visited in November of 2015, about 6 months after the tragic earthquake. Very much of the Dunbar Square is still destroyed and under construction. I happily payed the entrance fee of 1000 Rs since I knew it would go to reconstruction of the buildings. As soon as you enter, you're most likely to be approached by a person who offers to be your guide. I can't speak for every one of hear guides, but the one I had was very much competent of guiding me. Some might not be, since they're not employed by someone, I don't know. I enjoyed my visit. It needs the tourists and our money after the destruction.

Down but Not Out. .Background: As part of a two-week escorted tour of India and Nepal, our guide took our group to visit Kathmandu's famous Durbar Square, a UNESCO World Heritage Site that is sprawled over 5 acres. More accurately the Hanuman-Dhoka Durbar Square, the royal palace sits amidst several temples, idols, open courts and the like. The term "Durbar Square" is a generic name used to refer to plazas or open areas opposite the old Nepali royal palaces. Kathmandu's royal palace gets its name from the stone idol of "Hanuman", the Hindu monkey god, that sits near the main entryway. ('Dhoka' means door in Nepali.)PROS: Proximity to the city centre is a big asset. It seems like the entire city was built around the site. It took the better of a 30-min walk from our Fuji Hotel, unless you get lost along the way. But everyone knows where it is. The ticket booth provides a handy guide map.CONS: Double-standard entry fees aside, as a fundraising bid for the restoration of the damaged structures, the entry fees have been increased from NRs750 then up to NRs 1,000 now. (SAARC fees remain the same.) You will still need a map and/or a guide. Photography is still not allowed inside the Tribhuvan Museum, for which temporary lockers are set up at the entrance. WCs (toilets) are few and hard to find inside, but there's a couple between Dhak Chowk and Lam Chowk (accessed through Nasal Chowk) (Note: Bring toilet paper, just in case.)UPDATE: As of this writing, the April 2015 earthquake (and subsequent aftershocks) dealt considerable damage to many structures in Durbar Square. Among those that sustained damage were the Maju Dega, Kamdev Temple, Trailokya Mohan Narayan Temple, the upper floors of the Basantapur Durbar, etc. Surviving structures have been propped up by wooden poles. Further away, the white Dharahara (or Bhinsen) Tower was reduced to its base. However, by July 2015, the UNESCO decided not to put Durbar Square in its Danger List of Monuments. Hence, tourism still resumes albeit at about half the number of visitors.Verdict: Worth a visit. Even as the rubble have been carted away and the dust has settled, a trip to Kathmandu -- even for a passing trekker -- would not be complete without seeing this iconic Nepali landmark. Grade A-minus..
Very sad that it is destroyed now :(. Unfortunately one of the last historical place of Kathmandu. Give few rupees to the sadhus to have your good Nepal photo. Go and visit but don t expect too much.

Beautiful . Beautiful history!
Only to bad you see a lot of disaster from the earthquake.
Enormously many guides and ask a lot of money; never pay over 3000 NPR!
Much of Durbar Square DID survive the two earthquakes.. Nepal is country number 51 for me, and it took my breath away. Best rip I have had in a long, long time!

Post earthquake. It was with trepidation that i walked towards durbar square full well knowing what had happened since i last walked there 2 years ago. It is my most favourite thing to do in kathmandu ...an early morning walk through the indiana jones style streets of thamel to durbar square where the locals have markets streetside before the shops open their doors.yes the earthquake was devastating for the world heritage listed pagodas and palace but strangely i was happy because it wasnt totally destroyed and one could still be amazed at the sight. They are now very strict at charging tourists 1000Rps to wander around but i am sure they need the money to restore it. Dont miss seeing it if you are in town!

Much damage from the quake. Tons of people want to be your guide. They're actually worthwhile, but find one that is knowledgeable and speaks clearly and loudly enough.We tried a couple. Eventually, one went and got his brother when we explained we wanted clearer English. He was pretty good. Showed and explained many things we would never have noticed on our own. Afterward took us to a Thanks shop for private viewing of some high quality pictures.Also, get your ticket extended. Its free and you may want to come back.Many buildings are damaged or destroyed. All surviving building are propped up with sodden poles.

Love this Heritage Site. Best of all in Kathmandu. I have been here 4x time its like i was going there every day just to have the perfect shot around this place.. Almost everything got destroyed coz of the last Earthquake. I feel very sad for that but still there got lot more things to see. Should be there if you're flying to Nepal. Enjoy. :)

Amazing culture. Some buildings obviously have earthquake damage, however there is still a lot left around to see.Need about an hour or so for a goodLook. Definitely have a guide to explain the history otherwise it's some nice buildings around a square.The market has some bargains if you can wheel and deal.A must see in Kathmandu!

An important cultural experience. Although the April earthquake caused much damage in the Square, it is still important place to see. There are very many local people both viewing the site and enjoying the shopping and the many merchants in the Square. It was very interesting indeed.

Beautiful and Stunning. . Magnificent area but partially destroyed due to the quake. Restoration works are on. You get to see the marvellous architecture . just stroll along the square and soak in the history. must visit if u cone to katmandu

Cultural checkpoint. Though part of the buildings collapsed due to previous earthquake, most of the square survived. Structure of the architecture are under protection, and it is safe to travel there.

Traditional Heart of the Old Town. Tourists are charged 1000 rupees each to look around which seems a bit of a rip off as it is basically a building site following the April 2015 earthquake. However, I hope that the money is put towards restoration. The Nepali Government have allegedly been given 4 billion dollars in Foreign Aid but havent spent any yet. Despite the damage it is still well worth a visit.

Some old architecture remains, can see post earthquake damages.. There are a few durbar squares in and around ktm- Patan, Bhaktapur and Basantapur are those I know. I visited Basantapur. I have been there before and the damage post earthquake is significant. A lot of temples (?) have been destroyed and Only a few of the old architecture remain standing. A lot of the old buildings have wooden stilts or some sort to support the leaning structures. I did not have a guided tour so I did not learn much about the area. Surrounding the area are shops aplenty. Walking through the little alleys, you tend to worry that if an earthquake aftershock were to take place, where will you run to as there are still a great amount of old buildings leaning precariously. I guess tourists can still see some architecture as well as experience the destruction left by the recent earthquake as there has been much rebuilding since. I'm unsure about entrance fees and costs as I did not need to pay.

Sit and watch!. I am partial to the giant Kali in Kathmandu Durbar square... but who isn't? If in town, the Kumari will be in residence there, in here special palace. There is a temple were figures of Shiva and Parvati gaze upon all the people milling around, and there are devotees, offerings, decorated statues, saddhus, tourists, the occasional cow... Worth sitting there and just watching.

UNESCO World Heritage Site. We visited this during our Nepal trip in December 2010. This is one of the most beautiful pedestrian only zones we visited in Nepal showcasing ancient temples, palace and handicraft stores all around. Kathmandu Durbar Square in front of the old royal palace of the former Kathmandu Kingdom is one of three Durbar Squares in the Kathmandu Valley all of which are UNESCO World Heritage Sites. It has palaces of the Malla and Shah kings who ruled over the city. Along with these palaces, the square surrounds quadrangles, revealing courtyards and temples. It is known as Hanuman Dhoka Durbar Square, a name derived from a statue of Hanuman, the monkey devotee of Lord Ram, at the entrance of the palace.

It's so-so and overpriced. . Entrance fee is USD10 and extra for camera. I was super annoyed when I wasn't even near the grounds yet and security was yelling at me from the ticket stand to get my ticket. I decided not to go and just walk around the area, and behold, I was in the depth and middle of Durbar Sq without paying. Anyways, it was just ok, maybe the crowds and busy-ness of it, made it unpleasant to enjoy the architecture.

I visited Durbar Square as part of my urban adventure Kathmandu living. Durbar Square is a hive of activity, I visited on a Saturday morning and the country market was on, and the festival was starting on the Tuesday. It was sad to see that some have it had been damaged by the earthquake. We had a local guide Rina who was full of information, we got some lovely photos.

Interesting place. This is an interesting place to see in Kathmandu, when we were there, we could still see the magnitude of the damage caused by the earthquake, it is best to have a local guide to show you around if you are not familiar with the history of this place. We had someone to accompany us and explain the different temples around the square for 2 hours approx and we tipped him ~ $10 usd.It was interesting to see some of the ceremonies and locals sleeping on the steps of half destroyed temples.

Badly damaged by earthquake, but still a MUST visit. I visited Durbar Square a number of times over my 3 day stay in Kathmandu. I was priveleged to be there when a festival was in full swing. lively during festival. Sightseeing. Some damage from the earthquake, but overall still lots of historical buildings standing. It was fun to walk from Thamel to the square via Asan market. Good for an afternoon trip to experience Kathmandu on foot.

Amazing Temples with great history in the heart of Kathmandu.. Really worth the visit, even if you have to pay 750NR to get into the place. (like 8 US dollars). They close all the offices right before dark, you can just walk right in after dark for free. Go to Patan Durbar Square Instead.
back to the past. a very authentical place to visit. Even after the earthquake. There are a lot of guides for a reasonable price. And they will help you trough the maze of this place.

amazing palce to view art, archiecture and feel the histroy of an ancient city.. Its a must visit palce for everyone travelling to kathmandu. Though effected by earthquake, this place still holds a lot of see and observe.
Intense and exciting. Spent a few hours here before my flight. Took a rickshaw from Thamel through Kathmandus streets. So much activity and so much to see. Very interesting...

still hopes remaining. demolished many temple & the palace by 2015 April's earthquake but it smiles & regaining its power to uplift the head to invite many with a big heart telling story of History to learn the lesson not to lost in dust.
Beautiful!. We went after the earthquake, so there is definitely parts of it which is damaged but it is still very beautiful. Nice place to walk around and enjoy the area/support the locals.

Support Durbar Square After Earthquake. This is a remarkable site that was devastated by the earthquake in May 2015. You can see most of the temples and shrines, but the damage is extensive. They ask for a 1000 Rupee admission, although the parts of the site safe enough for the public can be accessed for free. After you see the damage you will feel 1000 Rupees is the least you can do to help these ancient structures.I did get to see the four year old living goddess Kumari. She stands in view from a courtyard every so often for about ten seconds. Durbar Square was the most enjoyable site I visited in Kathmandu

Nice, but too much damage. Used to be the magnificent heritage site, I can easily imagine. Still magnificent and historically important, but too much damage from the last quake. all destroyed. all temple in this area, stupa, kumari house, old royal place receive a very strong damage from hearthquake

my kids love to walk around here. where ever my kids are bored they want me to go here for a walk.. the place is very quiet and has a relaxing atmoshphere. it is also a unesco heritage site.

Beautiful.. Absolutely loved Durbar Square when we visited earlier this year. Extremely saddened to see the effects of the earthquake upon this historical landmark. I look forward to seeing Kathmandu rebuild and come together to overcome this tragedy.

Must explore in Kathamandu. A very friendly guide called Raju showed us Thamel/Durbar square one structure at a time briefing us on each of those structures. A lo of standing structures stand shaken and broken being supported by pillars.Thamel is home to a number of cute boutique cafes, pubs and clubs. All in all a must visit.

Not much to see,750rs is a rip off. Most of the temples were destroyed. Way too many touts, streets and so called guides.The government 750 rs fee is complete rip off. If you're around it's worth trying to get in for free, just find a small alley and walk in.For real experience visit Patan.

Shame about the damage. My wife and I visited during our 25th Anniversary Tour of India and Nepal whilst many buildings remain standing after the earthquake the damage is clear to be seen. The heart of Kathmandu. A lot of restoration is still required in Durbar Square , which bore the brunt of Aprils devastating earthquake. There is however still much to see of Nepals beautifil antiquities. Well woth a visit !!

Earthquake damaged but still interesting. The earthquake has damaged a large amount of Durbar Square unfortunately, but it is still worth the walk through from Thamel to visit. Great history, beautiful buildings, sad result of the earthquake.. Interesting area. I was rather disappointed in the sights here. Due to the earthquake most of the temples are closed because they are destroyed and crumbling. What was most disappointing is that homeless people, teens, and just people in general were loitering all over the temples in the square.

Damaged, but worthwhile!. Still suffering the effects of the April 2015 earthquake. Tourism has resumed, with some of the most damaged buildings cleared away. Others are out of bounds and clearly dangerous. Some others have wood and scaffold supports. Still a fascinating place to visit!

Revisit post earthquake.. It was sad to see how much damage had been done, with several temples largely destroyed and others supported by multiple props and scaffolding. However, there is still much of beauty and interest to see and should not be missed by any visitor to Kathmandu.

Still the heart of Kathmandu. Kathmandu has many wonderful places to visit, but there is still nothing that compares to Durbar Square. The earthquake might have damaged the physical structures, but nothing can destroy the emotional and spiritual feel of this place. Some of the temples and shrines have been totally reduced to rubble, but many others have suffered only "minor" damage and are still to be seen in all their glory. The palace complex is still intact (with much use of structural bracing) and there are many places to still get lost in. Tourist numbers are down by about 80%, so you'll have much of the place to yourself. Here's a tip, once you have your ticket, go to the site office (ask if you can't find it) and get a long term pass, it will be valid for your whole time in Nepal, that way you can come to the Durbar on multiple visits, you'll need to bring your passport and a passport size photo and there is no extra charge, great value. While in Nepal, I visited the square complex at least six times, each time discovering something new, most of the courtyards were totally empty.

Emotional. Beautiful place, even with the damages caused by the earthquake. Quite emotional to see all these people working together to rebuild the place, solodarity to the top.Still a must to see despite the damages !
The most amazing place in Kathmandu. A unique collection of old temples and shrines before the earthquake. Many locals are here to celebrate their festivals.

Beautiful architechture. Though it was very crowded the building were fascinating. there were lots of little shops to buy things. Not advised for those who are not historic or architectural enthusiasts.

30th Anniversary Trip. Most amazing buildings and hope that they can be salvaged since the damage from the earthquake. Much has been done to restore and clean up so it is easy to see the region with problems.

After earthquake not much to see. Gives you a insight into the severity of the april -15 earthquake, there's a quite high entry fee. Other than that its not much to see for the moment- hopefully there able to restore some buildings and secure the ones standing so that you can see them.
Spirutual place for visiting . visited durbar square with my friends. The temples and square are ao spirutual and amazing. I can understand now, this square is inside of unesco word heritage.

NOT what it once was. I spentvan afternoon at DunbarSquare, now I wish I had spent more time. However, a have a couple a hundred digital pictures to view. Deep pockets with Velcro closures are a good deterent. There is an open air market near the entrance to the square the is a fun place to look for interesting things, like pink Himalayan salt, also comes in black.
Wonderful. Old times in our Life back .. This is magnificent place with Awsome temples and such a huge and white Building.Travellors.. Take a Visit for sure.
Before the earthquake must have been magnificent. Still worth a visit. Hire a guide on site to get the best of it.Alot of damage. It will take ten years to fully recover.
Well worth a visit. Slowly recovering from the earthquake, much work to be done.stunning temples and a vibrant buzz, visit a roof top bar to see the whole vista

Touristy and somewhat over-rated. Much of Durbar Square in Kathmandu is not properly restored and I was disappointed. Very busy. Lots of shops and markets slightly cheaper than the shops were in the tourist part. People are so friendly and this is a place where you can haggle with the price
Durbar Square. Durbar Square was badly damaged in the earthquakes of Nepal...As off now its under renovation soo any review need to be put on hold...

Durban square. Durban square is a very interesting place I suggest that you take a guided tour as there is so much to take in with the history .we used outfitter Nepal the guide was extremely knowledgeable and very helpful and answered all our questions . The weather can change quickly in Nepal suggest take sun and rain protection and also plenty of water . Also whist travelling in Nepal take your own toilet paper everywhere you go and hand sanitizer as there is not always hand basins available. Always ask before you take photos of anything as you don't want offend .

Fasinating, and sad. The earthquake in April 2015 hit Durbar Square hard. The temples and buildings that remain are shored up and seem ready to collapse at any moment. Huge cracks run through walls and in some cases there's nothing left but teh foundations. Still, you can feel the history here and if nothing else, can enjoy the characters that mill in the square selling things (sadhus with brightly painted faces and crazy long beards selling photos of themselves) and people watching. Also baboon watching; we saw two dogs square off against four baboons. A huge crowd gathered and we all howled in laughter at how ridiculous they looked. Take a stroll through and wind up at one of the rooftop cafes that look down on the action. A good way to spend a morning.

Unique, Ancient, and Majestic. Revitalisation can be seen here and there, but this ancient complex still show its greatness. Worth a visit. However the sellers are rather annoying since they follow you everywhere.

SUFFERED FROM EARTHQUAKE BUT STILL UNIQUE, ARTISTIC AND MAJESTIC. We visited this twice, once in 2010 and second time in 2015. This time, we were worried that how much damage the April 2015 earthquake would have done to the magnificent wooden structures there.Yes, earthquake was massive. Yes, many structures were totally demolished. But those which stand show how great the whole area was in the past.Not only that, the spirit of nepali people and their organisation is simply indomitable. Hats off to them, they are going about restoration systematically, diligently and also step by step.The Durbar Square at centre of Kathmandu is a popular tourist attraction. It had and still has many wooden temples, very intricately carved and very tall and very artistic. In spite of the damage, the square area exudes some kind of peace and one does feel relaxed after spending time there.
Durban square. After Earthquakes iT is not worthed anymore to visit and they ask entrancefee too see only few monumentale left !

Old Kathmandu. This should be everyone's first stop in Kathmandu. The square is beautiful, full of monuments and pigeons ;-) Unfortunately is badly damaged after the earthquake and almost no reconstruction work is taking place (October 2015). Hopefully this will change soon as the place deserves it. The entrance fee is 750Rs, but you can ask for Visitor pass at the Kathmandu Metropolitan City office which will be valid until the end of your visa.

A place of palaces and the very heart of Kathmandu!. "Durbar Square" means literally a "Place of Palaces"! This complex, at the very heart of the ancient city of Kathmandu, is known also as "Basantapur Durbar Square" or "Hanuman-Dhoka Square", including palaces and beautiful temples and shrines, both Hindu and Buddhist. The April 25, 2015 earthquake has severely damaged "Durbar Square", where many temples and monuments - as "Kasthamandap", "Maju Dega", "Chyasin Dega", "Trilokya Mohan Narayan" and others - were completely destroyed. But fortunately, many others like "Kumari Chowk", "Shiva Parvati", "Taleju", "Basantapur Durbar", "Hanuman-Dhoka Palace" and "Gaddi Baithak" were partially or slightly damaged. Before the earthquake, "Durbar Square" was always full of visitors, souvenir sellers, fake saddhus, pigeons and cows. The square has re-opened for visitors and a fee of Rs.750,00 is charged per person upon entry. If visiting Nepal was on your plans, don't give it up! Visiting Nepal is a form of supporting the country's reconstruction efforts. Enjoy!

A peaceful and relaxing square to spend time on. Although the square was full of visitors, it is still worth spending time to sit down for a cup of coffee. You will then experience the life of the universe and the life of yourself.

The Square of Kathmandu. This place falls near to the Thamel area of Kathmandu and is the place which is surrounded by markets. The place is very ancient as you can witness many monuments here from the ancient times.
Temples. Great place to walk around and see the temples.There were lots of tourists and locals here.We were here before the earthquake of 2015.Hopefully it wasn't badly damaged.
Historical. You will be able to learn the history and culture of Nepal here. Only Hindus are allowed in the Teleju Temple. But the entrance is remarkable piece of art.

Great Temples and views of city life. Although some of the buildings have been destroyed or damaged by the April 2015 earthquake this is still a fine area to view temples, religious lifestyles and city life. Like stepping back in time.
Sad to see the destruction but still a magnificent place to see. A UNESCO world heritage site. Beautiful slice of Nepalese history badly damaged by the earthquake needs tourists now.
A Must See!. Experience the hectic, chaotic every day life going on in the square, we were lucky enough to be there for the start of the Kumari festival and see the Golden Mask being made ready.
Must go. As the ancient part of Kathmandu city, you have to go. Pay a small entrance fee. Parts have been damaged and some collapsed after the 2015 earthquake but still worth going.

Way too expensive. To avoid. Too many tourists. Entrance fee is totally ridiculous, Way too high, just a tourist routes shaver system. Very nice place but sadly to avoid. One of the only place in Nepal were I was "attacked" by pseudo tourist guides, merchants, etc.. Nice wooden structures, but 750 routes is totally insane
renovation work. I work in the square helping clear the rubble so that renovation work can continue. The square is still impressive with the structures that are still in tact

Wonderful art pieces!. A 'must see' for any one who visit Katmandu. The squares are like open museums of medieval art and architecture. It’s easy to spend hours wandering around the squares and watching the world go by from the terraced platforms of the towering Maju Deval; it’s a wonderful way to get a feel for the city.
Back on it's feet again !. Visited in February and again in September , sad to see after the earthquake but still an amazing heritage site . You can walk through local markets to Thamel from here .

Kathmandu Durbar Square. This is part of overall Kathmandu Durbar Square, it is nearby to each others in the Square. Good location to visit in Kathmandu even some damaged after the recent earth quake.

Take a chance to look. Yes, it's partly destroyed and some of the buildings are still in the reconstruction process. Don't know how it used to look, but now it's sorry sight. Foreigners have to pay to entry. I would definitely recommend to visit Patan's Durbar Square. It's in perfect condition and looks much better than Kathmandu one
Hectic but a must. Great place to visit. A lot of bargains. a lot of architecture. A lot of culture. A must see when you are in Kathmandu.

A destroyed center . I visited Durbar square of baktapur ,2 days before and I was surprised about the beautiful temples but I was wondering today; because of untheless of 16 kilometers distance between katmandu and baktapur , the earthquake destroyed most of the temples in this historical buildings. If you interst to see one Durbar square as a historical and religious palace, I advise you to see Durbar square of baktapur .

Needs your help. Brings tears to my eyes still to see the damage being done to this once beautiful location. Although I am not particularly well-versed in Nepalese history and culture, this was one of the spots I had anticipated going to well before I visited. Even though most of the monuments and buildings have been destroyed, I do consider visiting again for nostalgia's sake but also as a means to invigorate the deeply impacted tourism industry. Every person counts.

History with combination of story and myth,. If you want to check the historic places in Kathmandu, there in no better place to start with then Durbar Square. The place is a perfect blend of history, architecture, mystery, spiritual activities and fun loving atmosphere. Spend some quality time with the pigeons and check out the hotels surrounding the square.

Amazing place but sadly partially destroyed due to recent earthquake. This area is amazing but it has been partially destroyed due to the earthquake. The country is visibly poor so the reconstruction will probably take a lot of time to complete. I was asked if it is still worth going and my answer is YES! The country needs tourists more than ever and there are still great things to see. People in this country are super nice and friendly. This area, however, is full of "official" guides who want to tour with you. They usually ask for 300NPR (3USD) for one hour. I don't like to have guides but everyone will have a different approach on this one.

Still beautiful. To be honest most of the monuments have been destroyed by the massive earthquake but it still has the old vibes of ancient Kathmandu. Repair work is going on and i hope everything will fall back to their place soon.

The Old gold nepal. Very very crowded but yes a must place to see. All the buildings looked so good in architecture. Patan's Durbar Square and a little further out, Bhaktapur are much finer and also don't allow vehicles to come anywhere near to spoil your enjoyment, wandering around these beautiful old temples and shrines.Kathmandu's Durbar Square was quite badly damaged during the recent earthquakes in April and May 2015, but even by August a lot of work had been done to tidy up and start restoring these old buildings. Of course Kathmandu's Durbar Square has the advantage of being only a ten-fifteen minute walk south from Thamel, where most people stay when visiting Kathmandu. (The entry fee of 500Rs - about 5$ and rumoured to be going up to 750Rs - might put the budget traveller off.) However, the walk through Asaan, the bazaar district that lies between Thamel and Durbar Square is definitely not to be missed. Explore the narrow streets crammed with sellers, with little shrines and temples at almost every street corner, where time has stood still for decades.

A very sad sight. I have visited Durbar Square many times and it was always an almost magical experience. A wonderful collection of ancient buildings which are incorporated into locals' daily lives; whether it is worshipping at the shrines, sitting on the steps to monuments chatting with friends, selling and buying produce. Even the touts did not manage to detract from the atmosphere (well, mostly).In June, following the quake, it was very different. It is open and safe (if one is sensible) and most of the rubble is gone. Unfortunately, major buildings are also gone. Chief among these is Kasthamandap, the oldest and the highest of the pagoda-style buildings which gave the name to Kathmandu and is reputed to have been made from a single tree is nothing but the stone base and steps.Some pagodas, monuments and shrines remain and the visit was worth it if only to see the damage and how the resilient Kathmandu-ites are stoically returning to normality. Rebuilding will take place but will take a long time. Whether the magic can be restored remains to be seen.

Nepal is safe. After the 25th April Earthquake, Nepal is open to tourists, Much of the tourist and trekking infrastructure is up and running again. Hotels and restaurants in the tourist quarter of Kathmandu known as Thamel are open, likewise in Patan and Bhaktapur, Yes, there were many temples destroyed in the earthquake but the majority of temples in the Kathmandu Valley are still standing. Currently all areas in Kathmandu’s old city, north south and west Patan along with Bhaktapur, Pashupatinath, Boudhanath are open to tourists.The only major treks closed are Langtang and Manaslu. All the other treks are open and running.There are no food or water shortages in the touristic areas. There are plenty of guides available.So yes, you’ll be welcomed with arms wide open

Kathmandu Durbar Square. Durbar Square in the heart of old Kathmandu city in Basantapur never fails to impress first time visitors with its intricate wood carvings and rich history. Surrounded by concrete buildings, the complex is an oasis in a fast developing, chaotic modern city. Once the residence of Nepal's Royal family, all coronation ceremonies were held here. The palace is an amalgamation of eastern and western architecture with additions by Rana and Shah rulers over the centuries. An unbelievable 50 temples lie within the vicinity including the temple of the titular deity, Taleju Bhawani. The Durbar is divided into two courtyards, the outer Kasthamandap, Kumari Ghar, and Shiva-Parvati Temple, and the inner section consisting of Hanuman Dhoka and the main palace. Some floors have been converted to museums dedicated to three generations of Shah kings. Most parts of the palace premises are open to tourists throughout the week. Some important monuments to see in this area are: The Taleju Temple is the tallest of all structures, built by King Mahendra Malla in 1549 AD. This temple is open to the public for one day each year during the Dashain festival. The Jagannath Temple, built in the 16th century is known for the fascinating erotic figures carved on the wooden struts.The Kal Bhairav, one of the largest 17th century stone statues in Kathmandu, representing the terrifying aspect of Lord Shiva. Swet-Bhairav - the temple is open to the public once in year during Indra Jatra Festival. The 17th century Kumari Temple (the temple of Living Goddess) is an example of highly developed Nepali craftmanship. Kaandasthamp, from which Kathmandu derives its name, is said to have been built from the timber of a single tree.Nautalle Durbar (the nine storyed palace)

If you're into history, this place is fascinating. A rich site, with buildings, people, music, souvenirs, its got the lot. Allow an hour or two, to absorb the atmosphere, and to get your moneys worth, as foreigners are charged a lot to get in. Make sure you read a guide book, so you understand what you're seeing, to avoid the " just another old building/temple" syndrome. The Wikipedia page is very detailed. The highlight? The Hanuman Statue is memorable. The palaces are good. Look for the elaborate carvings on the windows. The Kumari, is my favourite, first seen when I was there 35 years ago, and still there today: a young girl, highly decorated, who appears for a minute at a window, with the alcove below packed with observers. No photos allowed. She's a human incarnation of Durga, a Hindu mother goddess. Get to the entrance at least 20 minutes before 4pm, and stand inside, so you can see her window. Don't get stuck behind a shrub! (Personally, if you're going to see just one Durbar Square, then I'd recommend the one in Bhaktrapur, which is further out of central Kathmandu, but has a much more "living history" feel to it. Costs more to get there (we had a day rental taxi, so I don't know if there is a bus), BUT if you ask for your passport details to be put on your ticket, you can re-enter for free for seven days. This is useful if there's a festival on).

Tragic results of the Earthquake of April 25, 2015. Durbar Square has always been one of my favorite places in Kathmandu, and so I was compelled to visit it on the day after the Great Earthquake. What tragedy! What sadness! Nothing had been cleared up yet, and people were still more or less in shock. Wandering around, sitting around forlornly. Garuda looked out upon rubble, The grand neo-classical buildings had lost their ruffles, and the are bricks were showing. The ancient Newar palace of the Malla kings was badly disheveled. People were just beginning to camp out in the square. Only the Kumari Temple looked perfectly intact, while Taleju suffered less damage than some of the others, and at least the pagodas still stood out against the blue sky. On that day, i couldn't take any more and didn't go to the Dharara Tower until about a week later.

Amazing array of temples and historical buildings. Visited the Kathmandu Durbar Square on 2 January 2015 ,organized by Outshine Adventures ,with our knowledgeable guide ,Mr.Prasant.This Durbar Square could be reached from Thamel , about 10-15 minutes by car with a bit of traffic.Some of the must see temples ,buildings and religious sites are the Jagannath Temple, the living Goddess Kumari building, Kastamandhap temple (heard that this particular one was destroyed during the earthquake :-( ), Kakeshwar Temple ,Mahendra Museum , Kal Bhirav,Nasal Chowk etc.Worth a half or fullday to get around .We don't know the condition of the Durbar Square at the present ,our pictures maybe would just a beautiful memories now ..A visit is highly recommended , and we sure hoped that if there's damage it could be restored somehow ..

A cultural explosion. The best thing about Kathmandu and around is that every corner there is a cultural surprise that will fill your eyes. At any time you may be surprised by cultural or religious manifestations in the streets, or even, a delicious food. And around Durbar Square is the best place to uncover those good surprises.Enjoy the life!

Amazing buildings from 14th century. Amazing people and buildings. to walk through a city that is 14th century is amazing. the craft and detail is astounding. i also loved people watching. the features are beautiful and the children stunningeasy to walk around and take pictures. lots of street merchants. if you are interested bargain; if not interested dont even engage in any dialogue. a great gift to bring back are small colourful purses; you can bargain to 50 cents a purse by buying 10

Beautiful. We wandered around the streets of Kathmandu and ended up at Dunbar Square. It is full of history and well worth the visit. It is unfortunate that most of it has now been destroyed by the earthquake and were lucky to have seen it beforehand.

You only miss it when it's gone !. That phrase is absolutely spot on to many of us, including myself ! My heart melt and saddened when I came to this world heritage site on 7th may aftermath of the quake only to see 50% of it is damage badly by the quake , many terns mostly emergency tents for families lost their home and emergency relief aids is seen in this square now, construction work start to carry out now by the military of nepal, but damage is now done, my heart is with them, to lose such a statue is as painful as losing a family member of themselves, let's all together pray for nepal for its recovery and always hope for the nation ! I'm gonna tell all TA friends and family who read this now that, this is the best moment to visit nepal if you have a plan to go ! Show them you care , we care , let's all restore humanity and faith on love people !

Another loss. Sustained very heavy damage in the recent earth quake, may never recover to its former glory.
The loss of the square only ads to the sadness of the Nepali people.
Reduced to rubble.. Was a fantastic square but understand that most of it has been reduced to a mound of rubble. Not sure how the living goddess fared, I hope she was not hurt.
It was beautiful. So, so sad that this beautiful busy area of Kathmandu was so badly damaged just a day or so after we were there.

Pre and Post Earthquake. I saw the Square on the Thursday before the earthquake and then the day after the event.Like many things in life it has to be lost before you appreciate its full beauty.It is now impossible to be accurate in my recollections as to how good I thought it was on my first visit.It now sits in my memory as a most enchanting, fairy tale mix of Shangri-la Palaces and Temples. It was a World Heritage Site. I hope it can be restored to its former glory.
Beautiful Art. it was really nice place to visit, really beautiful art presentation of Nepal but now I feel very bad to see it's destruction in TV, wish soon make up again.

Splendid history and bustling present. I feel sad to review Durbar Square since the earthquake happened since we left. It was a wonderful area of beautiful historic buildings. One of the best things about it was that people were still bustling about with daily commerce and socializing.

Durbar Sq pre-earthquake. So lucky to visit Durbar Square mid-April pre-earthquake. Nine-storied wooden palace tower, which we missed on our first visit three years ago, was amazing. Kumari came out to balcony too!
Historik. A nice place where you feel history mix with the new Nepal. Wonderful wood handicraft on the buildnings. A place to get your breath in a busy town.
wow place..but unfortunately destroyed now. was a great place with wood laden structure that reminds of an old kingdom.. standing like a palace..but now gone for ever..not to be adored any longer..

It is just the same with Hanuman Square. The Durbar square located downtown. You can feed the pigeon here and they will gathered surround you. Many temples used by people to pray, that is why you will smell the fragrance of incense all over the street.

world heritage. But by the time I am writing this review the place is damaged by Earthquake. It was a great heritage site which shows that world could live in a modern age and could still enjoy the past age.
Friends of Higher Places. Used this company to trek in Annapurna region and see sights in Katmandhu and Pokhara. A high quality company with personalized services.
Wrecked by earthquake. The area is now in ruins. Bulldozers are clearing the rubble. Will take years to reduild. Will never be the same again.

It was perhaps the top historical site in the valley.. Only time will tell how much survived of the square. The early pictures are heart braking. The quality of craftsmanship was superior in stone and wood.

Watch The Flow of Life. Such a beautiful and historical place to soak in Nepal. Haggle in the market place, admire the colors of flowers for temple offerings, observe the traditions, walk amongst the locals, eat, sit and appreciate the traditions of life in this beautiful ancient place but most of all learn. The is so much to learn here! Heartbroken to see the devastation of the earthquake but still go. Just go...help Nepal recover.

Beautiful, fantastic. This beautiful area is a must in Kathmandu. It is a fantastic evedence of the Nepalese architecture in all its beaty. Quite relaxing to sit down and just look people strolling around. There is so much what an eye can catch. You really should not miss this.
Vey nice place. We are very lucky because we had been there before the earthquake, I wish they don't have to much damage

a heritage building. the building and campus was called heritage of nepal built in year 1600 around. the old architecture construction and inside is a small and big temple. the area is said to be the center of nepal king at that time. at mine time of review i feel sorry that this place is in news of being total demolished by earthquake

A Kaleidoscope Of Colour. I loved Durbar Square. Loads to really sit and take in. This is the real deal not Thamel. Watching flower sellers threading the Marigolds for temple worshipers. The lighting of butter lamps, ringing of bells and the constant flow of prayer and mantras is a kaleidoscope of colour and brilliance. Being Mothers Day ladies were dressed in their best sari's - so beautiful. The Sellers on Durbar Square are not too pushy and most accept 'No thanks" - an interesting place to enjoy a Masala Tea and people watch.
An Ancient Palace. Elaborate carved windows and doors. Home to the Big Bell, bulit by the last Malla king. Next to the bell is the Barking Bell, named because dogs bark to its ring.

Nice to be there. We have there at day trip. This place is look king old king place and you can find out lots of gift items at street as well food court. our guide told yes this place is on world heritage side also . Relay you can spend good quality time out there .

Historic. A really interesting place with many palace buildings belonging to the ancient kings of Nepal. The temple of Kumari, the living Godess is also here although she was not present while we were there.- It makes one want to learn more about this fascinating part of Nepalese history

Lovely architecture and pretty streets. Wide range of architecture over many ages combined with markets. Some lovely rooftop bars to watch it all from. There is a charge to get into this area (ticket booths near each entry street) so if planning to visit over multiple days do get them to note this on ticket. Gurkha museum worth a look

crowded and unfriendly. This square has a street running through it so the traffic is constant and the flow if any tour is likely to be interrupted multiple times. i would avoid this one or plan on just walking through and visit Patton Square for a better feel understanding of the importance of these squares.

Beautiful place. This is a must to anyone visiting Khatmandu. It is a beautiful space. You need a few hours to enjoy the many different buildings and learn about their usages and history. I felt sage while walking around, people were friendly. Spend a nice afternoon walking around and if possible hire a tour guide which can share valuable info.
the hustle and bustle of the main square. absolutely amazing. Very historic. Get a tri shaw there. it all adds to the experience. Get a guide to show you round as its huge and needs explanantion.
Crowded. Beautiful architecture of the Royal Palaces but crowded. Despite what had been told Kumari doesn't comes out daily, she only appears about 12x a year on special occasions.

Heart of kathmandu. As mentioned it is the heart of Kathmandu, a lovely place to visit in the evening and enjoy a serene walk with your partner/family or friends.The durbar square has a museum which was actually a place and well preserved, it was really nice and had info about the early life of Nepal prince.The place is usually very crowded and noisy but still serene at few areas which is the beauty of the place, the 9 floor tower of the Nepal king was really awesome, its a lot of stairs to climb but worth.The ancient carving in the dry pool which was once used by the queen's was really awesome, there are a lot of small gods and goddess sculpture's around the place which is very old and nice. Plan at least 2-3 hours for this place to have a proper feel of the place and to enjoy.

busy sensory overload. sensory and emotional overload in every sense of the word. once behind the palace doors, calm to appreciate the setting and the architecture, with panoramic views a reward for climbers of the 9 storey tower steps.
Pricey entrance. I didnt enjoy that much durbar square, recomend a lot more Bhaktapur that its 1h or less by local bus and that is a real nepali ancient city.

not bad but lots of people. people are always after you to sell their stuff, even you say no to them. poor management, but history of the site is amazing. beautiful arts on the building. Museum is good.

Stepping back in time. Defiantly a must to visit is this World Heritage site in Kathmandu Metropolitan City. It will cost you 250rp or around $AUD3.50 and also includes a map which is a "must have" but do not expect to get a copy in your preferred language. We were given the French guide because that was all they had. You will most certainly have a bevy of guides offering to show you around. Not sure what this costs but in hindsight I would recommend you barter hard and take up this offer. Check the guide has an official looking guide pass. All signage is in Nepalese. The area is the old palace and is fascinating with its many temples and palace buildings with intricate carved wooden inlay work around windows, doors and eaves. While in need of massive restoration it is nevertheless incredible in size and construction. Your entry also entitles you to visit some parts of the palace grounds and the museum. Visiting the museum actually gets you inside the palace which is fascinating and houses a collection of photos, clothing, regalia, etc from one of the more recent Kings of Nepal. There is much to be discovered but unless you are well read on Nepalese culture, traditions, history and religion much of the significance of many of the sites is lost on the average tourist. I certainly include myself in this comment. Government of Nepal needs to explain what the process/plan is for the restoration and upkeep of the areas - money is being collected and needs to be wisely spent to ensure this magnificent treasure is looked after. The other great reason to visit Durbar Square is it does allow you to escape the throng of tourists and locals that otherwise flood the surrounding streets along with motorbikes, rickshaws, taxis, buses, cars etc - it is mayhem. Once you have finished your tour you will probably want to head for Thamel - the market area. This is a challenge and I strongly suggest if you have a guide that he takes you back to Thamel and shows you how to get to your hotel.

intersting place. A very large square that houses the living goddess. I picked up a book after I went there but wish I had read a little more about this place before i went there. There is a lot to see here. A museum that goes on forever, a 9 story structure to climb and over look the city, and square after square of connected parts of the palace. Plan to spend at least 2 hours here.

The heart of historic Kathmandu. Durbar Square is a world heritage site with the old royal palace, temples, markets and the maelstrom of Nepali life from beggars and lepers, to sadhus and holy men, hippies and the kumari - a living incarnation of a Hindu goddess that lives in a house on the southern side of the square. Great for people watching and brilliant for photography. Come at different times of day if you can as the square feels very different at dusk than it does in the middle of the day
Ancient Architecture. Good ancient architecture of Places of Nepal Kings. Good place to visit as one can see the life style of ancient nepal royal family

Nice attraction, but too expensive to visit. We visited Durbar Square on a misty day, hence it could have been nicer with clear blue skies appearing in the background of the temples. I really enjoyed visiting the museum of Durbar Square, see the beautiful courtyard surrounded by the stunning Hindu architecture. Nonetheless, I thought there wasn’t much to visit inside the building, several “no entry” signs were hanging in the door frames. Hence, I would have been curious to see a little bit more but didn’t dare to trespass at any point. Once we entered the square I was looking forward to this so called "pedestrian zone”. Which appeared to be at the beginning. Sadly I was wrong: scooters, and motocycles still drive through. So you have to watch where you’re walking!As well, I found the entry price to this UNESCO site outrageously expensive. Some tourist attractions like boudhanath only ask for 200 NPR. It seems like these Hindu places, like Durbar Square or Pashupatinath tend to rip off tourists by asking them to pay between 750 to 1000 NPR. All in all, not too bad. Just a couple of disappointments.

A must-see in Kathmandu!. Busy, full of people, exotic, noisy, beautiful, hectic, typical, so many adjectives to describe Durbar Square!That's what I have in mind when I think about what Kathmandu really is, don't miss it!
Definitely Worth Visiting. The various temples and museums scattered along the square and in the general area make it a neat place to visit.
One of my favourite places in kathmandu. It's beautiful and very interesting to go there, spend time there or just sit on one of the temples.The kids loved to run after the pigeons!!!

Lovely square. We came here and although you have to pay to get in, if you are staying in Katmandu or around the area it is worth getting an extended pass as it is definitely worth the visit. If you do go it is advised to get a tour guide as we were able to get one for 200 rupees per person and he was definitely worth it. It is not necessary but you wouldn't take in or understand all the fantastic buildings and meanings of the shrines available throughout the square. We returned here at the end of our trip in the hope to see the Kumari. We did after one of the tour guides requested her appearance and were slightly disappointed. We were glad to see her but we were under the impression that she would be made up like the photos and it was an event but the reality was that she was an average young girl who looked bored whilst looking out the window at us before flouncing off once she seemed to have had enough. That said, it was good to have seen her. Definitely worth visiting the square if you're in the are though, and can easily get a bite to eat or drink too.

A vibe of its own. I really wanted to see the hippy era Kathamandu and I did in Durbar Square. I prefferd staying in freak street adjoining the Durbar Square.The best part minus the nuances of staying in a budget hotel, is to walk around early mornings to the sqaure. That way I got to see the real local life minus the touristy hustle bustle. Its so different from Thamel. Freak Street has these tiny shops with remanants of the hippy era, and I almost got a tattoo done the place is so infectous!This place surely doesnt need a guide. All one would need is comfortable shoes, camera and lonely planet. I simply walked around the whole place, visiting the talking to the locals, having coffee alongside hardcore backpackers, trying to avoid getting run over by a bike, watching local people read newpapers on the steps of historical monuments.Best part was to sit at this corner coffee opposite Kastmandap, sipping coffee and watch nepalese way of life.Loved every bit of it.

Great architecture. We could have spent hours here, exploring the amazing temples and buildings. The palace was beautiful and very well preserved.I would recommend travelers to take some time aside to visit and more importantly, feel the place.
Great architecture. This is the place I liked the most in Kathmandu. I would recommend travelers to take some time aside to visit and more importantly, feel the place. The museum is great.

Lots to see. We could have spent hours here, exploring the amazing temples and buildings. The palace was beautiful and very well preserved. We were very lucky and saw the Kumari at her window. (You are not allowed to photograph her- the security men are very strict!)

No need for a guide. Yes, this is common to these types of ex-royal grounds that they charge tourists only for entry. If you have the Lonely Planet or another decent travel guide then no need to negotiate with one of the locals. As well, if you don't want to pay for entry then arrive at the southern end of Durbar Square and you won't be bothered for payment. The architecture is interesting, but even better is taking the stairs up the nine-storey tower at the southern end. Fantastic views from up top and great vantage point for your camera. There are monkees in this area. Beware of the pigeons - don't look up. So much history in this place. Also, a great place to sit and watch the horde of humanity pass by. Not that easy to find Durbar Square, but you will.

Amazing place - must see in Kathmandu. The Durbar square and surroundings present an amazing collection of palaces, temples, statues and squares. The place is full of life, sounds and colors. You should definitely visit Kumari palace and if you get there on time you will have a chance to catch a glimpse of a living Goddess. It is not allowed to take photos of Kumari. Unfortunately one of the tourist did not respect it, when we were visiting and the moment he pointed his camera in direction of Kumari she disappeared behind the wooden walls. Visiting Durbar square is also great chance to get to know some history and religion of Nepal, so either take a good guidebook or book a guide. As we booked the whole Nepal trip with Nepal Hiking Team, a local hiking agency, they organized an amazing daily trip in Kathmandu for us. In my opinion, getting to know the history of the buildings and meaning of the monuments adds a lot of value in sightseeing Kathmandu and Durbar square, especially that it is such a different culture than the European one. I can only recommend it.

Great atmosphere on April 3rd 2015. What a place. Fantastic square. Vibrant even in the rain. Love the old buildings.Kathmandu has so many attractions. So much to see and do.Will definitely have to go back soon.
breathtaking. make the time to sit and watch the square. i found it surprising that this square seems less renovated than its "relatives" in Patan and Bhaktapur

Beautiful architecture!. I spent several days wandering around the Durbar Square, making photographs, passing by protests, markets, prayers and candy sellers. Beautiful light in the evenings as families hang out and tourists make their way out of the square. Reminded me a lot of India.

Need a good guide. Walking few streets and seeing an old brick building will not be enough to learn about the this square. Fortunately we had a good guide and spend hours there. This is also one of "must see" place in Kathmandu.

Crowded historical place . This is one of the old historical place of Nepal. This place also declared as world heritage site.you can feel old history here.lots of shops.there are 3 darbar square in kathmandu.
Amazing Place. Amazing place to visit. Small gift shops around. You can sitdown and enjoy the view or read a book. Also, few great restaurant to try around. It could be a very busy place though!

Shopping Area. Plazas and areas opposite old palace of Nepal were known as Durbar Sqare. There are three such durbar Square in Nepal and one of them is known as Kathmandu Durbar Square and other two are Patan Durbar Square and Bhaktapur Durbar Square.This is modern part of present Kathmandu where you will found many roof top Restaurant ,eateries,Shops and a bazzar also. Nice place to spent time.
You are definitely not home!. Exotic, chaotic, colorful swirl of people, shops, roof top restaurants, and vehicles. Great sense of an older, more authentic Kathmandu.
Very Western. Good shopping district for the more upmarket experience. Very busy at times. Plenty of restaurants and eateries.

Visit if you're Intrested in Archeology.. To know about the Old Kathmandu & History of kathmandu. One Must visit. A dream for any history lover. Palaces and temples crowd the space, with daily rituals continuing despite the constant flow of tourists. One of many highlights in Kathmandu. Quite extraordinary. Guides are Very Helpful...

Large expanse of ancient architecture. You have to start at a rooftop of the building across this landmark to view the whole expanse of ancient architecture. It was a beautiful day and large group of tourists came to Dunbar Square.

Disappointing and deplorable state of buildings.. Durbar square Kathamandu is evidently a place to visit for its historical, cultural and political background. It is obviously an excellent place to see the hub of traditional socio-cultural Nepali life at the very heart of the city and perhaps the nation.The monkeys, the Sadhus, the food vendors, vegetable vendors, the flower vendors, the pigeons, the motorcycles, cars, and bicycle rickshaws, the pedestrians all trying to pass through with its horde of small surrounding businesses all overlooked by the once long gone majestic historical Nepali architecture of temples and castles is a world unimagined.The general state and inevitably apparent deterioration of the structures however is witness of a world heritage site of extremely poor or very little conservation efforts.The entrance fee for foreigners is 750 Nepali Rupees.

Durbar Square. A dream for any history lover. Palaces and temples crowd the space, with daily rituals continuing despite the constant flow of tourists. One of many highlights in Kathmandu. Quite extraordinary.

Lovely place, lots of history.. A lovely place to walk about and see some interesting things.I had a limited time there with my brother, so we had to rush around. There are lots of tourists and many interesting things to see. Some beautiful crafts and paintings too.

A MUST SEE!. Surrounded by temples and trekking stores, it's a nice mix of touristy while maintaining the site's sacred nature. Definitely swing by Freak Street just by Durbar Square too. Quite a sight!
It's a UN world heritage site for good reason!. Local guides are good and will help you find the nooks and crannies that make this site both human and magnificent.
History alive. For all those history and adventure lover out there, its a must visit, its like a journey in time, taking your breath away; very busy too, so if do not like crowds maybe best avoided.

At the Centre. Kathmandu Durbar Square is one of the important historic destinations in Nepal. It is a massive complex of Palaces, Temples and Courtyards. Loads of history and amazing architecture. A good guide is essential.
Excellent Place. Durbar square was a nice place and the buildings have good architecture and took photos and visited living goddess and it was great.

Excellent but go to Patan Durbar Sq first.. Patan Durbar Square is much smaller and compact and has the fantastic Patan Museum. If you are thinking of going to both, you should do Patan first. Street vendors here were not quite as annoying as Patan. This square is actually 3 loosely linked squares. I'm not sure if we were scammed or not. Upon entry to the square, some one came up to us, and said entry was 750/pp but he could guide us for 1000 and we wouldn't have to pay for the tickets. His English was excellent and he imparted a lot of good information. While I did see the tickets booths and the 750 price, I didn't see anyone collecting money there nor did I see anyone wearing the tickets around their neck like we did at Patan Square. I didn't mind paying the 1000 to get the hour tour, so if we were scammed, so be it. Lots of beautiful temples.
Good Shopping Place. If visiting Kathmandu and want to go shopping them must visit Durbar Square which is close to Hanuman Dhoka Square. Lots of shops but need to bargain on prices.

Overwhelming. The senses are overwhelmed by the size and number of temples. Each one different and each one an attraction on its own. Old wooden building which reminded me, in terms of design of the old houses in europe ..really enjoyed my visit here. Aided by the amazing knowledge of my Guide

place of ROYALITY..... it is made of wood and too beautiful we went there in 2013 july .we were there for 3 hours and we can spent time for long hours there,and there is a caffee ,i cannot recall the name but try to go there and enjoy the royal view of the place .good place for shoping also.and u dont need any guide.place is clean .there were so many more temples behind darbar square which is made of pital and chandi.good place for reunion,love birds and busness purpose also.

Good place to visit. Its historical and we listened many things from our Guide. 10-15 USD was nice as the tip for this Guide after about 1.5 hourse stories telling. When we came was rain, but did not hold us from walking around and listen to our guide.

Historical for Nepal. If one visits PATAN Durbar & HANUMAN Dhoka Square, its enough to skip Bhaktapur Durbar.
Patan Durbar requires more time and more of walking to cover places.
A 2-3 hrs Tour (Walking) of Patan will be around 400 - 600 Nepalese Rs.
Very nice Old temples. If you are religious, you should visit Panchmukhi Hanuman temple which is open only between 9 to 4. There are many small Hindu temples with old architect.

annoying rip off. 7 Euros entry fee for non Nepalese.
While inside, I was molested at average every 2 minutes by people trying to sell me something with partly infantile, partly evolved pusher methods.
Not fun, but nice scenery for picturs

The Charm of the Royals. The architecture, the stone-paved paths and the open market place for the throng where the King used hold his public meetings is a testimony to the traditional planning that is relevant even today. The place exudes an amazing grace and yet is abuzz with life . The structures live the bygone era, holding the visitor mesmerized.

Worth it but make sure you are feeling energetic. I wish I had time and energy to enjoy this more, was at the end of a very hectic two weeks, lots of walking and things to see. Many photo opps and shopping can be found here. Probably a good idea to have a guide of sorts (our group did) to explain things.

Don't miss the museum and Nine Storey Palace and living Kumari. Watch out for all the people trying to guide you and sell you things (unless you are wanting a guide etc). Lots of people willing to let you take a photo of them (if you don't mind being asked for money). Loads of markets, shopping opportunities and photo opps. I bought a few souvenirs here at a fairly good price. Was lucky enough to see the Living Kumari briefly too :)
500 years old Heart of Kathmandu. A must visit while you are in Kathmandu. Walk around the old temples, get to see the Living Goddess and feel the real Kathmandu ...

A place of fascinating contrasts. This is one of the great sites of Kathmandu and without experiencing this strange, unique collection of buildings and enjoying the variety of life here nothing of the modern city makes sense. This is was once the secular and religious centre of the valley and contains its finest monuments and the greatest diversity in commercial and religious life. Though noisy and hectic it has tranquil corners, small doors lead to courtyards and gardens, sadhu's pose for photographs and the devout light candles and leave offerings. Pigeons, people and prayer flags this is still the beating heart of the city.
must visit. This is a definite must see. Not too expensive and also beautiful temples all around. Such history to learn about. A great learning experience.

Lots to See!. There are lots of temples and interesting architec to see. I would suggest getting a guide to help you to understand the significance of all the buildings and designs. Haggle a price with the guide (I paid 500 Rps) before starting to make sure you have a good deal. There are plenty of guides around, so you don't have to go with the first guy that runs up to you.

great atmosphere. Enjoyed the very different mixture of architectures and styles all in this one square and the surronding squares. Make sure you wander down all the streets and squares, normal tourist shops but also still very much a living town, great to wander around for a few hours , take your time and appreciate the people. wthrtstreets and shops is
nice. if you like to visit historical places then you must visit this place. my husband like this most. its having museum & place where you can meet and see the live goddess.
authentic culture!. roam around to see the architecture of the old palace, go deeper to see local people and last one is to see the famous kumari

Sums up Kathmandu!. Square well worth a visit, with some fine buildings and a wide variety of religious sites. If you have only a 1/2 day in Kathmandu, which was my case, this is a handy spot to visit, together with the surrounding streets and alley-ways - gives you a good taste of touristic Kathmandu

Amazing place. All the three durbar squares I saw in Nepal are more or less similar. Huge area and buildings on both sides provides a good view. Many places within to capture good photo graphs. But one thing what I felt was ,being of historical importance and tourist place it needs to be kept in good condition. The huge area where I was told concerts are held are definitely a good place to walk about

Essential to visit if you come to Kathmandu. Well one just cannot come to Kathmandu without visiting Durbur Square. This place is very chaotic which I guess is the flavour of Kathmandu. The palaces and the temples are all mixed up. There is a huge European style palace which is less impressive than what the reviews have suggested. The square is full of life. People are passing by or sitting around watching the world go by. Of course there are also a lot of tourists. There are performances in the square but too many people for us to go near. The palace was very charming. Inside there was an exhibition on the life of the last king. However we really enjoyed the courtyard. There was the juxtaposition of the white palace with the old red buildings and the blue sky and white clouds. It was peaceful and tranquil.
too corwded. ok place old city with too many shopping places not so clean, just one time visit or passby would be enough nothin great
historical. preserved historical monuments but lack of info. a bit dirty n too many motorcycles running around the ground. tourist pay to enter the area expect safety n calm to roam around

Impressive but needs upkeep. the site is actively in use by those practicing their faith. Overall the location is clean, but I wonder if they have plans to restore any of the structures. It might be worth taking on one of the guides that come up to you. Each temple has its story, and the area is richly steeped in history.

Far inferior to the Durbar Squares at Bhaktapur and Patan - a festering litter strewn tourist trap plagued by motorbikes. We spent 4 days in Kathmandu and this was by a huge margin the biggest let down. The Durbar Squares in Patan and Bhaktapur are clean pedestranised areas as opposed Kathmandus square - which has a constant throughput of motorbikes and mpoeds and taxis.The day we visited there was a huge festering sea of garbage adjacent to one of the temples. The best thing to happen that afternoon was being approached by one of the army of "guides" who began hassling for us to have him as a guide. "Do you have any more garbage to see ?" I said sarcastically.... Having no idea what garbage was he offered to show us "The best Garbage all over Kathmandu !" We were about to take some photos and a Military Police van stopped right in front of the temples - blocking everyones view - so they could feed the pidgeons. In comparison with the other 2 Durbar squares its poorly maintained smelly crowded and generally litterstrewn. Compared with most other squares in the world its smelly crowded and litterstrewn. God knows what they are spending the entrance fee on ! It could be excellent. But it's a long way from it due to missmanagement and neglect !
Amazing place... you will have a different feelings when you reach the darbar square, nice architecture, be careful with money minded tour guide and vendors. bargain for everything minimum 40 to 50%.

Heritage but over crowded. Durbar Square, New Market & Thamel.
These 3 places are nearby. So you can cover all places by walk in 2 hours.
Durbar square nice heritage place but over crowded because of local markets. Difficult to get taxi while returning. But worth a visit.
Interesting. Great monument area in the hearth of Kathmandu, very caothic though. Worth visiting is the kumari house, where the living goddess resides and the courtyard of the anxient king palalce.

Wow! What an amazing place!. We loved the square and stayed in it! It is such a step back into time and there is something to see at every turn. Very safe for sightseeing on your own. Good places to stay, eat, and reasonably priced. Weather wasn't the best when we were there but it didn't put a damper on our trip at all!
Old world. History at its best. We wondered looking at the buildings that make our old ones look young! I didn't like the people hassling us to be guides though

Definitely worth a visit. Just a ten minute walk from Chhetrapati, we went here in the morning. This is a World Heritage Site. We had to pay the entrance fee of NPR 150 per head (SAARC). TIP: If you intend to stay around here an visit it often, you can request for an extension of upto a week (by showing your Passport) at no extra cost. The square is very interesting. We read about all the monuments before visiting here. It looks like an ancient city frozen in time.We spent a lot of time at the Hanuman Dhoka Palace Complex which houses an excellent museum. TIP:Be warned, bags and cameras are not allowed inside the museum. So please deposit them in the lockers provided at the entrance of the Palace.Definitely worth a visit.

Terrible Aggressive Men in Thamel's Durber Square. A good looking guy introduced himself as a guide, lied to get me in there and buy a ticket with promises of a festival and the Kumari girl, and then his ugly grinning aggressive friend moved in and took over. He was very controlling, did have some knowledge, but he stayed so talkative that I could not think for myself. My many answers of NO were ignored with their fast talking and I ended up getting worked over until I bought things I did not really want. I was cornered. And you know how we think that we have to be nice to the people, but I was very mad at myself for thinking that in such a situation. Don't be nice! Yell SHUT UP and GET AWAY FROM ME! There are police who will make these leaches go away. They are liars ad tricksters. Find one police man, no matter how much these guys turn the charm on. These guys a pros and they desperately want your money! Paton's Durber Square is more mellow. This is where you will find the artists. Many big golden statue stores, A carved and embellished crystal shop, & internet cafe. And the museum is superb!

Durbar Sqaure..heart of Capital City Kathmandu. Durbar Square lies in the Heart of the Capital city Kathmandu...Thamel.Surrounded by Ancient Newari architecture, high temples, popular shrines filled with devotes and the old royal palace.You can find alot of shopping n eating joints,cafes.Alot of foreign tourist stay near to this place..and find a exotic night life here.Namaste!!

Fundamental to visit in Kathmandu. When I asked my Nepalu friend where he would take his girlfriend for a date he said Durbar square. That is why everyone should visit this place not only for the temples and beautiful city view but for everyday life which is taking place there. Couples hanging out, children playing lot of performances and loudy nepali people. Really vivid!
Fantastic place and well maintained. Very well maintained with lot to see , purchase cheap goods, try some lcoal made candies and icecreams. you need to bargain hard and nice
Durbar Square. Good food and a place to wind-off. A must visit in the evening after a long day of exploring Kathmandu city

good place to visit. i went to this place as it was walking distance from my hotel and is between the busiest market place in Nepal , it starts fom where new road ends and one of the main tourist attraction in kathmandu

Nice place to visit. I like the place , it was clean and tidy. Weather was good. and you can shop a lot.
But don't forget to bargain.

Massive place, lots of pictures to be taken. It's a big place, with many different buildings including the Royal Palace. It's 750 rupees for non-Nepalanese, but once inside you can go to the office (near Freak Street & the outdoor bazaar) and have it extended for your entire stay for free. They create an ID on the spot.Most people will leave you alone, but occasionally people will offer their tour guide services, a polite no thank you (if you don't want it) and they will leave you alone.The Royal Palace is included in your Durbar Square ticket and is much quieter than the rest of the square. You can climb to the top through nine flights of stairs each getting more steep & creakier than the previous flight. It offers amazing views when you are up there too.The museum is not too special. It's mostly a political history, with lots of pictures of Nepal leaders, but little history. You don't really have to shed your backpack and cameras, just don't be caught taking photos or they will call you out.Lots of pigeons flying around too!
Beautiful and magic. Amazing place in the middle of Kathmandu. Go there, see tys place and admire the beautiful view and feel the history of Nepal.
Beautiful . Like others durbar squeres around Kathmandu, its beautiful, full of history, colors, people. You must see the square and all the temples.
Fascinating. First place we visited in Kathmandu and absolutely fascinating. Amazing architecture ... be ready to pay a small entrance fee It is really worth it.

Fusion. Fusion is the word that comes to my mind when I think of Kathmandu Durbar Square. This place houses mostly temples and palaces that are of local style and architecture but also a white palace of European architecture, which is the influence to Jung Bahadur Rana, first prime minister of Nepal to visit Europe. Just by the side of the square, there is freak street, where hippies during sixties and seventies started staying and enjoyed drugs which then was legal in Nepal. That marked start of tourism in Nepal. The temple that houses Kumari, living goddess, is worth visiting. The nine storey palace which is a museum is the best part in the square. It has excellent collection of royal family personal and official belongings. Happy to find that the nine storey palace is kept in excellent condition, which I was not expecting.
Worth the look. I always like to look at Buddhist Temples and the square has a nice communal feel to it. The huge prayer wheel in room to the side of the temple is certainly worth a look

durbar plein. This year it is better than one year a go it take time to make everything but this place is one of the first buildings in kathmandu Also there is a Siva babba nice person bring him food and 20 NPR you will like it have a good time

Exciting : to know what you'll find here!!. I liked the Palace of Kumari , and was able to see her for a few mins when she came at one of the windows to give Darshan. Foreigner are not allowed to go up in the Palace to visit her. The Durbar is full of shops of souviners & and lots of Birds to feed.

So many sites to see here!. We found this place to be v. crowded with aggressive vendors, but no problem if you have thick skin. One of my favorite moments was buying a coffee here from a walking vendor....she had hot water in a container on her back , and made a rather good cup of "white coffee." I loved the excitement and sounds of this square....definitely check it out!
Amazing. What a place 10temples in such a small area. Stunning architecture a must see if in kathmandu we had the pleasure of eating in a bar ov er looking the temples and it was stunning

The least interesting out of three Durbar Squares. I saw all three Durbar Squares in Kathmandu Valley.
