I believe the one in Kathmandu is the least interesting - very crowded and "touristy" and therefore least authentic. I liked the squares in Patan and Bhaktapur much more. The Royal Palace (Hanuma Dhoka) is not so bad, but generally there is not to much to see here.
big & fantastic. better to spend more time for visit this place. it is quite big but interesting. must visit place in nepal

must visit. must visit especially for starting at late noon. daytime is quite powerful/impressive and night time also interesting & turn to another feeling on this. hard to explain but good for try it by own.

Would have been lovely if it wasn't for all the traffic and pigeons. It was very interesting place, good to have a guide who explained well and led us round as it is easy to miss something because there are too many scooters buzzing round the square an pigeons everywhere making the place quite dirty. We saw the living goddess, so interesting to hear how they are chosen.

European architechture in heart of Nepal. Basantpur (durbaar square) is a unique mix of temples of Nepalese traditional architechture. But this one stands out as its inspired by western architechture.Don't miss it when you are at the durbaar square

Amazing place. Durbar Square is a UNESCO World Heritage Site. It consists of various temples and requires a considerable amount of time.Make sure you start early morning to beat the heat. Although a information leaflet is provided with the entry ticket, hiring a guide is always advisable.

Nepalese traditional city. This place is really clean. Nepalese can enter for fee but need to pay for foreigners (small fee). We did saw very beautiful shops next to the pedestrian pavement. They sell a lot of nepalese products. As we walked further, we saw big traditional temples designed and hand crafted on the wood/timber. I felt like they did alot of hard work for that. I loved this place.

Ancient traditions and beautiful temples. The Durbar square is a UNESCO world heritage site. There are several palaces and temples. The architecture is beautiful. A small fee is charged to maintain and restore the structure. The house of the living Goddess is a must see. As per Nepali traditions, a young girl prior to menarche is chosen as the living Goddess and is worshipped. She lives in that house and appears in public at specific times. Once she attains menarche, she is succeeded by a new living Goddess. A girl once selected is not allowed to get married later in life due to popular lore that any man she marries will shortly die. A bit shocking, but I'm sure my country has similar traditions if I try to dig deep.The place is a bit smelly, due to tons of pigeons everywhere. Pigeon droppings can be a problem. Beautiful palaces make it all worth it.

Great architecture. Walked here from Thamel in early morning. There was not many bikes or people on the road yet. Even the shops are not open yet. I was mesmerised by the architecture. There were many locals at the Durbar sqaure, possibly performing prayers. I was a very enriching experience. No wonder it is an Unesco World Heritage site.

Fantastic Place. This is a beautiful place including temples palaces and especially The Home of Kumari the living goddess. We were fortunate enough to see her appear at a window for about a minute…no photos are permitted. The Living Goddess is picked from specific astrological and birth criteria as a young girl and remains in this title till puberty. There are several in Nepal but the one in Katmandu is the most important one. She sees local worshippers and blesses them and hears their problems. Once she becomes the living Goddess her feet do not touch the ground.She is carried everywhere and she leaves three time a year to festivals in a chariot.You can find out more about her online.

Rich Experience!. Many Temples, palaces and over all interesting buildings, the architecture in Nepal is phenomenal. There is a museum here, and there is the palace of the living goddess. Very interesting.

Beautiful location. A great place to stop in Kathmandu! Be sure to see everything inside the museum! The Khumari was a little bit of a let down as she only made an appearance for about 30 seconds - not worth the wait! All in all well worth it!

went everyday.. Please walk to Durbar Sqaure early in the morning before the motorbike starts runnung all over the street. I took a nice walking every morning and drank 'Lassi'. There is FAMOUS LASSI shop over there. I dodn't know the name of shop. You can find while you walk. or you can ask local people. It is unbelievably cheap and more than fantastic! :)

Sensing Nepal. Durbar Square truly deserves it's world culture heritage title. From royal palace to Buddhist temples; from worshippers, wonderers to doves; from witnessing traditional ceremony to smelling the incense, that is where we feel Nepal.

Quintessential Nepal. Take advantage of the local guides that approach you - but negotiate a lower rate. The architecture and history were astounding - so very different than our western culture. The people are warm, kind and love to talk about their city.

Thamel-Durbarsquare-Kathmandu. Old Thamel,KathmanduA few streets from Thamel is an area called Old Thamel. We wandered into the narrow and winding streets of Old Thamel on a hot and humid day by 3pm. The streets were tangled with pedestrians, motorbikes, tuk-tuks, street hawkers and shops, and the air was filled with the honking sounds of vehicles and the smell of spices, dust and gasoline fumes.As people and vehicles came towards us from different directions, I tried to keep a close pace with my friends while captivating all that was evolving around me. While gazing upon the spider web of wires and telephone lines that hovered over the head,Old Thamel is indeed old. The poorly maintained yet still occupied historic architecture seem to be in need of repair. But even with its weathered round dormers, exposed brick walls and battered carved wood windows.With everything happening in front of me, it feels like my camera is not enough to capture the action.This place was really beautiful where we can find the ruins of past glory of Royal Kingdom.A very small area with lost of shops for souvenirs. But more than that, old buildings and narrow streets reflecting historic texture of the town. Buildings are collapsing as there are No funds for restoring them. So do come and see before it is lost.Soon to be heading to Durbarsquare in a whileDurbarsquare,-KathmanduPassing through the old narrow streets of Thamel we reached to a much wider space of fresh air of Durbarsquare.Kathmandu Durbar Square or also known as Basantapur Durbar Square is a huge plaza of courtyards and temples situated in front of what used to be the old royal palace.Durbar Square is the religious and social heart of Kathmandu's old city and is a complex of palaces, temples, shrines, statues and courtyards built between the 12th and 18th centuries by the ancient kings of Nepal. The square is a queer assortment of the old and the new: elaborately carved architectural features and curving roofs provide shelter for cows, beggars and weary tourists; Brahman priests and painted Sadhus perform rituals and pose for photosWe were in a hurry to get our tickets for entry to the palace since it was alraedy 4pm and we hardly had 1 hour to visit the place.You can spend a whole day walking around admiring every corner of the square or you can do as what most couples usually do, climbed a set of stairs, find a spot and quietly admire the picturesque Durbarsquare.The square reminds me of the time when family time is spent outside doing the simplest thing. A snack bought from the street vendor, a corner occupied to pray, to talk, to rest, a child let to play as he please,the pigeons, the beautiful couples around, the sadhus,and the beautiful Nepali ladies.Kathmandu Durbar Square is an obvious place of visit for anyone touring Nepal and I believe that it should be included on the “must see” not only for its heritage architecture but for the exuding ambiance of happiness from the Nepalese family and friends walking around.Moral of Durbarsquare visit:Nepali girls are really beautiful,Every place has a story to tell check snapsFrom Basantapur Durbar Square we started walking towards one of our friends house near Kathmandu Football stadium.We traveled through the busy rush hour narrow lanes of the crowded paths to our destination near the football stadium where our dinner was arranged .Buildings falling apart. Artists, handicraft pedlars and prettified bicycles,tuk tuks,people awaiting for the evening buses and so on Astha's dad already gave directions how to reach their home from Durbarsquare to their home.We crossed the narrow lanes beside the stadium and finally reached our destination.We were expecting one more friend who was chasing us since last evening from Nepali border Sunauli.Astha and her family live in the apartment of a large three storey block. Dad opened the sliding gate at the entrance from where we went to second floor of the building which is the living room , the rooms were prettyAsthas Mom was busy in the kitchen preparing momos, chicken and few traditional dishes.Over there I was busy discussing the details for our next day travel to Chitwan to Rhino Resort near Bharatpur and the places to visit across there.Once the discussion was over we all went to have our food ,since power was not there we had to follow the small beam of lights.The amount of ‘load shedding’ hours people there have to cope with is around 12 hours. People have to live through it every day but still the inverter was working.After enjoying our local drink made of rice grains and chat it was time for us to head in for dinner.Every dish was plated to perfection in Newari styleWe enjoyed the warm welcome and gracious hospitality extended to us. What I've enjoyed most, though, is meeting people who have a real interest in food and sharing ideas with them.Met a wonderful Mom & Dad an avid traveler who traveled across the globe shared the experiences , soon another trip to Manasarovar to explore the Himalayas to be planned,One of the best moments in life .There is no love sincerer than the love of food

Amazing. What a fantastic place. The wooden palace is beautifully carved. The windows look like lace they are so delicate. The carvings cover everything from birds, flowers, demons, gods etc. the local stalls that surround it sell everything you could imagine. The liquids teems with life and colour. This is a photographers dream location. Well worth a visit.

A must see. don't miss this historic gem. It will be mobbed with tourists and Nepalis alike. They have done a great job in restoring the temples, just sit on the steps and take in the scene. Don't forget your camera the place offers lots of opportunities for show off shots at home. We go there every time we are in KTM, perfect place to hang out for a while after a long flight.
Durbar Sq. Dirty, grubby & full of hawkers, who won't go away. Small fee to enter & not really worth the trip. Lots of better sights to see

Old historical palace. Durban square is in Bhakti pur Nepal. This is the old palace of the king. You can visit two tamples in Durbar square. One old Musiam is also there. One can stay at Bhakti pur . Very nice and calm place to stay.

Excellent site, but watch out for the motorcycles. While I really liked all of these old temples and their wonderful architecture, I did not like the fact that the area is still open to traffic which means you have to watch out for motorcycles. As in the other durbar squares in Kathmandu, you will be offered guide services if you don't come with one. Still worth a visit if you like temple architecture.
Beautiful , vibrant , so much energy. Great place to walk around, people watch, locals, tourists, shopping, delicious memos on the street, lovely temples

It's odd.. To me, it was quite bizarre to see a European style palace among very traditional and ancient Nepali temples. Apparently, one of the Kings, after his visit to the UK, fell in love with the architecture here, came back to Nepal and hired a British architect to design this palace for him. This white palace just looks out of place. However, I know that locals are proud of it. I was there right around Indra Jatra so I got to see Kumari on a carriage pulled by lots of strong man starting from this square around the city. It was an amazing event.

A must visit. The beauty of this spot is in its charming old fashioned architectural showpieces.Viharin.com- PaintingsPaintingsThe Bhaktapur durbar square.It’s renowned for its spectacular pagoda and shikhara style temples around a 55 window palace of bricks and wood.The wodden carvings in every place – struts , gateways , windows and on rooftops reflect rich cultural heritage of Nepal.Viharin.com- Khukri ShopKhukri ShopSome of the main intresting places are The Lion Gate , The Golden Gate , Palace of 55 windows , The Picture Gallery , Batsala and Pasupati Temple (Replica).The site was vast that it took us at least two hours to cover. Although we were quiet fast in exploring the same but would recommend to fish out at least 4-5 hours to explore the same if you are art lover.I would certainly recommend this place to all, even if you are on a short vacation to Kathmandu , Nepal.

Hard to avoid. A definite stop for everyone visiting Kathmandu. The entry ticket is 750 rupees per person and gets you access to the palace museum. If you think you might just want to come back another day, definitely take the time to just bring a passport picture to get a pass valid as long as your visa. They are a bit of sticklers about foreigners getting tickets (even if you wanted, as we did, to simply go to a cafe along the square).

Heritage of Nepal. Durbar Square is a World Heritage Site and concentrated with Temples, Place and Museums. It has more than 40 attractions. Major attractions we visited are:Kumari Temple : Built in 17th century and home to the Living Goddess (considered to be the incarnation of Taleju (Durka)). We were lucky to have the blessings of the goddess. Trilokya Moban Narayan Temple: Built in 16th Century a temple dedicated to Lord Vishnu Kasthamandap: A temple built by using the timber of a single tree. Dedicated lord Ganesh. It was built in 12th Century. Kathmandu inherits it's name from this temple. Taleju Temple: Built by Malla Kings in 15th Century and more than 35 meters tall. It was considered to be the tallest building in Nepal until recent time. Basantapur Durbar: nine story building built in 17th century.It is a very crowded place with local and visitors from all over the world. Do not take Photograph of Holy people they will bug you for money. If you are buying any gifts bargain Bargain and Bargain.

Another world!. No place quite like Durbar Square! Amazing architecture; incredible energy; diversity of people; a bombardment of sounds, smells and visual stimuli!! If you visit Kathmandu, you must visit Durbar Square! Incredible place!

One of the Kathmandu symbols. I wanted to see this place when I was in elementary school and luckily, I had a chance to see it live. Lots of history here - medieval temples and pagodas, merchants and stands with flowers and fruit, people in prayers in front of the shrines... Vibrant and busy place, packed with people and tourists. The best time to go there is earlier in the morning, as there is less crowd then (I think). It is a big place, so take the map and spare a few hours to see as much as you can. You simply cannot miss this place when you are in Kathmandu.

Really nice spot...GREAT if you like history!. There's so (SO) much to see here. I was a little confused by how it all worked (you pay an entrance fee, but it's to several buildings that aren't easily identified or partitioned off), but I broke down and hired one of the "tour guides" hanging out to show me around & give me a bit more of the history...and to take pictures of me as I walked around. At any rate, there's more history than I cared to learn about, but I got my fair share, and was satisfied! If you love history, you'll love this place. If you don't love history, you'll still have a great time. I'm somewhere in the middle, and I was more than satisfied with my visit.

Royal, religious, and national history; stunning architecture, and killer views of the city. For the history buff, architecture enthusiast, or anyone wanting a killer view of the city, Durban square is absolutely a worthwhile visit. While a little pricey compared to other activities or sights in the city (750 rupee entry fee), we found it well worth the cost for an afternoon of exploring the palatial grounds, the history museum (complete with fascinating royal artifacts, jewelery, clothing, and military medals, among other things), and especially the view from the ninth floor of the central building.
reflect of old kathmandu. basantapur durbar is like old kathmandu i used to see in documentary and pictures.very nice place if you like to explore heritage.
Great place to visit. While traveling in Nepal our guide took us to this area. Cute shops, great temples and architecture and nice to browse around the area.
Not to miss square in Kathmandu. Very nice historic area. Medieval palaces and temples. I suggest to go very early in the morning, at about 8 AM, to avoid crowds.

Crazy. Went there twice. Do not hire a guide at the site. Went back with a guide and saw parts we missed. First time there was a ceremony for young girls trying out to be the next goddess. Traffic is nuts. Walked all over the area. Step carefully. No sidewalks. Traffic is nuts. Very interesting

Travel back in time!. Visiting Durbar Square in Katmandu, Nepal is like traveling back in time! So much history and it's as if time has stood still. Durbar Square is surrounded by spectacular architecture and vividly showcases the skills of the Newari craftsman and artists. A must see when visiting Kathmandu.
So many temples. A great place to wander around & soak up the history and atmosphere of Kathmandu. Had a wander down Freak Street too, & around the market square selling lots of inexpensive trinkets

Kumari. It is a very big an noice part of Kathmandu, and you have to pay a entrance-fee to get there. It is also here you will find the house of the living godess Kumari. From time to time she will show up in the middle window in the yard of the house. Taken Photos is strichtly forbidden but outside the house you can buy a postcard with her picture. We managed to see her this time. A good local guide will know when there is a possibility.

Wonderful place, a must see. There are actually several Durbar squares in Kathmandu. The main one is fabulous. Many shops and cafe's to visit. Also lots of restaurants, very safe to walk around at night also. Well worth hiring one of the young guides, you pick them up at the entrance. Our young guy was very informative and he was well worth the little bit we paid. We have him a big tip.

Durbar Square- visit to get a feel of Nepal. Durbar square was much smaller than what I had anticipated., Though not much to see it has many shops selling local antiques. Luckily for us a Nepalese movie was being shot when we visited which enhanced the visit
Loved it!!!. Lots to see n loads to buy. A paradise for history buffs and shoppers alike. Had a great time there. Got a good many bargains. Went twice actually.

Heritage site with Goddess Kumari resident place. One of the must visit by tourists. It nestled within the bustling Thamel area. The durbar square of heritage site is well photographed. Another hype is Goddess Kumari been sothsaying of eye witnessing her will bring good luck luck, try to take photo of her if you are in time to catch her presence at the window!

Most beautiful place to hangout in Kathmandu. It's definitely the most beautiful place to hangout with your friends. Just walk around this place and you will know why. Sitting on the stairs of the pagoda style temples, gazing at the crowd is just so peaceful. There is a small shop where you get the most awesome momos in town. Totally worth spending a whole day here shopping, eating, chatting, doing nothing.

MOST BEAUTIFUL PLACES IN KATHMANDU. Durbar Square near Sundhara in Kathmandu is one of the most beautiful places to visit in central kathmandu. The architecture is from Shah kingdom and was built in 845 AD. It is known for its wooden art effects and architecture which is still preserved and most beautiful places to visit. The place is spread across in approx 30 acres and has a number of temples and museum from shah kingdom.

My 40yr relationship with Kathmundhu. A must visit, bring a cushion to sit and watch others barter, the wares are amazing. A silver walking stick is a must buy for your old granny/grandfather, ancient shells found in the Valley and Mts when the ocean was there are beautifully embellished. There are food stalls around the area

Very lively historic place. Around Durbar square is very lively. Local people live there live on this historic place. The building outside might look a bit ill-maintenance but inside the palace is very well reserve. Inside and outside the palace have completely difference mood and feeling. I can walking around this small area for hours.

INTERESTING PLACE TO WANDER AND PHOTOGRAPH. Don't get confused. Almost every town in Nepal has a Durbar Square. It just means central or palace square. The square in town around which was usually located a palace or palace building and from which the town grew around. Kathmandu, Durbar Square is very much like most other Durbar Squares. The surrounding buildings are ornately decorated (some with very erotic wood carvings in the trusses supporting the roof), filled with multitudes of tourists, locals and vendors hawking their wares. A great place to wander and take photos of Nepali atmosphere. You'll also probably find the ubiquitous Sadhus. Supposedly Hindu holy men. Maybe once upon a time, but now all they are are ridiculously dressed, professional beggars. They will try to put themselves into any photo you are taking and then demand money. Pay them once and all their friends will come over (use your telephoto lens and take their picture from a distance to avoid the hassles).
Fascinating. We went there and happen to visit their "living goddess". She views once in a while to those people who visits her. And blesses people she wishes to bless.

Nepal Heritage!!. To feel Basantpur, you need to have ample time and walk slowly to explore. The place is a km away from Thamel, and its sheer fun. The traditional fare and architecture really takes you back to history. Saw the Kunwari temple, though the sight of the Kunwari (Virgin Goddess) who is a small 10 years old kid was not a very pleasant sighting for me.

Great, Historic Temples. What a wild, colorful mixture of religions! Temples and carvings (some old ones are quite erotic!) and people of all kinds are here. Good to read about it a bit first to enjoy it thoroughly.

the living goddess. We will forever, remember, seeing the little 8 year old Kumari. She was chosen at the age of 4 to live with the priests to the living goddess. This is a prestigious status for the family. Disliked: the thought that a child could be taken away from her siblings and parents, not allowed to play with other children, allowed technology, etc until 13/14 (first menstrual cycle) when she is sent back to resume a normal family life.

Very busy place in Kathmandu!. There are 3 Durbar squares in the Kathmandu area and this one is the worst ... very busy and very congested compared to Patan or Bhaktapur. Choose either of those of you want a less-congested experience.

Teeming with life and activity. Kathmandu's main square is fantastic day or night. Always teeming with people, it's a great place to grab a seat on the temple steps and take it all in. Vendors of all variety abound, from flowers to momos (Nepali dim sums). We were there for the Holi festival and the place turned into one massive colourful party. Exhilirating.

750 rupees is a bit too much. As much as I love the architecture and general feel of Durbar square, I'm not sure if I'd actually recommend visiting it. Unless you find a way to sneak in (there are ways), you have to pay the 750 rs entrance fee which seems like a lot. If you don't mind paying, then go for it. The area is quite small and there aren't that many things to see, but it's old & beautiful like most tourist attractions in Kathmandu. If you're a foreigner, expect to be approached by "tour guides" and vendors. Some of them are quite persistent, so prepare yourself.

No Whining About the $5 Admission Fee!. It's only 500 rupees for foreigners to get in this place and with that they have to pay for a lot of upkeep. So, if you sneak in without paying please enjoy your time in hell. I can only add one thing to the positive reviews here. Near the entrance if you follow the signs to the "tourist restrooms" inside the building, you will come out into a little courtyard. Now look just above your head at the little carved decorations. They are a textbook example of an architectural decoration that was popular for a while hundreds of years ago. They're what we would call "porn" and it makes you wonder about how this courtyard area was originally used....

My least favourite of all durbar squares. Bhaktapur Durbar Square and Patan Durbar Square (which also has a lovely museum) offers more value for money - especially considering the outrageous fee of 750 rupees they charge nowadays.However, it is relatively easy to walk through the square (without paying) by telling the guards you are heading towards New Road (coming from Thamel). The square is located at the crossroads of two busy areas... so you are bound to "transit" it sometime as expat or long-stay tourist.

Variety is the spice of life!. Variety is the spice of life! The old saying comes alive once you are in Durbar Square. A pleasant walk through the narrow but clean lanes of Thamel shopping area, and suddenly a new world emerges. This is Durbar Square!.There are shops on both sides selling variety of things, ranging from shoes, clothes to bronze utensils - even champagne bottle and glasses or vegetables. In between, there are quaint temples which invariably draw attention with hundreds of candles lit in front of them. The buildings where the shops are running are old and some of them have beautiful carving and interesting architecture. After every 200 metres you can spot small shops selling authentic buff momos or some other local food.One lanes leads to another and kind of create a labyrinth. Walking in these lanes I ended up in an area full of beads' shops. There were necklaces of colourful beads, which the Nepalese brides wear as a custom, were eye catching. This area is worth taking a stroll at to taste the real Kathmandu.
Fascinating. Here is a bit of central Kathmandu where you will see all kinds of people. No doubt you will find yourself enchanted and stunned at the same time.

Very nice. Lots of different buildings to take pictures of. You can walk around them and visit the museum. What you must don't miss is to see the Living Goddess which has 9 years old and is very important for the locals who believe in her. I saw her in her building just at 4pm exactly, she only appears for 15 seconds so you can be either lucky or unlucky, but you can't take pictures of her.

What an amazing place!. You won't believe the variety of temples crowded into a relatively small area. Your camera will be exhausted and you will be drained by jaw-dropping sights. Try to time your visit for Holi...... advent of spring....colour festival.....wild and unforgettable.

Heart of the City. A visit to the Durbar Square with the former Royal Palace leads you around temples rich in wood carvings, metal works and stone sculptures. The interior might not be much but the surrounding area is a sight to see.

Living Monuments. There are several Durbar squares in Kathmandu, all of them beautiful, full of history, well-preserved. These are complexes of palaces, temples, courtyards with beautiful, intricate carvings everywhere. They are Unesco World Heritage sites and rightly so.Apart from the beautiful old buildings, carvings, sculptures, I loved that these were actually still in use. You can see locals hanging out in the squares, collecting water from the water spouts, etc. There's a lot of people about but it doesn't feel crowded.We loved Nepal and its people and would love to go back some day.

Chaos - but you need to see it .... First you need to understand that every city has a Durbar Square, just that the one in Kathmandu is so much larger and chaotic (sensory overload). You will quickly see how the shops have much the same merchandise, so look for what is different. A great place to people watch and begin to understand the culture ...

Cool place but not much to do. The temples are really interesting to see and there are delightful little alleyways, but I wasn't actually allowed to go inside them and so wandering around trying to avoid people foisting their wares upon me was the extent of my experience.

Walk back in history. Kathmandu Durbar Square is one of the 3 durbar squares in the Katmandu Valley. its basically a collection of historical palaces, monuments and temples. some of them are now converted into a museum. Once again a world heritage site and saw rule of 2 dynasties and hence you will see two palaces which are now converted into museums.

Uniqueness of Kathmandu. Your visit to Kathmandu is incomplete if you have not been to this local hangout area of the young and old alike with its the royal architecture and history of Nepal as its background. This is the only place in Kathmandu which I actually liked and admired. I do not think this feature can be visible in any other part of the world. Hundreds of temples, the king's palace, the locals, fluttering Nepal flags, the cafes and the people selling artifacts....and the cleanliness which is very very rare in Kathmandu..stole my heart away. I can sit in the Durbar square for a whole week and would not be bored. Yes! You get to see so many variation..The Durbar Square is the Pulse and pride of Kathmandu. It is a UNESCO world heritage site.
Buy a ticket and go inside. Worth visiting. Make sure you buy the ticket and go inside to understand how the kings lived, and do climb the nine story tower to get a good view.

Full of history. We then headed to a palace, our last stop of the day. It is Patan Durbar Square. The square is full of ancient monuments, temples and shrines. Patan was once an independent kingdom before the shah dynasty took over. The city is home to over 200,000 people. The Patan Durbar Square is UNESCO world heritage listed.The temple has this strange rope across the door and our guide explained it was animal entrails so ward off evil spirits (just a bit eww). Definitely worth going with a guide, or you will miss the significance of the eyes, the intestines and the statues.

Beautiful Structures. Durbar square is an exciting and busy location, the structures are very impressive and culturally significant. Well worth the visit. It is well within walking distance from Thamel, only takes about 10 minutes at most and you'll encounter some interesting sights and people along the way.
temples galore. This is the only place worth visiting in Kathmandu - spend as little time as you can in Kathmandu and make your way to the country side such as Nagrakot and Pokhara.

A walk back in time. Spectacular sights and sounds of ancient Kathmandu. Look for holy men meditating and appreciate the very old temples and pagodas. This is a very special place that if you have time must be visited. An easy walk from our hotel in the Thamel district in downtown Kathmandu. You will see the old palaces where the Kings resided in years past. Amazing!!!

Go the extra mile here!. Yes it is dirty and overwhelming but read your guide book and read about the history and then pay attention to the detailing of the buildings. You will be surprised at what you read and then what you see. Pay to go into the museum of history for Nepal, you actually get to see the REAL furnishings for the past kings of the country. Only disappointment is I wish they put some money into upkeep. This applies to the whole country.

Tourist Hot Spot. Interesting, but do he warned. The local guides constantly pester you for business. Just be firm and say No. For me it was just another tourist trap with stools selling overpriced tourist junk.

Make sure to wander around here. it's an interesting area to wander around, check out Freak Street, where the hash and grass was legal for a period in the late 60's early 70's and the hippies and musicians ( the Beatles, Led Zeppelin and others) visited Kathmandu for inspiration for their music.

Not to be missed. Katmandu Durbar square is the focal point for tourists with several temples and a palace to visit. Entry is $7.50 and if stamped at the office there can be used for multiple entries. Get a guide for $15 for a couple of hours. Dont miss seeing the Living Goddess who appears at her window on demand (with a small donation) and is a child chosen at the age of 3 to stay in the temple until puberty. Also the Karma Sutra temple has some interesting sculpures!For a relaxing lunch try the rooftop restaurant behind the temple next to the Living Goddess.Its also worthwhile taking the walking Tour no 1 in the Lonely Planet book.

Good place to know the religious culture. I've spent around 4 hours in Durbar Square, and we hired a guide who gave us very good introduction of the culture and religion. We saw the Kumari (who is believed as the Living Goddess in the eye of the beliver) as well.
Historical Landmark in Kathmandu !!!. If you are interested in old history of Nepal, you must go this place and see several nearby historical monuments, temples, palaces etc.
Famous Historical place !!!. A famous landmark place -- a must see in Kathmandu. The Nepal Royal Palace is located right here. One can learn a lots of historical facts, if interested ....

Worth spending atleast 5 hrs and go in 2nd half of day. We went to Bhaktapur Durbar square. Lot of pics to be clicked.
Good shopping place if you have idea and tempo to bargain. Very good quality clothes.
Also very nice place to eat.
Very good experience. Must go for any kind of tourist in Nepal

Chill Out Spot. Once you arrive in Durbar Square and find a perch to look at the passing parade that lies in front of you it is a great spot to be in. Interaction with everyone in this area was very enjoyable. Very well worth visiting

Fun fast-paced environment. If you're into the hustle and bustle, then Durban square is for you. Completely filled with locals as well as tourists, individuals and groups come here to simply hang and soak in the atmosphere of the old historic buildings. You can easily get lost if you decide to explore further into the smaller lanes that connect to the local markets. Pigeons scamper and flock the entire place. At the main entrance, there is an entry fee of 750npr, however, you can easily enter without payment as the guards do not keep watch here. However, guards may attempt to charge you at other smaller entry points.If you are after a location to sit down and relax, this is not for you. But if you are in for a bit of a rush, Durban square will be an excitement
Great place to shop. bargain till you gain and shop till you drop. That's where the Kathmandu Durbar square is, and you can also walk to Thamel from there. Nice place

Decaying Majesty. The square used to be a hangout place for hippies who smoked joints. The artwork on the buildings is amazing; spectacular; something you would only see in the movies.Becareful of aggressive local individuals who would try and aggressively ask you out for a tour. Some of them do not have good intentions. Overall, its a really beautiful sight to behold. Get a guide for this.
Don't miss it. Entry has become expensive over the years. But you cannot miss it. Rare are those places where so much of history, religion and culture is concentrated in so small a place.

Must See with Caution. A half hour walk from Thamel, Durbar Square is a "must see" for first time visitors with numerous Hindu temples, Buddhist stupas, historic palaces and buildings (now turned into a museum)... along with numerous local Nepalis going about their business. It's well worth wandering about and finding photo opportunities.One caution: a number of local people will offer "guide" services to obvious tourists. While a few may be legitimate, many of these are people only seeking money--they often know next to nothing about the sites but spin stories that have no factual basis. If you really want a guide to show the local sites, it would be best to book one before actually going to the square.There will also be fake sadhus inhabiting the square, gladly posing for photos as long as you offer contributions.
nice historical place to be. lost in translation, no words, the ancient city on the city. its looks very old historical place in kathmandu, you must visit this place if you are in nepal
simply amazing. Amazing sight, must to visit in Nepal! Hindu temples, buddhist stupas, royal palace, colorfully dressed people in one place!
Kathmandu, Durbar square. Amazing sight, must to visit in Nepal! Hindu temples, buddhist stupas, royal palace, colorfully dressed people in one place!

Antiquities on Parade. Durbar Square is just another amazing sight in Kathmandu. Thamel is great and access to scenes like this are the reason you tour it. Soak up the local ancient customs. Revel in the fact that all the women are wearing pretty much the same thing they've been wearing for centuries. This is no show. When you leave here and immerse yourself in the Nepali world at large there is not much cultural change at hand. It's breathtaking if you understand what it is you're seeing. Obviously I enjoy such things...

Nepal Architecture fest. I was driven right up to this ancient site. Access is fantastic. If antiquities are your thing and you're in town then you'll enjoy this thoroughly. Nice little restaurants around as well.

nice at evening. We loved this place...so say a place for hippies, place for daters, some say for elderly people, so say for evening strolling place. We found all here .. we find it very interesting at evening.....great place.. can be better if they can avoid vehicles inside..

Good Structure!. There are 4 durbar squares in and around kathmandu. Durbar square in Lalitpur is very nicely built and is worth visiting when you are in kathmandu. Lots of old building structures with temples and Shops inside and surrounding areas. You can buy ornaments,paintings,antiques etc here...

The absolute best ancient city center in Kathmandu. This is the largest and most intact of the Durban Squares or ancient city centers. If you have only time for one..... see this one. No cars allowed either. Just don't use the agressive first guide who rushes up. Get the gentle ones past the gate that don't try to guilt you to pay more money. We paid 300 rupees and our guide was fabulous.

Old-time Kathmandu. Durbar Square is the place to immerse yourself in the quiet of traditional Nepal. This is a car-free zone (thankfully) so you can zone out a bit, just like the hippies did on nearby Freak Street so many years ago.

heritage of nepal. one of the old palace ,, and one of the best attraction for tourist but the things there is very expensive, especially for tourist. you atleast need 2 hours to have a clear view of the place.

The most famous square of it all.. One of the eight Cultural World Heritage site by UNESCO, The square is a cluster of ancient temples, palaces, courtyards and streets with shops and restaurants. You can shop till you drop here and make sure bargain for at least 50% of the asking price.

Colour and movement. The neighbouring Durban squares at Pagan and Baktapur are much better architectural gems but the one in Kathmandu is a vibrant testament to daily life. The buildings are on a smaller scale and represent the "old" Kathmandu with an overlay of market activity that provides a buzz and excitement that is equalled only in the best souks and bazaars of the middle east. Plus bargains are to be made with good quality merchandise.

Temples temples everywhere. The durbar square is a place where you can witness religion and public life come together. The square is a heritage site yet is still used by the locals.The square has more than 40 shrines of varying sizes.. devoted to various gods and goddesses. If you are an architecture, history lover then its a place for one to see the fusion of Buddhist and Hindu architecture and religious teachings.

Bustling square. Durbar Square a fun to see, bustling, town square. It's crowded with food, shopping, temples, animals and children. It's definitely worth a visit but only if you're in the mood for a little chaos. There is a lot to take in. There are a few rooftop bars/restaurants for those who wish to take it all in from a distance.

Not the best of the Durbar squares. Kathmandu Durbar square is historical, yes, but quite rundown, crowded and noisy. Spend more time and enjoy better Durbar square in Patan, which has been substantially done up and do not miss the Patan Museum in this Durbar square. Don't worry to much about Kathmandu's Durbar square.

Photo shoot place!. Many places to hang out, restaurants, shopping and of course, temples. Birds here complete the pictures together with the Nepali's people with their painted faces.
Don't like was so commercial, like be careful if you want to take the Nepali's pictures they will come to you and ask for money.
Busy!. Great history. Small price for westerners to enter which includes entry to the old palace museum - which was a marathon to get out of!

Meh, pretty expensive and Patan Durbar is better. This place felt a bit campy compared to wandering around Bhaktapur or Patan Durbar. It was 750NPR to get in and the place had garbage and disrepair all over the place.
I would suggest skipping this one and just doing the other two which were much more worth it.
Child Goddess temple. LIVELY place to be there on your own.......you cannot spend hours but dyas just watching people around
Beautiful place!. A place which rich culture of one of the 3 dynasties that ruled Nepal at the same time. Loved the unique architecture!

Polluted, and crazy busy. I guess this tittle describes all of Kathmandu, but I spent a lot of timing hoping that I wasn't going to get pooped on by pigeons. There is garbage everywhere, and so many people that I couldn't enjoy myself, and it was hard to get pictures. The traffic surrounding this area is terrible. I agree with other reviewers that the admission fee is too high- we also would have never found the admissions desk if we weren't with a guide. If you're looking for something to do, then sure check it out, but I wouldn't recommend this as a must see.

"A must see if you are in the area!". A really stunning place to visit if you are in the Kathmandu area! So many iconic temples etc with great architecture . There is a very buoyant atmosphere and regular events; it is well worth putting up with the heavy traffic and consequent pollution in the streets around!!

Amazing Temples. Durbar Square is incredible, loads of amazing temples and palaces, tons of people there praying, a proper piece of Nepalese culture. If you go at the right time you can also catch a glimpse of the royal Kumri

Interesting but dirty. Unfortunately Durbar square is becoming a dirty and polluted place (as the rest of Kathmandu). It was a lot cleaner some years ago before they start to charge tourist to cross the street, I was in Kathmandu 30 years ago and enjoyed it greatly but now, it is so crowded and dusty that you need to walk between motorbikes and rickshaws with a piece of cloth over your mouth.durbar square is more interesting at night with some lighting but careful with the beggar kids around...Baktapur has a lot better feeling of authenticity.Too bad...

Ok to visit! . The square is ok but the entrance fee is just too expensive!! The temples and buildings inside are nice but the place is dirty and there are too many of those guides and tuk-tuk drivers around! If you really have free time, a visit is a good plan, otherwise I suggest Patan square!

Plenty to See. Lots to see in the square here, including the rather sad museum and several temples. Dirty, busy,crowded, filled with pigeons--but a lot of fun to walk around. Worth the couple of $ to visit in the inner areas. Go in the morning--first thing (before 0800)--for best views.

Even better at night. The lighting's make the temples come alive at night. I visited the place at night as not many tourists will be there, but that did not diminish my pleasure of seeing the place. Rather it was enhanced by the lights and peace.

Old world charm. I had the chance of visiting this place at night and that too when the lights went out. The whole square had a surreal charm exuding memories of another time. Even at night there were people and fares thick in this place. All the steps of the temples were full of young and old people. It looks like a very Kathmandu thing to do. There was a ceremony gong on in the main kashthamandap. The fire of this ceremony was the only light in this place. Worth the scene.

Fascinating. The Durbar Square just fascinatiting! yes everywhere is old and dirty, yes the people are so poor and pathetic but there is something on the air, the energy, the soul of the square, people's smiles, amazing sculptures all of them make the square fascinating.

you should visit here to admire the heritage structures. the place is full of history. it always inspires me. being in the heart of Kathmandu makes this place easily accessible. go there anytime of the day, you will discover something new about this.the place comes to life when they have open to all rock concerts in the premises.

Open air museum worth visiting. Went there when it was getting dark ( foc ) and found the place very crowded with pedestrians and traders selling their wares by the roadsides in the dark. The whole place was not lighted up.Went back there again early the next morning to avoid the crowd. Paid Rs 7500 entrance fee and was given a brochure.Spent some time figuring out the names of the temples ( numbered in the brochure ) using the directional map provided. If there is a plaque bearing the number at each temple, it would facilitate cross referencing with the brochure.Defintely don't need a guide if research was done prior to visiting.

The Palace View. Durbar Marg is the road in front of the Kings Palace, now turned to be the Museum...It is one of the best place in Kathmandu to enjoy shopping and eating...From the road, you can have the view of the main entrance of the palace...There are a varity of shops and shopping lovers can find all branded goods here...There are lots of restaurants with different varities of food...Also there are two more five star hotels in the Durbar Marg...
A must-see. Ancient temples and museums in central Kathmandu. Starting point for the many religious parades. Fascinating insight into the religious and political history of Nepal.

Eclectic Durbar square. the heart of Kathmandu , the old palace runs along eastern side of the square .watch out for the 'living goddess ' who appears at 4 pm daily at Kumari Chowk courtyard . Statues and temples ornate the square , with merchants selling wares . During our visit a political rally , a film being filmed and a boxing match in a boxing ring were all carrying on simultaneously !
Marvellous. Beautiful place where you can breath history. From a certain hour in the afternoon you can enter for free, but still it has to be seen properly during daytime. Just lovely

Interesting, historic but in desperate need of upkeep. Well worth visiting, but it's vastly over priced at BR750 for Europeans. The buildings are charming, but not well maintained & the numbers of pigeons is of real concern. It may be a recognized as a site of World Heritage, but it's in desperate need of upkeep and tidying up. Better sinage of the sights would be highly appreciated.Watch out for those pesky pigeons!
what are they thinking. why do they allow motorcycles to crash through this crowds? Some of those lanes should be one ways at the very least.

Average experience. This is one of the oldest parts of Kathmandu, which is sometimes referred to as the "old city". It was quite expensive for Kathmandu standards at $15 USD. I wouldn't say it was worth it overall as there wasn't much to do other than walk around the old town streets, which are just more shops. The only aspect that is better than the streets of Thamel is that it's less busy with less vehicles on the road. You could actually walk around the streets without worrying as much that a car would honking at your or almost hitting you! We mainly spent our time trying all of the different steamed momo shops around the town! Overall, if you have limited time in Kathmandu this would be one that could be missed.

Very interesting. A very interesting place with mythical explanations to history. Great malla architecture. excellent street food around the square.. a must try is the local newari food houses near the durbar walls. it may look least tourist friendly from outside, but its one of the best food in kathmandu.
time travel. visit here is a treat of travel through the times... along with good food options around..History is still alive and kept well..

Great place to see. We went in a rick shaw and e cause of that we didn't pay entry although I understand entry is reasonable, we only knew there was a fee after our driver told us. We hired him for an hours tour. Take a dust mask with you

Great Place. This is most fascinating with such history, architecture and even still even in use to this day. This is a good walk around, great picture taking place and plenty of nice places to eat in the area.
Very nice.. All r good and beautiful. i like the malla architecture. the temple city. Nice n beautiful i like temples and museums.

Couldn't understand. Went to this place to pass time until my conference started.
Had to pay a fee before entering here. And the ticket was never checked inside even once.
Got to know, the ticket was for a museum I never visited.

All in one. The good place to visit, and more fascinating because they still use the temple until today (most of the temple we use to see in other country wasn't use anymore, just for tourism). Oh dont forget to see the 'living God' or something like that.

Amazing museum. We visited Durbar Square and was very surprised. There are many temples within the square but the most amazing building was the old kings palace. It does take a good hour+ to go around it as it is large but fascinating. We are not really museum goers but would definitely recommend a trip here. Outside there are shops to look around and worth hiring a local taxi to take you and wait.

Lovely to see - be wary of cars, bikes, etc. The temples are magnificent the architecture amazing - but be warned stopping for a photo could get you run over - they allow cars and bikes to drive freely through the square and people do so with wild abandon!!!

Worth a visit but try not to pay. If you go to the Durbar square in the morning 7 a.m or in the evening you can get inside for free. Since the at that time there not guards and not as many people as during the day. If you go there during the day try to find and alternative exit in order not to pay the entrance fee. It worth to see but for free. There too many local people all the time.

Temples in Kathmandu. This is a place to go to with a friend who can tell you about the history of the place, or with a guide. There are many temples to take photos of, so you will not gt bored. Every city has its own charm, and this place in Kathmandu is surrounded by beautiful constructions that cannot be left behind. Just make sure you go when there is still sunlight so you can appreciate the details of th architecture.

Great destination but avoid the expensive guides in the square. lots to see and a good example of the Durbar squares (there are three or four in Kathmandu valley). Avoid the guides offering to give you a tour and show you the living goddess for US$20. You can easily find your way around and see the living goddess for free.
Durbar Square. This is the 'centre' of Katmandu, with a few temples and always many people milling around. Most of the temples are carved from wood.
Scenic and Historic. Crowded and full of hawkers, but worth a visit. Temples, palaces and a beehive of activiy. It is a religious and historic location.

Ignore the ticket booth. Basically just not that interesting. We walked around the square to an entrance at the southside and were not stopped to pay any entrance fees. I would strongly suggest to do so and NOT pay the ticket, as it is absolutely not worth 750 rupees. I mean come on, the state of it is terrible. You can have fun with the touts and hawkers though if you keep hold on your sense of humour.
Amazing cluster of ancient temples, and palaces. epitomizing the religious and cultural life of the people, you will take many photos of these beautiful places
basantapur. lost in translation, no words, the ancient city on the city. It's beautiful, lot of people. We see the Kumary (living godness) unexpectably.

Amazing architecture. While visiting the ancient city of Bhaktapur, we toured Dunrbar Square. All of the ancients buildings, temples, and monasteries were very beautiful. Plus, don't miss the wood-carving museum.

An essential place to visit. A key stop on any visit to Kathmandu. We were privileged to be allowed to witness a buddist ceremony in one of the temples. The Gurkha solidiers on guard at the entrance to the square all add to the distinctive Nepalise character of the area.

Awesome place. i recently been there with my friend,it was really nice, artistic and awesome place for every one, great different temple,pigeon,kumari living goodness, bit crowed otherwise beautiful highly recommended for every one.

Durbar Dirty Square. This square has some charm but the filthy state and the over crowding has made it unpleasant. The square has become a tourist gimmick now. Tourists are charged money to enter but if you ask your taxi to drop you to one of the many alleys that doesn't have a entry fee you can avoid this extortion. It's worth going to see the square and take some pictures.
Historic place. Darbar Square is a place to be visited when in Kathmandu. It is full of ancient monuments & now a shopping area.

Kathmandu revisited. I was here 18 years ago and some things havent change much. There is much more traffic and pollusion but when you seat on pogoda steps you can see locals passing by. You can touch ancient time ....

Durbar Square,Kathmandu,Nepal. This is the most visited place in Kathmandu the capital of Nepal. Situated at the heart of the city where the old Royal Palace of the erstwhile Nepalese kingdom is situated, this is a beautiful site to be seen,The Square is surrounded by centuries ols buildings depicting the Nepalese architecture . The Palace can be seen from the square. There are hotels around the area that meet the tastes of Indian visitors.
Must Visit!!!. Understand the history before visiting and then let your imagination take control.... great photo place.
The architecture of Dunbar Square. Just amazing and we even glimpsed the living goddess. The architecture of the temple to an old carpenter was most intriging, the feel of the people was love.
lively place. Very good place to spend evening time with your friends and love ones. the architecture of this place will simply blow your mind.

beware Tour guides. Beware tour guides negotiating to take you to see the living Goddess at a price which does not include the entrance fees to anything. You'll be shown to a ticket booth to buy your tickets after he explains he is a qualified guide and shows I'D and you make the assumption he fee is included. After the tour as well as you paying for all fees he will ask for at least 1000 R each from you .....very sneaking very dishonest and not pleased.

Historic heart of Kathmandu spoilt by motorbikes. Title says it all. We were there during the equivalent of Diwali when the square is open to traders. This was very colourful and atmospheric but unfortunately it also meant loads of maniacs on motorbikes. Architecture is stunning - if you can get to see it.
Absolutely Amazing !. One of those places you can't believe that you are there .Beautiful, spiritual , and great place for people watching .

A Place Worth Seeing. Yes, there are many ancient architecture that are --- really ancient. Beautiful architecture and in the corner is the museum. The place is quite spread out and it is one of a kind sight.
Even 40 years on it has lost nothing of its charm.. Well worth exploring with or without a guide. Calmer and cleaner than I had it in mind and with all the hippies gone its much less busy as well

How interesting!. WOW, the architecture and atmosphere of Durbar Square will captivate you. All the temples are so ornately carved, and different. It is difficult to know what you are looking at, so take along a guide book to help you understand it all. I did not see any persons offering themselves as guides there. Plenty of items for sale in the market square and along the side streets, so you should be able to find a map or guide pamphlet that discusses the square.

Historical part of the city. Well worth a visit, you can access the buildings as well, interesting museum, but limited English explanations, mainly photos of the royal family, but some memorabilia, Wood carvings on the buildings and the architecture are something to behold, small charge to the world heritage site.

Must see in Kathmandu. The historic square is a treat to the traveller, Well worth a whole day if you have it, You can finish off with a visit to the Thamel square which is quite near for a bite to eat,

Do not miss this site. Although not my favorite site in the valley (Bhaktapur, Swayambhunath Temple, Boudhanath Stupa and a couple other sites were my favorites) Kathmandu Durbar Square is still very significant historically and religiously and is not to be missed. Also be sure to take a walk down "Freak Street", which is adjacent to the Square and is filled with unique shops and is a cool experience. It is surrounded with pagodas, temples and shrines including the Kumari Temple and if you are very fortunate, the Kumari will make an appearance and bless your day. Quite an experience for me.
Temple's . This place has great temple with stunning view.. the best part is when, the pigeons take flight.. it has a different style, than the other durbar square..

Warning about tour guides . Durbar square itself is worth a look, but just be wary about tour guides. I was approached by a nice tour guide who showed me his government/official guide tag so I figured he was legit. After agreeing to pay him 2500 rupees ($25) for the hour, we did the tour which was just ok - didn't show or tell us a lot, and when he was talking he didn't face us. He finished the tour at an art school and after trying unsuccessfully for 20 minutes for us to buy something, when we left he turned cold and pretty much told us to go back inside and buy and guilt us into it, he then said the tour was done and upped his price and told me to pay 3500 rupees. When I said we had agreed on 2500, he told me that was the "on season" price. I tried to get out of it and told him that was very expensive, especially for an hour tour and that I got paid less than that per hour back in Australia and that I only had 2500rupees on me (which I did- I had nothing else at all) he WALKED me to the atm. My advice is if you want a tour guide, even if you talk about and agree on a price, pay them then and there and don't wait until the end.
Historic buildings. If you want to see the very old historic building of the city this is one of the places to go. Make the hike up 9 stories to the top the highest building for a great view.

Stunning buildings but hawkers were a pest!. A wonderful range of medieval buildings and temples some of which were simply stunning. Lots of crowds, colour and character. Hawkers were more persistent here than in Patan or Baktapur Durbars. Several good cafes in the square with views down but also across the rooftops of Kathmandu.

Great Site. We would rate this Dubar square third after the ones in Patan (Lalitpur) and Bhaktapur, but it is centrally located and does contan some neat temples. Some had too many steps to climb and were still in need of renovation but it is worth a visit.

Bustling Centre. not for those who aren't self confident as the roads are narrow and the people are ever on a mission. Having said that it is an experience you won't find in many places in the world. It has amazing buildings, a stunning atmosphere and a place to see the world at it's most fundamental for any modern city.
Fascinating. Three main interconnecting squares full of fascinating buildings. Great atmosphere and needs an afternoon to do it justice.

Heritage site and 'must visit' location. this is one of the finest concentrations of heritage architecture in Kathmandu - although do also visit the city of Bhaktapur for an even richer cultural experience. Its also a busy intersection for pedestrians and wheeled vehicles - although efforts are being made to control the traffic - and so is a lively part of the modern city. Art objects and curios are usually for sale; as are vegetables and other daily items. Walk slowly down through the old city from Thamel and you will be amazed at Durbar Square when you get there; or drive in from New Road; or up from the river for the best 'first view'
Beautiful!. One of the most beaufitul places in Kathmandu with old pagodas and great architecture. The location is central, so if you are staying in Tamel it's easily accessible on foot.

FASCINATING DURBAR. This beautiful Durbar square is made in a huge premises which is a very well maintained & gives feel of living of Royal Family. It should surely be visited as it let us know the True Sculpture & Touch of Nepali Tradition.

Temples Galore. This was a very busy vibrant place, with ancient temples, big and small, with worshippers making offerings and lighting candles. We were there at festival time so it was very busy. The cost to get in was expensive for tourists.

Interesting but so busy. If you are visiting Kathmandu you really must go to this square, but be aware of the constant crowds and noise, which is typical of most of Kathmandu. Be also aware of the people posing as guides. A guide is a good idea but make sure you use an official guide or one that you can obtain independently, who may include the Square as part of their itinerary for a full tour of the city. You should also go to Durbar Square, Patan, which I thought was better and not so busy
Beware the touts. This is an interesting area to visit. Beware of the touts ... they want to guide you around for a fee. You can easily get around and it is well worth the visit.

No.1 tourist attraction. Well you have to go there at least once, and what a place to take a decent camera! Bit sit on the steps and take in the atmosphere. It deserves the world heritage site status.

Simply stunning. Visited this historical area on our tour with a guide, the buildings are centuries old and stunning, showcasing the ancient crafts. There is also a museum here and of course shrines. The area is used by both tourists and locals alike, some ancient rituals are being revived and historical dance festival was being reintroduced whist we were there. Well worth a visit and a good few photos.
Neat square with plenty of temples. We had a personal guide so we enjoyed the very narrow streets around this square in addition to the many temples available. Go relax and enjoy.

crowded and touristy. this is a nice square.. crowded, lots of temples, the living deity palace, etc... must visit.. the day we went the living deity, Goddess, was likely to not give an apperance, but was still very crowded...

Temples and more temples. A tourist attraction full of temples and tourists. After a couple of temples I was bored, hot and hungry.If you're into history, architecture and politics, go for it. Otherwise it's a 'tick a box' tourist thing to see.

Journey to time tunnel!. It is an amazing place not to be missed.You can enjoy local feel as well as temple.You do not have to rate Kathmandu Durbar Square to Patan and Bakhtapur.Simoly try to make to all three as they deserve it.There is a street market of all sorts of local crafts around the palace.Museum in the palace is good to visit if you are not short of time .
Too crowded. Rather go to Patan to see the old temples. Too much traffic, rather overrated. If not Patan then at leest go and see Bakhtapur
Another of those special places.. Very popular and loads of tourists and pilgrims but a place you must visit. Beautiful temples and palaces.

Iconic landmark of Kathmandu. Kathmandu Durbar Square is Kathmandu's vibrant heart, with amazing ancient temples, a royal palace and the Kumari (The Living Goddess) house. Each temple and stupa presents the richest intricate carvings you can imagine. The square is closed to traffic, so it is pleasant to explore. Entrance is 750 rupees, but this includes the royal palace museum. Do not forget to visit "Freak Street" which is the lane exiting from Durbar Square and the street that made Kathmandu famous as a "Backpackers Hippy Paradise" in the 1960's/70's before Thamel was developed.
A remarkable square. This square is unique with an array of different buildings in differing architectural styles. The square is full of activity both locals and tourists ...a must see.

A busy centre of Kathmandu. There was always a lot going on in the square as I cycled through or when I took visitors into the palace complex. The place to get driving licenseswas situated in the Durbar SQyuare for instance so offices also had to be visited there.
Wonderful way to spend an afternoon.... Comparatively quiet and peaceful, for Kathmandu standards. Check out the Sunny Cafe for lunch. Shopping is more relaxed than in Thamel
Great History. Was there and trully enjoyed it. Enjoyed people watching and the place is rich in history.All kind of people can be seen. Entrance fee was 750 Nepalesse rupees.

Treading in historic footsteps!. With an excellent guide we explored the Hanuman Dhoka Palace complex with its beautifully carved windows, Gaddi Durbar with its white plaster and Greek columns, Kumari Bahal and its living goddess and Vishnupur and Indrapur temples
Old and beautiful. We had to pay to go in which was a little expensive (even in Kathmandu!), but if you like Temples and local wares rhen you will just love this place.

Brilliant. Absolute must in Kathmandu. Unmissable. With or without a guide. The guides may seem pushy at first, but they are a delight and very cheap if you say yes and you get to experience so much more of the history and brilliance of this square.

Madness mixed with history. An amazing area packed with lots of interesting things to see, beautiful buildings and architecture. However very, very busy- and not with tourists either! The peacefulness of temples was blown away by the horns and shouts and we had some interesting dodging moments as mopeds sped through the square (which is saying something, as I live in India!). The museum was interesting but so long and repetitive that we almost ran through the last section.

Durbar square. It's quite a buzzy place to sit and watch. I liked the architectural style of the temples and the sense of history you get. There are some restaurants overlooking the square which are pleasant to rest up in.

A living Newari architecture museum. There are two Durbar Squares one is in Patan / Kathmandu and the other one is in Bakhtapur both are quite similar and filled with Newari architectural pearls and wooden details as they are the master of.The Durbar Square is the place to be either you sit on the steps of many Stupas , walk around or watch the sun go down from one of the temples or cafes one thing is very clear at all times that you are among a very significant architectural gems of Nepal . The Newari are masters of carving and wooden details Don`t do anything just sit among the many local and watch the fabrics hanging on the edges of the roofs wave to give dynamics to the building and get the air in or watch people wonder around aimlessly , carry stuff here and there it is like a "conscious meditation " I love here every time I visit .
Ancient and everyone is there.. Brilliant examples of ancient Nepali architecture, a cacophony of noise, shopping, history, locals eating and hanging out and great sights. A must visit.

Great sights with plenty of shopping. One of the must see places. Crowded with locals and had plenty to offer everyone. Plan on spending 2 hrs hear window shopping and checking out the temples.. Great location for people watching.

great historical place. this is one o the most beautiful places in kathmandu. Its the original city, now called the old city. It has a lot of temples and building of historical and religious significance for Hindus. Not to be missed, preferably take a guide, who shouldn't be difficult to find since the place is overrun with guides. Do bargain a little to make sure you are not cheated. its a small tour and you can give the souvenier shops a miss. Nothing special to buy here.

Feeling of Ancient times. A must visit place for all the tourists either from India or anywhere ... It's a historical exp of how our kings n queens and our people use to stay .... The feeling of going back to times

A must visit. The heart of Kathmandu. Temples, pagodas, shrines, the living Goddess. The architecture is divine, the atmosphere unique. Full of character. If you intend to go back ask the ticket office to give you a pass for the duration of your stay but you must have a photo and your passport with you to get this pass. Well worth it. I went over two days. Best pictures for photographers.

The best Durbar Square!. I enjoyed and liked Bhaktapur Durbar Square compared to the other two: Kathmandu and Patan. It really takes you back to ancient times. It's also not as crowded as the two. I should've stayed at least 2 nights here. My tour guide, Shyam Shresta is also awesome--very knowledgeable, speaks good English and is a great photographer!

memories of monarchy of nepal. Durbar Square is a area where once the palace of the then king was situated,since the monarchy removed it has converted in secretariat and various important offices,still situated just at the doorsteps of Thamel and its good to have a stroll in the evening

Susan Manandhar. Susan is an incredible guide. I visited Nepal over the summer and Susan arranged a couple of private tours around Durbar Square, Swayambhunath, Boudhanath, Pashupatinath, and Patan. Susan arranged everything so that I didn't have to do a thing, and she made the tours a lot of fun, super educational, and definitely memorable! I recommend Susan to friends thinking about a trip to Nepal, and I will absolutely reach out to her anytime I go back. Susan is a terrific tour guide and a wonderful person. Any trip to Nepal will be made infinitely better with Susan at the helm.

a Great Walk Through History. Im usually not one for hiring a guide for these historical sites, but I am glad we did... such a historic part of Nepal... was great to learn about the politics, art and architecture... so many different influences established Ancient Nepal... Go Here... Get a Guide, I negotiated 500 INR, but ended up tipping double.... a great walk through History

Brilliant to see. The architecture and hustle and bustle of Durbar Square are all great to see. However I do not think that it is worth 750 rupees per person to visit. (there is one entrance with no ticket counter, but there is a maze of streets hiding it).

Tourist trap. As of writing this entry is 750NRP ($7.50, £4.70), a couple of years ago I was reading it was around 200-300NRP, if there was something worth seeing then fine but your best bet is to come via the western side of Durbar Square and if you're stopped by one of the loathsome guards, tell them you're going to Freak St. or your guest house is here and you don't need a ticket and keep walking on with confidence. The admission cost is steep and a total con and from what I read doesn't really go back into preservation of this place or at least not preserving it properly.We walked around briefly and quickly concluded that we would have felt totally ripped off if we'd have paid 1500NRP for entry.

Amazing !!!!. Amazing "square" beautiful at sunset. Great place to people watch, to take plenty of amazing pictures, relax. Try one of the roof top cafes (see recommendation in Lonely Planet). They have one of the best momos and fried beef rice. If you stay in Thamel definitely do the walk to Durban Square. Very interesting and great introduction to Kathmandu.
Beautiful. Lovely and beautiful.Especially where the pigeons are, quite nice.Recommended, and dont forget your camera.
A nice place to visit. Not that impressive, but it is good to visit it while you are staying in Kathmandu.Most squares look like the same, what differs is just the place of each.
Lot of history. A great place if you are into history and culture. Lot of people around - very busy. Arrange your transport before hand as taxi rates are on the higher side. Avoid weekends.

Fairly expensive, it was OK. It was crowded, loud and expensive. The price was about $15 for the two of us. No photography or backpacks were allowed inside the palace museum portion which was really annoying. The museum itself was cool, the view from the top of the tower was really good and walking around the grounds was a lot of fun.

excellent. A must see in kathmandu. amazing temples and palace. Don't forget yo tske a couple of passport size photos and your passport number so you can get free re entry for the period of your visa as quite expensive and too much to tske in on a single visit
A lot off people. When you go sitting on a rooftop restaurant you have a nice view about Durbar Square. A lot off different people are walking about the square.

Expected More. Maybe I missed something, but I spent two hours walking round the square / area and failed to grasp the significance of the older buildings. They seemed to be places where locals sit with nothing to do. It was not a friendly or particularly enjoyable experience, but I suppose I can tick it off the list as a place seen. My highlight was from above, where I stood and photographed eagles soaring high in the sky - now that was amazing.

Essential Kathmandu. Beautiful architecture, culture and history. A definite must-see in Kathmandu. Forget the rickshaws and go on foot to soak it all in. Find a place to sit and watch the world go by. Fascinating.
Magnificent architecture. Beautiful Temples, Baths, Lots if Shops again for little buys...The cravings of the walls, windows and doors was really amazing...such Great Talent...
Too crowded fine ancient place. A place filled with many tourists yet more worshipers and people praying. We saw a lot of poor people yet you can still see the hope and humbleness in their hearts.

This is an absolute *must*. Where else can you see such beautiful preservation of so many glorious historic buildings in such a small space, and learn the history of a whole culture while admiring them? It's essential you hire a guide to explain all the various facts.
Finest Place for arts. Its marvelous. Fine arts and its ancients temples and palaces are outstanding. All museums, art gallery and stupas of Malla kings are the best part of Kathmandu Durbar Sqaure.
Very good but very crowded due to Diwali festival and parades. Love all the temples - disliked the crowds and the car and bikes in the square which I belive is now being stopped

Durbar Square-Kathmandu. The entire complex consists of buildings with very ornate wood working, even among the dust you could recognize the attention to detail that was put into these buildings. There is a lot to see with all the Hindu deities being worshipped. Some of the structures are done in pogoda style which lends diversity to the square and the Kumari chowk is quite interesting. Just off the square there is a variety of places to eat and Freak St. if not just a replica for old times sake is pretty cool to stroll down.

Traditional Nepal. If you're staying in the Thamel area, chances are this is just a simple walk down the road, and a must visit on your list.Beautiful place and highlights traditional Nepal from their architecture, royalty and religious beliefs. If you come before noon, you may be able to catch a glimpse of Kumari, the living goddess.
Worth to take a look of the historical sculptures. It is a nice plaza. It is worth to take a look of the historical sculptures. Its beauty cannot be told until you see it on your own. GO~
absolutely a must. If you visit Kathmandu you have to visit Durbar Square as well. all the old temples the life there even the beggars and street sellers are a charming part of it

Nice Architecture. Have to pay to enter the site, but it is a reasonable amount. The buildings are quite nice. Sellers abound and will follow you around if they get the chance. We really liked the narrow cobblestone streets and old buildings.

A must see. The longer you sit and watch the more you see.. Great to people watch and generally watch the world go by. A meze of smells, colours and sights. Probably one of the best days of my life was spent here watching the world go by and visiting all of the truly magnificent buildings.

Beautiful chaos!. I have visited 3 durbar squares in kathmandu (kathmandu, patan, and bhaktapur). Kathmandu durbar square is the most chaotic maybe because it is in the capital. A lot of interesting temples and palaces though. If you have time to visit inly one durbar square, i would recommend going to bhaktapur, it has a more authentic and ancient feel!

Kathmandu Khaos. I think there was some kind of festival on when I was there, because it seemed really busy ...it seemed like an enhanced extension of the chaos of Kathmandu ...truly a great place to people watch, as well as check out the history of this amazing, chaotic city!

Great and varied architecure. Great place and worth a visit for half a day atleast. One should spend time in watching and understanding the architecture. There are different styles within the same place. The only place , I think, which a temple of Bheem ( one of the five Pandavas from Mahabharata).
Depressingly interesting. Was very interesting, especially the cremations by the river but I did find it rather depressing. Quite expensive to get in as well, 1000 rupees.

Amazing. Loved the temples, and the historical aspect of this place.
Day and night you will love this place.
Always crowded with people and there are many things to do around.
A must see
The one in Bhaktaphur is better. I was able to visit the Durbar Square in Bhaktaphur which I think is a lot lovelier, perhaps because there were less tourists there.
The Center of old Kathmandu. Very interesting architecture; great people watching and handy shops. Allow enough time to browze and eat nearby.
