Centre of town. This is in the old historic centre of Kathmandu. You have to pay to go into the area as a foreigner. Take a guide with you if you can so you have someone to explain the statues to you and allow yourself plenty of time to sit down and look around. Hindu temples are out of bounds to non-Hindus - a surprise if you are used to being welcomed in India - but there is plenty to see and admire.

Less attractive and chaotic.... We visited there in the morning and found some political stage is being made ready to occur..... local vegetable marketplace ..the entry fee for Indians is Rs.150 each and since kathmandu has lot of indian looking nepali.. the entry fee could easily be skipped if you look like one...but we didn't... as per the art and architecture is concerned it is way low to patan and bhaktapur.. but we still enjoyed.

Great Kathmandu tour guide - Susan Manandhar. We hired Susan to take us around Kathmandu for our first visit. Susan communicated with us handily over email before we arrived, asking all the right questions and preparing us for what she offered. Everything went seamlessly and Susan met us at our hotel in the Thamel disctrict with her driver AC included!) for a drive to places we wanted to see. She had some ideas herself and was flexible when we wanted one place different from what she planned. Susan is a wealth of knowledge about her city and we know we got so much more out of our tour with her expertise. She knew where to take us to look at less kitschy items, like real silver jewelry and Thanka paintings and neither she or the shopkeepers put any pressure on us us to buy anything. I cannot say enough good things about Susan's professionalism or expertise. Wish we had her in Varanasi! Susan Moray

Cultural density. Every Nepali here has told me that Bhaktapur Durbar Square in the best among three squares, but Kathmandu's one is still my favorite. It might be a bit small than the one in Bhaktapur but it's so beautiful and very much culturally concentrated with lots of local shops around the area. I suggest you read a little bit about some of significant features of the square before visiting. It'll be a thousand times more interesting than just going there and looking at all the temples without knowing a thing about it. Some of the highlights are:-Kumari house (Kumari Ghar)-Kasthamandap (Kathmandu is named after this wooden building)-The sculpture of Lord Shiva and his consort Parvati- The Golden doorway to Hanuman Dhoka Palace

a must. we were dissapointed that this beautiful place can be visited only if you pay a lot of money...but it's worth it...just wonder around and if you can - take a guide to explain you everything...

Worth the trip. This is the best of the Durbar squares perhaps because of the lack of traffic and just the locals going about their day. The buildings are the same as the other Durbar squares but you can relax and really enjoy. Well worthy the cheap taxi ride.

Kathmandu's Super Duper Durbar Square. A definite 'must see' Durbar square. Of the 3 I visited (Bakhtapur, Patan being the other two) this is probably my favourite. The day we visited was my first day in Kathmandu and the square set me up to get in the swing of the wonderful Nepalese culture. The sights, the smells, the joyful noise, the cafe/bars, the market stalls and the statues and murals, bells and gongs, offerings to the gods were all so fabulous. I loved it here. I especially enjoyed sitting on the balcony of a cafe bar on the second floor, looking down and people watching. You readers who haven't been here need to try it out. What great memories I have of this place.

old hippie street. the old hippie area of freak street is here, follow the trails n ask the locals, back in the 60s and 70s marijuana n hashish was freely sold here but now illegal! some kool spots to hang out n sip some chai though exists! and still some areas have the feel of old nepal.

Palace square. Once, some 50 years or earlier it must have been a magical place. i love this place in the early mornings n late afternoons, the vibe is really nice and people moving n chilling. street food and plenty of smiles and friendly people that strike up chats:-)sit down on one of the temple stairs n enjoy the buzz of kathmandu! the old hippie capital and now transition in the making between the ancient n modern!
Good for street photography. This is a good place for street photography. You can walk down from Thamel to this place and you will see the activities of people over there.
Nice place to visit but expensive. Nice place with lots of history but 750nrs to get in is a little pricey. enjoyed sitting on the steps and watching the world go by.

A maze of wonders. This is a huge complex of temples and shops and boutiques and people and energy. You will need at least 2-3 hours to enjoy this place. When you purchase your ticket, ask for a map - it is very helpful and also gives you a little history of all the key points of interest.
Exotic. This is a must see, if you're in Kathmandu. Ancient temples mixed in with shops. Shows the walled off nature of these old cities. Great souvenir shopping in the bazaars as well.

Worth a wander around. Does every old town in Nepal has a Durbar Square ? Kathmandu, Patan and Bakthapur certainly have one each . While the best is the one at Bakthapur, this one is worth wandering around for two or three hours. The architecture is rather unique and pretty amazing and its no wonder its designated as a world heritage site.The carvings on on the exteriors of the temples are exceptional with the ones in the Hanuman Dhoka square being the best. The palace itself is not all that impressive, while the museum housed in it was a disappointment;. After walking around the first floor, which displays only photographs of King Tribhuvan and a few of his son, we gave the upper floors a miss as the circular wooden stairs looked too forbidding for our senior citizen legs.The stone steps around the palace are surprisingly high for a country where the people tend to be rather short.Besides the handicraft vendors there are a number of restaurants where you can have a bite and watch the world go by. The Himalayan Java Coffee shop was our favorite.Since we were from a SAARC country, we got a substantial discount on the entry ticket.

The Trip Might Be Better Than the Destination. There are many, many Durbar Squares throughout Nepal, but THE Durbar Square in Katmandu is worth checking out. We used the walking tour included in the Lonely Planet Nepal book and it took well more than an hour to travel from Thamel to Durbar Square. Along the way we found ourselves in the markets frequented by locals rather than tourists, and that made the trip so worth it! When we got to the edge of Durbar Square, we ate at a rooftop garden, which afforded great views of the square.Once we go to the actual square, we didn't actually go in. For our group of four to walk around the area it would have cost $30 USD and that just didn't seem worth it. I'm glad we got close, though!

Must Visit when in Kathmandu. This place is a beautiful tourist attraction in Kathmandu. The buildings give perspective to Nepali History. Ensure to bargain to at least 1/3rd of of the offered price if your buying anything from the vendors.
Realy like this. When you wake about the place and cross the Kumari house go drink thee of coffee on a rooftop restaurant and you can the hole place see. Nice to see the people from the roof.
Hustle an bustle. Fantastic to see local produce and the local way of life in a market, full of fantastic shrines and temples. Loved this area. A must visit

Entrance Fee Not Required. Its worth going to, and there are multiple different Durbar Squares in different parts of the city. They charge anywhere from 750-1500 rupees for foreigners to enter. Each of the several times I have gone I just walk past the ticket booth and go in. I was living in the city for months so if I paid each time I had to walk through it would have been silly. If you have the money it is a nice thing to support, but if you don't have the money than don't feel bad about walking in without paying. You may be stopped by a guard inside and asked for a ticket (more likely to happen in Patan than in Thamel) but at that point you can either leave or pay for a ticket.
How many temples?. An iconic must visit and imagine the hippies sitting on the steps! All of life is here. A great photographic opportunity but beware of the touting guides.

Fascinating religious, must-see site. Spent a leisurely couple of hours being guided around the interesting variety of historic, religious architecture.
There is a lot to take in, but it is easy enough to enjoy the intricacy of the symbolism, without worrying about the details.
Add in the usual bustling crowds for plenty of local street level sights and sounds
A tourist must visit. A complex with a lot of things to see. If you are lucky, you can see the Kumari. There is also a bazar with a lot of handicraft to buy.

interesting place. Durbar is a must see and hard to miss location in the heart of the capital city. The immediate large square is surrounded by ancient Newari architecture, high temples, popular shrines and the old royal palace. We were very lucky because we have visited this place during a festival with a lot of people and music.

Still good on a wet rainy day!. Would have been greater on a nice sunny day, unfortunately the rain and mud kinda of spoilt the visit. It is worth going here, as there is so much to see. The young Kumari needs to be seen, and get a book to read about this religious tradition.

Must-see in Kathmandu. Very interesting and amazing with the large Hanuman Dhoka Museum (with many items of the former Nepali kings) and especially the Kumari House where you can see the "living goddess".

Great however very touristic. A must I suppose when visiting Kathmandu, but it is forgiven with tourists and many shops accomodating their thirst for local trinkets, probably best enjoyed out of the tourist season, also take into consideration an entrance fee to Bhaktapur. It is stunning to see though the many restored buildings to their former glory and a deff must when trying to see the typical architecture.

Dingy and glorious. The architecture is amazing, so different than anything I've ever seen before. However, the traffic is ridiculous, kind of takes away from the magic of it (but that's the way it is in all of Kathmandu)
A history you can touch. You can climb up the Ancient buildings, and feel the history by yourself. Locals there are quite friendly.Don't like the drunk guide who followed us the entire time.
First Square you will visit in KTM. Probably the first place to visit in KTM before you actually mature to better architecture. Must visit anyways. Nicely maintained as well.

A must visit!. A lovely square. Lots to see. Can spend some time walking or sitting. Many photo opportunities. We were fortunate to see the Living Goddess Kumari on the day we visited. She made an appearance in the window of her "palace". The architecture is astounding. Another major attraction is the Hanuman Dhoka. There are too many to mention. Really put aside a couple hours and spend some time at the square.

a nice place to pass some time. If you are between treks or you have several hours to spend, this place is nice to pass some time or drink a cold drink on one of the rooftops. I didnt find anything too special or interesting there. The Durbar square in Baktapur is much more interesting. not matter what, don't enter the "museum" of the king. that place is really boring and not clear what they want to tell there.
Heartstopping Beauty. Mystical experience for me, it should be known as the Taj Mahal is known, the ancient temples look like the Disneyland of world religions....see it, do not read about it.....

Fascinating architecture in the heart of Kathmandu. One the 3 'world heritage" squares in Kathmandu, the square is a complex of numerous 16th and 17th century buildings and includes the Hanuman dhoka palace which was the seat of the Malla and Shah kings. It is a classic example of Newari Pagoda architecture was It is suggested the that the origins of the square date back to the third century. We were fortunate to visit the square on the day of Dussehra, the most important day in the Nepalese calendar. Numerous temples, museums and residences clutter the area. The buildings were decked up with festoons, frills - all in bright red colour.. The palace itself has intricate decorative wooden doors and windows, and shows traces of Newari, European and muslim architecture. The Taleju temple opens its doors only once a year and we were fortunate to be there!Our only problem was the overcrowding and jostling..We were unable to spend time enjoying the square in peace.. A must visit when in Kathmandu.. A must see in Kathmandu..

Interesting and beautiful. There are many beautiful buildings and tempels on the "Square", but also many "guides", touts and people trying to sell anything from chicken and goat to purses, and at the same time cars and motor bikes honk their horns and pass you quickly, so it's hard to get all the beauty of this place. Would be better, if they did like in Bakthapur and prohibeted cars in the area.Also the price to get in is steep - 750 rupee per person!

travel to the past. Extraordinary complex of temples and buldings dated bach to 17th century.. Worth visiting. The place where "Kumari" lives. A young girl 7-8 years old who is believed to be blessed and whose blessings are valuable.. to believers, of course.

Amazing architecture and history. Hang on to your hat for some amazing history and sites. The architecture is beautiful. The culture is exotic. There is a living "Goddess" in one of the buildings here. Be prepared for the barrage of "guides" and flute vendors, but this is a must see. Sit in the Himalayan Java café and watch the people as they go by after visiting the temples and the palace.

A reflection of the local culture. Kathmandu Durbar Square is the plaza in front of the old royal palace of the then Kathmandu Kingdom. It is one of three Durbar (royal palace) Squares in the Kathmandu Valley in Nepal, all of which are UNESCO World Heritage Sites. The Durbar Square is surrounded with spectacular architecture. We also visited the Kumari Mahal and got an audience with the 'Kumari'. Jayaprakash Malla, the last Malla king to rule Kathmandu, built a temple for Kumari and Durga in her virginal state. The temple was named Kumari Bahal. In his house resides the Kumari, a girl who is revered as the living goddess. He also made a chariot for Kumari and in the courtyard had detailed terra cotta tiles of that time laid down. The Kumari palace has beautifully intricate carvings all around.

Expensive. The square has a 750 npr entrance fee p.p. this is a lot for what you get to see. I wouldn't pay it. And it is possible to avoid the entrance fee. We accidental did it. We entered the square through an alley. When you are on the plain. Make sure you go dance with the piggets. Believe me. Its more fun then it sounds. Just 3 stars because of the insane entrance fee

Beuatiful piece of Nepalese heritage. Once you get over the sea of touts and tour guides trying to sellyou their services, this place is amazing to simply wonder around and enjoy the magnificient scenary of its architecture and temples.Advice: Do get a good English speaking guide of this is your first time. There are many thingsthat will be pointed out to you that you would not otherwise see
So-so. Not the best experience. Too much crowd, the group of shrines at the northwestern end exudes a calming atmosphere in the evening.

Fascinating. A must to visit. I just love watching life going on. So colourful. Such diversity. The buildings ... Palaces, shrines etc are all very interesting and as festival time, even more undertaking their rituals.

Must see. Durbar Square is overwhleming, as well as the city of Kathmandu itself. Not one temple, not two, but dozens, of all shapes and sizes, right next to each other in a huge complex that brings up old times sensations. Overall pretty well preserved.

average attraction. what bothered us most was that we had to pay entrance fee with everything being closed due to the dashain festival. they did offer us to stamp the ticket and return two days later - which only would have been possible if we had stayed in kathmandu longer.
apart from that it was an ok view but nothing spectacular
Ok, but overpriced. This place is ok, lots of market stalls and a few temples to look at, but very crowded and at 750 NPR it is expensive for what it is. Worth a look but not top of the list.
Cool spot. Go check it out, it's worth a visit. Some interesting history there, but overall you won't want to spend too too much time there.

Not worth the fiver you pay. It costs around £5 to walk around this square and see some not very stunning sights and avoid fake yogi men trying to pose for a photo for money. The one in Patan is better.

splendid. It is great to see these magnificent old temples. maybe the best part is that they are part of the current daily life, when I was there it was the stage for a couple of guys doing a nepali rap/breakdance performance. People just stroll there, drink tea, buy & sell stuff, it is great to hangout and make lots of beautiful photo's.

Must visit. its an amazing place to hangout and a place to see temples, palace, living goddess, museum.. it is filled with culture and history. There are a lot of restaurants or you can just walk around and sit there at a corner and watch all the people.

Expensive. A beautiful structure but over priced. It costs 750 NR each to enter the square. We thought this was over priced and so we sat in a roof top cafe over looking the square and viewed it from there.

The real Kathmandu. A great area for shopping for saris and other local outfits and street food. You will usually get charged a local price, instead of higher prices in shops around Thamel. It's nice to take a rickshaw around, as well as walking.

Great Place, Stunning Views but Tourists expensive. This is a wonderful heritage location - temples, great museums and fine buildings whilst all around you people carry on there daily lives. The cost of entry is about GBP 8 and you need a ticket but this also means pestering but the local touts - albeit done in a friendly way. The squares is magical and seeing it early in the morning or late in the afternoon is best. It is of course overwhelmed by every singe visitor to Nepal.Relax, enjoy sitting, go to a cafe and eat, walk around but do see the Museum and just chill - its what you are supposed to do

Back to the past. Stepping into the square feels like you are back into the ancient city of Kathmandu. Culture, religion, and traditional livelihood of the people. Definitely a worthy UNESCO World Heritage Site that you mustn't missed.

Another must see. Yes, Kathmandu has lots of sights, but here is a great collection of old buildings and a nice museum of the palace. Enjoy the buzz around, sit on one of the benches and check the people pass by. Very interesting.Even more recommendable is the durbar in Patan, a bit more quiet and also very impressive.
Must visit Place. Actually i'm getting confused. It is a combination of so many temples , a palace, assembly square within a huge area
Must Visit Place. Hundreds years ages. A huge area with so many temples and a white palace where the Nepal king live before

Enchanting Cultural and historical Palace area. Basantapur is one of the UNESCO world heritage site in Nepal . This place contains ancient temples , palaces and courthouses now curated as museum .This place is very famous place to hangout among youngsters and tourists , very close to the center of the city . There are plenty of different restaurants and coffee shops.
very busy. lots and lots of tourist , a few temples to visit, plenty of souvenirs to buy. It is one of the main tourist attraction in Kathmandu
Classic. The square is very beautiful. I can stay in the square for hours and hours. It is also very educational. I learned a lot about the culture of the country.
Very Nice Historical Place. It is really a historical place, with lot of Temples, Kings old place and Museum. In the center of the city, busy place with lot of people visiting.

cool place to take pictures. Its cool and walkable from Thamel. you can totally avoid the 750 rupee entry fee by just walking in (try another side if caught) and you can say you live on freak street and must pass through. Very cool foto opps. Be aware ! those "holy Men",et are gladly posing for pics and then demand money...just walk away and act unaware, as they are too embarrassed to actually chase you and make a scene.haha
Very busy!. In the middle of Kathmandu, very busy site. Many temples to see, and great place to people watch! Be mindful of many people trying to sell you something or guide you around.

Busy Commercial District. The roads are wider, the sidewalks as well. However there are occasional vendors that are blocking the way along the sidewalks. More stores with nice window displays are open. You can find branded clothing, shoes, bags items here. Restaurants like KFC, Pizza Hut and specialty cuisines are here (Thai, Italian, Indian, Chinese) and the Annapurna Coffee Shop, which closes late. There are also new coffee shops to try like Brew, etc. There is traffic jam during rush hours.

Bussy. Lots to see and bring a camera! Reasonable shopping but be prepared to haggel. Try one of the resturants one the top floors in buildings around the temple. Worth the visit, but the backstreets around is also.

Nice Historical Place. With a lot of tourists. Local people trans passes through here and some of them come here for chatting-gossiping. There should be a well placed board for historical info. Some of us doesn't like to listen to guides all the time.

Open museum... Must visit , just amazing!!!. The history, scenes and architecture of this area are not to be missed. Have a guide take you so as you fully understand what you are seeing. Photographers paradise, and make sure you walk all the little side street areas.

nice place to but souvenir.. I went there a day after the festival for the chariot parade of their living goddess. Nice bazaar in the square. A place to get souvenirs and have fun haggling but please respect the local by not quoting too low a price or u will see that they r happy to sell to the next customer.
cool!. Lots to see and do! Reasonable shopping but more people watching and temple viewing. Loved it, worth the visit.

a lot of things to see. You will need a lot of time to enjoy it because there are a lot of temples, palaces and things to see. Carry a photo of you and get a visa to enter when you want. Go to Tourist Office at Basantapur Square with the photo, your passaport and your entry to Nepal visa and they will give you a card with the permission.
Good Local Attraction. The architecture of the place is very nice. A good spot to do some street shopping . Evenings are full of tourists . overall a good place to visit
Tipical Nepali square. Highlight.. It's the tipical nepali square. Very similar to Patan square and Baktapur square. You must see at least one of them.
Western style place in Kathmandu. Kathmandu Durbar Square is a magnificent place to stroll around and spend some time on food and buying branded materials.
center square. the city centre main square with lots of pagodas en temples, this is a must see. Lots of local vendors, don't be fooled, not all of them sell 'ancient' crafts.

Impressive, crowded.. If you have little time, skip this and visit Patan or Bhaktapur durbur square. In any other case, it's a few hours visit and easiliy included in a walk through Thamel. Don't use personal guides, they're expensive and not really that good.

Lots of history. There is a lot of Nepalese history here, but use a good guide book, don't take up with an unemployed person--they will know about the gods and the temples, but the history not so much. So thisv is basically a concentration of temples and shrines, a few Buddhist, a lot Hindu, and none of them really special. It's also a concentration of beggars and touts, mostly selling the same mass-produced knock-offs you find everywhere in Kathmandu--though, looking carefully, you might find something good. It's worth spending a few minutes at the main office to convert your 200 NR entrance fee into a pass that will last your whole trip. Two reasons: it will make it easy to get through to Freak Street if you want to try more than one restaurant there; and, it's an interesting keepsake.

Be careful... Now entrance fee is more expensive because, now it automatically includes ticket to museum and Basantapur. If you once pay for it, take your passport size photography and your passport and go to tourist office for permission that allows you to visit Durbar until rest of your visa. Ask on the place where you buy ticket they show you on the map, where exactly is tourist office located. Durbar square is nice place, full of history. While you will watch temples, be careful on pigeon’s excrements. You can watch daily life of local people there as well. Also be careful, there are some men that look friendly, and they will start talk with you. They will explain you things about square and they tell you they are not guides but on the end they want you to buy very expensive paintings, you can get everywhere in Nepal. Say them NO on the beginning, because after it is difficult to get rid of them.

Now entrance fee include entrance to the Basantapur. Don’t forget climb to the top of tower while you are in Basantapur square. There is amazing view on each side of Kathmandu and on Durbar square from there. Not recommend for people with problems with knees or legs, because stairs are very steep and you can easily injured yourself. Now entrance fee is higher and include also entrance to the museum which is connected with Basantapur, and Basantapur tower.

Historic Buildings Are A True Sight To See!. I spent a morning here looking at the numerous sites and sights from Nepal's colorful past. It has been designated as a UNESCO World Heritage Site and is well preserved. I recommend that those who visit here should spend at least a full day to see everything as there is so much to see and photograph. I was able to get a photo with a very willing Gurkha soldier who posed with me. I've heard so much about their fighting skills and, as a former soldier in the US Army, but now way as fierce in reputation as him, that I just had to pose along with him. This site, along with Bhaktapur, have significant importance in the history and for the people of Nepal.

Why pay 800 rupees when the locals get in for free?. Unfair pricing, too bad they let touts and beggars in for free which only adds insult to injury. Trust no one, many try to be your guide, tell them to fick off and get a real job. I used a trusted bike rickshaw driver for a guide in Kathmandu and he eliminated many of the hassles that a traveler has to put up with here. The Monkey Temple is just as interesting and only charges 300 rupees to enter. I recommend that over Dubar square an some of the other rip-offs.

Kathmandu Guide. Susan was our guide for two days, when we explored Kathmandu, Patan and Bhaktapur. She is an excellent guide and was a great source of information. She has been a teacher in the past and this is evident in the way she explains the history of the city in a concise and understandable way. She has a wealth of information and is happy to share as much, or as little, as you want. I would unreservedly recommend her for individual or group tours.

Oldest historic part of Kathmandu. Very interesting oldest part of Kathmandu.
Nice restaurants and palace.
After visit it is nice to walk around in nearby streets

Nothing special. In the evening ,we were walking along the street beside Royal palace. We saw a Square in front of the old royal palace of the Kathmandu Kingdom.The square is presently known as Hanuman Dhoka, a name derived from the statue of Hanuman, the monkey devotee of Lord Ram, near the entrance of the palace.

Quite Average. Nothing special. Markets, Shopping, Lanes, Traffic. Not exactly the best place to visit.
But again if your a first time traveller to Nepal, make sure you do.

Nepalese Cultural Heritage. Basantapur is place located very close to Kathmandu. It is mainly popular for its historical structures such as the Darbar Square. There are plenty of food stores around and you can try the authentic local cuisines. It is also known as the 'Old City' or 'City of Old People' since a lot of seniors citizens are seen here. I think we paid NPR 700 to get in. Overall the place is nice and worths a visit if you're in Kathmandu.
dont miss it. hello every one you most have to visit this place this is one of best place to see in kathmandu.its build during 16th century.here you can see living godes called kumari as well.

Ok but really run down and poorly managed. We never like the fact they charge people of a different ethnic back ground more money. You can easily go in a back way to access this sight as it is very over priced for such a run down square; the money by the way never seems to make it to the correct hands due to corruption in Nepal so don't feel guilty.

The centre of the town. It is the centre of the town that can be interesting to see. the best part was the tall building that you can visit and go to the top and from there see all the city and stay in peace and quiet far from the chaos of Thamel or the busiest roads around.another place to go is the Kumari Kiosk where, if you are lucky you can see at the balcony the young life goodness
Everything on one place. This is a must see. Although it might be more than crowded, please go see. Be aware tourist trap alert

Worth shopping. We enjoyed shopping, but bargaining is needed up to 40-50% levels. Crossing roads could be a night mare at peak hours. Too many bars, with few restaurants with out serving alcoholic drinks. can't get fruits any where.

World Heritage site with millions of people ruining its beauty. Beautiful World Heritage building clustered together in one zone. Badly cared for with people selling stuff all around, sitting on the steps and vehicles moving around in the center. The local authorities need to care for the place and make it more secure and clean. Local people should respect the property and keep its beauty intact.

Step back in time. Standing at the entrance, you think "this looks interesting" and you would be right. A truly amazing place, culturally, architecturally and historically engaging. If you have ever visited Carcassonne Cite and thought that was cool, this will blow you away! Like walking onto an Indiana Jones film set, Elizabethan London and Black & White movies from the 1920' s combined. People charming. If taking little ones, would love to hear the explanations given about the wood carving in one of the temples. Go, enjoy it, your life will be richer if you do and if it isn't afterwards, then there is no hope for you !

Genuine Antiques and Antiques made Yesterday..... A great place to buy items from Nepal, the market stalls are set up in approximately 3 or 4 rows the length of the square. As the title insinuates there are some new antiques along side the old ones, lots of great items from silver jewellry to carved Buddha's. Surrounding the square is the old royal palace, well worth a hike up the 9 levels of the tower.
Just awesome. Mad if you miss it. Temples, bazaars, food, tea/coffee, smells, people. It has it all. You can send ages there.

Historical expo. Kathmandu Durbar Square is a must visit place for any tourists. There are lots of monuments to see inside the Square like Kasthamandap, the Temple for Living Goddess- Kumari, Taleju Temple. Also visit the Hanuman Dhoka museum inside the square. It definitely can take you aback to the history of Nepal. Durbar Square may feel crowded sometimes as its a favorite junction for local youths but what troubles more is the vehicles inside this heritage area. I think the management should do something about it and allocate alternate road other than the heritage area. Also, beware of the guides with fake Ids. Its better to book a registered guide from any travel agency in advance.

Susan Manandhar. Susan Manandhar is a wonderful private tour guide for day tours of the most important sites in Kathmandu. She is warm and kind and a veritable encyclopedia of information about the history art and architecture of the city. A few months after my tour, my son made the trip to Kathmandu and also hired Susan for a private day tour. We both enjoyed her guidance very much.

A must. Central square with historical buddhist and hindu temples from various periods and kinds palace. Really nice wooden architecture and statues of gods. Numerous stupas and interesting souvenirs to buy at the square. Go see it!

Rhapsody of Colors. Durbar Square is a must see place if you are in Kathmandu. This world heritage site used to be the seat of one of the Royal families of Nepal. The place is compact with temples (big and small) and if you are lucky like us, you will see religious activities such as veneration ritual to the deities. There were singing and dancing and the women were wearing gorgeous dresses in all colors. It was quite an experience seeing all those people in colorful costumes.

Its a historical place - nice to visit.. The place was in kind of center of kathmandu. I really like those ancient sculptures. Its actually a small square. You can eat some delicious street food around. In the way, you will enjoy a lot a shops.

Tourist trap. Having been to Kathmandu on many occasions I cannot help notice the stark differences each time I go there. It's like someone lit a bulb in the heads of hundreds of human leeches in order that they can annoy the living daylights out of vulnerable tourists.I have known Durbar square to be a pretty ornate place to visit, un-hassled, relaxed and something to see without being annoyed by persistent leeches who don't understand the meaning of NO.Pay attention to fake guides, even though they will produce a Guides ID...it's likely to be fake. Arrange tours ahead of your visit, online and get a knowledgeable committed guide not a money grabber who has no clue as to what they are doing.Sadu's or holy men will resent you taking a photo and the hand will be out quickly for money if you do, and that's provided you can, as they have copped-on to the fact that tourists are in general stupid, and gullible and have turned their "holiness" into a trade, they cover their faces with cardboard if the see a camera and force you to approach them for a photo at a price, and maybe they are not all genuine Sadu's, but they do make for a good photo. Don't rush into photographing the first one you see and negotiate, you will see more Sadu's at other sites across Kathmandu that are more willing to be photographed at little or no cost.Visit the place of the living Goddess, just off the square, a reputable guide will arrange a visit there (there is a fee to enter), no photos permitted of the Goddess if she appears from her balcony, you will be watched. Visit the street occupied by European hippies in the sixties which is just beside the Square and the Palace of the living Goddess also for a trip, (not that type of trip), down memory lane and see where all the hippy shops are. Watch out for groups of young teenagers who are pickpocket gangs, these operate throughout Kathmandu and especially at tourist sites and Thamel, they often masquerade as "guides" complete with fake ID and you will be a wallet lighter if you engage with them...you've been warned. The Square and the adjacent surrounding are definitely worth a visit, but get a reputable guide.

Crowded place. Once upon a time this place was known for its' Royal value as the Royal Palace is situated here and the place was well guarded.As the royalty ended in Nepal, the charm of Durbar Square also vanished. Now a days you can just walk with crowd and do shopping. Some well known shopping brands and eateries make this place worthy to visit.

Interesting but unfortunately so filthy. This area has some amazing history but you need to be ready for the many peddler sand 'guides' who hassle you for the opportunity to take you around and explain many of the temples. We paid our guide what we thought was a fair price but he was clearly very disappointed so best to negotiate before if you choose to take one of these guides on. Like so much of Nepal the rubbish and filth lying around is disappointing and takes a lot away from the experience.
Old yet unique. The visit to Basantpur the older city was excellent. The museum here was amazing. The idol of Hanuman is still revered this day.

Hectic visit. The Durbar Square is more a commercial belt than a royal passage these days with all the major brands having positioned themselves well in the big commercial buildings dotting along the way.
Right place to shop. Could find plenty of Pasmina shawls,sweaters .Best part there was no bargains and we enjoyed purchasing as there were pixel prices

where a cultural loving person should go. There's a museum in the palace. Lots of things to see. Around the palace, many temples and shops are there. The living Goodness house is also there. Definitely a worth to visit place.

A truly traditional experience. Durbar Square is home to many Hindu Temples, still very much as they would have been 400 years ago.Durbar Square is a great place to take in some real old style Kathmandu. However, be prepared to be harassed. There was no respite from it until I went into a restaurant or café.

So so. Disappointing that foreigners are expected to pay 70rupees to walk down the road, even though i do understand that the money is needed to rejuvenate the area, but that is a lot of cash!You can get in around the side without paying. It is o.k, but if you are time conscious you could give it a miss and head to another more exciting place, like the crematoria!
Culture and History.. Anyone who is visiting Nepal who is interested in culture and historical significance will enjoy a visit to Durbar square and its surrounds.

Tourist trap!!!. Don't go there, you have to pay a lot to see nothing!This is a big squat for nepalese people who do nothing of their days: they are just there, seated on the temples, smoking, ... So you cannot see the temples because of them!A lot of noise (Horns), way too crowded and even if it is said (UNESCO) temples are in really bad condition!Harassment by fake guides and fake "nepalese in traditional clothes".Go to the Durbar squares of Patan or Bhaktapur instead!!!

The Ancient City - A Must See!. The ancient city of Bhaktapur and Durbar Square are located about 8 miles (13 km) east of Kathmandu. The brick streets, the amazing architecture, and the friendly people make this a must see attraction in KTM Valley! The city dates back 800 years and served at one time as the Capitol of Nepal. Visitors are immediately captivated by its rich culture, history, temples, and wood, metal and stone artworks.A ticket is required for entrance ($15 usd) but is well worth the expense. The money helps support preservation and restoration of the ancient site.

Colours full square. This is my second time to visit Durbar Square after 11 years. I still love to come back here. Everything still remain traditional and unchanged, especially the people are friendly and lovely. While the architecture of the building and temple, it's worth the visit. Bring your camera and gets some awesome shots of the people, especially the woman with very sharp and colourful saris. People, building and temple will bring you first experience of Nepal.

A group of temples in Durbar Square. A number of old Pagoda type temples are there. Puja is not performed these days in most of them. Maintenance of the area with proper signage for each temple is necessary. Museum inside is good. You have to buy Ticket for entry.

a must do sightsee. while its not the most phenomenal of the squares in Nepal, it still has a charm and beauty about it that's worth a visit - one of those "i've been there" moments. Just watch who/what you take pictures of, you may find yourself paying for it

Relax and enjoy!. Dont just walk, sit down on the tempels and just watch. Than you will make breath taking pictures. If u want buy souvenir, dont do it here. Its all plastic. Go to patan in the shops, best buy good wood carving. Eat on the rooftop restaurant called Bajra if u dont want to pay European prices. Take the chips chilly or the buff moma. U can make pics from baba s on the square but pay them its there only income. Dont give money to begging children give it to disabled those people got really hard time in Nepal.
Love The Colours. Take a walk around the area, you would get the first hand experience of Nepal. The colours are amazing.

Excellent heritage site. This is an excellent heritage site well maintained and you can see old structures standing tall giving you a picture of history.Nice wooden and stone structures all around the place. Must visit if you are in Nepal, Kathmandu - just few Kms drive.

Amazing heritage. Myself and my wife visited this area during our recent Nepal tour. The area has numerous beautiful old structures. Many with intricate wood carvings. It's a living heritage with people going about their day to day life. The cleanliness of the place can be improved.

The quintessential sightseeing must-do. This is what you expect to see when thinking about the history, culture and architectural wonder in Nepal. There is a 1500 rupee charge for entry into the area, but it's a must-do. From the beautiful temples and wooden palaces, the fact they're still so well-kept and the intricate detail on the buildings and statues makes this a key stop off point. You can't go inside the palaces but some temples are restricted for hindu worshippers and no photos can be taken.

Lovely Place. This place is one of the historical place of Nepalwhich is absolute to see historical analysis of Nepal.Wood Caving,Old temple and Unique-ability of this placemakes us to wondering about the Nepal. This Place was listed on World Heritage sites. Lots of Temple Around and besides that there are lots of shops around this place.

Post meeting chill spot. This place is good to chillax after meetings and sniper some good pictures of a strange assortment of people wandering around. Hike up one of the temples and relax away from the hustle of the city.

Nice place. Walking into the square you will find lots of shops and old temples..its just a walk in the street...its quite over prices NRS150 for SAARC countries and NRS 750 for others which is quite too much for just a walk in the street..Nepali people arent charged as they have houses inside the square..and remember as it is a street so you have lot of streets leading there..only front and back entrance has ticket counters..

MAGNIFICENT!!. Initially our guide discouraged us from going to this historical place saying there are old temples. But we went there to see it. And it is very unique and magnificent. It is a World Heritage Site. There are old temples, scattered in the big square and many palatial buildings and temples; most of the material appears to be wooden, with beautiful carvings done in it. There are temples of Lord Vishnu, Lord Shiva and others. The temples are photogenic. Sadly it is not maintained in proper conditions, there is traffic going on in the square. But when in Kathmandu, one must visit this place.

Transported to another age. Those dark forbidding buildings against the sky transported me immediately to another age despite the millions of people milling about. Photographer's delight - although capturing the essence of the carved wood in that deep shade of brown takes some adjustment. The maps made by the tourist department are no help at all - it takes a while to understand exactly where you are - unless you opt for one of the chatter box guides - who may be good or may overload you with unwanted information simply to show off their knowledge.

Durbar Square. Nice place to visit, however many of the buildings are in poor condition. Considering tourists are charged a fee to enter and the site is designated "World Heritage", it begs the obvious question as to where the funds are actually being allocated..

Sadly managed World Heritage Site. With a mental picture of this world heritage site in mind from 15 years back, when I visited Durbar Square a few days back, it reminded me of the streets of Baghdad from the early 50's (from what i have seen in movies) with hawkers peddling their fruits and vegetables and hordes of people just walking around in a very crowded and not enjoyable pace in this site. Perhaps it was because I went in after 6pm in the evening but any hopes of getting a glimpse and pictures from what i remembered were well and truly shattered..... was very sad and depressing.

Hot at the end of the day. We parked far away and walked through an interesting neighborhood to get to the square. That was the best part, for me. I was hot, thirsty, little shade to be found, and we were waiting in the courtyard of the Living Goddess for her to make an appearance. She finally did, and looked a little bored and put upon as she gazed down upon us from the window above. She didn't spend much more than a minute at the window. We visited one of the temples and made our way back to the van. I enjoyed Patan's Durbur Square much more. Different atmosphere.

just great. great history and architecture.What I dont like? The fact, that Tripadvisor is pushing to fill up more information, then I really want to. Next time I´ll just skip it. Think about that guys... :)
Nice. Dirty and overpriced. Full of pigeons. And people. NIce to just walk there as it is one of the "best" parts of Kathmandy, with long history and some attractions.
Life is passing by .... Just sit down at the Pagoda steps and observe how life is passing by ... enjoy and keep that moment in your mind ....

Square with a story. Having visited all three of the 'Durbar Sqaures' it is hard to suggest why you would need to see all of them, unless a complete travel experience is your objective. The Kathnamdu, or more correctly Thamel Durbar Square has impressive architecture, and a great museum with an interesting story. Here you can see many artifacts from King Tribhuwan's reign, including many quite bizarre items such as his favourite bird, now suitably stuffed in its original cage. Well managed and plenty of staff to ask questions if you wish. The wired roof in the main courtyard used to prevent the copious pidgeon population is interesting, but with limited success to be honest. In summary, one Durbar Square is fine, just choose which one suits your itinerary.

tourist trap. NOT WORTH THE MONEY!!!Durbar Square is the most disgusting rip off you could possibly go to in Nepal. Our experience there was absolutely horrible, nasty pigeons everywhere, people feeding them so they stick around. People, garbage, and graffiti over the "protected" buildings. Then there was the vehicles zipping around while your trying to check things out. Such a disappointment.You can go to beautiful relaxing places like Garden of Dreams, Monkey Temple or Boudhanath for way cheaper and they are much for pleasant to visit. Don't waste time or money on Durbar Square.

Could be cleaner.... If you are in Kathmandu it is almost impossible not to get into Durbar square. If you are foreign you have to pay 750NP to walk around the Streets, and police men will ask you your card/ ticket to enter. We think that others "Durbar" around Kathmandou Valley are more interesting and much cleaner then this one.. Don't forget to make your card to visit it many times if you stay in Kathmandou for a while.

A square which promises a lot but delivers average. The durbar square,the name itself makes one belief that it promises views of grandeur, classical views of architecture and heritage. But sadly not much to offer as most of the buildings are crammed. with people who have very at stake to showcase the place. It is not in the tourists paradise destiation presently

What a mixture. Agree with most reviews I read before our visit. The square is centered around the old Royal residence which despite the so called conservation and world heritage status will sadly one day end up as ruins. The "entrance" fee system is a farce but anyone would pay the 750rps to see the museum which gives you a fascinating glimpse of days gone by with Nepal royalty. The rest of the square is decaying slowly not helped by the attitude of the locals who continue to drive every manner of vehicle through the fragile area whilst giving no respect to the buildings, using them as selling areas and doss houses. Bizarrely a must visit place for us who deep down want to know some of the history of the places we have decided to visit.
Old and culture. This is very nice and very old Place. But little bit more entrance fees so not many people go insideReduce price

Very old,boring and a dirty place. There is nothing to see. It's a very dirty and dusty place. They charge high entrance fees. This place is a biggest waste of time, money and energy. Avoid this place and save ur money. One could visit many temples inside the patan but there is no lightning. You have to pay money from entrance till u visit boring museums.

So So. This was a heavily visited tourist place. If you are western then they make sure they charge for entry. Locals, who are supposed to pay a reduced fee, enter without being charged.Lots of interesting structures. Sadly, like most of Kathmandu, the sites are in a disrepair. Still, worth the time and the fee to visit.

Boring. The Durbar Squares in Patan and Bhaktapur are better. However, I did find a roof-top restaurant that over-looked the square where merchants were scattered around. You can also see the foothills from here.

Confluence of Modern Offerings and Architectural Designs. Don't expect a quaint, "Paris" or other developed country style, city corner since it definitely isn't one. Nor should it be like one - it has its own unique confluence of modern offerings and architectural designs that have centuries old history. It's charm is its uniqueness. You may want to view the pictorial blog to get a better idea of what to expect in Basantapur. http://purecamp.com/localities/basantapur .
Visit Durbar Square. Very old wood carved palaces of the Nobles, Temples incorporated into the structures. Worth visiting - to get a feel of what faith is worth.
Just ok.. I thought boktapur was more impressive. The harassment of tour guides is overwhelming. Not worth the money.

Nice, historic but slightly underwhelming. Durbar square is quite an interesting place to be, with tons of local life and lots of activity going on in the square. The 2 giant temples are pretty impressive too, but as a 'UNESCO' attraction it is kind of underwhelming, besides those things there are not much else there. Just a place to while away your time, get the iconic shot of the place and see locals go about their daily activity while you chill.

Reaching Durbar Square of Kathmandu, Touching History and Heritage. I visited Kathmandu Durbar Square on 26 th May,'2014 along with my family and enjoyed it very very much. By Nepal I was meant by Himalaya only, but by reaching there I really am admired with the reach Maharaja Heritage of Nepalese Kingdom. For future travellers I will give two suggestions:- (1) Reach the point before 3 p.m., otherwise the Museum will be closed, & (2) There is one more Durbar Square in the South of Kathmandu at Patan, which is also a good one, but you don't need to go there if your sight seeing includes Kathmandu Durbar......Because Patan Durbar is small in size, and excluding this point you can save your time and money. Good Luck

Just average. We visited the Patan Durbar Square before doing the Kathmandu Durbar Square. The latter is no doubt much bigger and contains 2 biggest attractions - Kumari house and the Taleju temple but it's far more noisier and crowded than Patan. This is because vehicles move about freely within the square which makes it difficult to move around. The Kumari house is a good visit but it was really painful to see a pretty little girl locked up. The Taleju temple can be seen from outside as it is never open for worship. It open only for a special prayer offering once a year. The Kalbhairav statue is another attraction that one must see. Overall strictly in my personal opinion, if you have seen the Patan Square you can give this one a miss.
43 Temples. It Consists Of 43 Temples In One Square.You Can Get Pass For Many Days From The Same Entry Ticket Because It is Impossible To Visit Each And Every Temple in The Campus In One Day.

Incredible place. This square is a excellent depiction of architecture and culture of Nepal. A spot where one learns about the Nepalese architecture and can also buy some handicrafts. There are some very interesting resturants too. A cool place to visit !
local treat. fantastic day and we were invited into our guides home to meet his family. A must see square but very very busy and take care watch out for motorbikes.

Very interesting. Not to be missed if you're in Kathmandu, its so culturally and historically interesting . Just wander around taking in all the sights, sounds and smells, (but watch out for the pigeon droppings!) You'll be pestered by guides offering their services at the entrance, don't really think its necessary unless you want the full details, facts and figures, we didn't take up their services but spent the afternoon just wandering around at our leisure. Well worth a visit!

" Awesome monument zone ". Kathmandu Durbar Square is located heart of Kathmandu. You may easily find, from thamel you have to walk just 15 min. I was there so many times with mine friends. It’s a one most popular monument zone and heritage site. You have to issue entrance fee then you may visit all place. There are around 50 temples in the vicinity including the temple Taleju Bhawani which was brought from Indian continent by Mallas with them in around 9th Century. The Durbar is divided into two courtyards, the outer comprising Kasthamandap, Kumari Ghar, and Shiva-Parvati Temple, and the inner consisting of Hanuman Dhoka and the main palace. Important ceremonies, including the coronation of the Nepali monarch, are held in the Kathmandu Durbar Square. If you are in Kathmandu please do not missed to visit this place.
city center. Beautifully restored old city center, the heart of the old city the main plaza, a must see in Kathmandu.

Beautiful Durbar Sqaure. Make some time to explore Durbar Square. My tip, get there early and watch the place glow with the sunrise. The locals feed the pigeons early before the crowds arrive. Stay a while and watch the place grow with many locals selling an array of goodies. You may get hassled a little by the market sellers. Also it does cost i think 1000 rupees to enter the square. But that does get you entry into the museum. Walk up the stairs to the 9th floor of the palace and get a great view over the city.

TIME!. This is a cultural hotspot. It will take your breathe away like most places in Nepal. However, ensure that you have atleast a day or two to see the place in its entirety. Only then will you do justice to this place.

Badly in need of tender loving care. This is a World Heritage Sites, and certainly the complex of ancient temples and old palaces is worth a visit, but it is in dire need of cleaning and renovation. The central part of the first courtyard, next to the imposing idol of Khal Bhairav, is a sea of pigeons, feathers and pigeon droppings, and several of the more ancient temples are propped up with rough wooden supports. Given the number of visitors (all of whom pay an entrance fee) surely funds are not an issue. The old palace is well preserved, but several of the large display windows are cracked, so it is impossible to get nice photos of the Royal palanquins, etc. I was intrigued by a sign for the bombed landrover of one of the Kings - the vehicle itself is just parked at the back with no information at all. There are many souvenir shops, but you need to drive a hard bargain .

Culture in a nutshell. Take a walk around Durbar Square, and it feels like Kathmandu from years ago. Learn so much about the history of Kathmandu in this one place. A great place for local people watching.

Unique. A taste of old Kathmandu. Interesting to walk around and relax. We did not opt for a guide though it might be good for those who are interested in knowing more about its history. Lots of touting though.
Interesting. We enjoyed wandering around the square taking photos of many things. It was our first trip to Nepal so we really enjoyed strolling around and feeling quite safe too.

Kathmandu Durbar Square. This complex of palaces, courtyards and temples like Hanumandhoka Palace, Kumari Ghar (Abode of the Living Goddess), Taleju temple, built between the 12th and 18th centuries, used to be the seat of the ancient Malla Kings of Kathmandu. An intriguing piece here is the 17h -century stone inscription set into the wall of the palace with writings in 15 languages. The Durbar Square, protected as a UNESCO World Heritage Site, is the social, religious and urban focal point of the city. Even to date, all the major state and social ceremonies, including the solemnization of coronations are performed in one of the courtyards in this complex. There are also museums inside the palace building. There is an entrance fee of Rs. 250 for foreign visitors. Your ticket to the Square entitles you to visit all the museums.
Not Impressed. The best part of the square was the view from a nearby rooftop restaurant. The architecture is interesting, but overshadowed by the surrounding filth and crowds.

Beware of the "Guides". Durbar Square is a great place to explore, people watch, take photos and be a tourist. Be careful not to unwittingly be drawn into having a guide. You can make your own way around and armed with a Lonely Planet book you will be fine. As with lots of places in the city, Durbar Square has lots of Temples and shrines. Also mixed with air conditioned coffee shops which is a welcome break in the heat. Great place.

Best Local hangout in the hub of the Kathmandu.. Every time we went to this place- we have so much fun . colorful people , yummy streets foods around corners . Best thing about this place is there's always some sort of activities going on which is very interesting to see. This is the major starting or ending point for every sort of festival in the tinsel town.will recommend people to visit once if you are going to Kathmandu.
A Must See In Kathmandu. Lots of things to see here in Durbar Square. I especially liked the King's museum. It's just fun to wander around soaking in the atmosphere.

Not what I expected. Perhaps my views of this are tainted by the fact that I went here late in my trip, but I found the square to be overwhelming and overrun with people trying to sell everything: tours, trinkets, etc. I went through the museum and found the museum staff to be very unfriendly, something I didn't find anywhere else in Nepal. The coolest thing about the square was that I got to see the Royal Kumari in a window of her house. If you want to see her, too, your best bet is after 4:00 p.m.

Better in Bhaktapur. In Kathmandu the architecture is quite amazing, but it is dirty, crowded with locals just sitting on buildings, lacking in restoration. Worth a look but if u can the sites in Bhaktapur are Much Better, less crowded, well preserved.

Durbar Square. a close ride from Thamel, has some markets and hotels around.. gets quite too early.. For a first timer its nice to see the architecture of the palace around but there's no entry so you can only see it from outside

Great place to walk around and people watch. If you love people watching, you will love the square. You can spend hours here, sipping tea or what suits your interest and watch the people and world go by. Its a great place to bargain shop as well, if you are good at it. Some of the merchant wares are well and truly spectacular. The square is also home to a number of temples and a museum. Feel free to wander into them as well. Its great to go either in the morning (early) or in the late evening, so that one can see the place come alive and wind down. While there is an entry fee, you are allowed to renew your existing pass for a second day as well at no extra fee in certain circumstances. Make sure you find that out before you leave.

the Garden on Dreams. the atmosphere, the architecture the tranquility of the Gardens makes it a fabulous attraction in the city. It is a gem in the heart of a messy polluted Kathmandu. A beautiful space for locals (many lovers) in hidden corners and tourists that just want a break from the heat, smell and noise of the streets, and open until 22h00 for 250rupees. Very centrally located in Thamel it has good (expensive) food. Coke cola around 100rupees. And clean western-style toilets with paper! A place to sit and read a book to pass time if you've had it in the noisy streets, and you can take your own picnic snacks to eat. Lovely lotus ponds and bonsai bouganvillas. Do visit it!!

Amazing place - skip the museum. The Durbar Square is admittedly a tourist destination, but I was quite the exception as a European visitor. The entrance fee is ok (750 Rs) and you seemingly can stamp the thing to return another day.The temples are very much worth to be looked at. Skip the museum : it only holds some artefacts of a recent king that you might not even have heard of - I certainly hadn't, but my interest hasn't increased after visiting the museum. It's a bit sad that no more money is spent on conservation, but I guess there isn't much money to start with. Absolutely worth a visit!

Interesting place, good shopping, architecture and worth a visit. Welcome break from the madness of Kathmandu and Thamel. It is a really greta place to do some shopping see some very old buildings and just chill out for a while after your trek.

Definitely get a guide!. This place has a lot going on! Make sure to get a guide to explain all the unique things you will see here. "Sensual" architecture, secret kingly chambers, one of the Shah's European-style palace wings, demon-slaying Shiva, the living goddess, and the royalty's personal god temple with rumored child-sacrifice would all have been missed if it wasn't for our guide Padme. Prepare for haggling wars if you plan to buy some souvenirs here as well, shop owners are experienced and resolute in their deals.

Worth a visit. A must place to visit, really old Kathmandu. You are taken back in time as Durbar Square is very much steeped in history, beginning with the Palace of the Kumari. The buildings within the area are very impressive. Worth exploring the side streets also. Allow plenty of time to just explore, well worth it.

Heritage..Royalty. Though currently the place is filled with locals and seems to be a common place once you view it there is certainly a royalty personified with it and the point becomes clear once you get to know the entire history of the place...Give it a try...

Architecturally quite stunning. Having spent days in the hustle and bustle of Thamel and Kathmandu, Durbar Square was a welcome surprise.
Impressive, imposing, a strong sense of history. Reminiscent of a large medieval European square, it's a must see - spending a couple of hours not only looking at buildings, but exploring the alleyways, shops and businesses.
Simple awesome.. Whole day is not enough. Make sure you stamp your ticket for next visit for free. 9 storied palace is simply awesome.
Very interesting historic place. I enjoyed visiting the museum and the Basantapur, the nine-storeyed place, but I also think that the house of the Kumari is a special place to visit.

A good place in wrong city. No doubt Durbar Square is an invaluable collection of art, culture and history. There are numerous temples each having their own significance. The buildings there provide a glimpse into historical architecture from times of kings. There is also the museum in palace of King Tribhuvan which present many items used by the then ruler. People would really be astonished to witness the Kumari Temple and history behind it (covered in my other answers on the forum). Nearby walk upto freak-street for some awesome local cuisine.

The city center. It is the city center of Kathmandu , not commercially , but culturally and architecturally! Durbar square and Kathmandu square are quite similar and are equally opulent with old-world charm . We see a fusion of Indian , Tibetan and Chinese culture here. Keep an eye out for interesting statues, extremely detailed carvings and an overall beautiful architecture, esp in the structure and construction of buildings and temples.Siting on the edge of the tall temples, biting into your brunch and enjoying the scenic view of the entire square - one of the most peaceful moments that one can have ! So , if you are planing to do a city tour , don't miss Durbar Square and Kathmandu Square !

I loved this square!. One of three of Nepal's main squares to visit, and this one did not disappoint. Lots of beautiful buildings, lots of interesting people, places to sit and relax, and shops and cafes in the surrounding area. A must visit in Nepal.

must do in Nepal. During our stay in Nepal like many tourists we had to experience durbar square.It is a great lively place to explore, see a bit of nepalise culture, dodge touts and look at the old architecture.There are many things to see. You can go into the museum, have pictures with the Hindu babas and haggle with the friendly market stall keepers over tourist trinkets.Only slightly annoying thing is that if you are foreign you have to play an entrance fee but on the other hand I don't mind as long as the proceeds go to maintaining the square.Overall a must do whilst in Nepal.
Emblematic place!. Emblematic place! The impressive number of temples of different religions located on a small area allows us to appreciate the importance of religions which all come together.
Heart of Katmandu. A must visit place if you are in katmandu. Multiple temples and palaces from over a thousand years of nepali history.

Beautiful Palaces and the Kumari. I loved the carved temples. We were fortunate that the Kumari; the living goddess, showed herself on the day we visited. She is a child who was chosen from her caste of silversmiths at age 3-5. She passed many difficult tests, including stoicism in the face of multiple animal sacrifices, scary noises and frightful masks, and other things. She will reign until she reaches puberty, when she will go back to her family.
open museum. awesome ancient Nepalese heritage site. I relay appreciated 9 storied pillar. all temple complex i felt glory of the human civilization. so, great and skyscrapers.

Worth a Visit. I know that this is a UNESCO site and it has a certain charm. Big prepared for the smells and dirt that accompany most tours of the area and be prepared to look past them and just be present in this place of tourism and daily living.

An architectural gem. A wonderful architectural gem that lives up to all expectations. The entry fee of 750 rupees is definitely worth it. This is a living museum of ancient buildings that has stood throughout the centuries and you cannot but be amazed at the wonderful condition of the buildings given the harshness of the climate that they have to withstand. We found that a couple of hours passed very quickly within the confines of the Square. When you purchase an entry ticket, make sure you proceed to the Kathmandu Metropolitan City office and ask for a free 1-week extension Visitor Pass if you want to go back again another day. You will need a spare passport photograph, though.

Kumari Temple Goddess. Durbar square was a great place, however next time I will take a guide with me. There was much to explore, with temples everywhere the eye can see, but going alone I didn't understand everything and I think it's worth having a guide.Kumari Temple was incredible - and I was lucky enough to catch a glimpse of the living goddess. Very special.

Soak in the sights and sounds. One of the most colourful places in Kathmandu. Didn't like paying the very high entrance fee of 750rp, I do agree with other reviewers that you could easily bypass it since there's no checks. I couldn't get out of it because our guide in the form of the son of the trekking agency we used was showing us around and he dutifully went to the ticket booth to get us the tickets. Anyway, the Square didn't disappoint at the least. You could sit and watch locals perform their religious rites, walk around and look at the interesting carvings on the very old buildings and imagine old Kathmandu and how life was then.

Fascinating. We took a tour of Kathmandu Durbar Square with a guide from our tour company. We were able to get complete (fairly) history of the area. Picturesque historical building and interesting people around will definitely amaze you.

Try another Durbar. Kathmandu's Durbar Square has some pretty cool architecture, but it's filthy. You're much better visiting Patan's Durbar Square, which is well maintained and in a more interesting section of the city.

Enjoy the Sroll through Old Kathmandu. We were able to see all the old Buildings and walk through the square.Once again there was a entrance fee of 750 Nepalese Rupees, £3.50 in Sterling! watch out they try and catch you at both ends for the fee make sure you keep your tickets handy.

Beautiful and fascinating (and not that expensive). Durbar square has a dizzying array of temples of different ages, styles and dedications. One of the good things is that many of them are still actively used, which helps to bring them alive.Some fantastic carvings (if you are interested in the erotic, it may help to bring binoculars). An interesting museum, much of which is dedicated to the last few kings, but worth visiting to go up the high tower.For several hours entertainment in a World Heritage site, I think that Rs750 (£5, $/€7) is fair value!

Excellent but expensive. loved the temples and culture but very overpriced for foreign visitors! Go to any of the roof top bars / cafes / restaurants for a fantastic view and and rest. Must do the nine storey house in the museum - lot of stairs but worth the view and photpos from each bfloor.

Don't miss the museum . Interesting center of KTM. You will have to pay 750 Rs entrance fee. It includes also entrance to the museum and 9 floors palace.
You will certainly enjoy this place. Reserve at least 2 hours.

Busy but worth the visit. Heaps of history crammed into a small area. Not as nice as Bhaktapur but still worth the visit.
The short walk from Thamel was also interesting as you pass through local shops and buildings.

Not a patch on Patan. Although it has to be done if you are in Kathmandu Durbar Square didn't hold the same beauty as Patan or Bhaktapur. It was busy, dirty and polluted, although I felt safe I didn't feel comfortable. A strange atmosphere but good for sitting still and watching the madness around you.
Worth a visit - kind of must!. Bit commercialised but def worth a trip to centre of kth - shouldn't visit it whilst you are there. Very high air pollution in centre of kathmandu

Utterly fascinating!. Wow oh so many historic, very old buildings in a small inner city area. Well worth a visit. The amazingly detailed carvings on practically every building showed the manner in which these places were built. Just a short walk from Tamil.

Astonishing beautiful, and plenty of city life. Apart from beautiful temples and the former Royal Palace, Durbar Square bustles wit city life (plenty of people, markets, rickshaws, etc) since it is a meeting point for many locals. A must in Kathmandu, even despite the hrelativeli high entry ticket price for foreigners (locals don't pay). Don't miss it.

GREAT HISTORY & BEAUTIFUL VIEW. I would easily say that visiting Nepal was a great experience for me, my husband and our friends. Especially Durbar Square was a marvelous place which depicts history, religion, culture and lifestyle at the same place.
Old & Magical. The detailed work on the pagodas and the gorgeous architecture behind the doors is definitely worth a visit - a well deserved world heritage site.

A must see - especially memorable if you hire a guide. A fascinating place! We paid 750 rs per person to get in, although it seems we didn't have to. But I guess it is worth it if that fee is used for maintenance of the place. It is truly wonderful. After having made the mistake the day before of not hiring a guide in Bakhtapur Durbar Square, this time we hired a guide for 1,500 rs for three persons. The tour lasted app. 45 minutes, and it made a huge difference. Our Lonely Planet Nepal tour guide has useful info, but no pictures in it- so you are never really sure if you are reading about a correct place. The only annoying thing about the square are all the persistent vendors of knives, necklaces, flutes, but I guess it is a good test to learn to say no.
Darbar square. The whole darbar square is a excellent example of old Nepali culture. The carvings on all the buildings are really very good .

Expensive entry ticket. Must see place. However,you will find that in all Kathmandu squares, they try to extract as much money as they can from western tourists. If you plan to visit several public places i few days, be prepared to spend a lot of money in tickets. The overall amount is expensive, even for a western...

Excellent heritage site. We loved the Square in Lalitpur that was full of history, people watching, Nepalese people celebrating and watched parade as harvesting season. The atmosphere was relaxing, watching others walking by.

Sacrificial buffalo. Durbar square is etched into my memory, not for the architecture or the street sellers but for the sacrifice of three water buffalo and some goats. The tension and anticipation hung in the air. Then the goats escaped and started copulating. Suddenly it became comical. Then the sword came down and severed the head off a buffalo. Not something one often sees in Trafalgar square.

Interesting and worth a visit. Durbhar Square is a mad-house of activities and very busy in terms of traffic. This area is the historic area of Kathmandu and have some really beautiful architecture. The living goddess, Kumari also has her palace there and it's open to the public, but unfortunately non-Kumari believers are not allowed to enter the palace, only the courtyard area. The tour of the palace is also worth it and interesting.

Such Historical site full of Heritage but pathetically maintained. There are three Durbar Squares in and around Kathmandu Valley. Kathmandu Durbar square(basantpur), Patan Durbar Square(lalitpur) Bhaktapur Durbar Square( Bhaktapur). The best among these is the Bhaktapur Durbar Square. Surprisingly, the Bhaktapur Durbarsquare is maintained well and is clean. Its a surprise since finding cleanliness in temples and tourist spots in Kathmandu is a rarity. People are habbitual in spitting around the place while walking and in markets. You will find Garbage and mud all around the place. you wont be able to walk a long distance on the road since the place is highly dusty and without a mask you just cannot walk around. Coming back to Kathmandu Durbar Square, it is located in a very busy market. so you will find all vegetable and flower vendors just crowding the place. the most irritating part for all the Durbar Squares is all unemployed youths climbing on the steps and sitting on those steps for hours together. How does a tourist enjoy the peace and tranquility of the place and how does a tourist click nice pictures. These people are sitting on those steps throughout the day and watching all the tourists. Somehow authorities are also just watching them and not asking them to not crowd the place. Is this is picture that a tourist should carry with them. Also within this area where this monument is located, while walking on the streets, look before you step since it is really very filthy.

Interesting. If you do not need to visit the museum, don't pay the 700 rupees entrance as most of the sites here are free to visit. Do visit on a Sunday when there is a market where you can see the local lifestyle and also to shop around.

This is a total scam!. The square is a general walk-through/hang out area for locals, who lounge about on all the temples, eating and smoking, but if you're a foreigner they charge you 750 rupees to get in. We paid it because this is supposed to be a must-see in Kathmandu but minutes later realised we'd been totally scammed. The temples are dirty and, as i said, crawling with people, so you can't really see them, and the locals all just walk through like it's a shopping center. A total rip off! When we returned to the ticket booth to enquire what we'd actually paid for, the price of the ticket includes entry to the 'museum', which is a crusty building with a few rooms containing some old photos and a small collection of dusty, faded artifacts, which weren't interesting and we didn't want to go to. Later, while we were walking about Kathmandu we inadvertently walked back into the square, where there was no one charging or any mention of tickets, so you don't actually have to pay, only if you go in at the wrong entrance. Don't waste your money. It's left a very bad taste for me. Oh, and i won't even mention the sheer number of touts, everywhere, who are also loitering to fleece the western tourist! Scam, scam, scam!

Certainly worth viewing. It is worth seeing this square for a number of reasons: the architecture, the vibrant life of the locals going on around you, and the interesting walk to get there. But that said, it is a little scruffy and could do with a little more maintenance.But try to see this BEFORE you see Durbar Sq in Bhaktapur, as it is not as good. I was a little disappointed as I saw it afterwards.

A trip back in history. Located close to Thamel, this is an easy walking trip. I see no reason to pay a guide as a ticket can be purchased for 750 rupees. If you go it is worth walking up the nine flights of stairs to reach the top. The view of surrounding area is worth it.The museum is interesting but not memorable. It's another place that doesn't allow photos and I'm not sure why.

The Best Durbar Square. I find Kathmandu Durbar square to be the most interesting of them all. There are many more temples to see here. You can spend hours here learning about them. The locals also use it as an access point to various parts of the city. So you have motorcycles driving through and you get to see people living their daily lives. Tour guides will find you. Many are just young adults looking to find their education. Around 500 rs is a reasonable rate to give them. I find Durbar Square to be very photogenic and there are some great places to sit and watch the world flash by.

Unforgetful Experience!. Everyone should visit Nepal, at least once in their life! Kathmandu Durbar Square is one of the major attractions. It's a stunning place where you can see many Hindu and Buddhist temples. And if you happen to be there at around 4pm in the afternoon, you might be very lucky to see the Living Goddess Kumari just for few seconds looking through the window.
