worth a look. Walked down one street and a ticket seller wanted to charge me to walk around the square, all you do is go back and enter from the other road and walk about like the rest of the people, did end up paying for a guide $15aus for 1half hrs, got all the info on Temples, Liveing Goddess, Kings Pa;lace

Great place, lots of traffic. Historically, an amazing place; it's worth taking a guide, because there are so many buildings and so many things to see, that a guidebook feels inadequate (it's impossible not to find a tour guide). The traffic is something else, especially in the evening - there's hardly any space to drive, which does not stop taxis, rishaws, motorbikes, and bicycles from doing so, with constant and often very aggressive honking of horns. Nevertheless, sitting on one of the palaces and watching people, life, markets and traffic is one of the highlights of a visit here.
Living History. Lovely place to catch a glimpse of what the old Nepal looked like with all the intricate designs you can find on the structures around the Durbar. It is worth a visit.

Old Kathmandu, very nice!!!. In Kathmandú you can visit three Royal Square, called Durbar Squares, one in Bhaktapur( you can't miss it), one in Patan ( very nice) and the third one in places in the old Kathmandú, very nice. You can see Hanuman Dhoka, Royal residence till XiX century, the Kumari Chowk, home of the Princess Raj Kumari, a little girl chosen by an antique method to be de vivid encarnation of the Hindu Godess, Durga. Is absolutely forbidden to take photos and hindu people go there because they consider this little palace as a sacred place. She has very little appereance in public. When I was there, people were eating in the central little court, as a way of celebration. If you want yo get a very good coffee after Kumari palace you will see people selling all kind of "antique thigs" that seems to, but are fake, and you will see an Himalayan Java, terrific place to get a break, there is no bathroom inside the coffe store
So much to see!. Many gorgeous temples and statues in Durbar Square. You could spend days here! We even got to see the current Kumari. What an amazing experience.

Lots to see here. Where else can you see the world's only "living goddess?!" The goddess Kumari is a spoiled young girl who made a short appearance from the window of her residence, looked down imperiously at us mortals, and quickly left to return playing with her companions. When she matures she'll be replaced with another virgin "goddess". One wonders how she'll deal with just being an ordinary human then.The rest of Durbar Square if filled with many unusual temples and shrines, and people from all walks of life. A totally fascinating place - not to be missed!

Interesting place.. It was pretty cool; however, there was not much on the history if the place. I gained more knowledge from youtube videos. If you really wanted to learn anything about this place you had to hire a guide but, you really didn't know if they were making up stuff or what! I already had a general idea about the history of Dunbar Square most however probably did not.

Briliant. We were very pleasantly surprised at how good this was. A very extensive area of Nepalese history and the only thing that spoils it is the failure of the government to ban motorcycles from whizzing up and down between the visitors. This is a common problem throughout India and Nepal and will probably be stopped as soon as the first tourist is killed by one.

Make sure you take your camera. The architecture is amazing! This is a site which compels you to click your camera at every turn.It is a popular place for tourists, so you may have to wait awhile to capture the buildings rather than the people. But it is also a site not to be missed.

Great to see. Great Square to see. So many temples, palaces and pagodas.Bit expensive at 750 Rupees but well worth it if you go early enough as everything closes at 3.30pm.Highlights are the Palace, Main Temple to Shiva, Statue of Shiva in Angry Format and the virgin window.Not a lot of good places near the square to eat or drink so you may need to wander a bit.

Nouva experience. The reason I call it a complete new experience is coz I got to see the living goddess Kumari. She is the only living goddess in the world and getting a glimpse of her was amazing. A bit too crowded but a good bit of history in the heart of Kathmandu.
Too crowded. Lots of people and lots of guides we did not want. We did not have piece at the Durbar Square... Not a good experience, although the place is amazing...

Interesting place to visit while in Kathmandu. This huge square with many temples in quite impressive, rich in history and culture. Taleju Temple was built in the 1500's and can climb up 7 stories to see a picturques view of the valley of Kathmandu with the surrounding mountains at every angle. There is a fee to come into the square FYI, very crowded as well with markets and many people milling around; fascinating place accept for the crowds cool place to check out.

Day Trip with Alpine Explore Nepal In Kathmandu. I had wander full Day trip with Alpine Explore Guide, It was amazing day for me to know all about the Nepal's history and Kingdom of Nepal. It is so beautiful place for knowing all about the early time in Nepal and how the country was and manage it. You will still know they have Live Codes Kumari. Visiting this please and having the professional guide makes the trip so wonderful.I recommend all the travel who like to visit this place better to go with Guide.

Holi Day. This square is amazing as are many others around in other city's. We were here for the celebration of Holi Day, which is to welcome the spring. This place was a mass of colourers in powder form been thrown over everyone that was willing to participate. Their were 100's of people young and old alike all very good humoured, not a sing spot of trouble lots of laughs. A very special day and a fantastic square to visit after to.

Back to the Nepalese Dynasty. The Durbar Square is a historical place. It used to be the office of the early Nepalese Kings. Good place for taking photographs. Although has a varying rate of entry fees for tourist which is weird.

Good cultural experience. Visit this place during holi, you will have loads of fun playing with colors and dancing.. Go to one of the roof top restaurants there to get a full view of Durbar Squre. It looks great.

A square different from others. I was surprised from the experience I had in Nepal. One of the most attractive square I have ever seen was this of Katmandu. In a few square meters you see more than twenty monuments, most of them are temples devoted to their gods. The atmosphere is so impressive and mysterious and the best time of the day to visit it is a little earlier oh the sun set. This because you can enjoy it with the day light, but also with the few lights of the night, which make the view, marvelous and surprising. You must see it!!!
So many beautiful temples. We even were able to see the current Kumari! If you do not know who she is, do read the literature before you visit!

Worth a visit. Visited here on a group tour so can't comment on the price of admission, but the place is absolutely fascinating and worth an admission fee of up to $10 US. The intricate wood carvings are worth the price of admission. We had a city native tour guide who noticed a goat sacrifice ceremony going on and got our small group an introduction to the participants and an explanation of the ritual ceremony. Clearly the guide added to my perception of the value of the venue, but the sights and architecture are still worth the visit. Only one minor nit is the aggressive nature of the street vendors. If you are uncomfortable with pesky street vendors, I am not, perhaps choose a different venue. You will be accosted multiple times. Learn the mantra "no thank you," repeat it nonstop and you'll have no problem.

The heart of old Kathmandu. Crowds and hawkers everywhere, quite annoying at times, but to understand the history and soul of Nepal this place is impt. and contains a large cluster of temples, palaces, and museums.

Fabulous. You will not know where to look first between the shops and smells and people and incredible architecture with magnificent wood carvings. We saw people involved in their daily rituals and women chanting in groups. Then we went to the palace to wait for the appearance of the Kumari, the very young girl who is worshipped as a living goddess. Everyone gathered and no pictures were allowed but we will never forget it. This youngster appeared and was trembling.That was the one part that was a bit upsetting however it is the culture of the locals.The only thing that I would not do in the Durbar Square in Kathmandu is shop. The prices and deals and haggling are much better in the Durbar Square in Bhaktapur.All in all, this area should not be missed.

ancient settlement. Its a ancient city. worth to go and see. every detail are interesting. the authentic stone water spout, palaces, temples and old houses....if you are lucky you get to see some procession that happen during nepali festivals..

Don't Pay - You Can Sneak In. Very old and exotic looking and worth seeing. Just don't pay the exorbitant tourist only fee fee by going around the backside bypassing the pay kiosks and see it for free

Disappointing. Was expecting a quaint town with decent restaurants and lodgings. really bad.. we are talking US$ 5/day backpackers with really bad, unsanitary food... views are nice,, everything else is terrible
interesting. The architecture and history was fabulous, the buildings so ornately adorned well worth a visit . Also a place of the old hippies ( freak street)

Worth a quick look if convenient. Due to the entry to the Kathmandu Durbar Square being quite expensive for tourists, and the fact we had already been to the Bhaktapur Durbar Square, we did not go beyond the outer gates. Worth a look if you are in the area, and probably worth the entry fee but only if you do not go to the more impressive Bhaktapur Durbar.

Crowded and Lots of Beggers. They only make foreigners pay, which is not so friendly as everyone else just walks in. Then you have many people asking you if you need a guided tour. Some leave you alone once you say yes, others just kept following and bothering us. Lots of stray dogs, and TONS of pigeons. Even cows. IT was too busy to enjoy outside. The inside section was calm and the wood carvings were cool. I dont know if I would recommend the square because of the chaos, but I am glad I saw it.

A good first encountar with a Durbar. A good introduction to a Durbar and a must-do, but personally I think the one in Bhaktapur is the most impressive. Try to make a day trip of town to experience a living museum

Peace Peace Peace. Right in the heart of Kathmandu the capital of Nepal this ancient palace square is a must visit for all travelers. The square is filled with large number of temples of over 250 years old. A great place for photo session. Once a meeting point for the hippys. A pleasant walk in the by lanes gives you a real taste of Kathmandu.
nice square. The square shows all kinds of temple, the price was a bit high to get in. We went to Bahktapur, Durbar Square, we liked that one more!
Great temples. Durbar Square is a magical place, filled with temples and beautiful architectures. Perfect for photo hunters

So Nepal. This is the typical city of this kind of Asia countries, Bikes, Motobikes, cows, chickens, people, street markets, people talking, beggers... You will find it quite interesting for a while... if you are a quite person, you will be overwhelmed after a while.PLease note the carvings at the ceiling of the temples at Durbar... most of them refers to sexual positions! Try to go upstairs to the main temple (In front of the Kumari Palace) and try to catch an excellent view of this vibrant square

Busy traffic not tourist . It's must see in Kathmandu, but the could fit it more for tourism, there is a lot of "guides" wanting to show you around,The traffic is driving right through it, and the rickshaws is almost pulling in you.The museum was kind of good and it's a lot of nice architecture !

Guides with haggle you nonstop! . A sight to see but nothing major if you miss it. The guides offering their services made this place annoying - one constantly haggled me to pay for his services. Lots of kids as well begging for money - which I didn't see at lots of the other tourist attractions.

So much culture in a small space!. So many old and interesting buildings to look at, with better views from the many steps up to the different temples. It's entertainment enough just to sit for a while and watch the world go by.Don't miss the Kumari House, where the pre-pubescent living goddess resides, the mask of the white Bhairab hidden behind a large wooden grille, and the large statue of the fearsome black Bhairab.Watch out for begging street children, hawkers and beggars who may hassle you. It wasn't too bad when I went, just something to be aware of. The magnificence of the surroundings easily make up for a bit of minor hassle.
Take a guide. We had a guide for the day, who was able to tell us the history of the region. Durbar square is a heaving mass of people, begets, site seeing and brilliant, I must see part of Kathmandu
Not to be missed - but expensive. If you have to do one thing in Kathmandu it is to visit Durbar Square - but be warned - it is pricey! Currently (Feb 2014) NR750 per person.

Great shopping !!!. The brands are here and a visit to Zara is a must !! They have a special offer all the time and prices are reasonable. Only the Large and extra large is less.There are lots of sports shops and Adidas has shoes that have still not come to India. Prices may be marginally less than India or some at par.Leather stuff like boots and jackets are a must visit. Prices are very reasonable.You can get Momo's at the Coffee shop, Nepali cuisine, Pizza Hut, KFC and Thai Cuisine. Annapurna Hotel is just there as well as the Yak and Yeti. So grab a sandwich at their Pastry shop ..great breads.Was at Durbar Square practically everyday..

A must-see but crowded and frantic. this is a must-see but be prepared from the thronging masses, beggars and hawkers constantly at your side. the templates around this area are amazing especially when seen with a guide.

Durbar Square. The durbar palace were the royal palaces of ancient kings of the valley.The complex is home to many palaces, temples and courtyards. The durbar square often named as Basantapur, Hanuman Dhoka all denoting the same location.The temples here are old and the richness of the culture and arts of the valley comes alive with the singe glance of these monuments.
Kumari's house is here.. Nearby the King's square. Not Easily to reach through Freak street. If you want to help Nepal by donations, acess from New road. Also there a LOT of sellers )
Happy to see it.. It's a huge concentration of people, temples, museums, plus, one house of Kumari- living goddess.It's a king's square,- translation.

Old, Traditional and Crowded. It is an interesting place to visit. A lot of traditional and old temples and the previous palace was there as well. But too many tourists and too many small pedlers. And a lot of so called self employed guides would bother you and follow you. And too many beggers. Not my favorite place. One visit would be enough.

Nice but touristy. There were tons of people but if you look like a visitor, they'll find you and charge you an entrance fee. I don't mind paying to support maintaining historic places but the fee is pretty high, considering you're just walking around the square - especially if you keep getting hassled by locals. The museum was neat, it's amazing how much memorabilia has been collected and that is worth a look, justifies the cost a bit too.
Durbar Square. Excellent place with old architecture. I loved the place and those older wood made curving on . This place was one of the best place in kathmandu to visit.

You should see this ancient place.. You should see this ancient place, it is quite expensive, the ticket fee is really too high for that visit, it would be better free because it is only about a small street, a corner, nothing more, don't expect a second Patan.

Old city. Old cities with lots of histories. If you don't want to be bothered by the guides, just study beforehand or check the internet while you visit. Same with the hawkers, do not look interested at all and they will not follow you. It wasn't that bad for us if you refuse politely.Don't forget to go upstairs to take a full panaroma view of the city, across the road from the entrance. One of the nice guides showed us that but didn't bother us!Another pretty view can be seen from roof top garden cafés, with also nice views of the daily life nearby.

Beware touters. A magnificent square - not surprising that it's a popular hang out place among tourists and locals alike. The non stop honking from traffic passerby just added more life to Durbar Square. Beware though with the persistent guides offering services and kids begging for money after they asked you to take their pics. Nevertheless, you can't miss this busy square in Kathmandu

Too many hawkers. We visited in off-season and there were simply too many desperate people trying to sell us something - bracelets, toys, tours. It's overwhelming. Durbar Square is steeped in history. It's absolutely stunning, and we couldn't walk ten feet without being accosted. I was frustrated and just wanted to take it all in and not have to continually tell someone I didn't want the bracelet they were selling.

Interesting history (find a guide). I found a guide for the day (right in the square) that told me the entire history of the palace and got me an entrance ticket to the former palace/museum and told me the entire history of the square and all the stupas and structures. He explained all the different Hindu Gods in the square and the animals associated with them. He also explained the selection process for the Kumari. I gave him about 1000 NPR for my tour and it was worth it! (He let me decide how much to give him after the tour was finished no set price)

Worth a Visit. We went to Durbar Square and enjoyed our look around. I would recommend though that you visit the square at the middle of the day. We went at 4pm and it was extremely hectic. At the box office where you purchase your entry tickets, there are touts waiting, wanting to show you around. They are very knowledgeable, but be sure to agree on a price for their services before they hurry you along with them. You could very easily be scammed. Worth the visit though.
Lovely place to spend some time. You can learn so much about Hinduism and Buddhism just wondering around in this colorful square. Don't miss the Kumar's house and yard and the ancient wooden temple.

A must see attraction in Kathmandu. A guide is helpful, there is so much to this place that you would never even know. But do make sure your guide is legit, there are a lot of phonies out there. Find out when the living goddess will make an appearance, such a fascinating practice.Each of the Durbar Squares are interesting in their own right, but Patan Durbar Square is very similar, less crowded and cleaner.

A walk into the past with the present very much alive!. It's full of history, yet the locals are very much keeping the area alive. Pilgrems come, vendors hawk, there's food and colorful customs, religious ceremonies and many things to watch and take in. If the hubbub gets to you, go up to a rooftop bar, drink a beer, have some momos and watch the crowds below.

Massive Area. Durbar square will take you some time to explore. Most likely you will get lost without a guide if you start making too many turns, but that's part of the fun.When you enter you will be asked by many if you want a guide. It is a little bit annoying since I wanted to start taking pics right away. We didn't take any of the offers and felt like we had to walk away instead of enjoying the area.Take a driver there and if you want a guide. We didn't want a guide since we prefer to just walk and enjoy our own company. However, if you have a guide then you won't have to worry about the annoying touts.

Wonderful. One of the three durbar squares in Kathmandu Valley, all of which are a Unesco World heritage. More than the Square itself, i enjoyed the alleyways around the square. The architecture is absolutely beautiful and you will see nepali people simply going on with life. I really liked it because you got to see what real nepal looked like.The entrance fee is 750.

ancient seat of the Nepali King. A World Heritage site, this temple complex is a mix of ancient Buddhist and Hindu buildings, temples and statues. You may even catch a glimpse of the beautiful face of the kumari.

Nice collection of monuments and temples. As an European, I have really enjoyed the feeling of the square, with its very nice monuments and temples spread all around, and with the sea of people doing business, shouting, walking around, etc. You are a bit "harassed" by "guides" who want to convince you to buy their services, but everybody is polite, and if you're in a good mood you often end up having nice chats with them :)

Not great. We were very excited to visit Durbar Square and it was our first stop when we arrived. However, the number of hawkers, beggars and general creepy weirdos put us off. We paid 750 rupees to visit a very poorly laid out museum. The kings personal items were on show, the violin he had once used was stuck up by cello tape. There were a lot of younger children following us which made us feel uneasy. It was very busy and we did not enjoy it at all.
good. Nice to move around the area to become cool while moving to Newroad. I have been there several times with friends and had spent my time there.

Historic but the very dirty. I went there last December. Though I love the cool weather, Kathmandu Durbar Square is a bit of a mess. I did like the internal part of the square where locals hardly goes to. I think locals are not allowed to enter because they do not follow the tourists inside. The surroundings of the square is filthy with pigeon poops and locals seem not to care about. I noticed that the locals her do not really care about the history of the place as they just throw rubbish all over the street. The fee to enter is NR 500 which is quite okay as they use it to preserve what is left of the durbar.
A lot of stupas. A nice place to understand the whole concept of worshiping. Many temples and a major tourist attraction.
Very Good. This is where the Kumari palace is. Love the smell sight and sound around the Durbar. Surrounded by temples, street shops, Freak street, local markets, it is a great place to stroll

Absolutely beutiful, worth the visit. Great place to visit, well worth the expensive entry, we didnt use the guides that hassle you, unfortunately you have to pay again inside to enter the museum a bit of a cheek, considering the entry price

Blend of urbanisation and tradition. If your dream is to stroll past historic monuments with your beloved one in the streets, paved with the stones and loved by the God, Durbar Square is the perfect site. The Museum at the centre of the square, the Kasthamandup Temple,which is believed to be built with the wood of a single tree and the beautiful statue of Kal-Bhairab are the gifts left to us by our history.A place to be!!
Not to miss. Liked :- Everything about it esp old temples and street foodsDisliked :- I dont see anything to disliked about it

a nice place to spend the time. this place is good for history buffs. It represents the culture of kathmandu. It is really a cool place to hang out too. Lots of people come around in the evening to durbar sqaure. Tea from street is really good. Nice place
Superb!. Like being in an Indiana Jones movie- this place has to be seen to be believed. Hard to tear yourself away

A good place to hang out in Kathmandu. The king's palace which is in the durbar marg is the obvious attraction and its a must see for anyone wanting to know the history of the Nepalese kingdom . Stepping out of the palace you will be greeted by tons of branded shops/malls and even eat outs.There is one restaurant just opposite to the palace make sure you sit there to get a good view of the palace.

In comparison to others, not worth it.. Having been to a few squares around Kathmandu I can't recommend this one as the best. It was the most expensive one to visit but not nearly as nice as the square in Putan. If you only have the time to see one make it out to Putan there are heaps of temples and great little restaurants with a view of the whole square. Kathmandu square is home to the living goddess, if you are interested in that kind of thing, but she very rarely comes out so don't pay a guide to see her it just wont happen.

Must visit. Walking to Durbar Square from Thamel is a good experience. This place is really nice, but I'd recommend a guide to be able to understand and learn all about the temples, culture and history. The entrance fee seems a bit overpriced for foreigners, but it is worth to visit.
Great but busy. If you dodge cars and bikes you will be okay here. I wish the spitting was limited but that is nepal for you. Good to see the history though and beautiful to understand the history.

Walk to Durbar square early in the morning. Walk there from Thamel via the back streets preferably early in the morning. You'll be rewarded with colourful markets of every description lining the narrow alleys and streets. Durbar square will be even better after your walk.
Culturally interesting. Worth a visit to see this Heritage site. The history, architecture & culture here are unique, but a face mask is useful to prevent dust choking & pigeon poo etc smell.

A busy square...or is it?. Durbar square represents the true culture and historic background of Kathmandu. Its a very busy place. You can see amazing architecture, the details of the palace. People wandering around, couples cuddling, children playing. Its amazing..

overrated, overpriced. With all due respect to locals, this place is extremely overrated and overpriced (750 rupees for foreigners) when you go inside there are empty temples surrounded by people eating, playing, hanging out...very dirty! and lots of vendors...I don't see why the charge! There is some history there but nothing you need a guide for. I do not recommend it but find out by yourself!

A magic experience. The ancient part of Kathmandu is a jewel , well preserved , with its temples , palaces of an unique architecture , ornate windows , open markets and holy men boasting incredible length of hair and beards . Despite the crowds thronging the heart of the city , the atmosphere is a magic one , as if the history of this old country could be at your fingertips .

A Square thats not at all square in attetude.. I'm going back to 1972, whilst hitching all over the middle east and the Indian sub continent. Having made my way to this city at the top of the world, A city that sits on a plateau surrounded by high mountains. the valley is the only flat and level terrain in the Himalayan mountains, Allegedly the result of a huge Meteor strike back in the dawn of history.The thing that struck me, and endeared me to the Nepalese people was when i entered a Temple, unusual in as much as it was dedicated to the Hindu Elephant God Ganesha, with this country being Buddhist in its outlook.Upon entering i was surprised to see a seated Buddha in crossed legged Lotus position. Another jolt to my senses was opposite hanging on the wall a Cross with the figure of Jesus upon it..Of course there was a statue of our friend the Elephant God, Albeit only just taking pride of place over the Goddess Kali. Now to me a cynic, when it comes to the divisive nature of religion, seemed a very grown up and sensible arrangement, when upon asking it was explained simply and in a matter of fact tone.that although, the Temple was for Ganesha,. Followers of other faiths, no matter who or what were welcome to worship inside. A good and healthy arrangement to my way of thinking. The other thing that i took too was the government licensed shop that sold nothing but the best Hashish to be found anywhere.Subsequently closed down after demands from the Americans, who in my opinion interfere far too much in matters around the world. Again your date box wont allow me to select so i'll click on one, But ignore it as the year was 1972

For a Slice of History of Nepal. Basantapur in Katmandu gives you a glimpse of the live of the Nepali Kings. The place is where the coronation ceremonies were held. The architecture has a strong bias towards Western and Eastern styles. The feature of the place is the presence of 50 temples within the area and comprises the temple Taleju Bhawani. The Shiv-Parvati Temple is also found here as also the Hanuman Dhoka. Parts of the area are converted into museums. Together with the museums one can glean the history of Nepal. Comingling with the ancient history of Nepal is the freak street which is nearby. This street has the dubious record of having been the epicenter of the hippie culture of the 1960s. Though not much activity is found in this street, it is worth seeing just to remind you not to get carried away by drugs.

Templetastic. D.S. is the heart of cultural and historic Kathmandu. If your into old buildings and fantasising about times gone by then this is the place to go to get that in Kathmandu. There is an entrance fee of 750 rupees per person. I feel is a little steep as cars and motorbikes erode the atmosphere a little but scores of temples and street vendors make for a fascinating place.

reliving history. In the middle of the chaos of Kathmandu, lies a place deeply mired in history. From children playing with pigeons in the morning to architectural delights from bygone eras, this place is a must visit. Go climb one of the temples and just soak in the sights that will engulf you.

Good architecture, the only place of relevance in Kathmandu. This place has a lot of historical relevance for Nepal. The different temples. The house of the living goddess. The museum with the history of the royal family of Nepal. Pretty good. A guide is recommended. We thought initially that we wouldn't need one. But when we finally did, we thought it was worth it.

A blast from the past, it hadn't changed. I was in Durbar square in 1977 but had been disappointed with the progress of the city when I visited again in Oct 2013, but once I returned to the square it was like I had experienced a time warp. Nothing had changed, it was fantastic.
Fascinating tour of the square and all the buildings. Took a guide well worth if lots of photo opportunities . Buildings are wonderful with fantastic carvings
Go knowing the history. It's a very fascinating place but go knowing the history and stories. Otherwise, it might look all the same to you!

Must visit the living goddess Kumari. This place is fantastic. There is much to see here; many temples. But the biggest draw card is the living goddess Kumari, who comes out very briefly at different times of the day. We saw her at 4 pm and it is said that if she makes eye contact with you you will,have good fortune. Be warned however, the area is full of 'guides' looking to give you a tour. Most will approach you with an offer and will leave you alone after you politely tell them no. However some are very aggressive. We got harassed by one fellow who kept following us around and would not take no for an answer even when we told him him to leave us alone (after trying to politely say no many times). This made the visit less enjoyable. Nevertheless, if you are prepared for this, it really is a must see. It is quite something, and there are cafes around the square where you can take some great rooftop photos of the grounds.

Interesting architectures. We were there with a guide hired by our local travel agent. He brought us to see Kumari, and we were very lucky to see a glimpse of her :) we walked past a temple with kamasutra statues and one with many pigeons. Buildings looked old but with lovely wooden design. We spent many hours there shopping, people watching - so crowded, dusty, and noisy. Best part, there's tourist toilet and reasonably clean.

Big. Restaurant sweet home (rooftop) overlooking the square. View is not as spectacular as Patan Square. Food at this restaurant is not as good as others.
Good shopping place though.

Marvelous Construction..... Like a court in front of the old royal palace of the Kathmandu Kingdom. Another spectacular architectural place in Kathmandu Valley recognized as UNESCO World Heritage Site….
Good for historic photography.

Pushy Guides, but do not be put off going.. I just wanted to chill and enjoy Durbar Square but was constantly being hassled by Guides. I most probably would have found out more about the area if I had a guide, but was happy just wandering on my own. One guide told me I was a very "difficult person" and they were just trying to support their families etc, and talking to others I am not alone in this sort of treatment. Do not be put off going to Durbar Square. If you choose not to have a guide, just beware of the tactics they use and be very firm. Aside from that this is a amazing place to visit I spent 3 hours and could have easily spent more time there. It is a busy place and great to just sit and watch the world. Entry fee is INR$750.00 and you are given a brochure/map. A funny thing happen to me there. I was standing near the entrance to the museum, next thing I hear this crashing noise, I turn to see broken clay roof tile on the ground about 5m from where I am standing and up on the roof, a monkey ready to hurl another clay tile.
Great place to hangouts. Get everything u want to. Ancient city, Colourful place, Ancient culture, Great wines & dines, Friedly people, Unique festivals, many more. One wholeday just not enough.

Stay with the Group !. My wife and I were part of a 12 person travel group trekking in Nepal. We had plans to meet for lunch at a restaurant in a nearby square, had been shopping for paintings, completed a purchase, and were attempting to go to the restaurant for lunch. Where ? Not quite as easy as we thought, kept moving from location (square) to location, nothing looked familiar concerning the defined restaurant. Long story short, went to Tourist Bureau, got connected to our tour Guide, he came and rescued us, first time in 27 years of international travel that we had been " lost " !

Sensory overload. Fascinating area. Great people-watching, a few interesting (and quite a few ordinary) buildings, a huge market for kitsch, and some of the only pushy, overbearing touts and would-be guides we encountered in Nepal. One of them threatened my karma if I didn't hire him. No photos of the Kumari, should you be lucky enough to see her. Some bureaucracy associated with your admission if you want it to be valid for the length of your visa; probably not worth it unless you need to traverse the area because of where your lodgings are.

Crowded place with historical buildings. Easy access from Thamel, but gets crowded with lots of beggars and unwanted guides that charge you afterwards. Templos are magnificente, some are curious such as Kumasi House, the towering and imposing Tulenga and a bit to the north the Akash Bhairav temple. To get a great view of Telunga area, come from the north via Akash Bharaiv temple and look for Jyona Belee bar and restaurant, rooftop with awesome view for pictures and relaxing place.

A feast for the eyes. Was disappointed that I could only spend a few hours here. It's the kind of place that would be enjoyable just hanging out over a day. It's far more enjoyable than times square or many other public squares around the world.
interesting. interesting to look around, the architure is really beautifull, again beware of the guys who constantly follow you around as guides, some do not take no for an answer,

wonder of the world. Lost myself in the historic durbar sq for a couple of hours. I was approached by a man who told me I needed a guide.and although his knowledge of the sq and its surroundings was without question , I found I was constantly being taken to area's where I was asked for money either by buying something I didn't want or for instance paying to take a photo. He then asked for 2,000 rupee as a tip. Or he would accept my watch in leu of payment. On my second visit I wandered around at my own pace and took in the sights and sounds without a guide or any fear of being approached for cash. You dont need a guide. And be aware if your wearing expensive jewellery or watches. Having said that I would go back tomorrow .

Colourful part of city. Visited twice and was fortunate to see a Hindu farmers festival the second time which was great. Worth seeing, but would really recommend you go further out to Bhaktapur which is a much more interesting walled city with real atmosphere. A local taxi will take you there for about 1000 rupees, and there is better merchandise to buy.

Nice Historical place. Kathmandu Durbar Square or Hanumandhoka Durbar Square is the plaza in front of the old royal palace of the Kathmandu Kingdom. It is one of three Durbar Squares in the Kathmandu Valley in Nepal, all of which are UNESCO World Heritage Sites.
Basantapur have clean environment nice place to hang out with friends in evening time. Will visit again .

things you should do before you die!. It is a beautiful place: it got the history, art, and the Nepalese culture blended in to it. "When in Rome, do as Romans do", we tried to see the Durbar square and Nepal as in its own, rather than from our own frame of mind/vision. It is quiet different than what we have seen before or what we are used to, but this is the history, art and culture of Nepal. We appreciated the difference, and happy that we lived the moment. We certainly recommend to others whether they are solo travellers, couple, or just friends.

Hard To See History Through the Commerce. I knew this was special from the guide book but perhaps the markets and filth interfere with that magical conection to the history and spirituality of the Square. For me at least!

VISIT TO DURBAR SQUARE. A must see place in the middle of the townto know the history of Kathmandu How it got its name etc.may not be of value for westners but not for Hindus entry fee varies for locals SAARC Nations and others,as it is a vast place taking a guide will be useful to know the history.but beware of exoribant prices they quote you have to really bargain,we a group of 12 were asked 1200 nepali rupees and we bargained for 600 N.C.GUARDS like in Bucking ham palace were seen who change duties every 3 hours.Kumai Garh Kastya Mandap Hanuman Dhoka etc are intersting which took nearly more than an hour,due to lack of time we skipped Museum which would need another 45 min to an hour as per thd guide
Expensive But nice. This is very big and very nice but very expensive  There are lot of historical palace and good and quite place
Old Palace and museum. One of oldest and biggest palaces of the Malla Kings and there is also a historic museum inside the palace. It is worth visiting as it is also a UNESCO preserved Heritage site.

Not missing anything. We did the lonely planet walking tour around Durbar Square and its surrounds. The streets are dirty, smelly, it is busy and polluted. The Hindu temples are poorly maintained. Street guides hassle you to pay them for a tour. There are many beautiful things only a short taxi ride out of Kathmandu city - I would use my time to see these.
Need time to roam about. A busy place with lot to see, and lot of vendors selling Kukri (Knife), flute etc. You can take photographs, ancient architecture can be seen in the buildings here.
Fascinating. Sadly only spent a couple of hours here. Could easily have spent the best part of a day. Every turning of a corner brought another wonderful building.

Fascinating insight in architectural buildings. Well worth a wander through - if only to see a neo-classical palace cheek by jowl with buddhist temples and other Nepalese buildings. Great atmosphere and always full of people.

maybe the first place in Kathmandu you should visit. It is very busy, the entrance fee was roughly $7.50 per person but you really should hire a guide, that added another $5.00 for two but so what?The guide knew his history and explained many of the temples, when they were built,what a Durbar Square is.The money I was told is used to repair some of the buildings damaged during an earthquake.The hustle and bustle of Durbar will somewhat "train" a person as to how to navigate Kathmandu.

Very busy. Other reviewers have commented on the price. We were with a tour so our entry was paid as part of the tour. An interesting place, but difficult to focus on any attractions. The various sites in Kathmandu seem to be similar. So many of the attractions were actually dirty. Our main focus became the attractive dress of the Nepalese ladies.

Overpriced for what it is. As everywhere, prices have been increased tremendously. 750 rupies is a steep enterance fee. Technically, you should be able to walk the square without paying (obviously, local visitors and traders don't pay). If you want to go inside the palace, you do need the ticket though. It is definitely worth a visit, put 750 rupies is rather overpriced.

Busy area, Patan and Bhaktapur better. Quite busy with traffic, both many motorcycles and a few cars running through so not an entirely comfortable and certainly not relaxing place to view beautiful old buildings. You can judge by the photographs posted. Patan Durbar square is better, and Bhaktapur with its Durbar Square along with the other squares in Bhaktapur is far better.

Not sure what the fuss is about. Maybe we visited at the wrong time but I really don't know what the fuss is about this place especially compared to the beautiful Durbar Squares in Patan and Bhaktapur.  We found it over priced and disappointing.  If you have limited time for sightseeing I would visit some of the other sites over here. We didn't take a guided tour as the ticket price was quite expensive so maybe we would have got a lot more out of our visit if we would have had one.

Museum beneath the sky. This is the very center of Kathmandu. It is packed with historical buildings, temples, palaces and thousands of people selling everything. It is understandable why it is so busy. You'll need a good local guide to explain you what you are looking at. Nice art galleries around, cafes, allow 2 to 3 hours to soak the atmosphere.

History mixed with modern. What a place! Extremely bustling and very crowded, if you can get over this it has beautiful buildings steeped in history with an incredible atmosphere not to be missed. It is not somewhere to visit twice, once experienced never forgotten but not to be missed. Bargaining is expected in the many shops and is good fun if you have the nerve, unfortunately like all the shops in Kathmandu they appear to contain all the same things and not owed by locals!!!,
good old place. wow i love this place its such wounder full and so good old place u will see many old historical things so i request you please visit there and you will be so happy !!

Ancient welcome. Certainly a must see, both to absorb the stunning architecture, the culture that the locals have up held (even though it is full of tourists). Makes for awesome photos to show friends , family and brag.

Madness!. There is no doubt that there are fabulous carvings, beautiful buildings and potentially a lot of atmosphere. However, if you stand still long enough to take notice of any of it you are likely to be run over by half a dozen motorbikes, invited for several rickshaw rides, offered the services of at least 3 guides and have a pigeon mess on your head. Intellectually - fabulous, emotionally - half an hour was more than enough!

Interesting. Hmmm... Not really sure what to say about this site. It has some interesting buildings and of course the palace of the Kumari, living goddess. We spent 30 minutes or so here and got fed up with the hawkers constantly trying to relieve you of your money.Don't forget that you need to pay to enter the square every time - no re-entry!

Worth a visit. Make sure you buy a ticket when you enter, my daughter nearlly got arrested as she was unaware that all foreigners need a ticket and with so many hustlers in Kathamandu you are not always sure who is genuine!

Ancient Nepal. I visited kathmandu durbar square on 9 Oct, 2013. It was a great journey to the ancient Nepalese Architecture. it was a nice day for travelling and the site was 10 min walk from my hotel at thamel. I with one of my friend, visited the place. as we are from saarc country, we got a discount in entry ticket which was good. we saw so many temples in this place, the place is well preserved.

Especial. A place known to have every stone, every bit of the entire place consecrated so that people live and work in an environment full of positive energy. The area is free of traffic and so walking around to admire this ancient temple city is a pleasure.

Fascinating architectural display of Hindu buildings. Although crowded, dirty, and noisy, the square is a must-see, preferably with a guide who can explain all the buildings and their uses. But don't get lost, and watch out for the motorbikes, motorcycles, and other vehicles!

Heart of Kathmandu. A lively, though tourist-oriented, place. If buying, bargain ferociously. Don't give to beggars, as it enforces a bad precedent. Beware of scammers (the "gemological" scam, in which you are scoped out as a foreigner, and offered priceless jewels for a meager sum to take to ready buyers in your home country, is quite common, and some of these scammers can be quite pushy, especially if they think you are naive.) Don't drink water unless it's bottled, and don't eat vegetables unless they are iodinated. Many cities in Nepal have "Durbar Squares" as a prime place.

Nothing Much. Nothing much to see here. Luckily i didn't plan to go to this place. I was just staying nearby and have a few hours time before flight so i visited this place. It was ok but nothing much really.

What a disappointment. The square has been allowed to deteriorate and is surrounded by tourist-orientated shops. The vendors in the square are pushy and try to overcharge westerers 3 or 4 times. Much better to go to Durbar Square in Patan a few miles away
Nothing to write home about. It's okay but only worth seeing if you're already in Nepal and have the time to see it. Don't change plans just to see it.
Nice cultural buildings. Evening at Basantapur are sight to behold. The people, lights, vendors and locals everything looked wonderful. Have clicked some photos, will upload soon

Wonderful. Wonderful architecture of the palaces and temples. The palace of the living goddess was a little bit of interesting, very un western Nepalese culture - go at 12 noon and you may see her at the balcony.

Top Spot. Kathmandu’s Durbar Square is a short walk from the Thamel district. Our guide actually took us to the square so we didn’t have the same problem that others have had with would-be guides hassling us to hire them. Lonely Planet has a couple of very good self-guided walking tours if you don’t want to hire a guide. Tickets for the Square cost around $10 but we were able to extend our 1-day ticket for free for the whole of our stay in Kathmandu by going to the site office in Basantapur Square (alongside the Durbar Square). I love all the beautiful old temples, palaces and monuments in the Square, it’s great to climb the steps on some of the buildings or sit in a rooftop café and watch the world go by. The history and the architecture on display in this area is amazing. Unfortunately, since my last visit to Nepal, the amount of traffic has increased markedly and the incessant vehicle noise and tooting of horns has spoilt the atmosphere of this lovely old part of the city. It would be great if traffic was banned from this area to allow tourists and locals alike to go about their business without being nearly run over every few seconds. However, this is still the number one attraction for me in Kathmandu – I consider it a “must see” if you’re visiting Nepal.
you may visit yeah. its a very old place to visit. you can see lost of temples here. there is 1 museum also. old people sit around at day time.

Watch out for those sneaky guides. Great place, much history, many shrines and temples all centrally located. If you happen to bump into a decent English speaking local they will most likely start telling you history and start guiding you. After that is all done they will corner you and say, you can pay me what you think I deserve. The best way out of this is to simply tell them that you've got a guide and you're waiting for them or you've already taken a guide. They will also try and sell you some traditional art. This reunited my experience overall!

Come here in the evening. If you're like me, you may have seen photos at night of the square and lots of things happening - come in the evening and watch from a rooftop cafe or restaurant as you sip your lassi and enjoy the movement down below. You can't come to KTM without visiting the square. Of great historical importance too.

life in kathmandu. from 5 am till 10 pm this place if full of people,cars and risciò. we payed for go inside but we went in the office of tourism for the "visitors card" in order the other day we no need to pay. It is a very nice square full of stories and ...shadu!

Historical place. 750 rupees entrance fee considerably high charge for just to walk around. Very interesting place to go and see but the evening with the lights gives the place a completely different look and feel. Be aware of the false Buddha Priests begging for money and of the women holding babies asking you to buy milk, which they later sell. A few tour touts trying their hardest to take you on a tour. Evening walk about is free.
Atmosphere !. Not to be missed ! So much to see ! The crowds of locals and tourists all taking their time to see all that Dubar Square has to offer create a marvellous atmosphere.

Architectural splendour in the square where India meets China.. Durbar Square is one of those unique spots where architectural cultures merge. This square is simply littered with fascinating buildings little changed over the centuries. It's a great place to hang out. Climb up to the top of one of them and sit with the locals and watch the world go by. If you are in need of refreshments cast your eye around for the roof-top restaurant. We had great veggie pakoras whilst looking down at the hustle and bustle of the square. Unlike 20+ years ago, there is now an entrance fee charged though it is poorly enforced. We walked right past the ticket booth unchallenged!The only downside is that the square is not pedestrianised. Lines of traffic inch forward through the market stalls and pedestrians honking their horns to no avail.

Stunnning buildings lost in traffic. Such beautiful buildings and such a pity that they are slowly being left to crumble and be subsumed by traffic and the general chaos of a market place .I don't think that the traffic and market actually add to the atmosphere either-I think they detract from it and the square would do better of it were pedestrianized so that the beauty of the buildings could be showcased rather than it being treated as a traffic roundabout.

Walk up the steps of any of the temples and you will generally be left alone. Just south of the Thamel district in Katmandu is the area of ancient palaces and temples known as Durbar Square. It will cost you about $10 for a ticket but your ticket can be made good for your entire stay in Nepal (ask the ticket seller where to go to get that taken care of). You can also wander around the smaller alleys just adjacent to Durbar Square and find yourself in the heart of the temple area having bypassed the ticket seller.You will be besieged by guides offering their services, by rickshaws and taxi drivers offering to take you to the monkey temple, by flute and fruit and tiger balm sellers, but this will be no different from your experience in any of the tourist areas of Katmandu. Walk up the steps of any of the temples and you will generally be left alone to sit or take photos or read a novel or chat with locals or with other tourists.There are parts of the enclosure which are really public streets and should be completely accessible. Many of the shops marketing merchandise to tourists can be visited only if you buy a ticket or get in otherwise. This was my fourth trip to Katmandu and the first time I had to pay. I wonder how much of the money they get goes to maintaining the buildings and how much goes toward the general Katmandu budget.While Durbar Square is an important site in Katmandu it's best to follow the guide book tours and visit the many temples and courts and shops north and south of the Square as well. It's even better to just walk and get lost, then locate yourself and get lost again. Be especially vigilant, though: the tourist areas of Katmandu are noisy and crowded and polluted and overrun with vehicles dashing madly along. Even a short walk can be exhausting.

Clean and enjoyable environment. You can see so many handicrafts in Basantapur area. Basantapur have clean environment and is good place to hangout with your friends.I say doing nothing there is very enjoyable. just sit in a corner and watch peoples and their activities like people selling things, romantic couples, kids playing etc.Evening time is perfect here at basantapur.

Bustling temples and shrines - in need of some upkeep. Located in a bustling area of town, this square features people in native dress (who expect a few rupees when their picture is taken) monkeys, an array of temples and shrines, cows, and residence of the living goddess. Many of the buildings are wooden, and in need of some upkeep. The military has an active presence in the square, and throngs of people coming and going and visiting the shrines. It is a good introduction to Nepali religious life, and the blending of belief into everyday lives. Patan is farther away, but better kept. The shop sellers at this square are aggressive. Watch your belongings carefully.

Timeless heritage buildings but they're not well managed. I was here 20 years ago and Durbar Square seems unchanged; it is as evocative as ever with its aged, crumbling and timeless buildings. The only difference is that tourists are now charged a fee to enter (however, we didn't pay the fees as we came in from Freak Street and nobody was guarding that entrance). We found the practice of paying a fee ridiculously inconsistent as locals are allowed to set up a market once the sun sets; then anyone can walk in and out, sit on the stairs, spit everywhere, etc. Nobody guards the Square once the sun sets, in contradiction to the govt's desire to protect its heritage. However, the night market is really interesting, full of local flavour and life. It's the best time to visit Durbar Square as it's most authentic then.

So many things to see!. There're lots of old temple around here which have interesting history. The local life was also interesting. So many ladies made plates from teak leaves, some sold flowers for worshiping, some just walked around, and some just sat still. The oldest temple also situated here. I hired a guide here because I didn't have any books and information with me, and I think that's a good decision because it cost $10 but I got so many knowledge about everything in this Durbar Square. I liked the Kumari Chowk the most, and Kamarsutra temple was also interesting. ^^You can walk here form Thamel, it take just 10 mins.

lots to see - palace, living goddess, temples. One of three Durbar (royal palace) squares in the Kathmandu Valley. It is the site of the Hanuman Dhoka Palace Complex, which was the royal Nepalese residence until the 19th century and where important ceremonies take place. The palace is decorated with elaborately-carved wooden windows and panels and houses the King Tribhuwan Memorial Museum and the Mahendra Museum. Good museumWe also visited the Kumari temple – home of the living goddess , a virgin girl chosen through an ancient and mystical selection process to become the human incarnation of the Hindu mother goddess, Durga. We were not able to see her though, because she makes an appearance after 4PM. We arrived 12NN. It was okay, we went to the balcony cafes instead and enjoyed the view. There is also the Macchendra nath temple dedicated to the god of rain and Bhairaw temple. We were able to find good souvenirs in the Durbar Square at reasonable prices. It turned out to be a good shopping place for us - although as tourists, we prefer the Patan Durbar Square.

Very interesting architecture. If you can I would recommend walking through one of the market streets on the way to Durbar Square. Bring a camera and expect to buy a ticket at one of the guarded tollbooths found at each entrance.You can see most of the area in about an hour. There aren't many (or any) people hawking wares here so you don't need to worry about being frequently approached like in similar tourist areas across Asia where sellers distract from enjoying the sites.

Historical Location. A lot of historical building in one place. A must visiting location while you are in Kathmandu. There is no notes, marking and information in the outside to know about the place. Need a book or you to search google to know about this location.

prefering patan. It is a great sight, but it does not beat Patan Durbar. Bhaktapur however is by far the best especially if you can stay a few days and just wander about early in the morning and late in the evening with all tourgroups trucking back to Kathmandu.

Durbar Square. A marvelous place but watch out for being charged if you access by one route rather than via others. However, the amount is small and the location quite spectacular. It's worth visiting at different times of the day and in the late afternoon the tiled roofs take on a lovely warm colour.One or two of the 'characters' will also expect payment to have their photographs taken.Watch out for motorbikes...........they seem to think they have right of way over everybody else.

Durbar Square. Lots of people wanting to take you on tours, then they dump you when you don't want to buy a Thangka painting! The Square itself had many beautiful buildings and is worth a short visit.

8 year old girl deitized as godess. The Kumari (living goddess) lives here and is worshipped by the locals.Other attractions are the centuries old buildings and fine craftsmanship of the architecture. We visited the palace museum which depicts a brief but informative story of ancient Nepal and the struggle to freedom from the Rana regime.US$10 entrance fee seems tough but I think they need the funds to upkeep the exhibits.

lots of retaurants and good for shopping. very busy road, lot s of cars, mortor bikes on the small street and theres no pathway. but lots of shops, restaurants, money exchanges, good for shopping and have lunch or dinner there.

Avoid pushy World Heritage Site People. Durbar Square is cool simply because it's so old. World Heritage Site people will try to make you pay. Leave the area and try to find a smaller street to enter the square. If you're white, you're basically going to be singled out when walking towards the square because you're white and they will ask you to pay.

Great place to shop for souvenirs. If you go early in the morning when there is not many tourists around you can negotiate the price of every item you want to buy. Don't be afraid to low ball the prices. And if they won't go down on the price just walk away, that's when the real bargaining begins. They will follow you and if you hang on to the price you wish to pay you will win the deal.

beautyful. this place is beautiful. though there were number of durbar square in kathamndu but i liked the bhagtapur more. it was so peaceful and beautiful.you can see all the monastery and also there are restaurants and shops. one can spend a whole day there.

Noisy, dusty, busy and fantastic heart of the city. What a sight to behold, people from all walks of life seem to converge here. Sellers, tourists, shop keepers and locals alike. Most of the major sights in Kathmandu are within easy walking distance from this central square. Enjoyed coffee and Momo's on the rooftop restaurant overlooking the square above the Himalayan Coffee shop.
A sight to see. The atmosphere was amazing the people the beautiful buildings worth seeing check out the art schools you can buy the real Thangkas there for a better price than at the temples

Fascinating place. Shocked with the over-charged entrance fee of 10 dollars but it was ok experience in general. It was the day of big festival so we got to see the locals celebrating the festivity, women wearing bright colorful dresses and dance on the streets. But most corners are quite dirty and slippery (it was rain on the day of our visit and the day before) not sure whether it was because of holiday time so that no cleaning crew are on duty, or is it always like that. But the view from the top of the temple was nice looking at the mountain.

A lot to discover !!!! GO IN THE DAY AND EVENING TIME !!. a fascinating place with many many corners and things to discover (guide was helpful)
Go also in the evening / sunset and go to the top of the highest rooftop resto you can find and shoot some fascinating fotos !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
enjoy ;-)

Astonishing magical place. We had only an hour between meetings, and it was the day of the living god, so crowded. But this was one of the most extraordinary places I have ever seen (and I have lived overseas for 35 years). It was a perfect day and bright, hot but fresh. The buildings are beautiful and grouped as they are, seemed powerful and instill assurance and peaceful authority. The public spaces led on from one to another with more and more remarkable sights. The variety of structures (some even classical) was deeply satisfying. It was really like something one had dreamed. The people were everywhere, colours and sounds, offering to guide or sell, but very friendly and polite. The mix of shops, cafes, religious shrines, open areas for traditional gathering, balloon and trinket sellers, was absolutely wonderful. I am planning my next trip with my wife and family. I recommend this place to everyone. It does you good.

Peaceful. Again expensive fees to get in here they even charged 10 dollars for foreigners but I still highly recommend the visit. It's a must see place when visiting Kathmandu and right a across the street is the best place to eat local food in kathmandu.....lunch for four was less than 10 dollars and fabouless..........

Busy Place. I got driven around in a rickshaw and to be honest when I did try and stop and get out to look round tens of people descended on me from beggars to traders and so I got back in the rickshaw and went somewhere else.
Durbar Square at night... amazing. Visited in evening time, ate at a lovely restaurant overlooking the square and all the fascinating buildings

Great Durbar Square. There's a fee to be paid at the entrance, which will be employed on maintaining the square. Locals hang out, and the fact that there are no cars, makes this Durbar a nice place to stay for a while. Even thought all the terraces around it are quite touristic, they offer amazing views and ok food.
Amazing place. I had a guide so I did not get lost. If you do not have a guide, make sure you have a map. The Pottery Square was amazing.
We saw Kumari. With just a simple shout from our guide, we got the chance to see the Living Goddess, Kumari. Great experience i must say.

Old city. Unlike anything we have seen, walking to get to the square lots of shops and different modes of transport of goods. since it is a holiday during this time lots of people especially young ones every where very festive like Christmas back home.

The happening place. this is the town square, sort of the old town. This is where the royal palace is, some temples, shops, museums, a big town square. Nepal has very unique architecture and this is the hotbed of it. Do walk through the museum, it is not huge but very informative about the past rulers of Nepal.I'm glad we had a guide to explain everything so consider getting a guide for a 1/2 day to tour this square.

always a must. the Durbar square in Kathmandu is the largest among the old capitals in the Kathmandu valley.the palace,even with the ice-cream-like neoclassic section of Rana style,has some of the best carving in town, the towers are the highest and it is full of interesting spots,as the mask of White Bhairab behind the window (open only during Indra jatra),the powerful Kal Bhairab (another masterpiece of the Licchavi period,who punishes the liars ,protects vehicles and is Lord of Obstacles) and the Shiva Parvati window,where the god and his spouse are smailing and always blessing everybody .the Taleju temple is peraphs the most fascinating temple in Nepal,peraphs because we are not allowed? its massive tower is dominating the square.in the Kastamandap area ,the most pretty temple is the one of Maru Ganesh.Maru means "which doesn't exixst" in newari,this name is given because the small pagoda is without pinnacle on the top.all the area is called Maru.curiosity can take you down to the old Pigs alley,where in hippies times many small lodges , guest houses and coffe shops were legendary for their famous "special pastries and cakes".of course,the main actraction of Durbar square is the celebrated house of the Kumari,the living Goddess whose legend one can read everywhere.Durbar square is at its best during the festival of Indra Jatra,held early autumn,with masked demons dances and the procession of the Kumaris chariots as the top event.

Absorb the history & living culture. Take a day, wander around, and get a local guide to learn more. Tip on a guide: you want a professional guide who has a permit. It's worth paying for the extra days if you love the culture - after you get the 1 day entrance pass, you can go to the Kathmandu Metropolitan City (KMC) office (it'll be on the map you get once you pay the entrance fee) next to the Kumari temple and get the 3 day visitor pass (take a passport photo along with you). We spent a few days wandering through the Ganesh temple, the old palace museum (fascinating) and bumped into a local guide who we negotiated for 100,000 for 2-3 hours PM me if you want his details. Too many temples/ experiences to talk about here, but the carvings on the old palace museum were already enough to get us going back for the 3 days. The price of entry to support the maintenance of this Unesco listed site is cheap, in my opinion. (Please don't be like the arrogant tourists we saw who refused to pay the entry fee as "they were only shopping, not going into sites/ temples"). A small price to pay to absorb such history/ culture. :)

Worthwhile seeing. Despite the apparent chaos given that it is the peak tourist season in Nepal, the Durbar Square (a world heritage site) is worth seeing. We went with our own guide from our local Tour operator (Smile Adventure & Tours) which was a bonus given his local knowledge & experience. The "living goddess Kumari" occasionally appears at her window but not for long & no photos are allowed. Just to see the craftsmanship of the Newari people makes the trip a must.

Durbar Square. No visit to Katmandu, Nepal is complete without a visit to Durbar Square. The square has many temples and palaces which epitomises the religious and cultural life in Katmandu. See the temples for Kumari, King Malla and Kal Bhariv.

It's quite fascinating.. I went with a group of friends, all of us girls. I know many would suggest to go with a couple males but if you're all women you WILL be ok, I would just recommend a group of 4-5+. It's not exactly cheap to get in, I think 750 rupees? So be prepared for that. Once you buy admission there will be lots of "tour guides" who will try to show you around, some licensed, some not. Licensed tour guides usually charge 350 rupee per person, but if you go with an unlicensed guy, you can bargain down to about 100 rupee per person. We got a guy who was unlicensed (he hangs around the entrance, wearing a white t-shirt with the little princess, or Kumari, on). If you see him, please use him! He's very knowledgeable and gives a really good deal-- the tour was 45 minutes long and we saw a lot. He's great but of course we never got his name. Make sure to see the Kumari!! She's really cool, and appears by request (your tour guide can do this for you, licensed or unlicensed... but you SHOULD have a tour guide to do it). Worth checking out. Have fun! Durbar Square is really once-in-a-lifetime!!

Central square - Living Godess Kumari. busy central area with a lot of temples and also the former king's palace. Definitely going to visit the living goddess Kumari. She appears occasionally on request for a window opening. It is a young girl playing the role of living goddess obliged to perform until they bleed the first time. It's not allowed to take pictures.

durbar mayhem. dont miss this ; you dont need a guide ; worth ducking into open gateways or youll miss stuff. we got to see the living goddess for a few seconds ;l she looked bored .chill out in one of the restaurants with a roof terrace and people watch . the streets surrounding are interesting too. shame they allow traffic through.

Good place to Hangout. I felt its a good place to hangout there for an hours with your friends. I am little bit disappointed with the street childrens out there who are begging with each and everyone in a different managers.

Good place to visit. One of the good place among the world heritage site. The only problem I see in this place is transportation inside the buffer zone which I would say the management need to manage it as soon as it is possible and offcourse the proper parking. We walked through all the way from government school both time.

Worth a Walk. We happen to walk into the market by chance, after crossing the overhead bridge from Rani Pokhari pond, on a Fri afternoon. There are plenty of things to see, traders on brass crockery, sari, pashmina, Hindu praying materials, ladies garment and sundry supplies. We didn't plan to buy anything as I know my bargaining skill is pretty poor.. need to watch out for tricycle and motorcyclers who rush by your side, a splash from the pothholes might be a pleasant experience.I enjoyed the lively atmosphere, after an hour of snapshots and people watching, we bought some "hand made" incense, my luggage bag is showered with the overwhelming fragrance til now!
wow to it. lot of shopping around, can buy lot many articles of ur interests, like t-shirts, trousers, toys, antiques, caps, hats and many many more.

Need a guide?. As with all the squares in Nepal, we found that you'll be inundated with requests to give you a guided tour. We took the first person here, however, shop around. You will get a better price if you're on a budged
Too crowded. The place was good to see around but too many touts and people tried to sell or offer anything to you....

Really nice travel to the past. A very atmospheric square. It worths to visit the palace and the King's place. Don't miss the roofs of the buildings above you and remember to have a look at them. They are really pieces of art! Make sure that you are good informed about the advantages that give you your entrance ticket in order to visit more than one time the square.
Mixture of Culture & Religion.. This place offers everything. Religion, culture and history of the Kings. Located within the walking range fromThamel. Definitely a tourist place.

Nice place with temples and shops. This place is another must visit while being in KTM. One can shop around for various local items therein and spend some quality time therein. As it is mostly an open space, one must carry hat and goggles.

Capital of once a Hindu Kingdom. The conversion of a Hindu Kingdom to a nascent democratic nation might have changed the nation only politically but the nation is still conservative. This was evident from the rituals and tradition that still prevails there. Durbar square or Hanuman dhoke reverberates with the old world charm. The architecture is fantastic with carvings and all over the building. Even erotic sculpters can be seen on the facades of certain structures.

Interesting sites. Overpriced for what is there. The tenfold increase in price for non-SAARC countries is offensive. Skip the 'palace', it is only an entryway and a court yard. A few interesting sculptures but if you are allocating time you won't cry if you miss this.

Easy to find, Historic Site. After strolling the streets of Thamel make your way to Durbar Square. You will see locals selling goods surrounded by culture and religious spots. Old buildings and beautiful spots will keep you interested.Take your camera!

UNESCO World Heritage Site. Kathmandu Durbar Square ( "UNESCO World Heritage Site") also known as Hanuman Dhoka square is one of the major attractions in Kathmandu Valley. Located at the heart of ancient city in Kathmandu it is surrounding both Hindu and Buddhist temples. Most of them are built in the pagoda style embellished with intricately carved exteriors. The Durbar Square, with its old temples, palaces, epitomizes the religious and cultural life of the people in Nepal.

Exotic learning center for traditional cultures. The picturesque view speaks itself. Wooden carving with longitudinal time frame indicates a portrait of human civilization more than a writing speaks.....

Kathmandu visit. Durbar hall square with its old palace is one of h attraction point in Nepal.the buildings and its architecture has a significant story to tells out the royal clan. The buildings and its near by places greater attention towards more cleanliness and up keep of the building.One can get a glimpse of Nepali culture and taste on visiting his place.
Day trip. Great place and nice local foods. Goats milk yogurt was fantastic! I definitely recommend this place if you get a chance.

Kathmandu Durbar Square. Katmandu Durbar square Pashupatinath is protected by UNESCO world heritage site. Katmandu Durbar square (old Royal palace) which built in 12th century. The Durbar square provides you numerous temples, Kumari Bahal (House of Living Goddess), Kasthamandap (house of wood) and the old museum.

Past & Present together. Durbar Square makes reference to the square opposite the Royal Palace in Nepal (there are many Durbar Squares in Nepal as it used to be made up by several small kingdoms).This clarified, only getting ready to enjoy is left!A great place to step back in time, Durbar Square is live history! One of the most cultural complexes of Kathmandu, a mixture of old Nepalese pagodas, small shrines, temples, narrow lanes and palaces to amaze at how the rich and famous of Kathmandu lived almost 9 centuries ago!Richly decorated building with beautiful woodcarvings. Touristy but still with a flavour of everyday life. Pulsating with life. Extraordinary to enjoy the atmosphere of the colourful old Kathmandu.It is this amalgamation of old and new what gives this magical place a feeling of ancient culture meeting present days. Kumari, “the living Goddess” lives in a palace in the area. An invaluable slice of history and cultural Heritage. Thanks Nepal!
Live History. The Newari arcitacture, design, local customs are amazing and attractive and one feels like living in the amazing past
Climb the stairs to get a good city view. Go into into the courtyard of the former palace area and you can climb up the steep steps to the top for a great view across the city!

A taste of history. Some fascinating buildings. We also saw the house of the Kumari - a female child who is chosen as the living embodiment of Parvati, the consort of the god Shiva. What this amounts to is imprisoning a child a guilded cage which she is only allowed to leave once per year until she reaches menstruation when another candidate is chosen.

Nepalese architecture. The durbar square was one of the memorable things we saw at Nepal, Nepalese architecture History embedded in the nowaday live. You see that people are around this square doing their business. A must see in Kathmandu
Very nepaleese. The Square is very nice as it shows all the Nepalese architecture. There is allot to see in this square and allot to shop for. It is a must see place in Nepal
There are better Durbar Squares.. In all of Nepal, this was the place we were hassled most, sometimes relentlessly. It did spoil the experience somewhat.The square at Bhaktapur was much nicer.

History and live. The durbar square was one of the memorable things we saw at Nepal, History embedded in the nowaday live. You see that people are around this square doing their business, but respect the things from the past. A must see in Kathmandu

interesting place. Very important site and should not be missed! In Durbar Square you will find an old Nepalese pagodas, temples and Palaces . This amazing area is in an historic part of the city, you will need at one day to spen here.

Heart of Kathmandu City. The best things in town is around this area. Fast food joints, fashion boutiques, airlines offices, big banks, good hotels, restaurants is within reach & Thamel is nearby. And so is the former Royal Palace which is now a museum.
HERITAGE SITE. One of the most cultural complex of kathmandu .Durbar square with its old temples,places and cultural life of the people. you need complete one day to cover all places.

Historic Beauty. The Durbar Square offers a mixture of old Nepalese pagodas, temples and Palaces with the presence of a more western looking Palace wing. This area is in an historic part of the city so you can extend your visit to the surrounding neighbourhoods. The only drawback and it is a common problem is that people, especially school children sit on the monuments making picture taking challenging. This is an important site and should not be missed.

Just a tip, really. please plan your day well - the Durbar Square - of Kathmandu as well as Patan - closes at 4pm! we did go to the Bhaktapur Durbar Square which was very nice. Just wish we'd known this piece of information well in time to plan better!

go see. a lovely little square , quite picturesque, home to quite a few temples and the residence of the kumari. we managed to get a glimpse of her, though no photographs are allowed. the vendors here have a lot of stuff but be ready to bargain to about 20% of the quoted price. nice to spend the evening here among the monuments.

The iconic site of Kathmandu. Full of monuments although with less character than before- following the removal of fruit sellers- The Royal Square is THE PLACE to be. Start in the morning or go in the late afternoon.Good coffee in the end of the square after the Kumari House and the souvenir stalls.

Kathmandu and Everest too. This is a place that requires a lot of your time.The many temples, some accessible to view inside and some you can only see from the outside, will take you a good two days.
