There is also a trip to see the sunrise over the Himalayas.The hotel will arrange this for you we paid $45 for a Guide and car/petrol for the day. Included in this the driver will take you to other sites.One site was the place where they carried out the cremations and then the ashes were swept into the river. There were two fires burning when we got there. We bought the driver breakfast and lunch, not compulsory but it was worth it to get his recommendations.The food prices were low anyway My wife and I could eat for about $6.There is an option to fly over Everest . A tip ,ask for a seat on the right of the plane flying in and the left flying oout and you fly over Everest anyway. for nothing.Chaotic but magical place.

Interesting but not what it ought to be. We had been fourteen years ago -- it is in the midst of Kathmandu's chaotic and polluted city center. A visitor should see it but it is less impressive by far than the Durbar Square of nearby Bokhtapur and Patan.

Step back in time. This place deserves two trips - one during the day, and one in the evening. In the light drizzle of Kathmandu in Monsoon season, in the evening, it is just magical. A collection of temples and palaces that make you wonder why they left all that behind for pseudo-Roman magnificence of their newer palaces and buildings. Be amazed at how the rich and famous of Kathmandu lived in the 14th century.

special place. very special,planty special antiq temples ,place for famous festivals,Kumari house, special market,sadhus, for 60 days i was visiting every day /pay once ticket have tousrist pasport-inscludind price of tocket/ visit every day...maybe 20 000 pictuers aws taken by me,

White and Clean Place in Kathmandu. The white Durbar and clean road make you feel good. I don't like the "Dabali (the place where people sit and talk)" as it's so crowded and people there have their own world: don't think it's a public place. The Kumari temple and other temples are the stars of the place. I miss the Night Markets.

Nice architecture but overall a bit disappointing. We went to Durbar Square only yesterday and it cost 200NR in a taxi from Thamel although it is also very easy to walk there and would probably take no more than half an hour.We were actually a bit disappointed with the place when we arrived after it being top of Lonely Planet's things to do list in Nepal and reading great reviews of it on here. The price of 750NR per foreigner is a little steep and although the buildings are nice to look at, they arent mind blowing or anything and the square packed with cars, ricksaws and police definitely took something away from the place.It was worth a visit anyway and it is easy enough to not pay the entry free as the area isnt fenced off and no-one asks for a ticket while walking around.The erotic wood carvings on some of the buildings were interesting to look at the cows and goats around the place definitely give the place that bit more character.

This was a fascinating place - teeming with life. The only downside is that these squares are replicated all over Kathmandu - so you see one and you have seen them all. However, the guides will show you each one with a renewed vigour.Watch out for the moss covered steps around the place - my wife found out just how slippery they are...
Don't miss the museum!. Durbar Square is amazing - just walking around will leave you slack-jawed. Be sure to tour the museum, and don't miss the Kumari who comes to her window each morning at 11:00.
Cultural Heritage. The place was full of ancient architectural buildings and the environment was warm with friendly local people.

See the Royal Kumari. The Royal Kumari comes out about once a month, during the full moon. You can go to the cho and see here when she comes to the window daily or you can see her in her carriage during festivals. This is the only place on this planet where you can see an actual living goddess being worshiped. Please don't believe the street guides who say they throw her away when she hits puberty or that her life will be cursed if she gets married. Both are NOT true. One of the former Kumaris wrote a book and I believe her over these shysters. I think these girls become a bit spoiled, but surely have blessings from the goddess above. The Kumari who wrote the book just seemed so amazing. It's available in the bookstores in KTM. And if you don't believe there is an actual goddess just ask anyone who has had a Kumari miracle-like me! I have to say there is something there...There is a fee for the square, but if you bring two passport sized pictures and a copy of your visa you can come back for free.

Impressive.... The temples, the people, street markets, I just loved it.. One of the main temples, a princess comes out to the balcony to greet the visitors, she shows up twice in the day, we waited over thirty minutes to see her. She's a baby cannot be older than 13 or 14 years of age. Was interesting to see but not sure if worth waiting that long. Forbidden to take pix of her.

Ancient culture meets present day. This place houses a lot of buildings that have been built during the times of the Malla dynasty. The red brick buildings will make you feel as if you are taking a stroll in an ancient city. This place also house the palace in which the girl who is referred to as 'Kumari' lives in. She is believed by the citizens to be a reincarnation of the blood thirsty goddess - Kali. I have been told that this place is used to kill a lot of animals during the time of a particular festival. However, at the time that we visited this place, it was clean and beautiful and inviting. There is a fee for this place as well. However, the charges are lesser if you are from a SAARC country. This place is also splattered with small shrines and temples. The square has been subject to a lot of destruction during the time of the earth quake some years ago. There are good restaurants and a museum inside the square. My husband and I were fortunate enough to visit a place in which the singing bowl is made. The shopkeeper was such a nice person and he sat with us explaining the whole process and demonstrating various uses of the singing bowl. This place is at the back of the 'Fair Trade Centre'. The singing bowl is used for meditation and healing purposes and it is allegedly good for the blood circulation. It is made of a mix of seven metals. The most pricey singing bowl is called the moon bowl and it is apparently made on the day of the full moon. In the square you will also find a lot of boutiques which sell Pashmina and Cashmere and Silk shawls. There are so many restaurants around this place and you might even be able to spend the whole day here! Do not miss this beautiful place!
get a guide. before entering and paying make sure to get one of the 35 recognised guides by the ministry. Ask them for their id.

Awesome!. you can see lots of god/goddesses' statues plus you can study a typical Nepalese life there, some are busy on selling their flowers,necklaces, candies, some are busy on meet ups. Its not only religious place, its also the one of major meeting place, you can see people hanging out with their friends, lovers, brothers, sisters. Its very nice place,

Amazing sight into culture in Nepal. The square has a large Rs750 entrance for tourists, however this is easily avoided if you enter down the side streets! There are lots of temples, don't forget to buy a Yak butter candle and light it for a loved one, 20Rs will buy you all you need. Look out for the quintessential looking Nepalese people who will pose for a picture with you and ask for 100Rs, but 20-30Rs is acceptable!A nice half day trip!

good pace for visit. Kathmandu’s number one tourist attraction swarms with life. Though a few of the square’s 50-plus monuments date from the 12th century, most are from the time of the Malla Kings. Probably the most famous building here is the Kumari Bahal, a building richly decorated with beautiful woodcarvings, which is home to the Royal Kumari, the Living Goddess, a manifestation of the great goddess Durga. Nearby the former Royal Palace is a Malla Dynasty dwelling, once considerably more extensive than today. Within, the courtyard Nassal Chowk, originally hosted dramatic dance performances, now it is the coronation site of the Shah kings and contains some of the finest wood carvings you will see anywhere in the country.

An exciting place to hang out. The area called the Kathmandu Darbar Square is made up of beautiful temples, a couple of large squares and a palace, surrounded by narrow lanes laced with old buildings where people still live and work. Even though touristy, one can get a flavor of everyday life, where locals use it as a thoroughfare and as a place to hang out. Often jammed with motorbikes and pedestrians, young love birds sitting in a corner or up in the open balcony of some temple, the place pulsates with life. The visit to Kumari Chowk is a must, as it showcases beautifully carved Nepali wood work that dates back several centuries. If you are lucky, like we were, you may behold the Kumari, the child living goddess, who sometimes peeks out from the tiny balcony above the smallish courtyard. Photographing the Kumari is forbidden though. Unless you want to see how a Nepali palace interior looks with its dark narrow corridors and rooms with poor display of photos of the former royal family, do not bother to pay an extra amount to visit the Hanuman Dhoka palace. Instead, just sit back and soak in the atmosphere of the colorful old town Kathmandu.

Sit down. Dont just walk, sit down on the tempels and just watch. Than you will make breath taking pictures. If u want buy souvenir, dont do it here. Its all plastic. Go to patan in the shops, best buy good wood carving. Eat on the rooftop restaurant called Bajra if u dont want to pay European prices. Take the chips chilly or the buff moma. U can make pics from baba s on the square but pay them its there only income. Dont give money to begging children give it to disabled those people got really hard time in Nepal. Coming on the square is 7.00 euro. ATM with European card is only working at the bank of Standerd Chartered. Its in Lazimpat. Relax and enjoy!

Interesting ... there's a lot to see. You will need to put a couple of hours aside (and get a guide, or at least a good guide book) to see what this place has to offer. There are lots of buildings, great architecture and interesting history to learn about here, its worth the visit and quite fascinating.
Shopper's Paradise. This is a great place to see the sights, but also to buy great stuff from street hawkers. Roam around, and negotiate. Make sure to walk away, as the prices start high.
Takes you back in time. Very different place transports you to different time in the past. There are lot of old temples and other architectural structures. Never seen something like this before.
nice place to be. Many things to see and a very interesting place. Some of the Saddhu's are fake. They want money to be on your pictures.

very cool. My only regret is not getting a tour guide. the sheer amount of temples and things to see is overwhelming! either study the guide book well, or shell out for someone to explain the buildings.

Beautiful historical buildings. A fascinating place to watch people and wander around, great place to photograph. The pigeons can be bothersome, they sell food to feed them (it's supposed to be good luck...) but it is becoming a real problem....pigeons are dirty! and I did actually notice some locals wearing masks because of all the pigeons.  I don't really understand people saying you shouldn't pay the entry fee and go in the back way or just don't pay....really? I do not agree at all!

Pricey. It looks just swell but you'll not write home about it, unless to complain about the entry fee of 750 rupee. Still, Bhaktapur Durbar Square charges twice that. Get your coffee on Freak Street and avoid the impersonal tourist traps here.

everybody has to visit it!. the main tourist spot in town! 51 temples, the old king palace, see the living goodness between 4-6pm (be lucky, she shows up just for a couple of minutes). If you enter the square from the round about of "new road" you don't have to pay the entrance fee (750 NPR).
A place to visit. This location is seen as the prime site in Kathmandu but it is not the most exciting. Take time to walk through and visit the buildings and take in a bit of history

Old Nepal. You don't have to pay the touristcard to walk around, to have this card is not enforced at all, although it is a nice gesture to the welfare of the place.The place offers good walks around, try to take some time in the side streets of the main drag for some real Kathmandu life which is abundantly present.

If You Don't Have Time,..... Durbar Square of Kathmandu was much smaller than I had expected and fairly disappointing. The ticket costs Rs 750, including the museum admission. You may be caught by a touting guide and their guide fee is very high. If you have more than a half day, I recommend Bhaktapur Durbar Square, not Kathmandu one. Lonely Planet introduces the historic area between Thamel and Durbar Square as a highlight, but it was also not impressive to me.

Charming place. I visited the Durbar square in Kathmandu once, haven't been to the one in Patan or Bhaktapur. I love the way this place feels, small temples and idols in open square, people sitting around and chatting, or people circumambulating with their prayer wheels or prayer beads. Feels good!

A central spot in Kathmandu. Dunbar Square is a haven of local activity. Local people doing their daily routine, visitors picture-taking, shopping, staring, street vendors selling their wares. One will get to see how commerce takes place, the various daily to tourist items sold and the various temples nearby. It is an experience worth treasuring in this far away land.

Great place to visit!. Loved Durbar Square! Wonderful architecture and history in this part of Kathmandu. Lots of shops and street vendors to pick up some beautiful jewelry and prayer wheels. Don't miss the chance to wander around this wonderful square!
handicrafts. so many handicrafts in Basantapur area.it is very nice place just next to new road.I bought nepali wood carving handi crafts.very lovely.

A must See. A good way to spend a few hours in Kathmandu. The Square gets very busy around Mid-Day so an early morning or evening trip is recommended. There`s quite a bit to see- like the Royal Palace, the house of wood (Kasthamandap), the House of the living Goddess (Kumari Chowk) and a few other temples.

An overpriced venue. You do not need to pay the 750 rupees to wander round Durbar Square. Instead why not have a meal in one of the rooftop restaurants overlooking the Square. I also recommend the two walks described in the Lonely Planet guide. They are easy to follow to and from the Square and there are lots of locas who are delighted to steer you in the correct direction.
nice one. Touristic place with clean environment between dirty kathmandu. Lots of couples and people roming around the area at evening. it is a romantic area.
Amazing slice of history. Some of the places have amazing stories - our guide was not too talkative - focussed on moving too quickly.

Feel of the past. Kathmandu Durbar Square has many temples built on traditional style. Our guide explained that it used to be a place for royal palace of Nepalese monarchs hundreds of years ago. Be in peaceful outing or a cultural experience or something of an architecture, if you are in Kathmandu then don't miss it.

Famous brands outlets. If you want to do some shopping, from famous brands outlets like adidas, nike, northface, puma, or different perfumes etc, then yes, this is the right place. But if you want buy some traditional Nepalee products, then No.

Durbar Square of kathmandu. Durbar Square of kathmandu is famous for the world heritage side, living goddess, kal bhairab statue, copper bhairab golden mask, museum inside the premises of the palace, Kasthamandap temple is located where Kathmandu capital of Nepal after that temple made by wood of single tree. lots and lots of more..
Great Architecture !. Great buildings and their designs. The statues are also beautiful. They require special attention. The place should be more clean.

Nice for strolling. I was here for less than a hour--which doesn't quite do the place any justice. However, I was tired and just got back from a 12-day trek to Everest Base Camp. I had to basically do a quick sweep of Kathmandu before my international flight out the next day.The place is quite busy, with people milling about, and those ubiquitous pigeons are pretty much owning the square. I can imagine how exciting Durbar Square would be during the Holi Festival and other special occasions.It costs 750 Nepalese rupees (approx USD 8) to see the Tribhuvan Museum and other parts of Durbar Square. However, since I was just there for 30 minutes or so, I didn't get approached by any official or tourist staff asking me for entrance fee payment, so I'm not really sure how the payment process should happen. At any rate, I should visit the place again (especially the museum) when I return to Kathmandu, and hopefully with more time for sightseeing.

A must see. You can't come to Kathmandu and not visit Durbar square. Theer is an entrance fee, but it's worth it. The entrance also includes a visit to the inner courtyard, which is worth the admission in itself. It's very peaceful there as the locals don't come in (they don't pay the general entrance fee). It's obviously a shame they don't / can't come in, but it is nice to climb the 13 (I think) floored building and not be jammed into the tiny stairway. Great views can be had from the top too. Finally, don't be fololed by those telling you that the child goddess will be coming out soon and they can get you a good spot . . she isn't and they can't. Great to visit though and there's a market at the back that you can get quite good souvenir's from, singing bowls and the like.

the carved buildings are amazing. paying more than the locals. There are guides that walk around with you and you pay them what you think they are worth. But they still ask for more lol. A few more dollars does not hurt. They do know quite a lot. Then they take you up stairs to this room to show you the hand paintings by the Monks which are pretty expensive.

Busy crowded crazy beautifull.. This is what must have been KTM hundreds years ago. Incredible architecture, you are amazed at every corner. I went 4 times (and i'll need a hundred more) and i still discover sculptures, details in the building.It is food for the eyes. Next to temples you have a busy life with street vendors, food stalls. I just love it. You have to take the time and if you can go at different time of the day. It is just enchanting.

The Royal Kumari. "Durbar Square" refers to the plaza opposite a royal palace in Nepal, so there are many durbar squares because Nepal used to consist of small kingdoms. This afternoon we visited the Kathmandu Durbar Square and the next day, we visited the durbar squares of Patan and Bhaktapur. These are the three Unesco-inscribed durbar squares.The highlight of our visit to the Kathmandu Durbar Square was seeing the Royal Kumari at her house, the Kumari Ghar. The Kumari is a pre-pubescent girl who is believed to be the incarnation of a HIndu goddess until she menstruates. We were not allowed to take her pictures. Anyone who does will have his camera confiscated. We took pictures only of her postcards. To the Nepalis, the Kumari is a living goddess. We were there in time for her daily appearance. My tourmates felt that we were lucky to be there at the right time. A glimpse of her is supposed to bring good fortune.I was more impressed with the quarters of the Durbar Museum which we visited next. I took several photos with the nice architecture. We were given an hour to stroll on our own before leaving for dinner.

Interesting look into ancient Kathmandu. This was the first place we visited in Nepal. So our minds was still trying to wrap around the chaos that is Kathmandu. There were tons of people and car/motocycle traffic within the square. And it was great to see the locals worshipping in the temples and just going about their daily lives. The old architectures and temples were very impressive. Although all the historic buildings appeared to be randomly placed. It was not just one big square with buildings surrounding it. There is a museum within the royal palace (?), which was okay. Not many descriptions in english. i don't think I would've miss anything if I had skip the museum. Overall a great place to check out ancient Kathmandu architectures.
Ancient Kathmandu. Very interesting stop! It really was fascinating to see some very old temples and structures. Great photo opportunities!
Not that amazing and costs money to enter. If you have a spare day in Kathmandu i would drive to Baktapur, only two hours by local bus and much more impressive with its temples overall atmosphere .

Interesting area - worth a visit. We were a little surprised to get pulled aside and asked to pay to enter the area, but the small fee ($7.50) was fine. There are a number of very intricately detailed buildings in the square, but also a lot of people trying to sell you things. If you're looking for shopping, you'll find better deals elsewhere.
history overload. amazing history impressive buildings. Watching people worship with small fires. The local people queuing for spring water.
the holi festival. hello color...what a fantanstic festival held on the duubar square here...everyone is singing, dancing, throwing the colorfull powder...it is absolutly a colorfull world!

way over priced. 1100 NRPs for entry and at least 500NRPs per taxi each way. forget it. patan is better. it is just so pricey to visit these sites now that you have to be selective. it also really irks me with the 100 rupee fee for SAARC countries. Imagine if we did that in the west???!!!!

rip off. terrible that the entry fee is now 750NPR, it used to be free. the $$$ supposedly goes into it's restoration, but sadly it has only degenreated since the fee was introduced. now taxis, motorbikes and cars ply thier way right through the centre of the complex. this didnt happen when it was free, how ironic! once you buy your ticket head to the site office with a passport photo and your passport where theyll give you a visitor's pass and this will allow you to reenter the square for free for the remainder of your trip.

Great Attraction to see the morning local way of life. Did a morning run (crazy as it sounds in Dusty Kathmandu) in the early morning. No fees needed as it was at 630am. Loads of locals doing their daily prayer ritual, loads of street vendors.Interesting photographic location for street photographs.

Felt like something was missing.... There are some beautiful buildings and I had a lovely view over the square from a rooftop cafe. However.... having been to Bhaktapur afterwards, with the benefit of hindsight, I wouldn't bother with Durbar Sq in Kathmandu. It's all a bit cramped and no centrality to it

Most fascinating part of Kathmandu. It's hard to describe the apparent chaos of Durbar Square. There was so much to look at while also trying to avoid being run over by motor cyclists. The bustle and activity of the stallholders selling everything from fruit to meat to handicrafts, was offset by the serene and timeless beauty of the old buildings. We had a guide who could answer all our questions, which really enhanced our experience. We were especially intrigued by the home of the young goddess Kumari. The street sellers were very insistent but eventually gave up after being studiously ignored. We enjoyed this Durbar Square much more than the one in Bhaktapur, which seemed quiet and tame by comparison. The sheer vitality of the Square was irresistible.
Must Visit. The world Heritage site of UNESCO situated in the heart of the city. We can see lots of temples and can visit the museum where the history lives.

The chaos that is Kathmandu .... It's all here.. everyone and their business, vendors, self appointed guides, the temples and buildings that make you wonder how they are still standing. The pay kiosks are scattered, so expect to be asked to pay every time you walk by one.. I loved it! The intricate carvings on the buildings, the cave like doorways, the the whole thing. If you come to Kathmandu, don't miss this living theater on the streets that is life in this amazing city.

A must see. Don't be put off by the street sellers, just ignore them.Begging is fround upon and not incouraged.A visit to all the old buildings and temples is very interesting and I would recommend that you find a guide to tell you about the history
Dont leave Kathmandu without visiting the square!. Interesting to see, gives a good view of the busy life, traffic etc in Kathmandu. Several temples with a long history. A guide is very useful!

loved this area. Some of the most amazing architecture I've seen juxtaposed with modern storefronts and business. Beautiful statues and temples. Lots of local people working, chilling, and doing their thing. I could have spent days here.
beware the vendors!

Must see, but don't over-expect. It's a must-see if you're in Kathmandu for the first time, especially with so many medieval buildings within a stone's throw of one another. But on hindsight, having seen Patan's Durbar Square, I wouldn't have spent nearly as long as I did lingering in this one. For one thing, the number of local guides pushing their services border on annoying. Steep entry fee too. If you can afford the time, visit the Durbar Square in Patan - it's prettier, the sightlines are better, and you're more likely to be left alone.
One of several. The Durbar Square in Patan is the best. Bhaktapur is also pretty good. Kathmandu next. All interesting, all now tourist traps.

Good place for meeting people. Its a good place to stay. to buy stuff .. there is a cafeteria in one of the corners which serves great coffee but there is no toilet. Many rickshaws and near the main monuments. Good place.

Interesting, but overpriced. Fascinating to see the old buildings and good to see that they're investing time and money in preserving them. Not sure it was worth the 750R per person entry fee though, once you get inside there's not actually a lot to see or do and the museum is a bit 'so what' to say the least.As an earlier reviewer suggested - bring water. Immediately outside the square you can buy tourist tat and polyester blankets but there's nobody selling cold drinks.

Amazing atmosphere, amazing temples. The temples can not be accurately described by me. Go there, take your time and see them yourself. If you are unfamiliar with Nepali iconography bring a good guidebook or guide. So many things become visible only when you know they are there, and they really come alive when you know their meaning. After you have looked a few hours take a break, go to a rooftop for a snack and some liquid. Then go down and look some more. This place and its immediate surroundings really capture the essence of Kathmandu. Highly recommended.

Enjoy the square and the area around it. So many cool examples of different styles of buildings. I went several times. Go early for good light and you might miss paying the fee. If you do pay the fee, have your ticket turned into a card which is good for the length of your visa.I enjoyed on visit when a huge rain hit and trapped several folks on a temple steps. We sat a visited for hours, it was really fun.

Historically Beautiful!. It is just amazing to be able to see history as such still standing.The artistry and the architecture of the buildings are awe-inspiring.You get a feel of the culture and that you are standing in a historical place.Definitely worth the visit.
A must see in Katmandu. Beautiful architecture and culturally significant. We enjoyed spending a few hours there. It was very hot though, so bring water.

A Historical, cultural and people watching zone. The square is beautiful and crowded. Loads of touristy souvenirs to buy, and shops to visit around the square. I usually enjoy sitting and soaking in the atmosphere and the history of the place with a cup of Chia for 15 Rs. and maybe grab a puff to dunk in the sickly sweet goodness.

Decent square, but overpriced. Take my advice, go at 6pm when there is no admission fee and save yourself 750 rupees. It's definitely worth seeing, there is plenty of light at that time, but not sure it's worth the price. They do have booths at every major entrance. The other two Durbar Squares in the region are much nicer, especially Bhaktapur, but it's also much further out of town.

First Square to visit. Sorry to say that the Durbar Square in Bakhtapur and Patan are more nice to visit en this place was very dirty. Only the police officer was nice and smiling for the picture. But the entrance fee of RP 500 was not worth it
Amazing. Firt contact with the great architectural monuments and temple of Nepal. Great experience and a fascinating one!

Possible to visit in an hour. As a UNESCO site, this site needs to be better preserved. The pigeons, revered and all, are ruining the temples! There should be signs telling people not to graffiti the temples and not to litter.Recommended but get a good guide... you get what you pay for. Tourists pay about $10 USD entry fee (and you can get your pass extended for your entire stay) and a guide cost around 300 R to 1000 R.
Amazing. Just beautiful and amazing that it so well preserved in the midst of this busy chaotic city. We enjoyed wandering around although it is a shame there isn't more explanation of things

Kathmandu - Durbar Square - Large area of various monuments which is a must see in Kathmandu. Like most who visit Kathmandu Durbar Square is a must visit and the location does not disappoint. There is a variety of buildings, temples and monuments in varying architectural styles which will captivate you and delight you. The level of detailing in some of the wood carvings is superb. There is a cost to get in which includes the museum and this is worth seeing although it is a little too long winded. The whole area is compact with plenty to see and is a wash with people, street vendors, tourists and pigeons. Still an amazing experience.

You have to go. Useful to take a guide, for like 500 rupees, it's nothing, and it gives the locals income. Buy them a beer at a rooftop restaurant, ours really enjoyed this...and he pointed out all the local sites..you can only pay in cash in rupees there so make sure you stop at the ATM's along the way... great day our

Well worth the Rickshaw ride!. Durbar Square in Kathmandu was hectic with pockets of tranquility. The tour around the palace was interesting and amazing at how some of the wood work is still standing. I paid 700 rupees for entry into the area and well worth it to see all the architecture.

Trip back in time. The entrance fee has seen a sharp hike but its still worth the admission fee - but watch out for the touts offering their services as guides. And there doesn't see to be any time when it isn't crowded - but this is Kathmandu.That the buildings have survived at all is amazing and just gawp in admiration at the architecture and the history behind them.

Poor state, head for the little backalleys in the area.. It's a nice square with beautiful buildings. We got a glimpse of the living Godess, that was quite special but feel sorry for the little girl being locked up in her palace.The museum is not very interesting... I would suggest avoid paying the entrance fee and just stroll around the little alleys and buy ice cream, fruits and other stuff.....

a taste of nepal's history. the durbar square has it all.... palace remains... temples... the mysterious kumari goddess.... nice tucked in vintage bars, cafes... shopping in the courtyard....if you are in kathmandu on a short trip, this is a must visit as it will be easy to get to and will give you a true glimpse of nepal....

Paused in time. Kathmandu surprises its visitors with its charms. A medieval city, large stupas, golf courses, shopping avenues with stylish stores, cremation sites, flights to Mt. Everest... Overall, the energy in the nepalese city causes goose bumps. It's relaxed. It's homey. It's blessed and you can feel it! Durbar square features stone & brick tiled temples, courtyards, palaces and its lion-like entrance guardians.The area exudes history and past-glories dating back to the 1500's.Beware of the street vendors who may be quite aggressive. Native medallions are sold for a fair price, provided some haggling.It is an interesting, educative walk.

A 'must see' but the Royal Palace has some drawbacks. This is definitely the most important place to visit in Kathmandu itself and every visitor should spend some time in and around the square. There are a large number of shrines and temples to visit, over 50 I think though some are very small, and many with quite splendid architecture – although it is crumbling a bit in parts. However, be aware that entering the old Royal Palace itself at the centre of the square does have drawbacks. The main problem is that it is quite a large Palace and took us around 2 hours to visit. There is a lot of walking involved, much of it up and down stairs, some very narrow, all over the Palace and this can get extremely tiring – and there are not many places to rest. I suppose we could have climbed over some of the barriers and taken some short cuts but we didn't have a map of the building with us so are quite likely to have got totally lost. In addition, my wife, who is a better walker than I am, sprained her knee trying to climb up the steep stairs to the top of one of the tallest buildings in the complex – I wisely remained further down. We did take the time to try and look at a number of the exhibits so could have speeded up things by looking at less – which is what we did after the first half hour or so. The trouble is that there are lots, and lots, and lots, of memorabilia relating to the lives of the ex Nepalese Royal Family – in fact that is nearly all there is inside the Palace. For a Nepali this would of course be of great interest but for a tourist it does become quite repetitive and not that interesting. In addition, most of the rooms are poorly lit, as well as being quite dusty. However the architecture of the inner courtyards are worth seeing and quite special. Although photography in the main Durbar Square is fine, it is not allowed inside the Royal Palace and there are lockable lockers by the entrance where you are asked to leave cameras and bags etc. You are encouraged by the staff to leave a small tip.Entrance to the Durbar Square is 750 Nepali Rupees though you need to pay at one of a number of booths dotted around the various entrances to the square – I think I counted 4 separate booths. However, we were never asked for our ticket except when we went into the Royal Palace. The temple of the Living Goddess is also in the Square but entry to that is not included in the price and you need to pay extra. You are likely to be approached by various people trying to get you to hire them to be a guide. They were a bit persistent but OK about it when we politely declined. There is also a handicrafts market in an open area in one part of the square – some nice stuff there but we thought the prices were on the high side.
Did nothing for us.. Nice enough for 10 or 15 minutes. Much better to go to Durbar Square in Patan or Durbar Square in Bhaktaphur.

A beautiful submission to the history of fine arts and culture of Kathmandu. The place is just radiating with bright rays of the culture and history of it. It tells a story that has long been going since its origin. The people and the place makes it a great experience to find oneself so easily fused into the beauty of this place. The art as well as the culture i found there was just dazzling and took my breath away into its past, present and future and i couldnot stop wondering about it. I am out of words to define how blissful this experience was for me. I recommend anyone that loves travelling to go there. This is a definitely a place to visit.

It's falling apart. Looks like it was amazing at one time but so sad to see how old & uncared for it is, buildings look like they're ready to fall down at any time, I didn't even take pics of the buildings as they're in such poor shape

Very peaceful rooftop tea... Dont get sucked into a tour guide you dont need, but is nice to have someone show around, look for rooftop terraces to enjoy a nice iced tea whilst looking down at the square...

Historical Place. You need a guide when you visiting here, do remember to get a mask too. Too many stranger approached me as guide, made me felt unsecure and refuse. It should be a must place to visit with a guide.

Fantastic pieces of architecture - horribly kept. You cannot avoid going there. Temples and old buildings are so impressive and interesting. BUT locals including administration don't care, full of pigeon dirtt, that destroys the old wood. Unbelievable ignorance. People unfriendly and aggressive. Don't eat anywhere near, it's a rip off. Many idiots on bikes

A very mixed review. The old temple buildings are interesting but the 750 NR entrance fee for "foreigners" is way too high given that Asea members only pay 150 & its always congested & polluted by local cars & motorbikes that pay nothingIts a classic example of overcharging visitors because you can - and there's no sign that any of the money is actually being spent on restoration.Its a heritage site so unfortunately they get away with the charges & the high prices for mostly faked antiques & thankas.
A must UNESCO. The 3 Durbar places are interesting, Thamel, Patan and Bakthapur, do not miss the Museum in patan , one of the most interesting in Asia about hinduism and buddhism

Have to go. The buildings and the history require a guide, so get one before you go.
Be warned to enter the Kumara the residence of the Living Goddesswill require another entry fee.
However, the rest of the Durbar is fascinatiung and worth the efforet to explore.

Its CP of Kathmandu (Delhite will understand) all Brands. wat I disliked is it gets closed by 12 o clock, it houses all the good restaurants in kathmandu its central also it host two good casinos! and has a palace at the end
Market place. Stumbled onto a main square whilst wandering around the markets. Local women chanting prayers others selling the very bright flowers. Wonderful buildings

I know you have to go, but its such a pity it's not better taken care of. It should be the best place to visit in Kathmandu, but its just not taken care of.I was so disappointed to find:- this heritage site is not being taken care of, and is falling apart- got hassled here more then anywhere else in Nepal- there is great stuff in the museum, but it is sooo poorly organized, you don't get the story you should from it- it's hard to follow what's what (poorly signposted and the brochure is blah)- the stray dogs and pigeons and trash just make it feel dirty

Excellent place to see Temples and local life. The Kathmandu durbar square is the best Durbar square amongst the three durbar sqaures in Nepal. The temples are really very nice and are frequented by lots of locals and tourist, Must see attractions is Hanuman Dhokha palace its kept in very good condition with great meuseum inside. It gives a very Good historical view of King Birendra and his life.

chtf. Durbar Square is an intereting place but we could not believe that the entrance fee was now almost $10 for tourists. For local people to gain entry to the Square it was only about 50 cents. We decided not to go in for that price as we had been in before on our last visit only three years before. It really is unjust the way tourists are made to pay so much more than the local people for everything in Nepal.I know we are considerably wealthier than they are but sometimes it is verging on exploitation.

Great historical place. The Durbar Square in Kathmandu is a great historical place to spend the morning amongst many old temples. The large square is surrounded by ancient Newari-Architecture: the old royal palace, high temples, popular shrines and this architecture makes the place so unique...

A must visit. This is the smallest square/city among the three big old cities in Kathmandu but I like this the most because it's got everything and if you want to experience Nepalee culture and religions, this is the place to go. Plan 2 hours to be there if you just want to visit the sites and nearby temples and architectures. plan extra 2 hours if you want to do some shoppings.

Too many street sellers. Certainly one of the places to visit in Kathmandu, but we found the street sellers extremely enjoying. This was the only place in Nepal people were so impertinently trying to push their useless items on us. A real downer.

OK but.... Bhaktapur Durbur Square is so so much better. This one is being renovated so that affects the level of attractiveness too. If you have time, grab a taxi and head over to Bhaktapur. I was grateful I took the advise of a friendly Nepali and did just that!

Mixed feelings. Its worth a visit as the temples are amazing and the place is a photographer's paradise, but it is not worth the extortionate price being charged (700rs for foreigners outside of SARC), probably not much by western standards, but considering Bodanath is 150rs, its a rip off. The buildings are in a sorry state which is a shame considering just how astonoshingly beautiful the carvings are and how ancient some of these are (you would think that some of that ridiculous entrance fee proceeds should go on cleaning and protection, but it clearly does not). You will be bothered by tour guides, rickshaws, shoe shiners and just beggars, but no more so than in rest of Kathmandu, just the way things are there.

Durbar Square. A great group of Hindu and Buddhist temples to wander around and visit, with the former Royal Palace facing the square. A better choice might be to take a short taxi ride to the neighboring town of Patan to visit its' much less touristy Durbar Square.

Very dirty and dusty.. As you get there, many people will offer to guide you and there is a small booth just to charge you the visit, but no guide maps offered. The place is a mess and dust over all temples. Food remains and disrt all over the streets. Not a pleasant visit.

Don't miss it. In the heart of Kathmandu, Durbar Square is a feast for photographers and sightseers. The square is a heady mix of temples, souvenir sellers, bicycle rickshaws, motor bikes, guides and people just hanging about. For me, this mix of history, religious artifacts and everyday life is typical of Nepal's capital. The Kumari House and the museum are worth a visit.

extremely exotic. going to and through Durbar Square in Kathmandu is just amazing because of its beautiful old traditional Nepalese architecture and also to see the Nepali people in their spiritual practices like making gifts or sacrifices to different gods etc. i highly recommend a visit
photos galore. Great for making photographs and a wander. Be careful of pigeon crap - a sun brolly is a good idea. Be sure to ask which is the Kamari place as best part for us as a family.

One of the world's heritage place. Kathmandu Darbar square is in the heart of Kathmandu City. Which historically, culturally big name and place. The architectural foundation, cultural and temples always attractive to the people. Kurami "Living goddess" is in the Kathmandu Darbar square, small girl known as a goddess, you can see her and know about her. To know all those things you have visit at least once in this place. "Imagination is not reality".

world heritage. I visited this site because it's a part of the world heritage site. It shows the architectures of typical Nepal styles. The other reason I visited this site because I would like to visit the Kumari, the chosen Goddess of Nepal. Nepal has a lot of interesting legends and histories so it's worth to spend some hours in Durbar Square. The only reminder is that we walked from Thamel to Durbar Square and the road is dusty, dirty and chaotic. So try to get a cab if you want to go.
Intersting but could be better. The place is nice, but not WOW. harassment from tour guides is annoying. The palaces are interesting, but I have seen better places in Nepal

Mixture of spirituality, history, commercialism and the bizarre. A definite must see for the temples, the architecture, the devotees doing their offerings, the "ascetics", most of whom will charge a few rupees for a picture and the omniscient tourist shops. Go with an open mind and enjoy the chaos.
Must see. World Heritage site. You can spend a good bit of time wondering around. Gives a great sense of old Kathmandu.

Def. See!. Very beautiful buildings, a nice place to walk around and get lost in. The vendors here are a bit more aggressive but other than that it's still a very beautiful part of Kathmandu that should be seen.

Crowded, dirty.... no improvement at all since my last visit more than a decade ago despite a sharp increase in the entrance fee!! I don't mind paying a high price if you feel it will benefit to the heritage site but it does not sound the case...

Good to see if you're in KTM. Beautiful place in the middle of Kathmandu. A good idea is to reach it through the 1h walk from Tomen which takes you to various statues, stupas and temples.
Durbar square in itself is quite impressive with all its temples, and it would be sad to miss it if you're in Kathmandu.
I don't like this place. You should go to this place only if you want to check out the museum and get some photos of the crowd there! Here you get everything!

No need to pay. Everything in Nepal costs money. Durbar square is no exception. If you come by taxi it will most probably drop you at the entrance, just walk down the street a little, turn around and then slip past the ticket booth. You will save about 750rs and can spend it on something else. The square is quite nice to look around but certainly not worth paying for entry. There are a few temples and freak street is right there to wander down aswell.

Peaceful part of the city, watch out for "guides". This is a peaceful, Hindu part of Kathmandu. There's several restaurants lining Durbar Square (much like at Boudhanath Stupa), and there is at least supposed to be an entry fee. It's easy to walk through without paying any fee, and to find a place to eat, but be very wary of the so-called guides here. They are obnoxious and aggressive, will show you a few places and will gladly leave you to shop in a part of the city not worth visiting if you aren't wary of where you're at or going. There's tell that they will basically beg for money, so if you want to make the most of this part of the city, get a printed guide and wander around yourself.

Better than Patan Durbar Square.. The Kathmandu Durbar Square is a lot cleaner than the one in Patan and more spectacular. My favorite part was the palace. It is also a lot more quiet than the busy streets.

example of what terrorists can do. for reasons best known to the maoists they have demolished the annexxe of the palace where entire Royal family was massacred by the Crown Prince. A flat grounds greet the visitors where once a palace was standing. On top of that surrounding area including gardens, swimming pool, fountains are in a mess. Stark contrast to the main palace which is maintained little bit and open to visitors as a museum.

City visit. Busy but very interesting. Get a guide but don't be conned into buying a Mandala or a meal in a restaurant you didnt choose.... guides will often guide you to these places after they complete your tour.

Great historical site. First, learn to say "no" when you come to Kathmandu. Say it with authority and say it often."Tour guides" and "salesmen" of junk will hound you at every landmark in Kathmandu. Just say no.Now the overall experience in Durbar Square Kathmandu was amazing. The sites were well preserved, and the museum on the premises was very well thought out. Easy to spend two or three hours at this site. If you combine the quarters, the courtyard (including a ton of tourist outdoor market shopping in main square) and walking the temple, easily a good afternoon traveled. Highly recommend this Durbar Square. i'll review Patan's Durbar Square separately. VERY DIFFERENT PLACES which I didn't understand when I first arrived in Kathmandu.

Disappointing to say the least.. The architecture and temples were amazing! However like the other temples we visited the local people know tourists will come here so every inch of space is taken over by vendors selling cheap made-in-China souvenirs. Hard to get pictures of the beautiful historic buildings without getting vendor shops in them as well. Sad that the locals don't understand they are ruining the views the tourists are coming to see.

Lots of touts. Great part of Kathmandu to see. The architecture is what you see in the photos of Kathmandu. There are a lot and I mean ALOT of tour guides trying to get the tourists to employ them. One guy that approached us later had a go at us after we hired a different guide. You're looking at about 2000 NR to have someone walk you around for about an hour or so. Our guide ended our walk in a store where he obviously wanted us to buy merchandise. I am guessing he got a cut if we purchased something. A lot of people just hanging around the area.
interesting. fascinating look into kathmandu life, well worth a look very interesting. definitely worth ensuring you have a guide to give you the historical background
Durba Sq. It's quite nice but not as nice as that of Patan and especially of Bhaktapur. There isn't much to see in Kathmandu apart from trade shops of all kinds.

Nice Area. Nice history of the royal family inside the museum. Tons of shopping outside but be ready to be pressured by the sellers. Great place to negotiate. You can see the Living Goddess and many temples.

Good for shopping and walking around just to observe the culture. Beware that there are 3 durbar squares in kathmandu so be careful what you ask for. The one near Lalitpur is the more famous one. If you don't mention this to the cab driver they just drop you at the one which is closest so don't get fooled. This is what happened to us. It's a good place to shop and get good bargains on Khukri and other souvenirs

It's good, but not Bhaktapur. A good square in town to see and take pictures. Its worth going to and paying the 750Rs to go in if you have time and want some pictures. But if you only have time/interest for one, take the drive to Bhaktapur.As a note, Holi is celebrated here too, with a DJ right in the middle of the sqaure. That is an event not to be missed.

excellent way to spend a day. Spent a good part of an afternoon at Durbar Square. It's a fascinating area with everything imaginable. The square itself is filled with a variety of temples from various ages that surround the old royal palace, which is now a museum. Although there are places at the entrance that ask you to pay 750Rs entrance fee as a foreigner, I didn't find that you had to do this just to walk around the square (I didn't even realize that it was necessary until about an hour in). You do need to pay the ticket price in order to enter the museum. It is well worth it for the architecture. The exhibits on the various kings of Nepal are also interesting. Explore the area around the square as well. filled with various markets and experiences. You could easily spend a full day in the area.

Photo opportunities every where. Be sure to take the time and just sit and watch from the top of the highest structure in Durbar Square. From here you can zoom in and get great photos of the locals. Worth a visit

Interesting, but not as ggood as Bhaktapur. Durbar square is full of interesting temples and other very old buildings, but it can get very crowded, and is full of touts and over-priced tourist shops. Still worth a visit if you are in Kathmandu, and want to kill an hour or two.

You have to visit a Durbar Square - the ones at Patan or Bhaktapur may be better. This is a must visit particularly if you have not visited Durbar Square in Patan or Bhaktapur. The temples were spectacular but on reflection I think you get a much better feeling for the temples and the atmosphere in the much quieter Bhaktapur. The museums included in the 750 rupees charge were not really worth visiting except perhaps fleetingly.I do sympathise with Puede from Bangkok who said "It is a disgrace that foreigners are now forced to pay an entrance fee just to wander across the city center square". 750 rupees was a bit excessive, particularly as it effectively was a main thoroughfare for locals. It also seems to be a big hassle of the following is correct, 'If you want to this ticket to be valid for more than 3 days you need to bring a photograph and your passport'. I agree that the 'Vendors on Durbar Square are a (bit of) pest'.
A highlight!. i guess it has always been a highlight of kathmandu :-) i enjoy durbar square a lot...good to spend on a tour guide since i have zero knowledge of Nepal...Royal family and Buddhism.
culturally interesting. the durba has some interesting view, by sitting down you can be guaranteed to observed lots of things that you don't get to see in Tokyo!

Forced to buy a ticket to enter a city center. It is a disgrace that foreigners are now forced to pay an entrance fee just to wander accross the city center square. If youwant to this ticket to be valid for more than 3 days you need to bring a photograph and your passport. Vendors on Durbar Square are a pest and heavily overcharge for all the kitsch they are selling. We shall not return to Nepa.

Sam's the man. I went here with my wife in February and found it a beutiful, historic site. The place is well worth a visit but it's well worth hiring a guide as they give you so much information about what your seeingWhen we arrived we were approached by a guide called Sam (definately not the right spelling), he said he was there if we wanted and wasn't at all pushy. We went back to him and he was fantastic, good fun and very knowledgable.We paid him a set price and he was in no hurry to show us round which was great.You are charged a few hundred rupees to go in and Nepalis go in for free which I think is great, just the way it should be. You shoulld also try the little coffee stall near the ticket office, the one at the end of the line.'Cheapest and best'. you'll hear this a lot in Nepal but definately true of this stall, lovely people too

unbelievable carvings. I must have been an architect in a previous life. I paid for a guide to explain the history and intricacies that exist in Durbar Square. For me the most spectacular part was looking at each eave that supported the roof. Each one is unique, showing a deity, the animal or being that transports them, and then something specific to the building itself. Intricate details, amazing stories, look up to see a compelling story of the past that continues to be honored.

a dizzying visit of sights and smells. We spent a few hours in Kathmandu Durbar Square visiting Kumari Ghar, the museum and the square itself with its many temples. Found the place dirty and not well-maintained. Was expecting that the money visitors pay for entrance would go towards maintaining the area. There were even beggars on the streets! and you have to be careful walking around because a car or a bike would just dart out from nowhere. But despite the place being crowded with all sorts of people we didn't feel scared or anything about being mugged or robbed which was a positive thing to say. But between Bhaktapur and Durbar square, think the former is better in terms of cultural immersion.

expensive attraction. I went to Durbar square because I heard it was not to be missed. I read that the entrance fee was 300 rupees, but when I got there it was 750! That is very expensive considering it is a general area and free to Nepali people. I got the free extension at the site office so I can go back again. Immediately a "tour guide" started following me around and wouldn't leave me alone; he was rude to me. I would probably go back again to learn more about the buildings and history and try to get more out of it. It's a nice place but so expensive, I couldn't help but feel disappointed because of the price.

You rally feel on the far east. I loved this place!! The old temples.. And everything around! Good to have a seat at the temple's stairs and let the time run. Enjoy it! And go to the visitor's office to extend your permission to enter this place

Take your time. A place to wander, sit down and watch the crowds - listen to the temple bells - even light a candle at a shrine and have a tika on your forehead topped off with marigold petals in your hair.
interesting. it is interesting place to see, many temples with architecture . the people around are good, some shopping as well. the temple of kumari and the the living godness kumari is inpressing.
good squire. The basantapur is little quite place to rest and see the people. good place to spend the time with local peoples. the temples are good.

historic place. teh durban square is a big place to visit and its nice with the old age buildings and very spacious...you will like to roam around the place ...the area is quite big and there are some restaurents around it,,,, there are some buildings which are used for schools now... i liked it overall...but the disturbance of the guides were a bit annoying

Just average. I think the entrance fee was way too expensive for foreigners. It was Rs 7,500 per person although it can be used for 3 day but you've got to bring a passport sized photo to get a stamp.Being at Patan Durbar Square about a week ago, I think they're almost the same & alike to each other. Besides they were full with locals who can enter the site for free!
Unique and beautiful. so many beautiful and unique buildings with its rich history. Great place to walk around and watch the local people interact.

Bentravel_13. Brilliant site to visit will do it again and again anad again and againBrilliant site to visit will do it again and again anad again and againBrilliant site to visit will do it again and again anad again and againBrilliant site to visit will do it again and again anad again and againBrilliant site to visit will do it again and again anad again and againBrilliant site to visit will do it again and again anad again and againBrilliant site to visit will do it again and again anad again and againBrilliant site to visit will do it again and again anad again and againBrilliant site to visit will do it again and again anad again and againBrilliant site to visit will do it again and again anad again and again
Lovely architecture. Very interesting to hear the history but we could have done without the guide who wanted to tell us the full story of every Hindu statue.

Well worth a visit.. I went back to Durbar Square twice because the 1st time I missed the museum. The "entry fee" of 750 NPR seemed a bit steep for somewhere that was freely open to the public! I went to the site office and got a pass that allowed me to return as when I wished for the duration of my visa .The museum entry is included in the initial entry charge. There was a lovely atmosphere about the Square and a very interesting place to go.
Nice for photo. Nice to sit on highest platforms of the temple during sunset and watch the world below. Dislike the crowd.

beautiful experience. Durbar Square is World Heritage Site but it is also very live place that participate in everyday life of the citizens. That mixture of traditional and contemporary (though in a Nepalese sense) is what makes this place amazing. I was lucky enough to see the live goddess, Kumari. It was as if I traveled into a fairy tale, into a fiction (which I probably did).

Best City Walk -Durbar Square Kathmandu. A delightful combination of architecture and culture, not many places can offer such a variety of building styles both everyday and religious sitting in everyday Nepalese life. Mothers in traditional dress looking after young children in front of old temples, old women selling spices, young men carrying enormous piles of boxes oblivious to the old buildings and temples they navigate... Of all my travels so far this is the best city walk i have ever done. Find yourself a quiet spot up high on one of the temple stairs and watch this colourful everyday life. And give yourself plenty of time!

World Heritage Site. Durbar Square is now a World Heritage site. Glad that the ancient architecture and shrines have been preserved, but seems a bit sterile. The museum isn't really worth the visit, but you may get a peek and see Kumori, the living goddess in another temple. The Newari woodcarvings are quite amazing.

A visceral experience on all levels. This place - although small by traditional 'bazaar' standards - is an otherwordly experience, particularly during sun down. Go at around 4-5pm for some quick local crafts shopping, then spend the rest of the evening at any of the many rooftop restaurants over a beer. Watch as the sun disappears, and the square below bustles with life in the dark. It really is surreal.Make sure to ask for an extension on the slightly pricey NPR750 entrance fee. They can extend your ticket for an additional 2 days for free. Just ask at the ticket counter and they'll tell you where to go.

Beatutiful. Durbar Square is full of beautiful and exotic buildings.The Kumari House for example, the house of the living goddess. If you are lucky, or pay enough money, she will pop her head out of the window and smile at you, but you're not allowed to take her photo. Fascinating place to go.

how much???. 750 rupees to get into a square!!! And apparently going up to 1000. Didn't pay to get in as cannot justify the cost. Looked like a small area, ripping western tourists off whilst locals mill in and out as they wish using it as normal road for traffic and cycles. We were prepared to pay the 300 rupee price as quoted in the guide book but apparently this was a 'mistake'.

Most disappointing !. Its such a disappointment to see that a great monument of the history is left to the locals who have occupied the square with vegetable vending, tea shops, cars/bikes zipping around etc. Very sad indeed !

Pigeons Galore. This was a really lively place with market stalls and temples aplenty, and also millions of pigeons! This was definitely a place to people watch, just so much going on. There were a lot of child beggars, which was sad, but the tour guides insisted that you would do more damage giving to them than not. We took a rickshaw ride through the narrow market streets, which was an experience in itself. Well worth a visit.

Excellent place. Very nice place where you have loads of branded shops. In case you walk into to a store don't push your luck too much trying to bargain. They will let you walk away but not bargain. You have quite a few casinos on the Durbar street.
Happening place. Avoid the souvenir vendors and visit the pagodas at the end of the street and the markets around them. There are many good photo ops.

Really enjoyed the area. Quite a beautiful area with numerous buildings/monuments of interest. Really felt like I was in the orient. There was a political demonstration organizing there they day we visited. Look for the tent with the little girls that are dressed up similar to the Kumari (the living goddess).

Not much to see!. There are some nice buildings, esp. temples, but it' the same kind of buildings you'll see everywhere around Kathmandu. Foreigners have to pay a ticket which I found expensive for what you get!

definately visit. been coming her for 25 years and i never get bored or disappointed fantastic pagodas great for people watching pity about the touts but what to do best time is early morning when the frit and veg traders are setting but any time is good

History and faith. An amazing collection of shrines and temples-the spiritual heart of the city. Crowded with both visitors, residents, and worshippers, this collection of ancient buildings is not to be missed.
To see. A must , very beautiful and peaceful , better with a guide to understand the culture and history. 50 temples all together , but with plenty of of place to accomode many tourists

Durbar Square. The history and sheer abundance of temples congregated in a small "town-square" type of area was impressive. Again, the crappy get-n-your-face people wanting to be your "tour guide" and hawking their tiger balm and other garbage was a pain. I did hire a guy to explain the temples and stupas to me, and it was well worth the money overall (high priced hourly wage for a place like Nepal, but feel as if I received value for my money).

DURBAR SQUARES NEPAL-MUST SEE ALL THREE. We visited Kathmandu on 26th Jan 2013. In and around Kathmandu there are 3 Durbar squares.Durbar squares are plazas in front of old Royal Palaces of Nepal. 1 is in Kathmandu, second in Patan & 3rd in Bhaktapur. All these squares are Unesco World Heritage sites.We visited all of these in 1 day excursion. Kathmandu Durbar square also known as Hanuman Dhoka as is having a nice statue of Hanumanji.Its a huge complex with lot of temples & large clean pavement.Patan is famous for Krishna temple, Golden temple & numerous statues of Shri Ram,Hanuman& other Hindu Gods & Goddesses.Bhaktapur is little far off from Kathmandu (30-35 kms) having a tall 5 storeyed temple along with old palaces & monateries.Lots of pigeons were seen in Hanuman Dhoka & in Patan Durbar square.Though all three squares are more or less same having Pagoda style temples,and excellent wooden & metal carvings but each has something extra to offer to the visitors. I personally feel one must visit all three during a visit to Kathmandu.

Nice place to hangout and see old temples. Durbar square is a nice place to visit if you are in Kathmandu. There are many temples in the square and a good place for religious people but It’s kind of a hangout place as well for locals as well as for tourists. You can enjoy the walking in the square; there are some temples which you can visit. The buildings are very old and the architecture is very impressive. At the entrance, some local people sell beautiful handicrafts; some of them look like antique. You can grab yourself a good bargain if you have the skill.

The old surrounded by the new and life bustling all around. This was a fascinating place to visit. The hustle and bustle of daily life, people selling their wares, weddings being celebrated and the living Goddess all happening in a fairly small area. the building are just stunning - all these pagoda shaped buildings with their red fabric frills, fantastic carvings and statues. It was a cultural feast.

you have to do it. You can't visit Katmandu without a vist here. We took up the offer of a guide which was worth the small fee and discovered places on the square we wouldn't have found on our own. We were lucky to see the living godness, a little girl who appears on her balcony on rare occaisions and our guide explained how she was chosen and the history very well. Its busy and crowded but fascinating, well worth a visit but if you get chance go to Durbar Square in Bhaktapur its sublime

Very Commercial. Not as well preserved as Bastanapur and much more commercial. I was surprised by how many locals sit all over the various buildings / temples - quite amazed as to how high they climb to sit and/or lay down. Unfortunately, very much detracts from the view.

If you have to choose - Basantapur is better than Kathmandu Durbar. If you only have the time to visit one Durbar, be sure it is Basantapur not Kathmandu.Basantapur is much better preserved and far less commercial than what you will see in Kathmandu

Not a place for everyone...but I loved it.. I was fascinated by Dubar Square and Kathmandu in general. My friend Kimberly and I were there the day The Living Goddess (The Kumari) was allowed to leave her home be seen by the commoners! The crowd was enormous. I felt completely immersed in the inner city and the heart of Kathmandu. What luck! The Nepali people were friendly but needy and a bit untrustworthy. There were moments of 10 people surrounding us if we pulled out a dollar. Our guide was great for 2 days until he asked for $700 cash for his sick mother by the end. It broke my heart. He was a wonderful kid but really just needed money like the rest of the Nepali people. There was a tiny handful of tourists from Australia and Europe to balance out the tour but I was the only blonde person I saw for 2 days. I was stunned by the poverty and desperation of the people of Kathmandu. I was energized by the sites in Dubar Square with the shrines and temples and the blessings and completely blown away by the energy of these crowds. This is not a place to bring your kids but one of those places that is so layered with rich culture mixed with joyful color and hindu/buddhist/Nepali tradition as well as so much sorrow for the poor that this place will always be in my heart. It will stick with you forever.

Do it, do it, do it.. We loved Durbar Square. GET A GUIDE. If you can find Sam you're on a winner but I'm sure there are many others. We got so much more from the experience with the benifit of his knowledge and insight.

Don't miss it. The historic and spiritual heart of Kathmandu is the #1 attraction in the city. You can spend many pleasant hours walking and looking at temples or sitting and watching the Nepali who gather there to worship and visit. It's the best place to get a sense of how ancient the city really is and how they lived and worshipped. There is an entrance fee but once through the gate evrrything else is free unless you are tempted to hire a guide..(read tout) or shop among the merchants who display their goods. Freak Street is at the far end of the square although there is not much left to see of it's notorious past. The whole area for blocks around the square make for an interesting walk with lots of small shops and narrow streets. If you take your passport and entrance ticket to one of the offices in the Square you will be given an unlimited free pass for a week. Don't miss it!

Good place to start.. This is a great place to start, and has a very informative museum - provided you bring along someone who is literate in Nepali to translate. Be warned that the Foreigner Tax to enter is a bit loftier here than elsewhere. It's not really too much, but it is a nasty surprise when you do not expect it.
Lots of things to do. It was great to walk around and view the shops and offerings. A little disconcerting with the constant request for funds.
Once is not enough. Great place to hang out with friends, learning and being around ancient and historical structure. Could visit the museum to learn something more

beautiful but lots of hassle. the durbar in kathmandu is beautiful. Many years of architecture and religious meaning. There were lots of "guides" that were trying to charge absurd amounts for 1 or 2 hour tours of the area. they were overly persistent and annoying. We ended up leaving because one of the guides would not leave us alone despite us asking him to several times and ignoring him for about 30 minutes. it is a shame that they ruin such a lovely spot.

One of the happening places in Kathmandu. Durbar square is the place in Kathmandu. It holds the old palaces of the Malla and Shah kings who ruled the country. You can see the old buildings and will be amazed at the skills of the Newar artists especially the windows and the doors of these building which show cases the beautifully carved wooden windows. Don't miss it when you are in Kathmandu

Walk there from Thamel. It's about 20 minute cruisy walk from Thamel along fascinating alleys. Plenty of things to look at along the way. Kids under 10 are free. Durbar square is big but plenty of places to sit. DO go to the office and have your ticket extended because if you have a free day you will probably want to come back again. Buzzing atmosphere. Worth the entry fee of around 800

Unbelivable place to see. This was one of our high points of our visit to Nepal. Dunbar Square has some of the oldest wooden structures in the world. You are surrounded by them. Everything about it is unique and very interesting. Its a must see while visiting Nepal.

a place to be ever remembered. a must visit by one and all . great stone works and the cafes and handicraft and what not . the narrow lanes and the brick works and the temples the water areas. very ancient and one gets a feeling of living in the medieval life . please visit this place for it good tea and loads of pictures can be taken to preserve

Don't worth the price. Durbar Square is nice, but busy, badly maintained and expensive if you're a foreigner. We entered the Durbar Square from a small road beside it and didn't know that we need to pay - signals are non-existent. When we're informed about the price, we gave up because we found it very expensive. There are some temples and it's interesting, but I think it's better going to Bhaktapur or Patan, where there are more things to see.

Temples. A must visit for every traveller lots of ancient temples to cover durbar square minimum 2 to 3 hours are required must take care of your belongings very crowded place please take along with you some snacks and water bottles one can light lamp at bhairava statue.

Beautiful area not to be missed. The history, scenes and architecture of this area are not to be missed. Have a guide take you so as you fully understand what you are seeing. Photographers paradise, and make sure you walk all the little side street areas.
Durbar. Very busy, difficult to enjoy after all day in Kathmandu. Better to came early morning, before locals and tourists. Good place to ear local cusine

Be prepared to pay if you are a foreigner.. I think it's a little steep that foreigners have to pay 750 rupees to visit this magnificant square. Still it is worth going to if you are visiting Kathmandu. There must be a back entrance somewhere to avoid the fee.
Full of life. What a great place to see what everyone is getting up to and to watch the world go by. All kinds of festival, protests, demonstrations etc go by here.

Stunning old town area with amazing temples. Full of temples, Durbar Square is stunning. Although there is an entrance fee, this is a bustling part of town. The sights, colours, smells - it is all well worth seeing and we met some great people. Beware of the touristy-type shops, especially near the exits, selling the 'singing bowls' and other tourist items which can actually work out very expensive. Some of our party bought these things, and although some workmanship has clearly gone in to them, I saw far nicer things in the regular shops around Kathmandu.

World Heritage site. Its like stepping back in time, a really interesting place which foreign tourists have to pay an entrance fee. I can understand why they charge, however it did stop me from revisiting on other days.To make the most of the entrance fee remember that you cannot get in to the Museums after 16.00 and these close at 17.00 and you will be charged the same fee.

Very interesting. The square was busy with hustle and bustle and had many temples. Since we had already seen a zillion temples, etc. we probably could have done without seeing this one. However, it is always good to see and learn something new.

A Good Place to Start. A great way to start your trip is to walk from Thamel down to Durbar Square, have lunch there and then walk accross to Swayambhunath Temple. Great way to get to know the city. Make sure you see Kumari.

NO MOTORBIKES PLEASE!. It's a wonderful place full of uniqe Newari temples but the noise from the motorbikes mars it! It costs 750 Rs to enter the square, so there should be no traffic at all! It's a Unesco Heritage Monument for heaven's sake!

a must-see if going to Kathmandu. Probably one of the most iconic area of the city, it is packed with old religious buildings which are all more impressive than the others. Very interesting to see for their peculiar architecture, but also for the atmosphere wandering around, it's a high place of cult.
great buildings, but crazy busy. Overwhelming environment in terms of people, and those trying to sell you stuff. Building architecture is great.

Beautiful Architecture. Durbar Square is for sure a "must-see", but frankly if time limited, places like Monkey Temple and Pashupatinath Temple arguably offer a greater learning experience. The Square is visually exciting, has lovely architecture, but busy, many hawkers, and guides continually come up offering service. Shopping is limited and much less varied and intriguing as at Monkey Temple. A guide might be worth hiring, but if going to Pashupatinath - which you should, you'll surely want a guide there. We did Dunbar Square as part of a day where we hired a taxi.

Nice Durbar Square. I don't like children begging for food and money. I know that they are innocent and poor but their behaviors are not nice. When you visit the durbar square the local guide will offer you the service. Some are nice when we refuse to heire them but some are not in the good manner as we were scolded for not hiring them.The Kathmandu Durbar Square is very nice although it is a little unclean for me. I saw Kumari and she was very nice that we are speechless when staring at her just for a couple minutes.

Classic Nepal. The square is a must see, although Backthapur is less busy and better preserves. Don't be frightened to walk to Durbar from Thamel it's a straight shot through a thriving area complete with temples and local non tourist shops. 15 mins if you're striding... 2 hours if you rubber neck at everything. Cheap taxi back? Have a coke or beer in a rooftop cafe overlooking the square.
good. intresting place, by the palace, we where lucky enough to see the living goddess , prefered Patans Dunbar square, more looked after maybe. so many pigeons, on mass here
Amazing!. The history and temples are amazing. Very lucky to see the Kumari when we were there. Wish we had more time to wander around!
Interesting. An "interesting" place at so many levels. I think a guide is absolutely essential. We didn't have one and will certainly get one on my next visit.
Consider hiring a guide here. Wonderful architecture and atmosphere here. It is probably worth hiring a guide, otherwise you will be pestered by hawkers which can detract from your visit.

Beautiful in it's own way but many hawkers.... The size of this square is a draw and for the first day in Kathmandu it is lovely to see. I complain because we had groups of kids and mothers following us throughout begging for food or asking us to buy things....We much prefer to donate to a local charity and do so as not to support this behavior. The temples are beautiful, made of wood and overall it is lovely and grande....however we found Bhaktapur to be far far more beautiful. Of course we were taken there on our last day....

Amazing architecture and a "presence".. I went twice to see the square as I ran out of time the first time I went. At night time it is also a good place to visit as the atmosphere is just as great. The opportunity to enjoy a Festival at some time with the Nepali people while there gives it my thumbs up.
