Asia as I imagined it.. I wish I had spend more time here to explore. There was amazing detail which at first you might not notice. I would recommend hiring a guide to tell you about Durbar Square.

Get a local guide to help. Unless you have a thorough guide book, negotiate a price from a local guide who will likely solicit you soon upon entering. We paid $5/pp, but based on what we paid for a guide the next day, you can get better than that. Otherwise you are just staring at temples with no clue about their meanings. The tour would last about an hour. You can also go into the museum, but we didn't do that. Around 4 pm - 4:30 pm, you may get a glimpse of the living goddess.
Dunbar Square. It was very busy, plenty of Sadhu ready to take your money if you photographed them !! Beautiful wood carvings on the temples.

Once the heart of a Kingdom. The history and the temples in Durbar square make this a special attraction. We visited the Kumari house which is just off the edge of the square, the home of a living goddess. The ancient palace must have been an amazing place in its heyday. It is certainly impressive today.
Touristic place. It is a good place to see all the temples and to walk around. It is beautiful but nothing extraordinary. I would recommend it. Make sure you take a picture with the "monks".

Spend a morning here. Overall its a must see because of the history, but you don't need more than a morning. A lot of the square is open to noisy traffic so it can get a bit smoggy, but its fun to people watch here and see the flower vendors. Skip the museum though. Its drab and not worth the admiasion price.

A great insight into Nepalese Culture. A very fun day! Spent a whole day at Durbar Sqaure, sitting ontop of the temples and watching the everyday lives of Nepalese. Make sure you visit the Museum!!! Was surprisingly very very good!!
Get there early -Durbar Square. Get your ticket stamped for a second visit as I enjoyed being there to photograph and watch the crowds as well as arriving very early the next morning.

History abounds!. Wow! so many temples and history is such a small place. Our guide was a mine of information and listened and answered questions as needed. He took us through many little alley ways to get to Durbar Square.
Put it on the list. I didn't do a guided tour. I opted for a map and a really cheap taxi. I was able to hit this and several of the sights in the valley in an afternoon.

Kathmandu Durbar Square, or Basantapur Durbar Square.... Kathmandu Durbar Square, or Basantapur Durbar Square is the plaza in front of the old royal palace of the Kathmandu Kingdom. It is one of three Durbar Squares in the Kathmandu Valley in Nepal, all of which are UNESCO World Heritage Sites.The Durbar square is surrounded with spectacular architecture and vividly showcases the skills of the Newar artists and craftsmen over several centuries.

Lots to see and enjoy.. Lots of temples,palace and chance to see the Kumari Goddess. But perhaps best is just watching the colours and culture of Nepalese people going about their daily business. If you take a photo with you to get your ticket stamped they will let you have multiple entries as long as your Visa is valid.

Interesting but entrance fee over priced. Really interesting. The architecture is fantastic.Kumari was interesting as the traditional is a combination of Buddhism and Hinduism. Paid 500 NPR additional to see the kumari.The tickets are expensive at 750 NPR but if you intend to visit repeatedly, you can get additional card at the office area which allows multiple entry at no additional cost.

Kings and a living Goddess.... This is a beautiful area and the old palace has been opened as a museum. Entrance fees for the square will cover visits over 3 days if you pop into the tourist office for a free extension. A grate area to visit.

Splendid collection of temples and shrines. This square is heart of Kathmandu. Covering quite a few acres in the city centre, it contains a marvellous collection of temples, many with exquisite wood carving. Most memorable for me was the Kumari-ghar, a handsome 3-storey building where the 'living goddess' resides. Taken from her family at the age of 3, she remains the living goddess until the moment of puberty. Only the most recent incumbent has insisted that she be educated, so that she can have some career in later life. I was puzzled initially by a sign that said 'Forbidden to photograph the Kumari'. But this is the name for the living goddess herself, who resides on the top floor and is occasionally glimpsed by visitors. An aged male guardian was clearly visible, gazing down on the many tourist visitors.  Non-Hindus are not allowed to enter any of the Hindu temples in the square, but there is a wealth of beautifully decorated buildings of various sorts to enjoy. While we were there, we witnessed a noisy musical procession in the main part of the square. We returned to our tour coach with an enjoyable down-hill race through the streets on cycle-rickshaw.
Feast for Architecture lovers. Really took me back to the past. Beautiful historical buildings with different architecture types. Also lots of shopping. Artist at work doing pottery etc.

Fantastic place..!. Actually, I have went here for many times because I love go here. Here, I can find more foreign people than Nepalese people. Actually, it will a matter of surprise when you see A Nepalese person walking instead of foreign people. Walking around its amazing streets with light music played all around makes it great...

nothing beats this place!. this is one of the most beautiful places in Kathmandu. It'd be great to have a guide tell you of the grand history of the temples scattered around the square. unmissable place!

Nice place to see. To start out, if you don't look Nepali/Indian, have 750 Rps on you, because the guards at the entrances will hunt you down to snag your money for the "People from other countries Entry Fee", or so it happened to me.Went here on a solo trip and just sat around on a beautiful clear day doing people watching. There are a lot of buildings, lots of shops, and lots of people to see. There are roaming tour guides who you can easily talk into giving you a brief 20-30min tour for USD $5 or less. I skipped that, although was approached by various tour guides offering me their services. Upon each refusal, their prices dropped. Seems somewhere in the $4-5 range is their minimum.Would recommend going to see this.
historical. Like: enjoyed its rich historical memorabilia. Admired it well maintenance.Dislike:Certain areas are barred to Non Hindus

One of the three ancient cities to see in the kathmandu valley. Durbar Square, Patan and Bhaktapur are essential places to visit. Be sure to look for the Living Goddess, Kumari when in the square. And learn her story.

Awesome place. This place is called as local market. one can find all kinds of shops here. Remember one thing if you plan to purchase anything here. BARGAIN! BARGAIN! BARGAIN! Start from 1/3rd of the quoted price. Depending on the item, you can also start from 1/5th of the quoted price. You can purchase Pashmina's, Kashmere shawls for a cheaper price here when compared to Thamel market.

It is great to see historical spot and local people. Swoyambhunath is the most ancient and enigmatic holy shrine in Kathmandu valley. This stupa is located on a lovely hillock lies about four kilometer from the center of Kathmandu city. Its lofty white dome and glittering golden spire are visible for many miles and from all sides of the city. Historical records found on a stone inscription give evidence that the stupa was already an important Buddhist pilgrimage destination by the 5th century AD. This stupa is also known affectionately as the ‘Monkey Temple’. Because the large troop of handsome monkeys that guards the hill and amuses visitors and devotees with tricks. This site offers fine views over Kathmandu valley. It is particularly striking in the early evening under the soft glow of moonlight.

Kathmandu Durbar Square can take my breath away for Historical so amazing and make me complete. i love Nepal ...... realy there make me complete in this trip i find some place like this but i can found Nepal and go there and always i want be back again
One of three Durbar squares in Kathmandu. Too busy, could not see the square well to photograph. Would be good to have some diagrams or maps set up.

Beautiful old temples. Filled with locals hassling. Temples are interesting and beautiful. Beware of locals trying to be your guide for a fee. Our guide changed his price afterwards which was frustrating
Costly admission for tourists - Very crowded. It's a must visit. Too many sights not to pass up and you'll want to experience enjoying people watching. It's a very crowded and fasr past Square.

Well worth a visit. Durbar Square Kathmandu is a world heritage site and well worth a visit. Amongst the host of temples they have a 'living goddess' who you can glimpse at through an upstairs window at various times of the day. A lovely atmosphere with rooftop restaurants and many street sellers give a lovely atmosphere. It also borders Freak Street which is worth a stroll down. On the down side traffic still goes through most of the square. If you have a white face there's a charge of 750 Nepalese rupees, but if you take your passport and a spare passport photo for the same price they turn your ticket into a pass that will last for the length of your visa. Also if you go by taxi make sure the driver knows exactly where you want to go. They have a few Durbar Squares and a museum. The driver will drop you at the one most convenient to him and argue that's where you asked for. We where dropped miles away.

Interesting Site. This was an interesting site to visit. Lots of old buildings and temples. Locals get in free, but tourists need to pay. They will tell you it is 750 rupees at the gate, but you shouldn't pay more than 200 rupees.
Although chaotic, worth a visit. Palace museum was interesting and has potential for the future. Lots of creative events on during our visit. What out for holy cows and cheeky monkey's!

OK, but.... This is a "must see" for most tourists and is certainly interesting, but Patan and Bhaktapur both have Durbar Squares which I enjoyed more. The King's museum in Kathmandu was a bit dilapidated, and not nearly as nice as the Patan museum. If you are in the country for a long time, see this, but if you have limited time, consider skipping it for other things
exposure to the local culture. Great place to visit to get the hang of the local culture. Don't miss the Goddess temple and buy the local artifacts.

Interesting and fun to visit. I went twice.. It is the historical heart of Kathmandu with many temples and shrines. The first time I went as part of a guided tour and got the history of the place. I went back on my own to take lots of photographs. It was theTihar festival and it was filled with vendors.

Ancient Temples. Listed as one of the eight cultural world heritage site by UNESCO, you can visit ancient temples, palaces, courtyards and streets that date back to the 12th and 18th centuries. The major attraction in this area are Kumari House, Kathamandup temple, Teleju temple and etc. It will attact you for everything if you like cultural and ancient stuff.

Rip off. In its infinite wisdom, the Nepalese government has placed a 750 rupee fee to see this site. The fee is only for Westerners as Asians only pay 150 rupee. I found the tiered fee to be very distasteful and prejudice and therefore I do not recommend going.
Classic Kathmandu. This shows the tradition of Kathmandu more than any other spot. Tons of temples in a small area. Fun place to go for a few hours. Very quick walk from Thamel (1 mile maybe?).

Not worth the entry fee!. We much preferred to enjoy Durbar Square from the roof of the wi-fi available cafe where we enjoyed momo's, chicken chowmein and black coffee. They get you if you are a foreigner and to be frank, it really was another tourist attraction we chose to read about over lunch rather than pay to walk through.
Must visit!. Kathmandu Durbar Square, Patan Durbar Square, and Bhaktapur Durbar Square is World Heritage Sites in Nepal
nothing can beat a cup of tea in the evening at basantapur. this is the most historical place in Kathmandu you can see lots of nepali architecture around the area.

A nice place to take pictures, but too chaotic. The place is interesting to take good pictures. If you go early in the morning it could be a nice experience, but be prepared to find dirt, noise and too many motorbikes.

Ancient Feel. Ancient feel as if you have been brought to those Malla and Gurkha King era, which is kind of good to see historic monuments in pristine condition. Please have a guided tour as every structure has its own meaning to its existence and explanations make you want to see more. We had a walk to another temple, and the experience was amazing.
Craziness but a must do. It's wild and crazy with tons of people driving, walking and biking in the streets. Good deals on souvenirs but make sure you negotiate.
Really nice and unique. the new pricing.the trip from northern Thamel is part of the adventure - take the time to explore the side streest too

Nice place.. We visited the Durbar Square the fist thing on day two. Nice clean place with a of wood cared buildings. Saw the Taluju Bhavani Ghanti, Shiv Parvati mandir and the 17th Century Taluju Manidr. We were in time to see the living Goddess of Nepal as well as she give darshan just for 15 to 20 secs each day.

Vibrant & hectic. We eventually found Durbar square after going through lots of narrow ally's selling an array of wares. We paid the entrance fee that gave us admission to several museums etc. Lots of street sellers who followed you everywhere, but if you were polite they eventually left you alone. It was a bit in your face but well worth the visit. Not sure you would attempt a second visit though.You also have to hand in camera's that are locked away when you enter the museums.

The main square, 1of 3. We visited Durbar square a day befor Indrajatra selebration and it was free for coming. Very interesting place with Kumari palase, temples and amaizing wooden architectural details on walls and doors and windows.

hellhole. noisy, dirty, not worth the walk. try backtaphur or patan for a real feel of Nepal. this one costs like 7 euros and by the time you get there you are knackered and in a bad mood cos of all the obstacles and dirt on the way. not worth it!
very oldpart of citycentre. If youwalk around here you do not know what you see.Such old buildings and in such good shape.Alsoit is possible to visit Royal Palace
Interesting enough to take a look.. A few nice temples. Was crazy busy the day I went due to festival, so lots of cool people watching opportunities.
Crowded. The square is very interesting. But if you must choose, better go to Patan or Bhaktapur. The Durbar Sq in Kathmandu is very crowded. There are also lots of really annoying would-be guides.

Early morning vist.. Can I suggest that you get up at 6am and get a early morning rickshaw ride. Great to see the city before it really gets busy and you can also vista Durbar Square with out paying the entrances fees. Jason
Colours, sounds, stimuli everywhere!. I liked the atmosphere, the colours, the architechture. Beware of pigeons, I saw some turists getting "baptised" at the Leaving Goddess temple.

Dashain Festival. I was here for the Dashain festival this year. Very photogenic with the ritual sacrifice of Bullocks, goats and cocks, Thousands of people, A happy time for all. Except the sacrifices, Everyone that I wished a Happy Dashain to just beamed and wished me a Happy Dashain too. I was here 30 years ago and It was much bloodier,

Not to be missed!. It is a UNESCO World Heritage Site - enough said! Amazing! The touts that hang around offering tours are a detraction, but just be firm. Also, if you are staying in Kathmandu for multiple days you can go to the official office there and get your ticket stamped so you only need to pay once (have your passport and an extra photo available)

Temples Galore. The centre of Kathmandu is graced with this collection of beautiful temples. There is Durbar square in all three cities of the Kathmandu: Patang, Baktapur and Kathmandu. They are all impressive but confusing without a good guide book or guide. They are fascinating when properly described and put in their historical context. The one in Kathmandu is 10 minute walk from Thamel. My favorite part is the residence of the Kumari Devi, the living goddess. You don't get to see her but the concept is interesting.
Wow, that's amazing. It is really amazing, but you must also see Bhaktapur Durbar Square as well. It is much more silent and somewhat has a different beauty...

Worth a visit. Interesting place with hawkers trying to sell you crappy stuff, all claimed to me hand made by themselves!Westerners mean wealth to them and the prices asked are ridiculous and its not uncommon for them to drop their price from $25 to $3

So much to see!. This place is a must-see in Kathmandu, but try to go with a good guide (Bikash, who you can contact through Outshine Adventure is fantastic!) becausethe devil is in the detail and you will miss a lot the significance of the sights on your own.

Entry ticket scam. You can actually walk right through, if you don't attract attention to yourself and do so quickly. They only man the entrances - which is just some ropes in the wide footpath- when they see a bunch of 'money bags' coming that way. They overprice the entry ticket, BIG time. As a foreigner you pay 10x the amount that a local would pay. What a scam. Their mentality that we all have deep pockets really got old after three weeks between India and Nepal. 'Welcome to our country, give us your money,' was what they pretty much were saying with their hand out in expectation.

Nice attraction. Very nice Attraction. We thoroughly enjoyed the ancient woodwork and metalwork. Our guide tended to go into much historical detail about all of the religious history -and we kind of got lost on that portion.
Shopping Heaven. The history and culture is very exciting to be a part of. Save lots of time (and money) for shopping. The handicrafts are unique and a wonderful addition to my collection.

Must but too expencive. Everybody must visit Durbar, but now they found new money collecting system, one visit is up till Rs 750, some 7 euros. If you stay longer, go with your passport, color photo, no b/w (sic!) and ticket to site office near Kumari house and you can get Visitor pass. You can stay there long time, but only temples are open. Anyway, climbe up to many see the daily life on a square. All places are nowadays very expencive to visit, like Bhaktapur town Rs 1100. (Free with press card only.)

Left after 10 mins. This may be an historical site and does have a lot to see but the hawkers , street sellers and beggars made our visit intolerable. We visited during Dashain festival and this made it much busier with local people but the overall experience was too much.

A must see but dont take a buggy if you go with a young child. The Durbar Square is impressive and interesting with lots of photo opps. Definitely a must see. It does get really busy though so if you are going with a young child you will need to be prepared to carry them. We made the mistake of taking our daughter in a buggy which was a nightmare to get through the crowds.
Quiet on the holiday. We walked down from Jyanti and greatly enjoyed the entrance to the square. It is full of life and wonderful buildings.
A must see. Among places you need to see in Kathmandu and just take a walk along the area...you will see many other places of interest.

... not the destination, the way to it makes it worthwhile .... Agree, this is an exaggeration, maybe it is downright unfair to this famous square but still I would say the way to it is not enough appreciated.From Thamel center it is a nice, 2-3 km, walk to Durbar square. Along the way you will be engulfed by everyday Kathmandu life, not the Thamel kind, but the normal life for the Nepali living near the center. You will pass through their shopping area containing micro shops selling just about anything for everyday life. Spices, meat, groceries, drinks, fish, vegetables, kitchen utensil, garllands to be used for religious ceremonies, clothing, etc etc... As said, anything you can think of.If that all gets too hectic, step through one of the small ports that may bring you into the inner space of a court where the people live, do their laundry and children play their games, seemingly miles away from the hussle and bustle of the street.There is one drawback to going into Durbar Square that way. When you finally reach the square you may reach the Square more ready for a moment of mental rest then for the call from the entry booth to pay your 750 pp fee for entering Durbar Square. The continuous flow of people and traffic that passes through the square also makes it unclear why YOU suddenly should pay to be allowed to go further. The added emphasis of the policeman that escorts you to the booth however makes it clear that there is no escaping, even if you do not mind to just walk through the square and not go into any of the buildings that are open to visitors.Durbar Square Kathmandu has a lot of historic buildings in a relatively small space. Apparently there are more then 50 temples/shrines on the square, among them the most intriguing (to me) residence of the living goddess, the Kumari. The leaflet you get after paying the entry fee lists the most notable ones with some explanation. Of the buildings we were allowed to enter we visited the Royal Palace. This is a complex consisting of a number of connected courts. It is a pity that most of the interior is not open to visitors.As said Durbar Square Kathmandu is certainly worth the visit, but I certainly would not want to miss the walk to it.
Fascinating place to visit. Recommend a guide. Lots of people but traffic free. ould definately recommend the use of a guide as there is so much history assocaiated with the place.

Great architecture. Lovely buildings in the centre of Thamel. Lots of great photo opportunities. Because it is a World Heritage Site you have to pay quite a lot to get in (750 rupees). This does not prevent you being followed by guides hoping to show you around. The booklet you get with admission gives lots of information about the buildings.

Durbar Square colour. What a place! As soon as you arrive (in Thamel), walk down here. The walk alone is exciting! However you see so much of Nepali life there, not to mention the exquisite architecture. We visited the Square on 4 separate occasions and loved the whole spectacle.

Nice Place. Beautiful place to see, a lot of temples inside the durbar, Hindu's can go up and see the Kumari.You do not need a guide in this place, a map and a brochure given when you purchase a ticket, its more then enough to explore using the map by yourself, you wont get lost and the place is not so big.A lot of people selling stuffs are the entrance of the place, bargain alot to get a good deal.
A must see for any visitor. A great place to sit and people watch and life as it goes by at 100mph in the city extraordinary place Kathmandu is wish had more time here

Wow. A hidden gem in the centre of Kathmandu - and very few hawkers (makes a nice change), the usual babas waiting for their photos tobe taken and asking for a few rupees - but not oppressive in any way

Can't miss this.. We absolutely loved Durbar Square. We hired Dilip as our tour guide (ask for him, everyone knows him). We got so much more out of it because of his tour. I'd definitely recommend hiring someone. Tell them that you want to SKIP the final stop at the store where they get a commission for selling you something, unless you like shopping. We bought a tanka, suckered right into it, but we love it anyway. All part of the experience.

A wonderful place full of spirituality and history. The Kathmandu Durbar square is an enthralling location for the beauty of its structures and the variety of people you meet there. You can get a good taste of how good it is by checking out the pictures online. I'll just warn you that the place smells really bad and that you should beware of pickpockets and beggars. Besides that, it's really a must see place.

Crowded but stunning. We took a cab through the city and that was a crazy experience. There is so much dust it's hard to breath. (they are working on the roads -- indefinitely). However, the square was fantastic. The sights were exquisite.

Dont pay to get in!. We went into the square without ever being asked for a ticket, then suddenly out of nowhere we were being shooed out and yelled at for taking photos. They wanted us to pay 500R and for what? The square is less than impressive and there is trash EVERYWHERE! If they are going to charge (after you have already gone half way through no less) it would be nice to at least see clean temples with no plastic bottles littering the foundations... We did not pay, seems if you ignore them for a short time they give up. It does not sit well either when you see them miss half the tourists gonig in and only charge the ones that roam close to the "ticket counter" wich is not located at the entrance to the square...

start here. yes, start here.you can see freak street,legend , only legend today, continue to Kumari house, living legent, many temples aroun, you can spend here easyly 2 hours.you can heve nice walk from here to tourist heard of KTM,which is Thamel.

Don't miss this. Ancient, beautiful and like taking a step back in time. We took a guide with us and think it was well worth the money as we got so much more history and information from him. A good guide will also help you explore off the beaten track safely. Beware of so called 'local guides' hanging around the square.

nice, but not mandatory. Kathmandu Durbar Square is a nice and interesting place to visit, but don't expect to be amazed. It's not cheap (750 rupees per person, which we were surprised to find out), and it's a lot of the same. It is a UNESCO world heritage site, so if you have the time and the money, and you already came all the way to Kathmandu, I would recommend to go and have a look. We liked the nine stories pagoda, and the place where the Kumari lives (we got to see her as she stepped out on the balcony when we were there). We didn't try to visit all the buildings and just left when we felt like we've seen enough.All in all it was nice.
worth a visit. 750 rupees entry fee, which is pretty steep, constant hassle inside but some pretty good stuff to see
the beginning. Where Kathmandu began, it's like an open air museum. you have to pay a small fee to enter Durbar Square, but it is worth it!Also a must see when you are there.

Too expensive. Compared to the other Durbar Squares at Patan and Bhaktapur, this one was far too expensive to enter(R750), was a little drab and just not as impressive as the other ones. You did get free second entry if you came back. The museum and thus the walk through the palace should be done, but if you are tight on time, see the others and don't feel you are missing out on much

We didn't bother. When we got there and found out the price had gone up to 750, we didn't bother.. I was told by other travelers that I met that it was okay and the museum was the best bit, but that the higher cost made it not so worth while

Nice but expensive. Durbar square is the heart of Katmandu. It has the highest concentration of temples in the city. There are several very interesting temples, like the temple of erotica. The palace is very impressive, but the fact that we had to pay 750 Rupees (almost $10) just to enter (while locals enter freely) was a bit upsetting. We thought that UNESCO's heritage sites were supposed to be free. If you do decide to visit, take a tour guide. Many of them are available near the ticket booths, and they well deserve the 1000-1500 Rupees they usually charge. Without a guide, the buildings are just buildings. A guide can make them come to life.

great for walking. Once you get past the guide touts and jewellery sellers this is a great place to wander around and soak up the atmosphere of Kathmandu, get out of the square and walk around the cobbled medieval streets round about, definitely worth wasting a few hours just pottering around with the locals...a walk to/from Thamel is a nice way to spend an afternoon, even if you get lost which is likely!!
Don't go out of your way to come here.. Bhaktapur and Patan are way better, so if you miss this, no big deal. It is nicely lit at night though, and very busy.

Do not miss it!. If you want imagine how great the Kathmandu Valley civilization ever was, you have to be there. It is unforgivable to be in Nepal and not vist Durbar Square. The Palaces, the temples, the chows, etc. Take some minutes to visit the Palace Museum, you will not find many thing but at least you will understand the late history of a new country(Nepal).
Not the best.. While pleasant enough, the Patan Durbar square is much more impressive, and seems to have a lot fewer touts. Art in some of the temples is explicit.

Wonderful, but expensive. It costs a lot for a tourist to enjoy Durbar Square, but if the money goes towards its preservation as claimed, then it would be worth it. Wander, soak up the atmosphere, check out the medieval buildings, then repair to one of the panoramic rooftop cafes (I recommend Cosmo Cafe for this).

What a joke!. Four stars? REALLY??? This place is was the biggest waste of time!!!! I mean, it’s really, really bad. The architecture that everyone’s there to see is maintained so poorly, it’s pathetic. And, as if they’re not making enough money on entrance fees, they’ve put up HEAPS of big, plastic banners advertising stuff like Pepsi and SIM cards on all of them so you can’t even get a decent photo. Then on the ground there isn’t a square foot without a big piece of trash. On the plus side, it’s really easy to just walk in without buying a ticket – THANK GOD because if I would have spent 750rp ($9.15usd), I would have shot myself! Seriously, skip this one – there’s NOTHING TO SEE
Great Photo Ops. This place was not too far from Freak Street and had a lot of great views and older buildings. It was a great place to spend a few hours.

Lovely Experience. It is worth getting a guide from the gate as it makes it even more fascinating. Just don't let them land you with two on purpose as they want paying full price each. They even tell you the tour is free so be careful of that too.
A classic go-to place. A classic go-to place in Kathmandu when visiting Nepal. I stayed just around the corner and it was great.

interesting. Well worth a look to give you an in depth cultural perspective of Kathmandu's history and culture. Take your time and people watch as well especially the holy men who have sold themselves to the capitalist devil.
too expensive. they charge 750 R for a backpacker it is too high . The "guides" that try to adopt you are a problem...
caotic balance. first u see u feel caos inside your body but when u understand the way of living culture and history u start seeing the living energy....amazing and crowded :D
Very interesting. worth a visit but be prepared to be swamped by people wanting to be your guide, we went without and guide and didn't feel like we had missed anything.
One to see. Worthwhile experience whilst in K-du. The main attraction in the centre off which most other places seem to spread. Gives good sense of area and architecture.

rustic site. it's one of the few Durbar squares to be found in Kathmandu and and I'm not mistaken, the largest as well.
Go on to gawk at the medieval architecture and maybe even get a glimpse of the Kumari!
A Palatial Palace of the royals of Nepal. Just visit once to know the history of the royals of Nepal and their culture, paintings, & ornaments exihibit.

Most interesting old royal palace plaza and museum. Very large beautiful plaza with lot of shops around perimeter. Lots of people just hang out setting on temple steps and people watch. Interesting to see people filling up water jugs from public water pipes. Museum has a lot of history of Kathmandu and Nepal.

Ancient magic and birds in the air. I arrived to Durbar Square by foot when the sun was almost setting already and the approaching twilight added to the feel of magic in the air. If you start your walk from Thamel along the cobblestone street you will experience buildings getting older and the feeling holy in a secular way as different types of temples line the way. The old buildings of the square are wonderful to photograph and one can sit and mingle with the crowd, photographing and watching the birds. There are interesting Buddhist art shops nearby, some with authentic artwork. Just be careful on your way back to the hotel - if that's where you are staying and especially if it is a smaller one - some of the taxis may not know yours, nor English, and it is good to have a precise address and if possible a cell phone handy. Strongly recommend a visit here!

Should be one of the wonders of the world!. Next to the similar squares of nearby Patan and Bhaktapur! It is a mesmerizingly beautiful, untouched by modernity, whole unit of tiny streets, temples, palaces, pools, dwelling abodes, small shops and eateries. It is also a meeting point and a hanging out place for the people of Kathmandu. Architectural beauty, spiritual experience and living traditions in the 21st century!
A place i would go to.... ...over and over again. Whether for shopping, seeing how people live, learning about Nepali architecture, admiring carvings ...

Pay your entrance - Get a card!. If you're spending some time in the capital then you'll come here and unless lucky be pounced upon by the police/guards who will charge you. They will do this every time you walk across the square. But if you pay once you can get a ticket for the same price. Simply take your original ticket and receipt (if you get one) with a passport photo and take them to the small office located just behind the open air stall holders - the guards will point you if you ask. This will entitle you to weeks of entering the square, so you can just flash your card and wander through. This is great for those staying in freakstreet or simply exploring the city for a week as you'll cross the sqare alot and it beats arguing/avoiding the guards. Also the money is being spent on the actual square and those looking after it. You can do the same for Bhaktapur too (not sure about Patan).

friendly people. its the place where most of the temples are , and a lot of people trying to sell you what they have some of them are realy smart in selling you things if you say no they will tell that its a gift from them and you cant help but to give them money there are too many shops around , go and try the roof top resturant (kasthamndap Resturant) have the most amazing MoMo (traditional nepaly dumpling, vegetable chicken or buff, steamed or fried) i like the steamed vegetable, and also try the chawmien (noodles)

Should be pedestrianized. You will get collared to buy a ticket but it is worth seeing. I really liked the old palace and just sitting looking at all the activity in the area. Well worth spending an afternoon or morning leisurely looking around.
a must do. a must do in Kathmandu valley.You should take at least 5 days to enjoy this part of Nepal.It was so intersting that we went there twice ;)
Excellent place. This place is an architectural marvel. No visit to Kathmandu is complete without visiting here. The sculptures, the ancient buildings, temples...everything is so fresh in my memory

A Place full of Culture and Tradition. Durbar Square has a lot of open markets selling souvenirsa lot of temples around the areayou will find a lot of locals jus sitting talking and havin a great time in the evening a lovely time to go in the evening
Nice place. This place has lot of temples of different gods. Place is crowded most of the times. This being a world heritage site with quite a hefty entrance fee, can be maintained better
Mesmerizing. Old world Charm still intact. One can get a glimpse of the lifestyle and architecture in the old times.

The Heart of Kathmandu in many ways. Go there early in the morning and you will love the sights and sounds all around. The prayers, the pigeons being fed, the vegetable vendors, the markets slowly waking up.
Do not miss seeing this. Spend time readingand learning about each. There is a fee to enter but avoid con men posing as professional tour guides.
Interesting history. We experienced a Buddist festival, so locals out in force with colorful dress and dance activities. All the architecture was amazing as well.
magic. I have been amazed by this place since 1985. Hasn't changed much but it use to be a living museum whereas now it is just a museum.

go to bhaktapur instead. after going to patan and bhaktapur, we were disappointed with kathmandu's durbar square. with so many things to see in the valley, this one can be skipped. better to eat at a resto in thamel, too.

Motorbikes everywhere. I had visited Durbar Square only a year before and I was surprised that the price of the entrance ticket was three times more expensive than last August! However, I paid 750 Rs but was quite annoyed when I realised that there were motorbikes driving everywhere making a lot of noise with their horns! That was quite unacceptable!!!

Worth a short visit. Since it is a big part of local history, it is worth a visit. It is also walking distance from Thamel. Many of the temples and buildings are in disrepair. If you look like a foreigner you will be asked to buy the admission ticket to gain access. Also you will be approached by "tour guides " who will tell you you are lucky to be there on a special day. They want you to pay them for an hour 's tour. If you want some history it may be worth it. Bargain them town. Patan Durbar Square is better preserved and has a much better museum.

Loads of people. There were lots of people all around, local and tourist alike. It had the feel of a local market where vendors would sell vegetables, dried fish etc. Do try the steam dumplings (Momos) which are served in every corner. The place needs some renovations though.

Definite must see in Kathmandu. It oozes history - as the temples in the square are I don't know how many hundreds of years old (although Wikipedia says one of them is about 1000 years old). Not a whole day's adventure to be sure, nor worth a long journey just to see them. But if you're in Kathmandu, I think they give you a sense of the mystic history of the city. Not a lot to do there, and kind of touristy. But it is a nice walk. It is in the middle of a market district, and so there are lots of little shops and vendors in the area.

very good place. very nice place. to get inside you have to pay a ticket and if you want you can extend the ticket for 3 days free, in the office situated in the place next to durbar square. You need a guide to understand everything.

Save your time and money. The temple area charges I think 200 Rs to get in and walk around. We managed to just walk in for free but really the temples aren't so nice. It was more fun walking around and shopping in the area just north of Durbar Square, en route to Thamel. (Thamel is also nice for walking around, shopping, and drinking.) Save your time; save your money :)

Chill on the roof. We went to a nice restaurant on a roof, which had great views of the square, and spent several hours and quite a bit of money up there. It is not as spectacular as visiting Bahaktapur but it is still worth visiting

Tour in Nepal @ basantapur. Basantapur, is area of old palace of Kings of Nepal, i was there and found it the best place for any people from whole world to pass their time in fun. i love to be there with my friends and enjoy the crowd as well as the different musical tones which fascinate us to be there
Nice place but too crowded...!!!. Too crowded and no power back-ups. So if the electricity in out in the evening, you're out of luck to see or do anything there.
Nice. Just takes 15 minutes to get there from Thamel to see the living God Kumari!!!
Amazing. It’s a most beautiful place one can witness in Nepal the Square Is actually a palace which is modified into museum.

Great wander!. fun to wander around. you can also avoid paying entrance feeby entering through the Freak Street! Lots of people trying to get money off you inside as usual, money in exchange for photos, beggars, touts, 'tour' guides etc but just ignore them. lots of great photos! :)

Go on, take the guide!. Having been pestered all day by touts I was in the process of shooing away a chap who claimed to be an "official" guide when it dawned on me that he actually might be able to add value to the process. I was then treated to a nice walking tour of the highlights that was both educational and informative.As always nothing is free but the detour via a thangka painting school actually just added to my knowledge and enhanced the experience, the lady patiently spent time educating me as to the different styles, techniques and quality of paintings and the backstory to them. This obviously came with some mild sales pressure but I politely reiterated what I'd clearly stated at the start of the process, namely that I wasn't in the market for a painting and that I didn't want to waste their time.Hope this was helpful.
a place worthy of visit. as you come to kathmandu, you should not miss this place, it surely is a significant place, it expresses something of the past, like Nepalese culture...

Durbar Marg..........road to royalty.. Can spend a whole day hopping and sitting in any of the cafes or restaurants of Darbar Marg. Even a coffee and something to munch can pull you back in this place.
Full of life. This is one side of the real Kathmandu, even if kids are still trying to see you trinkets.

You have to pay (or maybe not). Arriving in Durbar Square by taxi, we were taken in the middle of the main square where after walking for a while we were approached by a kind of guardian who asked for money for the visit. As we were a bit surprised we said we did not yet know if we'd stop there and visit it as we had just arrived & had not yet decided what to do. After a few moments we were left alone and didn't have to pay at all... The square is nice and so are the palaces in it, but the presence of cars, motorbikes and rikshaws make it a bit too stressfull for pedestrians: you always have to pay attention or you might be run over! We only had a quick look around and then headed back to the shopping area of Tamel. Durbar Sq apparently is one of the best place in town for the tankas, so you can have a look at them here.

Really enjoyed hanging out here. So much to see - just worth it for the people watching opportunities! The buildings are very chinese-like. Prices in the nearby shops are good too. A good place to stock up on souvenirs and goods. And lots of monkeys, I like monkeys...
Peacefulness. We always go back ...and take more and more photos. The place is a magnet...and the peaceful Bhudists...make the place nice

A nice place to visit but not as picturesque as Patan Durbar Sq. Its 750rps to enter and you can extend your pass when you go inside to 3 days. Its a beautiful place to visit but after Patan Durbar I felt it was not as nice
Confusing. This was very confusing as their doesn't appear to be a specific entrance in which you pay. Most people just walk past and get away with not paying. Buildings are very interesting.

Not to be Missed. Thankfully I'd arranged a half-day guide who explained many of the highlights in this must-see place in Kathmandu. Lunch over looking the area was delightful. We climbed up high and sat outside observing all the action.

Durbar square poor compared to Bhaktapur. We've heard many things about this square, but it is quite a mess, everywhere pigeons so in maybe 100 years there's not much left to be seen. If you want to see a beatifull place go to Bhaktapur.
Good. Good, very interesting and historical. Wish had some more time
Historical!. Very interesting architecture and full of history but also full of street touts, urchins and beggars. Though once told firmly and politely 2 or 3 times they eventually left you alone.

Wow.....if u love old buildings.... This is a place that would make any lover of old buildings swoon. The traditional Nepali structures have been well restored and look great. Spend atleast half a day here and lunch in one of the quaint cafes.You can buy good Tbetian thanka paintings here but need to haggle over the price.Just wander around, but if u pick up a guide at the gate, they are cheap and speak good english (again u need to haggle, don't pau more then 10-15 us dollars for one) , you will have a much better experience and all your questions will be answered.
High historic content. Tourist trap as sellers hassle you in the streets before the square. But hey everyone has to make a living
just not improving. this is a place where you could enjoy the ambiance but the tourist depatment is just doing nothing for tourist attraction and very very dirty and un clean

Very nice square but not worth the entry fee!!. We went early in the morning and did not have to pay. However, later in the day they were charging an outrageous 750R ($10)...just ridiculous for Nepal. There isn't actually a lot to do in the square. You could get food at a restaurant. You can feed the birds/cows. Mostly you just observe.

Royal Palace. The Royal Palace is now a museum after the monarchy was slaughtered about 2001. Some rooms looked like they were modeled after wealthy american homes from the 1950s . None of the museum guards spoke english. I had questions that noone could answer.
UNESCO Site in Downtown Kathmandu. Definitely worth viewing for the unique temples, palace and museum.
Facinating and educational. Watch out for the cars! A guide helped us learn about the history and culture, and all about the Living Goddess.

Impressive, busy, lively... and expensive. It clearly is a must-see, yet the price for non-SAARC citizens has raised to 750 roupies (which includes the fee for the museum and the Kathmandu tower) which is incredibly expensive compared to local price levels. Several temples are real highlights, my personal one was the Kumari temple, where you can enter the courtyard & even see the living goddess if you come at the right moment.

Busy and crowded. I'm pretty sure that i got in t the complex from behind because I had to walk through the smelly river and then walk until I saw the first temple.There was a lot of people selling you mandalas and musical instruments, it was uncomfortable, so be prepared.

Beautiful architecture. There are so many temples, taht is simply impossible to know all of them by name !If you're staying in Thamel, opt to go to the square walking, starting at Thahiti souk and following directions towards the Durbar. There are some really amazing temples and stupas to see, with a little afford to find them behind the buildings or the hidden corners. There are so many architectural and art gems in the buildings of the square, it's impossible to list them all. Possible annoyance are the many ,,guides,, coming to you and convincing you have to take a guide to show you arround.
Crossroads of the City. Liked the Temple of the Living Godess, the crowds, the colour, and the sense of helping to maintain and upgrade what is a beautiful historical place

Worth a visit. It's nice to see a historical and holy place still used a lot by the locals (for prayer). The square is very chaotic. We recommend to get a guide or at least go with a guide book as there are many temples with different stories. Everyday at 16.20, the Goddess Kumari looks from a window in her temple courtyard, so don't miss it if you're visiting. Our guide told us non-Hindus are not allowed to get in unless they have a guide but we are not sure about who enforces that. You can have a nice view of the square if you go on one of the roofs for coffee. If you are going from Thamel (5 mins walk), there is not an entrance fee, however from the other sides to the square (for instance from Freak Street), you have to pay to enter.

Temples, temples everywhere !!!. A bit disconcerting to having to pay to enter Durbar Square but when I was there I walked out straight into the streets of Thamel and could have got in that way without paying. I know World Heritage Sites need a lot of uptake but the entrance fee could put you off. Plenty to see.
What KTM is all about. Spend the day just strolling around and taking in the sights and sounds of chaos.

Improve. The local people have to keep the area clean. They have to maintain the buildings, so that people can view them as it was 15yrs ago. In the evening couples sit all around the monuments and eating and drinking.

Amazing history. My favorite was looking at the craftsmanship of the buildings. There is so much woodwork in each building. We paid a guy 600R for a guided tour of which was worth maybe 200. The karma sutra temple is, of course, my favorite. A little confused on the winged statue as to whether it's vishnu or the vehicle of vishnu. Anyways, more things to research. A great way to spend the day in dirty KTM.

Nice place to visit but too many tourist shops. It was interesting going to the squares and seeing some of the temples and the cultural areas. I didnt like the fact that EVERYWHERE you turned, there were people trying to see you cheap souvenirs that were made in other countries. Worth checking the square out though

Beautiful architecture. Like all the Durbar Squares in Kathmandu Valley the architecture is great. Downside is the large number of tourists, which also implies a lot of people trying to get some of your money.

World Heritage but used by all. The mix of people here was great - all religions, ages and visitors alike - used but locals as a route through the city - did not know where to look first as so much to take in and absorb - just loved it
Lovely!. Worth visiting if you love Nepalese architecture! Also there are plenty of options to shop around. But always negotiate!
Holi Festival. We visited during the Holi Festival on 7 March 2012. It was great. Music, colour, people and lots of fun.

This one is sort of "eh". Durbar Square is a little bit of a rip-off. It's a neat place to walk around, but the entry fee was a bit steep considering. There are some neat shops along the way and pretty temples, just don't expect too much.
worth visiting. it is a nice place worht visiting, from where you may get some images of the past age of Nepal

better than expected. They was a Mao party meeting when we arrived here, with trucks of miltary, so the square was not busy and meant we could take photos easily. It is like stepping back into history. We walked from the Thamel area, enjoying all there is to see enroute.

Expensive, but worth it. Tourists are charged 750 rupees to enter Durbar Square off of New Road. Its a hefty price, but you can always say you're staying on Freak St. if you're skint on money. Remember, though, the money does go towards preservation of the ancient temples. The scenery will make you want to help preserve its beauty for all those to come.

The old glory is evident. This renovated square show the amazing stone carved buildings from hundreads year ago. A museum in the Square is nice place to get out of the crowd outside. Wood carvings display kamasutra to your wildest imagination.

The place to start exploring Kathmandu. Durbar Square and its surroundings are beautiful and amazing with the amount of sights at every corner. Just walk around. The only downsides are the many motorcycles and persistent touts around.
renovations ongoing. renovations and dust spoilt this site,but needs to be done

The good old times. This place is take you back to the times of the kings. Preserved well, this place gives a fair amount of picture on the durbar of the kings. A little messy in the evenings but a must see in Kathmandu. with an open space to walk around and run through the temples and the palaces, it is a good experience
Must See. It take a some time to get there but it is worth the trip. Amazing place and town. A lot of artisan areas. I spent an entire day exploring this town.

Rip-off!. We were filled with excitement as we walked through the streets of Kathmandu in the searing heat with a map heading to the World UNESCO Heritage site of Durbar square. On arrival the first thing that struck me was that it was absolutely falling to pieces. The "gaurds" in plain clothes at the entrance were asking an exorbitant amount of rupees to visit - they said it was a tourist price - but clearly it was because we were white! We saw indians who were clearly tourists with backpacks and maps amd looking lost like us being allowed in for free without question. In addition the money is meant to be going for the upkeep of this beautiful and historic site but it seems that the local authorities using the money elsewhere because it is clear that nothing is being done to preserve/restore these monuments . Frankly I would much rather visit Pathnar Square - it was just as old and beautiful and well looked after (and cheaper!)

The place where tourists come to watch the locals and to view the many temples and palaces.. I visited Durbar Square with a couple of local friends, it was interesting to see the many different temples and former palaces. Some of them where built to worhsip various gods and it was an experience to visit and watch the locals as they sat around in the cool of the evening chatting to each other and watching the world literally go by.

Very nice. Extremely busy, but a nice place to sit and watch the everyday life of nepalese, as well as looking at all the temples and holy places. We also saw the Kumari girl when we where there, which made the trip even more special!
nice atmosphere. Great atmosphere, both for tourists and local Nepali people. Take a book and read at one of the temples or just hang around the market and watch Nepali go about their daily lives.

Outstanding historical area. many centuries old temples and palaces are grouped in this relatively small pedestrian area. The area itself requires a single entry pass that includes entry to the museum in the old palace. Enjoy lunch in one of the many neighbouring rooftop restaurants that offer a view over the sites : marvelous !
great place. Its is worth staying there for some time more than only fast sightseeing ;)

Get a guide. Would have had a quick look & left if I hadn't paid for a guide. The cost of our guide was certainly worth it (around $10 & I didn't bargain), he was informative & kept us interested for over an hour. Just be careful that they will try to take you to see other businesses at the end of the tour, such as artists, where they would most likely get a commission if you buy.

Noisy and over commercialised. Noisy, full of traffic and full of shops selling tat. Crowds made it difficult to stop and enjoy the sites and a very high entry fee for very little. The litter and general waste throughout the site is disappointing considering the entry fee is supposed to be used to maintain the square.

Excellent. There is a lot to see here. You will need to buy an entrance ticket at a gatepost.Although it is the main tourist square there is still a fair amount of local life going on here - building loads being carried on heads etc so every couple of minutes there is a new and interesting sight. There is also a good market just to the south of the square on the way to Freak Street.Definitely worth a visit. Look out for the 1950's fire engine kept in a garage on New Road!
A must see. This is where most things happend. Also the most tourist walk around here. The close by Kings Castle is not worth visiting unless you have a special historical interest

Durbar Square. I really enjoyed Durbar Square the first time I visited with a guide, lots of fascinating Buddhist and Hindu Shrines to see including the Kumari - a living Goddess - a tradition unique to to Nepal as far as I am aware. I would recommend going with a guide as written information about what you're seeing is thin on the ground. However, on the second visit (back from our trek and returning to Kathmandu before our flight home) we went without a guide and a local official tried to charge us 750rupees just for crossing the square as they assume the only reason you are there is to go round the temples rather than to simply walk round the square and look. (this charge only applies to foreigners). I think they need to make better arrangements for visitors to pay for individual attractions as many people such as myself like to be able to walk around a place and experience the atmosphere more than once rather than being charged a fee for simply crossing the square which is admittedly less than $10US, but still, if you're getting near the end of your holiday and running low on local currency it's a bit of an annoyance.

magnificiant. go for sometime there and enjoy this beautifull place.
small teaschop available there with one open market
next to it.

Very old and impressive part of city. This scenery is so old and very impressive .
Can spend most of the day here.
Also around corner is shoppingcentre with 3 floors off all kind of shops

A Historic View. Durbar Square was the only tourist site I had heard about prior to arriving in Kathmandu. I didn't know much about it, but heard the name and knew it was an UNESCO site.Walking through the area really takes you back into time. You really don't understand the significance of the square unless you walk through the Royal Palace Museum. That is where we learned of the royal family and Nepal's history. I do agree that the price is a little expensive, but that shouldn't hold you back from visiting this wonderful location.
See the World pass by. A great place to amble around and watch everyone else doing the same. Timeless place

A WORLD HERITAGE 'MUST'. This is an absolute 'must' for all visitors to Kathmandu. Where else can you see such beautiful preservation of so many glorious historic buildings in such a small space, and learn the history of a whole culture while admiring them? It's essential you hire a guide to explain all the various facts to you, but that's easy enough to do.
Breathtakingly beautiful. There are no words; don't miss it. It is an easy and efficient way to observe the ancient palace and some great shopping for the best of Tibetan crafts.
Lots of History. Short walk from most hotels, and the museum gives a lot of history. Temples are beautiful and numerous. Bustling part of the city.
Durbar Square. Wonderful architecture, look for a rooftop cafe to watch the people milling about. Take ID and get your ticket validated for multiple visits for the length of your visa

A taste of years gone by. This UNESCO site has been wonderfully preserved, full of temples and the old royal palace. The price of entry is worthwhile to keep this place in good condition. Our guide recommended a Thanka painting shop here, and the other shops have quality handmade items (compared to Kathmandu).

A beautiful place that is abused by its managers (if any). Poorly maintained, extremely dirty, you can hardly see any monument because everything has been transformed to a souvenir market. Entry fee is 19 USD now and I am 100% sure that not a single USD is going to the preservation ans maintenance of the "World Heritage Site". I am very much convinced that the entry fee is actually benefiting a local "mafia".It is a shame that such a place is managed in such a poor way. I could pay more if I knew that the money go to the place but with the current management status I think it is a rip off.

To go or not to go. The fee for non SAARC residents to visit Durbar Square is steep and I felt there wasn't much to see, though it would seem a bit weird to go to Kathmandu and not see it. I enjoyed Durbar Square - Bhaktapur much more!
Crazy busy. This is well worth it on the Durbar, Asan and Thamel Loop. Otherwise, my opinion is catch Patan or Baktahpur.
Colour and Excitement. Culture at its finest. Take time to feel and eat and touch and smell. And just to sit and watch!
As good as it's going to get. There are some interesting things in Durbar Square, but nothing that will entice you to linger. Do a 1-hour tour and call it a day.

Splendid Architecture. One could OD on temples in this area. They are all magnificent structures built between 14th and 18th century. My guide had grown up in this area so I got to visit the back streets and meet some of the residents which still remember him or his family.
A big market. It's interesting to see this square after sunset, when a lot of women sell flowers, vegetables, spices. The square is crowded with people and riksas and also beautiful buildings.

Visually stunning, avoid museum.. Really impressive as you walk the well healed streets from Thamel. spend time people watching rather than paying the entrance fee and getting stuck in the maze of a museum. I personally thought the museum at Patan's Durbar square was much more impressive and generally better laid out. (also visit the museum cafe in Patan)
cool hangout place.. if you want to see the locale of the Tinseltown walk 10 min. form the touristic hub Thamel- u will be there . place is awesome suburb mixed with newari cultural an old town .

Too crowded. The old town is worth visiting except too many local people sitting and walking around doing nothing. Some buildings outside the palace are falling apart but the palace is well kept and not many people as you have to pay to get in.
nice bur massy. The square is full with temples. For my openion, dont try to stick to your "lonely pllanet" guide, but try to enjoy the alleys by letting yourself to go lost
Look back in time. An interesting place to visit, make sure you have your own guidebook and use to guide you to the area's highlights.

nice place. it is very old palace and good to visit. I love the place for what i see in front of durbar square. a lot of hand made things we can get in very low price. beautiful statue, lockets, traditional khukuries and many more things
Fascinating Walk. A walk through another time. There is a true living princess and the old Palace. Very interesting if you have the time

A stunning place steeped in history. We made our way to Durbar square walking from Thamel, it only takes about twenty minutes.Be persistent that you do not need a guide but do take a Lonely Planet or other suitable guidebook along. Visit the Palace museum while you are there and enjoy the many eccentricities on display such as the old King's coffin, which casually lies on display within one of the rooms. Also do try to see the Kumari who might just make an appearance if you're lucky.I found the Kathmandu Durbar square to be the most novel out of all the other squares with its many interesting monuments. Our time at the square was made more novel when we later discovered that we had attended a maoist protest there, by accident.
Kathmandu stopover. Very interesting, well worth taking a look. Very busy and crowded but thats Kathmandu.

Early morning market walk. Each time I've been to Nepal and stay around Thamel, I like to rise early, 7amish, and walk towards Durbar Square. The streets past Thamel as you approach Durbar Sq are bustling with locals setting up their market wares on the ground in front of the shops before they open. There are usually no other tourists around to be seen and you can stand in a corner and just take in another day in the life of Nepal.
Amazing architecture. Vibrant complex with many fanscinating buildings and even a sight of the Living GoddessMany persitent hawkersYou need a guide to get the modst from this experience
Must see. Great place to check out the locals and grab some good souvenirs’. Bring your camera!

The place to start your sight seeing. An open air museum!!! make sure you decide if you need a guide or not and then you can choose from the guys that start talking to you or just avoid them. Some of them are really educated and some others just try to take your money. There are a few roof top nice restaurants that you can enjoy the view while eating. Make sure you don't miss the appearence of Kumari, the living Goddess that shows up at her window 2-3 times a day to bless the tourists!
very atmospheric. The mixture of holy places, old buildings, crowds, motor bikes and tourists was almost overwhelming. It was vibrant but seemed very safe for tourists during the day.

Just a square. It's just a square with many buildings. The Kumari only appears for a split second a day and disappears.There are many "guides" and "college students" who are willing to bring you on a city tour for a small fee or for a coin from your country. The entrance fee to the museum was Rs750! I did not pay for it as you can see most of the buildings and items from the outside. The entrance fee is a ripoff!
Noisy and busy but full of life. This is the tourist center of Kathmandu and is great. Everything seems to be available here
Too busy. Overcrowding by other tourists takes away the charm to experience this medieval area although the whole site and architecture is worth paying a visit
Beautiful but dirty!. The architecture and preservation was great but the streets were very dirty.

Ticked the box, wouldn't go back.. Durbar Square is in all of the travel brochures, so I hired a guide to walk me around it. It's a huge complex of building, temples, streets and shops. It has much historical significance, but I think you would miss a lot of that if you didn't have a tour guide showing you around.As I went in the off-tourist season, we were constantly pursued by pedlars. Warning: Once you buy one souvenir, you will be surrounded by others trying to sell you stuff!!I didn't quite appreciate the 'magic' or popularity of this place, as told in the travel guides. I think if you stayed in a hotel here, you might get more of an insight. An afternoon was enough for me.

Excellent Travel Arrangement with Champawati Tours & Travels. Champawati Tours & Travels Thamel, Kathmandu, Nepal Have arranged us the Sigthseeing Tour in Nepal including Kathmandu Durbar Sqaure.That was fantastic & memorable trip.They provide us the professional Guide & useful information alwas. We like them very much.Zbiginew FigasPoland

the best,. after coming buy ticket next go to tourust dubar sauare ofiice take a touris passport for free ticket for time of your visa,because you comebiack here Im sure. Itas so plenty to see,so take local quide -no more than 200 nepal rupia,and visit visit vost,m see, take a picture. Fo on festival time ,its amazing

Love it or hate it!!! Must see when in Nepal.. Hanuman-dhoka Durbar Square - World Heritage Site Monument Zone - this is "short" and official name of this all amazing complex of temples, shrines, palaces and other interesting buildings. This is 'must see' point of your tour when in Nepal. It is crowded, crazy, commercial and lost 'original spirit' long time ago. Plus, the most annoying and actually sad is, that there are too many pigeons (people feed them there) and they totally ruin this incredible place. All wooden parts of shrines or houses are rusted because of the birds' guano... Honestly, that's really sad to see that these sculptures survived few hundreds years and now they are all in great danger because of people feeding these flying vermin and allowing cars (and motorbikes) to enter this area. Be ready for sticky polluted air around you.Another think which I really didn't like and it was making me leave this place ASAP were 'local guides'. I know and understand that for some of them this is only one way to earn some money, but they should take it as well when somebody says 'no!' and leave, not insist. Anyway, as I mentioned earlier, this is great historical complex with few most important places in Kathmandu. Do not forget to visit living goddess Kumari shrine, Hanuman Statue and Museum in old palace. Entry fee for foreigner is 750 NPR (approx. 7 EUR). Ticket is valid all day, but if you wish to come back you could do so for free, but... You have to go with your ticket and photo ID to Site Office and ask for Visitor Pass. They do that for free. TAKE 1 PHOTO with you because then they can extend your ticket up to 7 days, other less they can do that only for 3 days. Ladies there were kind enough and gave me as well some CDs about Kumari. That was nice. Photos are allowed in most of the places (not inside of some shrines) and in museum they will tell you that you need to leave your camera in the locker - do not do that as you can take some nice pictures inside and from the palace tower. I've seen so many people doing it and I was only one stupid leaving my camera inside with the bag. Museum ticket is included in the price.
Awesome, colourful place but entrance fee is expensive. Beautiful place, rich in culture but the entrance fee for foreigners was a put-off.

The best ancient feel for shortcommers. If you only one day in Kathmandu - don't miss itIt is only just 15-20 on foot from Thamel and its realy worth it...It will give a glimps of history, traditional architecture and everyday activity of the locals
world class architecture. Entry ticket for foreigners is expensive, but worth the money
Colour galore. A great place to simply hang out and people watch. Photographers will love the colour, variety and architecture.
Cultural experience. Beautiful buildings, bustling square with souvenir stalls, eating places.
Royal Square. This place houses the palace of the King of Nepal, one of the best markets of Kathmandu on the Darbar Marg is close to this Square
Kitschy but fascinating!. Especially liked the born-again hippy's and pot-heads in and around Freak Street.
Nothing like it.. Kumari's house is the first place to stop then look up at Ram and Sita peering from a window. Hanuman at Hanuman Dokha is worshiped by most people. Just to be there is amazing.

Cultural Heart of Nepal. Durbar Square is in fact a series of square's and is the heart of the old town which is where the royal family used to reside in a palace called Hanuman Dhoka.The buildings are an eclectic mix of shapes and sizes which makes Durbar Square so special. Most of the buildings date back to the 17th century, many were badly damaged in the 1934 earthquake but you would not be able to tell by looking at them.I would strongly suggest you visit Hanuman Dhoka you have to pay extra but it is well worth the cost. Durbar Square can get very busy and Hanuman Dhoka is an oasis of calm and far from the maddening crowd as well as being a very good museum.The downsides is that the area is very dirty with waste lying all over the place and you can get hassled by so called "official" guides wishing to take you on a tour. Don't let these minor distractions put you off. If you enjoy this experience there are two more Durbar Square's in Patan and Bhaktapur. The square in Bhaktapur is a 45 minute taxi ride and in our opinion is the best of the three.

Found international chain shop & restaurant. KFC & Pizza hut with Ice cream, lots of international chain shop at Darbar Square ..... even walking on that road is pleasent. Apple store, Annapurna lots of attractions.

Go to Patan!. Durbar square Kathmandu is hectic, noisy and too many beggar saddhus! we liked the Durbar Square in Patan most.Bhaktapur square is too expensive and the same for Kathmandu.Patan has at the square the most beautiful museum!
Great wooden carving.... So great place historically. So great historical wood carving and nice square. This is the place you most visit if yougo to Kathmandu..
Filthy beyond description. Garbage, litter, dirt, thousands and thousands of motorcycles intermingled with tourists, dogs, cows, begging children and feces galore in the gutters and potholed streets.

A very Nepalese Square. Not only centuries-old temples or monuments but also farm produce vendors, florists, traffic snarl and even wandering bulls and goats play leading roles in a uniquely Himalayan setting of Durbar Square. It earliest traces back to the first king of Kathmandu City in 11th century, Durbar Square used to be a courtyard of a royal palace wherein numerous religious constructions devoted to Hindus God sand Goddesses were phased in during subsequent hundred years. Ever since, the gilded time of wooded houses has never stopped shining and attracting worldwide tourists’ curiosity.Spend a full day in the square and its vicinity to taste the real Nepalese life pulse. At first light, the square plays a fresh food market before being packed with traffic and local youth. At noon, Durbar Square definitely belongs to cameras of foreign visitors while the streets nearby becomes a shopping paradise of inexpensive souvenirs. By night, Durbar Square either is a hub of festival activities or stays hushed and silently slumbers away.

A glimpse of history and culture of Nepal. There are plenty of historical things to see in Kathmandu Durbar Square. The Temples had a unique architecture and lots of intricate details. As u walk into the Square u really feel the essence of Kathmandu immersing into you. The place was buzzing with tourists and local people. Durbar Square is one of the main tourist attractions in Kathmandu but it did not seem as clean as the other places like Bodnath.
Durbar Squares in Patan & Bhaktapur better. Kathmandu's Durbar Square is interesting but if pressed for time, I would recommend a visit to Patan and/or Bhaktapur's squares instead.

Lively center of life in Kathmandu. Take time to wander around Durbar Square and watch the daily life of Kathmandu and then go up and have a drink on a bar overlooking the square. It's a fascinating place!
Great cultural site. We were there during the Tij festival. Most of the women were dressed in beautiful red sari's as they participated in the celebrations.
Interesting view of lots of temples. Well worth seeing on a trip to Kathmandu. It's right in town and gives you a view of some interesting architecture.
Hassle from traders. The only place in Kathmandu or Nepal where we got major hassle and didn't feel particularly safe with the kids.

Must visit!. If you are in Kathmandu you have to go and see the square and climb up the steps of the "hippy temple", unless of course you were there in the '60s and did it already. It manages to be both chaotic and relaxed at the same time and the atmosphere is absolutely great
Amazing. Very impressive and very old.You can really spent so much time overhere and also here many shops and restaurants which are also with the local food of Nepal.it is the time worth trying it.

Amazing Square have ever seen!. The square is really spread and huge. There are more than 10 temples you should visit in that and also there are some shops that valuable to see and buy unique things.In the entrance of square, when you buy the ticket, they give you the brochure of this attraction. It is better to follow the temples by this brochure, if you don't have lonely planet! Visiting this square take about 1.5-2 hours. After that you can go to the south side of square and visiting local market. It's interesting.
Chaotic. Poor mainteined, taxis, motos, people using the monuments as resting places, a Unesco World Heritage being dilapidated
history. busy, but nice! getting informations about the history is a good idea and a good place to connect with the history
Take your time. Sit down on the stairs and watch life on the square go by. The madness of the crowded square and the serenity of the temples.

Temples, Shopping, Birds, and People Watching. A short walk from all of the major hotels, Durbar Square is easy to find and get lost in. Very picturesque and filled with vendors of all types. We ended up pushing our giant stroller but never had any problems with crowds or cars. Be sure to bring a map if you walk, because it sure was easy to get lost. This is more of a walking site within the city. It suddenly pops up as you walk through the streets. Take your time and get the perfect photos.

The real heart of Kathmandu. Even full of touts and would-be guides, Durbar Square is the real heart of the capital, and most definitely worth spending an early morning or afternoon there. If you spend long enough in the Kumari Chowk, you might even be lucky to be graced by the living goddess from one of the upper windows (a donation in the donation box is expected, but not demanded). After visiting the various temples/stupas/nooks/crannies, relax having a drink at one of the caffes on the high terrace of one of the hotels overlooking Durbar Square, and watch the world going by.
Cool. go get what you want just roam around this square you will find what you desire shopping dinning everything you want cool place to roam around especially in the evening
Must be seen. Almost everything historically is here. I liked the buildings and temples in the square. Also Patan and Bakhtapur have their Durbar Squares, among them Bakhtapur's is amazing.

Go walking 15 minute from Thamel.. I suggest to all the visitors to go walking through Asan (a local vegetable market) to Durbar Squire also you have change to see metallic things on the way. We used to go every day evening while we been in Kathmandu. Ask them to make a card so you do not need to pay again.
huge place. I was sick at durbar square so I can't enjoy a lot T_T
Beautiful. Excellent experience with lots of people around and a faboulous picturesque of the history of Nepal.

Of pigeons and pagodas .... Very, very, different. The combination of pigeons and pagodas lend this place an out-of-the-world charm. Grand and royal, this is typical of Nepal - cannot be replicated anywhere else on earth!
Two crowded. Better temples in other places you could try but just for an hour walk
Yes, spirited, splendid, interesting!. Check out the pulse of life there. Pray, eat, drink, have all your senses open and witness and enjoy this wonderful culture.
sights within easy walk. within easy reach, but their systems of seeling entry tickets is flawed!
Good for a days' excursion with the Boudhanath temple.. Good for a days' excursion with the Boudhanath temple.

Busy and bustling- you really feel like youre in a different world.. Just at the side of the square there is a tiny shop with an Indian man selling silver and gem stones. he will take you in and give you tea and chats and tells you all sorts of information. he even guided us to a great restaurant. Make an effoert to find him.

Beautiful although crowded. The Nine storeyed Palace is fascinating. Just next to it is the Hanumandhoka palace with the architecture inspired by the colonial architecture. It is a good place to wander around in the evening with street vendors selling curios to street food. And its not too far from Thamel.
Beautiful architecture. The eternal problem of Kahtmandu. Beautiful architecture in historical sites but the garbage and the poor manteinance of the place is notorious.
Dirty and old holy men intimidating when asking for $. Respect the religion but challenged by the lack of hygiene around temples - layers of animal excrement with odours etc
A busy centre of local activity. Plenty to see and experience here ..OK well geared up for tourists too but worth the effort to visit
