Visit at least one Durbar Square in Kathmandu area.. Interesting place to visit. Picked up be a 'guide' who took us, at our request, to a cafe which was at rooftop level with a wonderful view. Didn't visit in depth as had been to Bakturpur Durbar sq.just enjoyed the general ambience.

A true asian Times Square. A lot of people come to this place. It is crowded and taxis drop you before getting inside the Durbar Square. There is a nice coffee shop in the middle, so if you are lucky you can find a nice spot and enjoy the scenario. There are beautiful things to shop and very cheap!!! If you want to dress like them, you can find the clothes almost everywhere.
durbar square. Great place to spend the afternoon amongst many ancient temples.
A great historical site. Loads to see - temples, shrines etc. Busy and chaotic, vibrant and full of life. Take a break in a rooftop cafe for a bird's eye view.

Wonderful Historical Palace! haldeu. Many temples, wood-carving and street shops. durbar squire is really better to visit in early morning with sunrise on those temples. The Kumari (living goddess) may appear at her palace window around 11.00 or sometimes around 16.00 in the afternoon, who visiting the temple please manage your time to see Kumari but Not allowed to take pitures. anyway i strongly recommend this place to whom going to visit kathmandu.
lots to see. take your time.. yet another unmissable place if you are in Kathmandu.All the sights are fantastic. Well kept. Easy to get to. Affordable entry.

A revisit. Thew last time I went to Durbar Square was 16 years ago - it was very dirty and we were beseiged by beggars. This time it was clean & we were able to wander round at will. Great improvement.
Durbar Square. liked all the temples in close proximity/disliked tour guides pestering us for business
Nice place. its one of the best place to hanging around with frens specially evening time. i went so many time with my honey.........
Party..... Lots of joints for drinks and parties, Discos, avoid going to most small ones , for locals pick up fights among themselves

get a guide. On arriving here we weren`t planning on getting a guide we were going to go solo. However after being approached by so many we decided to go with it, and it was definately worth it. There are so many temples that it is difficult to know where to start. It was very busy when we went due to it being divali. It is very fascinating place just to watch people go by their every day lives.
Don,t bother. Nothing here actually, however they still charge people to enter the compound
a must see. wonderful insight into old Kathmandu. we had a wonderful guide which i would recommend so that all your little questions can be answered
nice place. It's all red building. so peacful place. It like a history come out from history book. I have a great time in there. But here not I expect that much large.

Definitely a Must-See For Kathmandu. When we arrived i had initially planned to walk around using my Lonely Planet Guidebook as a guide which did a decent job describing the temples, however their are a lot of "private guides for hire" walking around and we decided to hire one who spoke really good English. We agreed on the price before hand and the time length of the tour and it turned out really good. The temples were pretty unique and we even got to see the Kumari, the Living Goddess poke her head out of her window from her living quarters.
Durbar Square. Nice to walk around all the structures but it was sometimes hard to know what you were looking at even with the map.
People Watching. This is a great spot to people watch, no one hassles you if you sit on the steps and watch the world go by.

Great place to sit and watch the world go by. Durbar Square is an amazing place. The temples are stunning. Early morning is a nice time to be there-Just to watch people coming to life and going about their business. Sadly there is a lot of refuse to be seen on the streets.

Durbar Square KTM. There are 3 Durbar Squares.This one is in Kathmandu near the Tamel District.Full of everyday life,fantastic architecture.Take a guide with you to fend off the invasive street vendors.Be aware of areas that photography is not allowed.

Chill. We were many friends just dream to go hang out some clean city out by Kathmandu but i choose bhaktapur durbar square is enough clean and also what they paid for entry fee. I recommend this place for travelers.
Realy nice place. Durbar Square is worth seeing, it is great historical place with perfect atmosphere

nice. small area with lots of charisma, nice mult-storey wood-carved buildings. major tourist area, only place where we encountered lots of annoying souvenir sellers. Relax in a rooftop cafe and watch. no trafic inside, but very chaotic trafic outside.
not all that. a bit of a jumble, touting tour guides everywhere. See the Living Goddess and learn the story about that...is the word intriguing? or disturbing?

Skip it if you've gone to Bhaktapur or Patan. **I'm assuming this link is referring to Kathmandu Durbar Square in Basantapur near Thame.**Kathmandu Durbar Square is nice...if it's your first experience going to a durbar or Hindu temple. My advice would be to skip the site and all its touts and head south to Bhaktapur or Patan Durbar Square. KTM Durbar Square has one large temple that you can experience watching Hindus pray or give pujas (offerings) and receive your own red tika (third eye) on your forehead. The flower decorations and the ornate metal fencing surrounding the temple are very nice.
Fascinating. Great place to see a snapshot of Nepal rather than jsut scenery!

Poorly maintained. This square is nothing compared to Patan and Bhaktapur Durbar Square. The square has busy traffic and loads of beggers spoils the ancient mood of the place. Can be avoided if you are visiting Patan and Bhaktapur. Has entry fee for the same.

Intersting Historical Place. Very interesting and many Palaces to visit in a small area but again Street Vendors a bit difficult to get rid of. Lovely buildings and a beautiful heritage site for Nepal.

durbar Square. A medieval square with fantastically restored palaces, temples and buildings. Often there are festivals and processions in the square and these are brilliant to visit. Wander around the side streets and soak up the atmosphere, witness how people live here and use the temples daily. Watch the flower garlands being made.... It is a wonderful place.

Restoration in progress gives great opportunity. Durbar Square is the oldest area of Patan, a city adjacent to Kathmandu. We saw one part that had not yet been restored, and one area where restoration was complete. Fine examples of old woodcarving on the buildings. Worth a visit, but expect to encounter narrow streets choked with vehicles while trying to get there and allow extra time. Our guide gave up and told the driver to stop, while we walked the remaining 5 blocks to the square as it became clear that going on foot was going to be much faster.
Worth the visit. Lovely tourist spot but you'll be pestered if bviously a tourist. Dodgy box selling tickets but think it is real and spectacular temples.

Taking through the history. There is a very good mesume showing pictures, statues and stone carvings. I really enjoyed the way they carry the first car in to Kathmandu. Lord Buddha statues are very beutiful. the architecture and the carvings in the doors and windows take you through the ancient history of the country.
Kathmandu Durbar Square is Kathmandu. It was our introduction to Kathmandu - the sights, the noise, the people, the history, the works!
Good. Full of people, tourist, Indian, Nepali and western tourist. Sellers of souvenirs are not aggressive

Durbar square. quality of old buildings. Like many cultural sites in nepal the old buildings have been quite well maintained and are a delight to see. I don't think Durbar square was affected by the quake so this should still be true.
Felt like I entered another world. Kathmandu can seem a little dirty and crowded. Durbar Square was so exotic, so much to see. Had lunch on a rooftop cafe, it was very cool.
Busy Square. Fab Durbar Square - plenty of temples - toursit shopping - and just people watching - museum closes on certain days - look up before you go.

Lots of temples, shrines and chowks to explore. There are more than 40 different points of interest at this UNESCO World Heritage Site which includes temples, shrines, chowks (town squares), statues, drums, shops and restaurants. It is an open area and anybody can just walk in but they require tourists to pay an entrance fee at various entry points (near Mahendreshwor Temple, Maru Tole, Freak Street or Ganga Path). You can spend an entire day exploring temples, watching people, shopping for souvenirs and taking pictures at Durbar Square. Make sure to have lunch on a rooftop so that you can see the entire square from above.

they insisted tourists have to pay an entrance fee. there are a lot of ways to get into the place without paying. if you ask me whether is it worth paying the entrance? my answer is NO because it is a small area
old part of the city worth checking!!. Old part of the city worth seeing although I find The Durbar square of Patan much nicer and spacious!!!The Durbar square of Kathmandu is too crowded!!

BUSY PLACE. Busy place with no information for tourists.not well maintained.crowded and local fruit sellers and rickshaws occupying the area.we had a local guide and so he could tell us the history.the temple there was dark inside and not well maintained.

Visual feast. The street vendors skirting the square can be quite insistent but the square itself is an amazing collage of architectural design. Make sure your camera batteries are charged and you have space on your memory card.
Historical Temples. It's worth seeing as there's little other historical sites in Kathmandu but it's typical of Kathmandu - filthy, noisy and full of beggars who refuse to leave you alone.

The heart of the Kathmandu. The temples in Durbar Square are amazing pieces of religious art. Their beauty cannot be over stated. We were there during the Dasain Festival, but it was clean and calm. The highlight was the visit to the Kumari's palace.
nice!. beautiful area, very rich. But western tourist will have to pay the 300NR to walk in...

Travel back in time!. These Durbar Squares ( one in Ktm, one in patan & one in Bhaktapur ) are actually old palace precincts. On one side of the square is the old palace buildings and on the other side are scattered temples, which are all built in Newari style architecture ( Built by Newar kings some hundreds of years ago, and absolutely unique to Nepal). With so many festivals happening in Ktm, there is every possibility that you might witness one being carried out in one of these squares. While there, do check the details of the palace buildings and temples. The wood & stone carvings on these temples often have many stories to tell. These durbar squares also house museums which are worth checking. The one in Hanumandhoka is the biggest, but I particularly like the one in Patan. The museum building was renovated, but still retains the style of old architecture and has so many antique collections which all reflect newari style tradition. Though all Durbar squares follow the similar composition, if you want to travel back in time, and not get hassled by the bustling crowd and busy vendors, then I particularly recommend the one in Bhaktapur. Not just the durbar square, the whole city of Bhaktapur takes you back in time. Do walk through the narrow alleys, the pavements of which are still intact with local bricks, check in the local potteries, handicrafts, statues, stone artefacts etc being made around (some crafters are so engrossed in their work that they won’t even notice you are there! ) So yeah, do sit back and relax in one of the many cafes, situated on the top floor of any of the renovated temples and enjoy the day to day life of the locals. I’m pretty thrilled to see items like wheat, chillies, etc, just being laid on the road for them to dry! People taking baths & washing clothes in public stone bath areas! People transporting water in specially made vases for their everyday use! Must visit! Just a few kilometres away from Ktm, yet it feels like you are well and truly centuries back in time!

A world heritage gem. Beautiful place to walk around in early morning. Watch out for touts who will try to sell you everything from flutes and tiger balm to trekking trips. It can get very busy here during festival times and when the Kumari (living godess) makes an appearance.

A must in Kathmandu. The architecture of the whole area makes it a place unique, with all kinds of old and very old temples. That place really merits its recognition of a world heritage fund site. Must be visited while in Kathmandu.

Must see if in Kathmandu. This area has significant history for the Nepalese. It houses the believed reincarnation of the goddess Kumari. We visited on a religiously important day and the amount of people including, holy men, was amazing.
WOW!!!. Amazing place! It was great to experience the HIstory of Nepal.
Rather dirty. Fascinating buildings, and has to be done, but traffic zooming around does not help the experience, nor I would think the structure of the buildings.

There are better places to visit. I've been to the Durbar Squares in Patan and Bakhtapur, and both are more interesting than Kathmandu's - so if you are visiting either of those places I would recommend giving this one a miss. The collection of temples isn't as impressively situated or displayed, and the area is busier and more full of wannabe guides touting persistently for your business.Even within Kathmandu itself, I would recommend a visit to Boudhanath, Pashupatinath or Swayambunath before you bother visiting the Durbar Square.

Collection of Temples. This is one of the main attractions of Kathmandu. A collection of old, not ancient, temples. On the day i visited for the first time I had just missed a festival which had taken place earlier but the temples were still nicely decorated and there were still lots of people around and on the temple steps. There is a fee to enter the Durbar Square but it isn't always collected. I entered at approx 3.30 on 1 day. No one asked or approached me for a fee. I entered about 10am another day and was immeadietly stopped by a gaurd to go and pay to enter. It isn't expensive so don't worry if you do pay.

One of the best historical places in Kathmandu. The Kathmandu Durbar Square is one of the best historical places to visit. It has the Hanuman Dhoka, the Kumari residence and the Freak Street shopping area close by-which means a good half day you could spend here taking pictures and with a good guide, you can absorb a lot of history......People are peaceful and generally dont disturb tourists-even the street vendor shops from KTM square walking towards Freak Street. The souvenirs in this area are better priced than the other market and tourists area though you need to bargain a lot. Those looking to buy souvenirs can have a look at other areas then buy from here. There is one small MOMO shop which is a must try (just off freak street towards ktm durbar square in a small lane).Enter this attraction from the "New Road" side (opp Bishal Bazar Mall)...it will be more attractive and no entry fees.

Beware of Opportunist's. We really didn't plan on touring this place but we were stuck in Kathmandu due to the transport hike last August (no public vehicles were travelling outside the city). People we met in the hotel where we were staying suggested Durbar Square. When we arrived, we immediately took pictures of the amazing temples and the scenery (busy streets packed with tourists). After a few steps, a guy (without any ID) approached us and asked us to come with him to the Security Post. We were frightened because we thought we violated some rules (I was wearing a sleeveless shirt so I put on my jacket). The guy at the post informed us that we need to pay the tourist fee of 300 rupees / head just for touring the place (relieved). We told him we need to exchange money first and we were escorted by the same guy who first approached us to the nearest money exchange booth. While walking, the guy told us that we don't need to pay to see the sites for as long as we walk with him. We just need to pay him some money for the tour. We agreed. During the walk, he introduced us to another guy (who speaks very good english and japanese) who was a licensed tour guide in Nepal (he showed as an ID). He brought us to all the amazing temples (the erotic temple was my favourite... LOL... and the Palace of the Living Goddess) and explained the history of everything we visited. We ended the tour with a small snack in a roof-top restaurant over-looking the square. I handed him 500 rupees then said that they normally charge 1000. We obliged since me and my friend were satisfied with their service. We find it better than paying 600 rupees for nothing.

Recommend a visit but be prepared for traffic!. It is a very fascinating experience walking around this square taking a close look at different carvings. While you are there you could enjoy visiting Kumari Bahal (house of the living goddess), Kastha Mandap (Wood-Covered Shelter ), and Maru Ganesh. Kumari Bahal, house of a young girl who is selected to be the town's living goddess, consists of beautiful wood carving of different god and goddesses. Kasthamandap, built in the early sixteenth century by King Laxmi Narsingha Malla using wood of a single tree, is believed to have inspired the name of Kathmandu City. Maru Ganesh is small but one of the most visited temple in Kathmandu. Every Tuesday thousands of people gather to worship Lord Ganesh.Only thing that most people complain about is the traffic. Well, it is crowded all day long and could be very frustrating at times.One thing that I enjoy the most is watching the pigeons get fed. If you are planning a visit, I hope you have a great time!

If you are in Kathmandu, you should go to DS. It is definitely in a state of disrepair & could use some TLC, but apparently they are working on that. It is a good experience just to walk around and take in the square. Some good photo opps as well. Takign in all the scenery and noises and the people selling various wears, or sitting and relaxing on the steps of the many buildings in and of itself is worth a good couple hours of walking and observing in the Square..

Not really fantastic. Compared to the other Durbar Squares in Patan and Bhaktapur, this one in Kathmandu is just a mess, not very inviting and with lots of through traffic. Even Kumari´s house, while interesting from the outside, just leads to a grim courtyard covered with bird [--]all around. When she appears at her window you´re not allowed to take a picture. It´s a lengthy walk from Thamel so if you give it a complete miss, nothing is lost as long as you see Patan and Bhaktapur.

Minus the traffic, it's perfect!. Whilst all three parts of the square can be covered in an hour or two, I'd recommend spending at least half the day there. When walking around, have a close look at the carvings on the buildings for many of them depict stories of Nepal's history and/or writings and scriptures.A camera with a good zoom is handy to take in these details. Best not to take photos of anyone dressed like a sage and also, try to visit the Kumari's palace at a time when she appears as it's apparently an honoured experience.Watch out for the traffic weaving through the square, especially the motorbikes.

The middle of Kathmandu's history. I took a tour of Kathmandu Durbur Square with a guide from my hotel. We drove there in a taxi from Thamel. I was able to get a fairly complete history of the area. It was a fascinating experience. The fact the square was once the palace for the king and the way the square was added on to over the years was interesting. I was able to get great pictures of the historical buildings and the people. There are shops are similar to other places in the City where you can buy local items. The cost to visit the square as a foreigner is 350 Rupees – about $4.50 US$The area is definitely not a comfortable tourist destination. It can be a harsh overload to the senses if you are not ready for it. There are not clean cozy cafes and clean and plentiful restrooms. It is a crazy mish-mash of people sitting on the street selling produce, spices etc., people worshiping at their favorite temple and a crush of vehicles ranging from cars & motorcycles to rickshaws all in a hurry honking their horns. The traffic is complete chaos. The key is to know this and plan for this.

Don't waste your time. This is rubbish, the guide book suggested it was the best thing to do in Khatmandu, so I had high hopes. We walked there from thamel, the mian tourist district (although it is a good 20 min walk thoguh town so get a taxi if that doesn't appeal to you). I was promised gradeur pagodas and amazing sites, it's actually just an area with about 20-30 pagodas which are all in a state of dis-repair, there's only one or two you can go inside, but they were all closed for refurbishment. We ended spending all day in the roof top restaurants surrounding Durbar (these I would highly recommend for the views).
